<span id="L13310" rel="#L13310">13310</span>

           </td>
           <td class="blob-line-code"><div class="code-body highlight"><pre><div class='line' id='LC1'>The Project Gutenberg EBook of A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC2'>Court, Complete, by Mark Twain (Samuel Clemens)</div><div class='line' id='LC3'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4'>This eBook is for the use of anyone anywhere at no cost and with</div><div class='line' id='LC5'>almost no restrictions whatsoever.  You may copy it, give it away or</div><div class='line' id='LC6'>re-use it under the terms of the Project Gutenberg License included</div><div class='line' id='LC7'>with this eBook or online at www.gutenberg.net</div><div class='line' id='LC8'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC9'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC10'>Title: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur&#39;s Court, Complete</div><div class='line' id='LC11'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12'>Author: Mark Twain (Samuel Clemens)</div><div class='line' id='LC13'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC14'>Release Date: July 20, 2006 [EBook #86]</div><div class='line' id='LC15'>Last Updated: May 19, 2010</div><div class='line' id='LC16'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC17'>Language: English</div><div class='line' id='LC18'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC19'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC20'>*** START OF THIS PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK CONNECTICUT YANKEE ***</div><div class='line' id='LC21'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC22'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC23'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC24'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC25'>Produced by David Widger and Janet Blenkinship</div><div class='line' id='LC26'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC27'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC28'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC29'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC30'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC31'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC32'>A CONNECTICUT YANKEE IN KING ARTHUR&#39;S COURT</div><div class='line' id='LC33'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC34'>by</div><div class='line' id='LC35'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC36'>MARK TWAIN</div><div class='line' id='LC37'>(Samuel L. Clemens)</div><div class='line' id='LC38'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC39'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC40'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC41'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC42'>PREFACE</div><div class='line' id='LC43'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC44'>The ungentle laws and customs touched upon in this tale are</div><div class='line' id='LC45'>historical, and the episodes which are used to illustrate them</div><div class='line' id='LC46'>are also historical.  It is not pretended that these laws and</div><div class='line' id='LC47'>customs existed in England in the sixth century; no, it is only</div><div class='line' id='LC48'>pretended that inasmuch as they existed in the English and other</div><div class='line' id='LC49'>civilizations of far later times, it is safe to consider that it is</div><div class='line' id='LC50'>no libel upon the sixth century to suppose them to have been in</div><div class='line' id='LC51'>practice in that day also.  One is quite justified in inferring</div><div class='line' id='LC52'>that whatever one of these laws or customs was lacking in that</div><div class='line' id='LC53'>remote time, its place was competently filled by a worse one.</div><div class='line' id='LC54'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC55'>The question as to whether there is such a thing as divine right</div><div class='line' id='LC56'>of kings is not settled in this book.  It was found too difficult.</div><div class='line' id='LC57'>That the executive head of a nation should be a person of lofty</div><div class='line' id='LC58'>character and extraordinary ability, was manifest and indisputable;</div><div class='line' id='LC59'>that none but the Deity could select that head unerringly, was</div><div class='line' id='LC60'>also manifest and indisputable; that the Deity ought to make that</div><div class='line' id='LC61'>selection, then, was likewise manifest and indisputable; consequently,</div><div class='line' id='LC62'>that He does make it, as claimed, was an unavoidable deduction.</div><div class='line' id='LC63'>I mean, until the author of this book encountered the Pompadour,</div><div class='line' id='LC64'>and Lady Castlemaine, and some other executive heads of that kind;</div><div class='line' id='LC65'>these were found so difficult to work into the scheme, that it</div><div class='line' id='LC66'>was judged better to take the other tack in this book (which</div><div class='line' id='LC67'>must be issued this fall), and then go into training and settle</div><div class='line' id='LC68'>the question in another book.  It is, of course, a thing which</div><div class='line' id='LC69'>ought to be settled, and I am not going to have anything particular</div><div class='line' id='LC70'>to do next winter anyway.</div><div class='line' id='LC71'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC72'>MARK TWAIN</div><div class='line' id='LC73'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC74'>HARTFORD, July 21, 1889</div><div class='line' id='LC75'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC76'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC77'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC78'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC79'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC80'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC81'>A CONNECTICUT YANKEE IN KING ARTHUR&#39;S COURT</div><div class='line' id='LC82'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC83'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC84'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC85'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC86'>A WORD OF EXPLANATION</div><div class='line' id='LC87'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC88'>It was in Warwick Castle that I came across the curious stranger</div><div class='line' id='LC89'>whom I am going to talk about.  He attracted me by three things:</div><div class='line' id='LC90'>his candid simplicity, his marvelous familiarity with ancient armor,</div><div class='line' id='LC91'>and the restfulness of his company--for he did all the talking.</div><div class='line' id='LC92'>We fell together, as modest people will, in the tail of the herd</div><div class='line' id='LC93'>that was being shown through, and he at once began to say things</div><div class='line' id='LC94'>which interested me.  As he talked along, softly, pleasantly,</div><div class='line' id='LC95'>flowingly, he seemed to drift away imperceptibly out of this world</div><div class='line' id='LC96'>and time, and into some remote era and old forgotten country;</div><div class='line' id='LC97'>and so he gradually wove such a spell about me that I seemed</div><div class='line' id='LC98'>to move among the specters and shadows and dust and mold of a gray</div><div class='line' id='LC99'>antiquity, holding speech with a relic of it!  Exactly as I would</div><div class='line' id='LC100'>speak of my nearest personal friends or enemies, or my most familiar</div><div class='line' id='LC101'>neighbors, he spoke of Sir Bedivere, Sir Bors de Ganis, Sir Launcelot</div><div class='line' id='LC102'>of the Lake, Sir Galahad, and all the other great names of the</div><div class='line' id='LC103'>Table Round--and how old, old, unspeakably old and faded and dry</div><div class='line' id='LC104'>and musty and ancient he came to look as he went on!  Presently</div><div class='line' id='LC105'>he turned to me and said, just as one might speak of the weather,</div><div class='line' id='LC106'>or any other common matter--</div><div class='line' id='LC107'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC108'>&quot;You know about transmigration of souls; do you know about</div><div class='line' id='LC109'>transposition of epochs--and bodies?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC110'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC111'>I said I had not heard of it.  He was so little interested--just</div><div class='line' id='LC112'>as when people speak of the weather--that he did not notice</div><div class='line' id='LC113'>whether I made him any answer or not. There was half a moment</div><div class='line' id='LC114'>of silence, immediately interrupted by the droning voice of the</div><div class='line' id='LC115'>salaried cicerone:</div><div class='line' id='LC116'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC117'>&quot;Ancient hauberk, date of the sixth century, time of King Arthur</div><div class='line' id='LC118'>and the Round Table; said to have belonged to the knight Sir Sagramor</div><div class='line' id='LC119'>le Desirous; observe the round hole through the chain-mail in</div><div class='line' id='LC120'>the left breast; can&#39;t be accounted for; supposed to have been</div><div class='line' id='LC121'>done with a bullet since invention of firearms--perhaps maliciously</div><div class='line' id='LC122'>by Cromwell&#39;s soldiers.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC123'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC124'>My acquaintance smiled--not a modern smile, but one that must</div><div class='line' id='LC125'>have gone out of general use many, many centuries ago--and muttered</div><div class='line' id='LC126'>apparently to himself:</div><div class='line' id='LC127'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC128'>&quot;Wit ye well, _I saw it done_.&quot;  Then, after a pause, added:</div><div class='line' id='LC129'>&quot;I did it myself.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC130'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC131'>By the time I had recovered from the electric surprise of this</div><div class='line' id='LC132'>remark, he was gone.</div><div class='line' id='LC133'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC134'>All that evening I sat by my fire at the Warwick Arms, steeped</div><div class='line' id='LC135'>in a dream of the olden time, while the rain beat upon the windows,</div><div class='line' id='LC136'>and the wind roared about the eaves and corners.  From time to</div><div class='line' id='LC137'>time I dipped into old Sir Thomas Malory&#39;s enchanting book, and</div><div class='line' id='LC138'>fed at its rich feast of prodigies and adventures, breathed in</div><div class='line' id='LC139'>the fragrance of its obsolete names, and dreamed again.  Midnight</div><div class='line' id='LC140'>being come at length, I read another tale, for a nightcap--this</div><div class='line' id='LC141'>which here follows, to wit:</div><div class='line' id='LC142'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC143'>HOW SIR LAUNCELOT SLEW TWO GIANTS, AND MADE A CASTLE FREE</div><div class='line' id='LC144'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC145'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Anon withal came there upon him two great giants,</div><div class='line' id='LC146'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;well armed, all save the heads, with two horrible</div><div class='line' id='LC147'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;clubs in their hands.  Sir Launcelot put his shield</div><div class='line' id='LC148'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;afore him, and put the stroke away of the one</div><div class='line' id='LC149'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;giant, and with his sword he clave his head asunder.</div><div class='line' id='LC150'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;When his fellow saw that, he ran away as he were</div><div class='line' id='LC151'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;wood [*demented], for fear of the horrible strokes,</div><div class='line' id='LC152'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and Sir Launcelot after him with all his might,</div><div class='line' id='LC153'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and smote him on the shoulder, and clave him to</div><div class='line' id='LC154'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the middle.  Then Sir Launcelot went into the hall,</div><div class='line' id='LC155'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and there came afore him three score ladies and</div><div class='line' id='LC156'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;damsels, and all kneeled unto him, and thanked</div><div class='line' id='LC157'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;God and him of their deliverance.  For, sir, said</div><div class='line' id='LC158'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;they, the most part of us have been here this</div><div class='line' id='LC159'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;seven year their prisoners, and we have worked all</div><div class='line' id='LC160'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;manner of silk works for our meat, and we are all</div><div class='line' id='LC161'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;great gentle-women born, and blessed be the time,</div><div class='line' id='LC162'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;knight, that ever thou wert born; for thou hast</div><div class='line' id='LC163'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;done the most worship that ever did knight in the</div><div class='line' id='LC164'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;world, that will we bear record, and we all pray</div><div class='line' id='LC165'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;you to tell us your name, that we may tell our</div><div class='line' id='LC166'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;friends who delivered us out of prison.  Fair</div><div class='line' id='LC167'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;damsels, he said, my name is Sir Launcelot du</div><div class='line' id='LC168'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Lake.  And so he departed from them and betaught</div><div class='line' id='LC169'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;them unto God.  And then he mounted upon his</div><div class='line' id='LC170'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;horse, and rode into many strange and wild</div><div class='line' id='LC171'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;countries, and through many waters and valleys,</div><div class='line' id='LC172'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and evil was he lodged.  And at the last by</div><div class='line' id='LC173'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;fortune him happened against a night to come to</div><div class='line' id='LC174'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;a fair courtilage, and therein he found an old</div><div class='line' id='LC175'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;gentle-woman that lodged him with a good-will,</div><div class='line' id='LC176'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and there he had good cheer for him and his horse.</div><div class='line' id='LC177'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;And when time was, his host brought him into a</div><div class='line' id='LC178'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;fair garret over the gate to his bed. There</div><div class='line' id='LC179'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sir Launcelot unarmed him, and set his harness</div><div class='line' id='LC180'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;by him, and went to bed, and anon he fell on</div><div class='line' id='LC181'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;sleep. So, soon after there came one on</div><div class='line' id='LC182'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;horseback, and knocked at the gate in great</div><div class='line' id='LC183'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;haste.  And when Sir Launcelot heard this he rose</div><div class='line' id='LC184'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;up, and looked out at the window, and saw by the</div><div class='line' id='LC185'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;moonlight three knights come riding after that</div><div class='line' id='LC186'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;one man, and all three lashed on him at once</div><div class='line' id='LC187'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;with swords, and that one knight turned on them</div><div class='line' id='LC188'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;knightly again and defended him. Truly, said</div><div class='line' id='LC189'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sir Launcelot, yonder one knight shall I help,</div><div class='line' id='LC190'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;for it were shame for me to see three knights</div><div class='line' id='LC191'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;on one, and if he be slain I am partner of his</div><div class='line' id='LC192'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;death.  And therewith he took his harness and</div><div class='line' id='LC193'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;went out at a window by a sheet down to the four</div><div class='line' id='LC194'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;knights, and then Sir Launcelot said on high,</div><div class='line' id='LC195'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Turn you knights unto me, and leave your</div><div class='line' id='LC196'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;fighting with that knight. And then they all</div><div class='line' id='LC197'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;three left Sir Kay, and turned unto Sir Launcelot,</div><div class='line' id='LC198'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and there began great battle, for they alight</div><div class='line' id='LC199'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;all three, and strake many strokes at Sir</div><div class='line' id='LC200'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Launcelot, and assailed him on every side. Then</div><div class='line' id='LC201'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sir Kay dressed him for to have holpen Sir</div><div class='line' id='LC202'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Launcelot.  Nay, sir, said he, I will none of</div><div class='line' id='LC203'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;your help, therefore as ye will have my help</div><div class='line' id='LC204'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;let me alone with them.  Sir Kay for the pleasure</div><div class='line' id='LC205'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;of the knight suffered him for to do his will,</div><div class='line' id='LC206'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and so stood aside. And then anon within six</div><div class='line' id='LC207'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;strokes Sir Launcelot had stricken them to the earth.</div><div class='line' id='LC208'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC209'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;And then they all three cried, Sir Knight, we</div><div class='line' id='LC210'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;yield us unto you as man of might matchless.  As</div><div class='line' id='LC211'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;to that, said Sir Launcelot, I will not take</div><div class='line' id='LC212'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;your yielding unto me, but so that ye yield</div><div class='line' id='LC213'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;you unto Sir Kay the seneschal, on that covenant</div><div class='line' id='LC214'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;I will save your lives and else not.  Fair knight,</div><div class='line' id='LC215'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;said they, that were we loath to do; for as for</div><div class='line' id='LC216'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sir Kay we chased him hither, and had overcome</div><div class='line' id='LC217'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;him had ye not been; therefore, to yield us unto</div><div class='line' id='LC218'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;him it were no reason.  Well, as to that, said</div><div class='line' id='LC219'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sir Launcelot, advise you well, for ye may</div><div class='line' id='LC220'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;choose whether ye will die or live, for an ye be</div><div class='line' id='LC221'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;yielden, it shall be unto Sir Kay.  Fair knight,</div><div class='line' id='LC222'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;then they said, in saving our lives we will do</div><div class='line' id='LC223'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;as thou commandest us.  Then shall ye, said Sir</div><div class='line' id='LC224'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Launcelot, on Whitsunday next coming go unto the</div><div class='line' id='LC225'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;court of King Arthur, and there shall ye yield</div><div class='line' id='LC226'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;you unto Queen Guenever, and put you all three</div><div class='line' id='LC227'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;in her grace and mercy, and say that Sir Kay</div><div class='line' id='LC228'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;sent you thither to be her prisoners.  On the morn</div><div class='line' id='LC229'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sir Launcelot arose early, and left Sir Kay</div><div class='line' id='LC230'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;sleeping; and Sir Launcelot took Sir Kay&#39;s armor</div><div class='line' id='LC231'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and his shield and armed him, and so he went to</div><div class='line' id='LC232'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the stable and took his horse, and took his leave</div><div class='line' id='LC233'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;of his host, and so he departed.  Then soon after</div><div class='line' id='LC234'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;arose Sir Kay and missed Sir Launcelot; and</div><div class='line' id='LC235'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;then he espied that he had his armor and his</div><div class='line' id='LC236'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;horse. Now by my faith I know well that he will</div><div class='line' id='LC237'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;grieve some of the court of King Arthur; for on</div><div class='line' id='LC238'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;him knights will be bold, and deem that it is I,</div><div class='line' id='LC239'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and that will beguile them; and because of his</div><div class='line' id='LC240'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;armor and shield I am sure I shall ride in peace.</div><div class='line' id='LC241'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;And then soon after departed Sir Kay, and</div><div class='line' id='LC242'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;thanked his host.</div><div class='line' id='LC243'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC244'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC245'>As I laid the book down there was a knock at the door, and my</div><div class='line' id='LC246'>stranger came in.  I gave him a pipe and a chair, and made him</div><div class='line' id='LC247'>welcome.  I also comforted him with a hot Scotch whisky; gave him</div><div class='line' id='LC248'>another one; then still another--hoping always for his story.</div><div class='line' id='LC249'>After a fourth persuader, he drifted into it himself, in a quite</div><div class='line' id='LC250'>simple and natural way:</div><div class='line' id='LC251'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC252'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC253'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC254'>THE STRANGER&#39;S HISTORY</div><div class='line' id='LC255'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC256'>I am an American.  I was born and reared in Hartford, in the State</div><div class='line' id='LC257'>of Connecticut--anyway, just over the river, in the country.  So</div><div class='line' id='LC258'>I am a Yankee of the Yankees--and practical; yes, and nearly</div><div class='line' id='LC259'>barren of sentiment, I suppose--or poetry, in other words.  My</div><div class='line' id='LC260'>father was a blacksmith, my uncle was a horse doctor, and I was</div><div class='line' id='LC261'>both, along at first.  Then I went over to the great arms factory</div><div class='line' id='LC262'>and learned my real trade; learned all there was to it; learned</div><div class='line' id='LC263'>to make everything: guns, revolvers, cannon, boilers, engines, all</div><div class='line' id='LC264'>sorts of labor-saving machinery.  Why, I could make anything</div><div class='line' id='LC265'>a body wanted--anything in the world, it didn&#39;t make any difference</div><div class='line' id='LC266'>what; and if there wasn&#39;t any quick new-fangled way to make a thing,</div><div class='line' id='LC267'>I could invent one--and do it as easy as rolling off a log.  I became</div><div class='line' id='LC268'>head superintendent; had a couple of thousand men under me.</div><div class='line' id='LC269'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC270'>Well, a man like that is a man that is full of fight--that goes</div><div class='line' id='LC271'>without saying.  With a couple of thousand rough men under one,</div><div class='line' id='LC272'>one has plenty of that sort of amusement.  I had, anyway.  At last</div><div class='line' id='LC273'>I met my match, and I got my dose.  It was during a misunderstanding</div><div class='line' id='LC274'>conducted with crowbars with a fellow we used to call Hercules.</div><div class='line' id='LC275'>He laid me out with a crusher alongside the head that made everything</div><div class='line' id='LC276'>crack, and seemed to spring every joint in my skull and made it</div><div class='line' id='LC277'>overlap its neighbor.  Then the world went out in darkness, and</div><div class='line' id='LC278'>I didn&#39;t feel anything more, and didn&#39;t know anything at all</div><div class='line' id='LC279'>--at least for a while.</div><div class='line' id='LC280'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC281'>When I came to again, I was sitting under an oak tree, on the</div><div class='line' id='LC282'>grass, with a whole beautiful and broad country landscape all</div><div class='line' id='LC283'>to myself--nearly.  Not entirely; for there was a fellow on a horse,</div><div class='line' id='LC284'>looking down at me--a fellow fresh out of a picture-book.  He was</div><div class='line' id='LC285'>in old-time iron armor from head to heel, with a helmet on his</div><div class='line' id='LC286'>head the shape of a nail-keg with slits in it; and he had a shield,</div><div class='line' id='LC287'>and a sword, and a prodigious spear; and his horse had armor on,</div><div class='line' id='LC288'>too, and a steel horn projecting from his forehead, and gorgeous</div><div class='line' id='LC289'>red and green silk trappings that hung down all around him like</div><div class='line' id='LC290'>a bedquilt, nearly to the ground.</div><div class='line' id='LC291'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC292'>&quot;Fair sir, will ye just?&quot; said this fellow.</div><div class='line' id='LC293'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC294'>&quot;Will I which?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC295'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC296'>&quot;Will ye try a passage of arms for land or lady or for--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC297'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC298'>&quot;What are you giving me?&quot; I said.  &quot;Get along back to your circus,</div><div class='line' id='LC299'>or I&#39;ll report you.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC300'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC301'>Now what does this man do but fall back a couple of hundred yards</div><div class='line' id='LC302'>and then come rushing at me as hard as he could tear, with his</div><div class='line' id='LC303'>nail-keg bent down nearly to his horse&#39;s neck and his long spear</div><div class='line' id='LC304'>pointed straight ahead.  I saw he meant business, so I was up</div><div class='line' id='LC305'>the tree when he arrived.</div><div class='line' id='LC306'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC307'>He allowed that I was his property, the captive of his spear.</div><div class='line' id='LC308'>There was argument on his side--and the bulk of the advantage</div><div class='line' id='LC309'>--so I judged it best to humor him.  We fixed up an agreement</div><div class='line' id='LC310'>whereby I was to go with him and he was not to hurt me.  I came</div><div class='line' id='LC311'>down, and we started away, I walking by the side of his horse.</div><div class='line' id='LC312'>We marched comfortably along, through glades and over brooks which</div><div class='line' id='LC313'>I could not remember to have seen before--which puzzled me and</div><div class='line' id='LC314'>made me wonder--and yet we did not come to any circus or sign of</div><div class='line' id='LC315'>a circus.  So I gave up the idea of a circus, and concluded he was</div><div class='line' id='LC316'>from an asylum.  But we never came to an asylum--so I was up</div><div class='line' id='LC317'>a stump, as you may say.  I asked him how far we were from Hartford.</div><div class='line' id='LC318'>He said he had never heard of the place; which I took to be a lie,</div><div class='line' id='LC319'>but allowed it to go at that.  At the end of an hour we saw a</div><div class='line' id='LC320'>far-away town sleeping in a valley by a winding river; and beyond</div><div class='line' id='LC321'>it on a hill, a vast gray fortress, with towers and turrets,</div><div class='line' id='LC322'>the first I had ever seen out of a picture.</div><div class='line' id='LC323'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC324'>&quot;Bridgeport?&quot; said I, pointing.</div><div class='line' id='LC325'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC326'>&quot;Camelot,&quot; said he.</div><div class='line' id='LC327'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC328'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC329'>My stranger had been showing signs of sleepiness.  He caught</div><div class='line' id='LC330'>himself nodding, now, and smiled one of those pathetic, obsolete</div><div class='line' id='LC331'>smiles of his, and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC332'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC333'>&quot;I find I can&#39;t go on; but come with me, I&#39;ve got it all written</div><div class='line' id='LC334'>out, and you can read it if you like.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC335'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC336'>In his chamber, he said: &quot;First, I kept a journal; then by and by,</div><div class='line' id='LC337'>after years, I took the journal and turned it into a book. How</div><div class='line' id='LC338'>long ago that was!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC339'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC340'>He handed me his manuscript, and pointed out the place where</div><div class='line' id='LC341'>I should begin:</div><div class='line' id='LC342'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC343'>&quot;Begin here--I&#39;ve already told you what goes before.&quot;  He was</div><div class='line' id='LC344'>steeped in drowsiness by this time.  As I went out at his door</div><div class='line' id='LC345'>I heard him murmur sleepily: &quot;Give you good den, fair sir.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC346'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC347'>I sat down by my fire and examined my treasure.  The first part</div><div class='line' id='LC348'>of it--the great bulk of it--was parchment, and yellow with age.</div><div class='line' id='LC349'>I scanned a leaf particularly and saw that it was a palimpsest.</div><div class='line' id='LC350'>Under the old dim writing of the Yankee historian appeared traces</div><div class='line' id='LC351'>of a penmanship which was older and dimmer still--Latin words</div><div class='line' id='LC352'>and sentences: fragments from old monkish legends, evidently.</div><div class='line' id='LC353'>I turned to the place indicated by my stranger and began to read</div><div class='line' id='LC354'>--as follows:</div><div class='line' id='LC355'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC356'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC357'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC358'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC359'>THE TALE OF THE LOST LAND</div><div class='line' id='LC360'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC361'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC362'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC363'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC364'>CHAPTER I</div><div class='line' id='LC365'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC366'>CAMELOT</div><div class='line' id='LC367'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC368'>&quot;Camelot--Camelot,&quot; said I to myself.  &quot;I don&#39;t seem to remember</div><div class='line' id='LC369'>hearing of it before.  Name of the asylum, likely.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC370'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC371'>It was a soft, reposeful summer landscape, as lovely as a dream,</div><div class='line' id='LC372'>and as lonesome as Sunday.  The air was full of the smell of</div><div class='line' id='LC373'>flowers, and the buzzing of insects, and the twittering of birds,</div><div class='line' id='LC374'>and there were no people, no wagons, there was no stir of life,</div><div class='line' id='LC375'>nothing going on.  The road was mainly a winding path with hoof-prints</div><div class='line' id='LC376'>in it, and now and then a faint trace of wheels on either side in</div><div class='line' id='LC377'>the grass--wheels that apparently had a tire as broad as one&#39;s hand.</div><div class='line' id='LC378'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC379'>Presently a fair slip of a girl, about ten years old, with a cataract</div><div class='line' id='LC380'>of golden hair streaming down over her shoulders, came along.</div><div class='line' id='LC381'>Around her head she wore a hoop of flame-red poppies. It was as</div><div class='line' id='LC382'>sweet an outfit as ever I saw, what there was of it.  She walked</div><div class='line' id='LC383'>indolently along, with a mind at rest, its peace reflected in her</div><div class='line' id='LC384'>innocent face.  The circus man paid no attention to her; didn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC385'>even seem to see her.  And she--she was no more startled at his</div><div class='line' id='LC386'>fantastic make-up than if she was used to his like every day of</div><div class='line' id='LC387'>her life.  She was going by as indifferently as she might have gone</div><div class='line' id='LC388'>by a couple of cows; but when she happened to notice me, _then_</div><div class='line' id='LC389'>there was a change!  Up went her hands, and she was turned to stone;</div><div class='line' id='LC390'>her mouth dropped open, her eyes stared wide and timorously, she</div><div class='line' id='LC391'>was the picture of astonished curiosity touched with fear.  And</div><div class='line' id='LC392'>there she stood gazing, in a sort of stupefied fascination, till</div><div class='line' id='LC393'>we turned a corner of the wood and were lost to her view.  That</div><div class='line' id='LC394'>she should be startled at me instead of at the other man, was too</div><div class='line' id='LC395'>many for me; I couldn&#39;t make head or tail of it.  And that she</div><div class='line' id='LC396'>should seem to consider me a spectacle, and totally overlook her</div><div class='line' id='LC397'>own merits in that respect, was another puzzling thing, and a</div><div class='line' id='LC398'>display of magnanimity, too, that was surprising in one so young.</div><div class='line' id='LC399'>There was food for thought here.  I moved along as one in a dream.</div><div class='line' id='LC400'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC401'>As we approached the town, signs of life began to appear.  At</div><div class='line' id='LC402'>intervals we passed a wretched cabin, with a thatched roof, and</div><div class='line' id='LC403'>about it small fields and garden patches in an indifferent state of</div><div class='line' id='LC404'>cultivation.  There were people, too; brawny men, with long, coarse,</div><div class='line' id='LC405'>uncombed hair that hung down over their faces and made them look</div><div class='line' id='LC406'>like animals.  They and the women, as a rule, wore a coarse</div><div class='line' id='LC407'>tow-linen robe that came well below the knee, and a rude sort of</div><div class='line' id='LC408'>sandal, and many wore an iron collar.  The small boys and girls</div><div class='line' id='LC409'>were always naked; but nobody seemed to know it.  All of these</div><div class='line' id='LC410'>people stared at me, talked about me, ran into the huts and fetched</div><div class='line' id='LC411'>out their families to gape at me; but nobody ever noticed that</div><div class='line' id='LC412'>other fellow, except to make him humble salutation and get no</div><div class='line' id='LC413'>response for their pains.</div><div class='line' id='LC414'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC415'>In the town were some substantial windowless houses of stone</div><div class='line' id='LC416'>scattered among a wilderness of thatched cabins; the streets were</div><div class='line' id='LC417'>mere crooked alleys, and unpaved; troops of dogs and nude children</div><div class='line' id='LC418'>played in the sun and made life and noise; hogs roamed and rooted</div><div class='line' id='LC419'>contentedly about, and one of them lay in a reeking wallow in</div><div class='line' id='LC420'>the middle of the main thoroughfare and suckled her family.</div><div class='line' id='LC421'>Presently there was a distant blare of military music; it came</div><div class='line' id='LC422'>nearer, still nearer, and soon a noble cavalcade wound into view,</div><div class='line' id='LC423'>glorious with plumed helmets and flashing mail and flaunting banners</div><div class='line' id='LC424'>and rich doublets and horse-cloths and gilded spearheads; and</div><div class='line' id='LC425'>through the muck and swine, and naked brats, and joyous dogs, and</div><div class='line' id='LC426'>shabby huts, it took its gallant way, and in its wake we followed.</div><div class='line' id='LC427'>Followed through one winding alley and then another,--and climbing,</div><div class='line' id='LC428'>always climbing--till at last we gained the breezy height where</div><div class='line' id='LC429'>the huge castle stood.  There was an exchange of bugle blasts;</div><div class='line' id='LC430'>then a parley from the walls, where men-at-arms, in hauberk and</div><div class='line' id='LC431'>morion, marched back and forth with halberd at shoulder under</div><div class='line' id='LC432'>flapping banners with the rude figure of a dragon displayed upon</div><div class='line' id='LC433'>them; and then the great gates were flung open, the drawbridge</div><div class='line' id='LC434'>was lowered, and the head of the cavalcade swept forward under</div><div class='line' id='LC435'>the frowning arches; and we, following, soon found ourselves in</div><div class='line' id='LC436'>a great paved court, with towers and turrets stretching up into</div><div class='line' id='LC437'>the blue air on all the four sides; and all about us the dismount</div><div class='line' id='LC438'>was going on, and much greeting and ceremony, and running to and</div><div class='line' id='LC439'>fro, and a gay display of moving and intermingling colors, and</div><div class='line' id='LC440'>an altogether pleasant stir and noise and confusion.</div><div class='line' id='LC441'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC442'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC443'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC444'>CHAPTER II</div><div class='line' id='LC445'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC446'>KING ARTHUR&#39;S COURT</div><div class='line' id='LC447'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC448'>The moment I got a chance I slipped aside privately and touched</div><div class='line' id='LC449'>an ancient common looking man on the shoulder and said, in an</div><div class='line' id='LC450'>insinuating, confidential way:</div><div class='line' id='LC451'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC452'>&quot;Friend, do me a kindness.  Do you belong to the asylum, or are</div><div class='line' id='LC453'>you just on a visit or something like that?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC454'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC455'>He looked me over stupidly, and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC456'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC457'>&quot;Marry, fair sir, me seemeth--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC458'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC459'>&quot;That will do,&quot; I said; &quot;I reckon you are a patient.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC460'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC461'>I moved away, cogitating, and at the same time keeping an eye</div><div class='line' id='LC462'>out for any chance passenger in his right mind that might come</div><div class='line' id='LC463'>along and give me some light.  I judged I had found one, presently;</div><div class='line' id='LC464'>so I drew him aside and said in his ear:</div><div class='line' id='LC465'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC466'>&quot;If I could see the head keeper a minute--only just a minute--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC467'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC468'>&quot;Prithee do not let me.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC469'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC470'>&quot;Let you _what_?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC471'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC472'>&quot;_Hinder_ me, then, if the word please thee better.  Then he went</div><div class='line' id='LC473'>on to say he was an under-cook and could not stop to gossip,</div><div class='line' id='LC474'>though he would like it another time; for it would comfort his</div><div class='line' id='LC475'>very liver to know where I got my clothes.  As he started away he</div><div class='line' id='LC476'>pointed and said yonder was one who was idle enough for my purpose,</div><div class='line' id='LC477'>and was seeking me besides, no doubt.  This was an airy slim boy</div><div class='line' id='LC478'>in shrimp-colored tights that made him look like a forked carrot,</div><div class='line' id='LC479'>the rest of his gear was blue silk and dainty laces and ruffles;</div><div class='line' id='LC480'>and he had long yellow curls, and wore a plumed pink satin cap</div><div class='line' id='LC481'>tilted complacently over his ear.  By his look, he was good-natured;</div><div class='line' id='LC482'>by his gait, he was satisfied with himself.  He was pretty enough</div><div class='line' id='LC483'>to frame.  He arrived, looked me over with a smiling and impudent</div><div class='line' id='LC484'>curiosity; said he had come for me, and informed me that he was a page.</div><div class='line' id='LC485'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC486'>&quot;Go &#39;long,&quot; I said; &quot;you ain&#39;t more than a paragraph.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC487'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC488'>It was pretty severe, but I was nettled.  However, it never phazed</div><div class='line' id='LC489'>him; he didn&#39;t appear to know he was hurt.  He began to talk and</div><div class='line' id='LC490'>laugh, in happy, thoughtless, boyish fashion, as we walked along,</div><div class='line' id='LC491'>and made himself old friends with me at once; asked me all sorts</div><div class='line' id='LC492'>of questions about myself and about my clothes, but never waited</div><div class='line' id='LC493'>for an answer--always chattered straight ahead, as if he didn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC494'>know he had asked a question and wasn&#39;t expecting any reply, until</div><div class='line' id='LC495'>at last he happened to mention that he was born in the beginning</div><div class='line' id='LC496'>of the year 513.</div><div class='line' id='LC497'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC498'>It made the cold chills creep over me!  I stopped and said,</div><div class='line' id='LC499'>a little faintly:</div><div class='line' id='LC500'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC501'>&quot;Maybe I didn&#39;t hear you just right.  Say it again--and say it</div><div class='line' id='LC502'>slow.  What year was it?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC503'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC504'>&quot;513.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC505'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC506'>&quot;513!  You don&#39;t look it!  Come, my boy, I am a stranger and</div><div class='line' id='LC507'>friendless; be honest and honorable with me.  Are you in your</div><div class='line' id='LC508'>right mind?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC509'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC510'>He said he was.</div><div class='line' id='LC511'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC512'>&quot;Are these other people in their right minds?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC513'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC514'>He said they were.</div><div class='line' id='LC515'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC516'>&quot;And this isn&#39;t an asylum?  I mean, it isn&#39;t a place where they</div><div class='line' id='LC517'>cure crazy people?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC518'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC519'>He said it wasn&#39;t.</div><div class='line' id='LC520'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC521'>&quot;Well, then,&quot; I said, &quot;either I am a lunatic, or something just</div><div class='line' id='LC522'>as awful has happened.  Now tell me, honest and true, where am I?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC523'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC524'>&quot;IN KING ARTHUR&#39;S COURT.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC525'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC526'>I waited a minute, to let that idea shudder its way home,</div><div class='line' id='LC527'>and then said:</div><div class='line' id='LC528'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC529'>&quot;And according to your notions, what year is it now?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC530'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC531'>&quot;528--nineteenth of June.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC532'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC533'>I felt a mournful sinking at the heart, and muttered: &quot;I shall</div><div class='line' id='LC534'>never see my friends again--never, never again.  They will not</div><div class='line' id='LC535'>be born for more than thirteen hundred years yet.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC536'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC537'>I seemed to believe the boy, I didn&#39;t know why.  _Something_ in me</div><div class='line' id='LC538'>seemed to believe him--my consciousness, as you may say; but my</div><div class='line' id='LC539'>reason didn&#39;t.  My reason straightway began to clamor; that was</div><div class='line' id='LC540'>natural.  I didn&#39;t know how to go about satisfying it, because</div><div class='line' id='LC541'>I knew that the testimony of men wouldn&#39;t serve--my reason would</div><div class='line' id='LC542'>say they were lunatics, and throw out their evidence.  But all</div><div class='line' id='LC543'>of a sudden I stumbled on the very thing, just by luck.  I knew</div><div class='line' id='LC544'>that the only total eclipse of the sun in the first half of the</div><div class='line' id='LC545'>sixth century occurred on the 21st of June, A.D. 528, O.S., and</div><div class='line' id='LC546'>began at 3 minutes after 12 noon.  I also knew that no total eclipse</div><div class='line' id='LC547'>of the sun was due in what to _me_ was the present year--i.e., 1879.</div><div class='line' id='LC548'>So, if I could keep my anxiety and curiosity from eating the heart</div><div class='line' id='LC549'>out of me for forty-eight hours, I should then find out for certain</div><div class='line' id='LC550'>whether this boy was telling me the truth or not.</div><div class='line' id='LC551'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC552'>Wherefore, being a practical Connecticut man, I now shoved this</div><div class='line' id='LC553'>whole problem clear out of my mind till its appointed day and hour</div><div class='line' id='LC554'>should come, in order that I might turn all my attention to the</div><div class='line' id='LC555'>circumstances of the present moment, and be alert and ready to</div><div class='line' id='LC556'>make the most out of them that could be made.  One thing at a time,</div><div class='line' id='LC557'>is my motto--and just play that thing for all it is worth, even</div><div class='line' id='LC558'>if it&#39;s only two pair and a jack.  I made up my mind to two things:</div><div class='line' id='LC559'>if it was still the nineteenth century and I was among lunatics</div><div class='line' id='LC560'>and couldn&#39;t get away, I would presently boss that asylum or know</div><div class='line' id='LC561'>the reason why; and if, on the other hand, it was really the sixth</div><div class='line' id='LC562'>century, all right, I didn&#39;t want any softer thing: I would boss</div><div class='line' id='LC563'>the whole country inside of three months; for I judged I would</div><div class='line' id='LC564'>have the start of the best-educated man in the kingdom by a matter</div><div class='line' id='LC565'>of thirteen hundred years and upward.  I&#39;m not a man to waste</div><div class='line' id='LC566'>time after my mind&#39;s made up and there&#39;s work on hand; so I said</div><div class='line' id='LC567'>to the page:</div><div class='line' id='LC568'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC569'>&quot;Now, Clarence, my boy--if that might happen to be your name</div><div class='line' id='LC570'>--I&#39;ll get you to post me up a little if you don&#39;t mind.  What is</div><div class='line' id='LC571'>the name of that apparition that brought me here?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC572'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC573'>&quot;My master and thine?  That is the good knight and great lord</div><div class='line' id='LC574'>Sir Kay the Seneschal, foster brother to our liege the king.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC575'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC576'>&quot;Very good; go on, tell me everything.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC577'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC578'>He made a long story of it; but the part that had immediate interest</div><div class='line' id='LC579'>for me was this: He said I was Sir Kay&#39;s prisoner, and that</div><div class='line' id='LC580'>in the due course of custom I would be flung into a dungeon and</div><div class='line' id='LC581'>left there on scant commons until my friends ransomed me--unless</div><div class='line' id='LC582'>I chanced to rot, first.  I saw that the last chance had the best</div><div class='line' id='LC583'>show, but I didn&#39;t waste any bother about that; time was too</div><div class='line' id='LC584'>precious.  The page said, further, that dinner was about ended</div><div class='line' id='LC585'>in the great hall by this time, and that as soon as the sociability</div><div class='line' id='LC586'>and the heavy drinking should begin, Sir Kay would have me in and</div><div class='line' id='LC587'>exhibit me before King Arthur and his illustrious knights seated at</div><div class='line' id='LC588'>the Table Round, and would brag about his exploit in capturing</div><div class='line' id='LC589'>me, and would probably exaggerate the facts a little, but it</div><div class='line' id='LC590'>wouldn&#39;t be good form for me to correct him, and not over safe,</div><div class='line' id='LC591'>either; and when I was done being exhibited, then ho for the</div><div class='line' id='LC592'>dungeon; but he, Clarence, would find a way to come and see me every</div><div class='line' id='LC593'>now and then, and cheer me up, and help me get word to my friends.</div><div class='line' id='LC594'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC595'>Get word to my friends!  I thanked him; I couldn&#39;t do less; and</div><div class='line' id='LC596'>about this time a lackey came to say I was wanted; so Clarence</div><div class='line' id='LC597'>led me in and took me off to one side and sat down by me.</div><div class='line' id='LC598'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC599'>Well, it was a curious kind of spectacle, and interesting. It was</div><div class='line' id='LC600'>an immense place, and rather naked--yes, and full of loud contrasts.</div><div class='line' id='LC601'>It was very, very lofty; so lofty that the banners depending from</div><div class='line' id='LC602'>the arched beams and girders away up there floated in a sort of</div><div class='line' id='LC603'>twilight; there was a stone-railed gallery at each end, high up,</div><div class='line' id='LC604'>with musicians in the one, and women, clothed in stunning colors,</div><div class='line' id='LC605'>in the other.  The floor was of big stone flags laid in black and</div><div class='line' id='LC606'>white squares, rather battered by age and use, and needing repair.</div><div class='line' id='LC607'>As to ornament, there wasn&#39;t any, strictly speaking; though on</div><div class='line' id='LC608'>the walls hung some huge tapestries which were probably taxed</div><div class='line' id='LC609'>as works of art; battle-pieces, they were, with horses shaped like</div><div class='line' id='LC610'>those which children cut out of paper or create in gingerbread;</div><div class='line' id='LC611'>with men on them in scale armor whose scales are represented by</div><div class='line' id='LC612'>round holes--so that the man&#39;s coat looks as if it had been done</div><div class='line' id='LC613'>with a biscuit-punch.  There was a fireplace big enough to camp in;</div><div class='line' id='LC614'>and its projecting sides and hood, of carved and pillared stonework,</div><div class='line' id='LC615'>had the look of a cathedral door.  Along the walls stood men-at-arms,</div><div class='line' id='LC616'>in breastplate and morion, with halberds for their only weapon</div><div class='line' id='LC617'>--rigid as statues; and that is what they looked like.</div><div class='line' id='LC618'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC619'>In the middle of this groined and vaulted public square was an oaken</div><div class='line' id='LC620'>table which they called the Table Round.  It was as large as</div><div class='line' id='LC621'>a circus ring; and around it sat a great company of men dressed</div><div class='line' id='LC622'>in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one&#39;s eyes to look</div><div class='line' id='LC623'>at them.  They wore their plumed hats, right along, except that</div><div class='line' id='LC624'>whenever one addressed himself directly to the king, he lifted</div><div class='line' id='LC625'>his hat a trifle just as he was beginning his remark.</div><div class='line' id='LC626'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC627'>Mainly they were drinking--from entire ox horns; but a few were</div><div class='line' id='LC628'>still munching bread or gnawing beef bones.  There was about</div><div class='line' id='LC629'>an average of two dogs to one man; and these sat in expectant</div><div class='line' id='LC630'>attitudes till a spent bone was flung to them, and then they went</div><div class='line' id='LC631'>for it by brigades and divisions, with a rush, and there ensued</div><div class='line' id='LC632'>a fight which filled the prospect with a tumultuous chaos of</div><div class='line' id='LC633'>plunging heads and bodies and flashing tails, and the storm of</div><div class='line' id='LC634'>howlings and barkings deafened all speech for the time; but that</div><div class='line' id='LC635'>was no matter, for the dog-fight was always a bigger interest</div><div class='line' id='LC636'>anyway; the men rose, sometimes, to observe it the better and bet</div><div class='line' id='LC637'>on it, and the ladies and the musicians stretched themselves out</div><div class='line' id='LC638'>over their balusters with the same object; and all broke into</div><div class='line' id='LC639'>delighted ejaculations from time to time. In the end, the winning</div><div class='line' id='LC640'>dog stretched himself out comfortably with his bone between his</div><div class='line' id='LC641'>paws, and proceeded to growl over it, and gnaw it, and grease</div><div class='line' id='LC642'>the floor with it, just as fifty others were already doing; and the</div><div class='line' id='LC643'>rest of the court resumed their previous industries and entertainments.</div><div class='line' id='LC644'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC645'>As a rule, the speech and behavior of these people were gracious</div><div class='line' id='LC646'>and courtly; and I noticed that they were good and serious listeners</div><div class='line' id='LC647'>when anybody was telling anything--I mean in a dog-fightless</div><div class='line' id='LC648'>interval.  And plainly, too, they were a childlike and innocent lot;</div><div class='line' id='LC649'>telling lies of the stateliest pattern with a most gentle and</div><div class='line' id='LC650'>winning naivety, and ready and willing to listen to anybody else&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC651'>lie, and believe it, too.  It was hard to associate them with</div><div class='line' id='LC652'>anything cruel or dreadful; and yet they dealt in tales of blood</div><div class='line' id='LC653'>and suffering with a guileless relish that made me almost forget</div><div class='line' id='LC654'>to shudder.</div><div class='line' id='LC655'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC656'>I was not the only prisoner present.  There were twenty or more.</div><div class='line' id='LC657'>Poor devils, many of them were maimed, hacked, carved, in a frightful</div><div class='line' id='LC658'>way; and their hair, their faces, their clothing, were caked with</div><div class='line' id='LC659'>black and stiffened drenchings of blood.  They were suffering</div><div class='line' id='LC660'>sharp physical pain, of course; and weariness, and hunger and</div><div class='line' id='LC661'>thirst, no doubt; and at least none had given them the comfort</div><div class='line' id='LC662'>of a wash, or even the poor charity of a lotion for their wounds;</div><div class='line' id='LC663'>yet you never heard them utter a moan or a groan, or saw them show</div><div class='line' id='LC664'>any sign of restlessness, or any disposition to complain.  The</div><div class='line' id='LC665'>thought was forced upon me: &quot;The rascals--_they_ have served other</div><div class='line' id='LC666'>people so in their day; it being their own turn, now, they were</div><div class='line' id='LC667'>not expecting any better treatment than this; so their philosophical</div><div class='line' id='LC668'>bearing is not an outcome of mental training, intellectual fortitude,</div><div class='line' id='LC669'>reasoning; it is mere animal training; they are white Indians.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC670'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC671'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC672'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC673'>CHAPTER III</div><div class='line' id='LC674'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC675'>KNIGHTS OF THE TABLE ROUND</div><div class='line' id='LC676'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC677'>Mainly the Round Table talk was monologues--narrative accounts</div><div class='line' id='LC678'>of the adventures in which these prisoners were captured and their</div><div class='line' id='LC679'>friends and backers killed and stripped of their steeds and armor.</div><div class='line' id='LC680'>As a general thing--as far as I could make out--these murderous</div><div class='line' id='LC681'>adventures were not forays undertaken to avenge injuries, nor to</div><div class='line' id='LC682'>settle old disputes or sudden fallings out; no, as a rule they were</div><div class='line' id='LC683'>simply duels between strangers--duels between people who had never</div><div class='line' id='LC684'>even been introduced to each other, and between whom existed no</div><div class='line' id='LC685'>cause of offense whatever.  Many a time I had seen a couple of boys,</div><div class='line' id='LC686'>strangers, meet by chance, and say simultaneously, &quot;I can lick you,&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC687'>and go at it on the spot; but I had always imagined until now that</div><div class='line' id='LC688'>that sort of thing belonged to children only, and was a sign and</div><div class='line' id='LC689'>mark of childhood; but here were these big boobies sticking to it</div><div class='line' id='LC690'>and taking pride in it clear up into full age and beyond.  Yet there</div><div class='line' id='LC691'>was something very engaging about these great simple-hearted</div><div class='line' id='LC692'>creatures, something attractive and lovable.  There did not seem</div><div class='line' id='LC693'>to be brains enough in the entire nursery, so to speak, to bait</div><div class='line' id='LC694'>a fish-hook with; but you didn&#39;t seem to mind that, after a little,</div><div class='line' id='LC695'>because you soon saw that brains were not needed in a society</div><div class='line' id='LC696'>like that, and indeed would have marred it, hindered it, spoiled</div><div class='line' id='LC697'>its symmetry--perhaps rendered its existence impossible.</div><div class='line' id='LC698'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC699'>There was a fine manliness observable in almost every face; and</div><div class='line' id='LC700'>in some a certain loftiness and sweetness that rebuked your</div><div class='line' id='LC701'>belittling criticisms and stilled them.  A most noble benignity</div><div class='line' id='LC702'>and purity reposed in the countenance of him they called Sir Galahad,</div><div class='line' id='LC703'>and likewise in the king&#39;s also; and there was majesty and greatness</div><div class='line' id='LC704'>in the giant frame and high bearing of Sir Launcelot of the Lake.</div><div class='line' id='LC705'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC706'>There was presently an incident which centered the general interest</div><div class='line' id='LC707'>upon this Sir Launcelot.  At a sign from a sort of master of</div><div class='line' id='LC708'>ceremonies, six or eight of the prisoners rose and came forward</div><div class='line' id='LC709'>in a body and knelt on the floor and lifted up their hands toward</div><div class='line' id='LC710'>the ladies&#39; gallery and begged the grace of a word with the queen.</div><div class='line' id='LC711'>The most conspicuously situated lady in that massed flower-bed</div><div class='line' id='LC712'>of feminine show and finery inclined her head by way of assent,</div><div class='line' id='LC713'>and then the spokesman of the prisoners delivered himself and his</div><div class='line' id='LC714'>fellows into her hands for free pardon, ransom, captivity, or death,</div><div class='line' id='LC715'>as she in her good pleasure might elect; and this, as he said, he</div><div class='line' id='LC716'>was doing by command of Sir Kay the Seneschal, whose prisoners</div><div class='line' id='LC717'>they were, he having vanquished them by his single might and</div><div class='line' id='LC718'>prowess in sturdy conflict in the field.</div><div class='line' id='LC719'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC720'>Surprise and astonishment flashed from face to face all over</div><div class='line' id='LC721'>the house; the queen&#39;s gratified smile faded out at the name of</div><div class='line' id='LC722'>Sir Kay, and she looked disappointed; and the page whispered in</div><div class='line' id='LC723'>my ear with an accent and manner expressive of extravagant derision--</div><div class='line' id='LC724'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC725'>&quot;Sir _Kay_, forsooth!  Oh, call me pet names, dearest, call me</div><div class='line' id='LC726'>a marine!  In twice a thousand years shall the unholy invention</div><div class='line' id='LC727'>of man labor at odds to beget the fellow to this majestic lie!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC728'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC729'>Every eye was fastened with severe inquiry upon Sir Kay. But he</div><div class='line' id='LC730'>was equal to the occasion.  He got up and played his hand like</div><div class='line' id='LC731'>a major--and took every trick.  He said he would state the case</div><div class='line' id='LC732'>exactly according to the facts; he would tell the simple</div><div class='line' id='LC733'>straightforward tale, without comment of his own; &quot;and then,&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC734'>said he, &quot;if ye find glory and honor due, ye will give it unto him</div><div class='line' id='LC735'>who is the mightiest man of his hands that ever bare shield or</div><div class='line' id='LC736'>strake with sword in the ranks of Christian battle--even him that</div><div class='line' id='LC737'>sitteth there!&quot; and he pointed to Sir Launcelot.  Ah, he fetched</div><div class='line' id='LC738'>them; it was a rattling good stroke.  Then he went on and told</div><div class='line' id='LC739'>how Sir Launcelot, seeking adventures, some brief time gone by,</div><div class='line' id='LC740'>killed seven giants at one sweep of his sword, and set a hundred</div><div class='line' id='LC741'>and forty-two captive maidens free; and then went further, still</div><div class='line' id='LC742'>seeking adventures, and found him (Sir Kay) fighting a desperate</div><div class='line' id='LC743'>fight against nine foreign knights, and straightway took the battle</div><div class='line' id='LC744'>solely into his own hands, and conquered the nine; and that night</div><div class='line' id='LC745'>Sir Launcelot rose quietly, and dressed him in Sir Kay&#39;s armor and</div><div class='line' id='LC746'>took Sir Kay&#39;s horse and gat him away into distant lands, and</div><div class='line' id='LC747'>vanquished sixteen knights in one pitched battle and thirty-four</div><div class='line' id='LC748'>in another; and all these and the former nine he made to swear</div><div class='line' id='LC749'>that about Whitsuntide they would ride to Arthur&#39;s court and yield</div><div class='line' id='LC750'>them to Queen Guenever&#39;s hands as captives of Sir Kay the Seneschal,</div><div class='line' id='LC751'>spoil of his knightly prowess; and now here were these half dozen,</div><div class='line' id='LC752'>and the rest would be along as soon as they might be healed of</div><div class='line' id='LC753'>their desperate wounds.</div><div class='line' id='LC754'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC755'>Well, it was touching to see the queen blush and smile, and look</div><div class='line' id='LC756'>embarrassed and happy, and fling furtive glances at Sir Launcelot</div><div class='line' id='LC757'>that would have got him shot in Arkansas, to a dead certainty.</div><div class='line' id='LC758'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC759'>Everybody praised the valor and magnanimity of Sir Launcelot; and</div><div class='line' id='LC760'>as for me, I was perfectly amazed, that one man, all by himself,</div><div class='line' id='LC761'>should have been able to beat down and capture such battalions</div><div class='line' id='LC762'>of practiced fighters.  I said as much to Clarence; but this mocking</div><div class='line' id='LC763'>featherhead only said:</div><div class='line' id='LC764'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC765'>&quot;An Sir Kay had had time to get another skin of sour wine into him,</div><div class='line' id='LC766'>ye had seen the accompt doubled.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC767'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC768'>I looked at the boy in sorrow; and as I looked I saw the cloud of</div><div class='line' id='LC769'>a deep despondency settle upon his countenance.  I followed the</div><div class='line' id='LC770'>direction of his eye, and saw that a very old and white-bearded</div><div class='line' id='LC771'>man, clothed in a flowing black gown, had risen and was standing</div><div class='line' id='LC772'>at the table upon unsteady legs, and feebly swaying his ancient</div><div class='line' id='LC773'>head and surveying the company with his watery and wandering eye.</div><div class='line' id='LC774'>The same suffering look that was in the page&#39;s face was observable</div><div class='line' id='LC775'>in all the faces around--the look of dumb creatures who know that</div><div class='line' id='LC776'>they must endure and make no moan.</div><div class='line' id='LC777'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC778'>&quot;Marry, we shall have it again,&quot; sighed the boy; &quot;that same old</div><div class='line' id='LC779'>weary tale that he hath told a thousand times in the same words,</div><div class='line' id='LC780'>and that he _will_ tell till he dieth, every time he hath gotten his</div><div class='line' id='LC781'>barrel full and feeleth his exaggeration-mill a-working.  Would</div><div class='line' id='LC782'>God I had died or I saw this day!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC783'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC784'>&quot;Who is it?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC785'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC786'>&quot;Merlin, the mighty liar and magician, perdition singe him for</div><div class='line' id='LC787'>the weariness he worketh with his one tale!  But that men fear</div><div class='line' id='LC788'>him for that he hath the storms and the lightnings and all the</div><div class='line' id='LC789'>devils that be in hell at his beck and call, they would have dug</div><div class='line' id='LC790'>his entrails out these many years ago to get at that tale and</div><div class='line' id='LC791'>squelch it.  He telleth it always in the third person, making</div><div class='line' id='LC792'>believe he is too modest to glorify himself--maledictions light</div><div class='line' id='LC793'>upon him, misfortune be his dole!  Good friend, prithee call me</div><div class='line' id='LC794'>for evensong.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC795'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC796'>The boy nestled himself upon my shoulder and pretended to go</div><div class='line' id='LC797'>to sleep.  The old man began his tale; and presently the lad was</div><div class='line' id='LC798'>asleep in reality; so also were the dogs, and the court, the lackeys,</div><div class='line' id='LC799'>and the files of men-at-arms.  The droning voice droned on; a soft</div><div class='line' id='LC800'>snoring arose on all sides and supported it like a deep and subdued</div><div class='line' id='LC801'>accompaniment of wind instruments.  Some heads were bowed upon</div><div class='line' id='LC802'>folded arms, some lay back with open mouths that issued unconscious</div><div class='line' id='LC803'>music; the flies buzzed and bit, unmolested, the rats swarmed</div><div class='line' id='LC804'>softly out from a hundred holes, and pattered about, and made</div><div class='line' id='LC805'>themselves at home everywhere; and one of them sat up like a</div><div class='line' id='LC806'>squirrel on the king&#39;s head and held a bit of cheese in its hands</div><div class='line' id='LC807'>and nibbled it, and dribbled the crumbs in the king&#39;s face with</div><div class='line' id='LC808'>naive and impudent irreverence.  It was a tranquil scene, and</div><div class='line' id='LC809'>restful to the weary eye and the jaded spirit.</div><div class='line' id='LC810'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC811'>This was the old man&#39;s tale.  He said:</div><div class='line' id='LC812'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC813'>&quot;Right so the king and Merlin departed, and went until an hermit</div><div class='line' id='LC814'>that was a good man and a great leech.  So the hermit searched</div><div class='line' id='LC815'>all his wounds and gave him good salves; so the king was there</div><div class='line' id='LC816'>three days, and then were his wounds well amended that he might</div><div class='line' id='LC817'>ride and go, and so departed.  And as they rode, Arthur said,</div><div class='line' id='LC818'>I have no sword.  No force,* [*Footnote from M.T.: No matter.]</div><div class='line' id='LC819'>said Merlin, hereby is a sword that shall be yours and I may.</div><div class='line' id='LC820'>So they rode till they came to a lake, the which was a fair water</div><div class='line' id='LC821'>and broad, and in the midst of the lake Arthur was ware of an arm</div><div class='line' id='LC822'>clothed in white samite, that held a fair sword in that hand.</div><div class='line' id='LC823'>Lo, said Merlin, yonder is that sword that I spake of.  With that</div><div class='line' id='LC824'>they saw a damsel going upon the lake.  What damsel is that?</div><div class='line' id='LC825'>said Arthur.  That is the Lady of the lake, said Merlin; and within</div><div class='line' id='LC826'>that lake is a rock, and therein is as fair a place as any on earth,</div><div class='line' id='LC827'>and richly beseen, and this damsel will come to you anon, and then</div><div class='line' id='LC828'>speak ye fair to her that she will give you that sword.  Anon</div><div class='line' id='LC829'>withal came the damsel unto Arthur and saluted him, and he her</div><div class='line' id='LC830'>again.  Damsel, said Arthur, what sword is that, that yonder</div><div class='line' id='LC831'>the arm holdeth above the water?  I would it were mine, for I have</div><div class='line' id='LC832'>no sword.  Sir Arthur King, said the damsel, that sword is mine,</div><div class='line' id='LC833'>and if ye will give me a gift when I ask it you, ye shall have it.</div><div class='line' id='LC834'>By my faith, said Arthur, I will give you what gift ye will ask.</div><div class='line' id='LC835'>Well, said the damsel, go ye into yonder barge and row yourself</div><div class='line' id='LC836'>to the sword, and take it and the scabbard with you, and I will ask</div><div class='line' id='LC837'>my gift when I see my time.  So Sir Arthur and Merlin alight, and</div><div class='line' id='LC838'>tied their horses to two trees, and so they went into the ship,</div><div class='line' id='LC839'>and when they came to the sword that the hand held, Sir Arthur</div><div class='line' id='LC840'>took it up by the handles, and took it with him.  And the arm</div><div class='line' id='LC841'>and the hand went under the water; and so they came unto the land</div><div class='line' id='LC842'>and rode forth.  And then Sir Arthur saw a rich pavilion.  What</div><div class='line' id='LC843'>signifieth yonder pavilion?  It is the knight&#39;s pavilion, said</div><div class='line' id='LC844'>Merlin, that ye fought with last, Sir Pellinore, but he is out,</div><div class='line' id='LC845'>he is not there; he hath ado with a knight of yours, that hight</div><div class='line' id='LC846'>Egglame, and they have fought together, but at the last Egglame</div><div class='line' id='LC847'>fled, and else he had been dead, and he hath chased him even</div><div class='line' id='LC848'>to Carlion, and we shall meet with him anon in the highway.  That</div><div class='line' id='LC849'>is well said, said Arthur, now have I a sword, now will I wage</div><div class='line' id='LC850'>battle with him, and be avenged on him.  Sir, ye shall not so,</div><div class='line' id='LC851'>said Merlin, for the knight is weary of fighting and chasing, so</div><div class='line' id='LC852'>that ye shall have no worship to have ado with him; also, he will</div><div class='line' id='LC853'>not lightly be matched of one knight living; and therefore it is my</div><div class='line' id='LC854'>counsel, let him pass, for he shall do you good service in short</div><div class='line' id='LC855'>time, and his sons, after his days.  Also ye shall see that day</div><div class='line' id='LC856'>in short space ye shall be right glad to give him your sister</div><div class='line' id='LC857'>to wed.  When I see him, I will do as ye advise me, said Arthur.</div><div class='line' id='LC858'>Then Sir Arthur looked on the sword, and liked it passing well.</div><div class='line' id='LC859'>Whether liketh you better, said Merlin, the sword or the scabbard?</div><div class='line' id='LC860'>Me liketh better the sword, said Arthur.  Ye are more unwise,</div><div class='line' id='LC861'>said Merlin, for the scabbard is worth ten of the sword, for while</div><div class='line' id='LC862'>ye have the scabbard upon you ye shall never lose no blood, be ye</div><div class='line' id='LC863'>never so sore wounded; therefore, keep well the scabbard always</div><div class='line' id='LC864'>with you.  So they rode into Carlion, and by the way they met with</div><div class='line' id='LC865'>Sir Pellinore; but Merlin had done such a craft that Pellinore saw</div><div class='line' id='LC866'>not Arthur, and he passed by without any words.  I marvel, said</div><div class='line' id='LC867'>Arthur, that the knight would not speak.  Sir, said Merlin, he saw</div><div class='line' id='LC868'>you not; for and he had seen you ye had not lightly departed.  So</div><div class='line' id='LC869'>they came unto Carlion, whereof his knights were passing glad.</div><div class='line' id='LC870'>And when they heard of his adventures they marveled that he would</div><div class='line' id='LC871'>jeopard his person so alone.  But all men of worship said it was</div><div class='line' id='LC872'>merry to be under such a chieftain that would put his person in</div><div class='line' id='LC873'>adventure as other poor knights did.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC874'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC875'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC876'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC877'>CHAPTER IV</div><div class='line' id='LC878'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC879'>SIR DINADAN THE HUMORIST</div><div class='line' id='LC880'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC881'>It seemed to me that this quaint lie was most simply and beautifully</div><div class='line' id='LC882'>told; but then I had heard it only once, and that makes a difference;</div><div class='line' id='LC883'>it was pleasant to the others when it was fresh, no doubt.</div><div class='line' id='LC884'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC885'>Sir Dinadan the Humorist was the first to awake, and he soon roused</div><div class='line' id='LC886'>the rest with a practical joke of a sufficiently poor quality.</div><div class='line' id='LC887'>He tied some metal mugs to a dog&#39;s tail and turned him loose,</div><div class='line' id='LC888'>and he tore around and around the place in a frenzy of fright,</div><div class='line' id='LC889'>with all the other dogs bellowing after him and battering and</div><div class='line' id='LC890'>crashing against everything that came in their way and making</div><div class='line' id='LC891'>altogether a chaos of confusion and a most deafening din and</div><div class='line' id='LC892'>turmoil; at which every man and woman of the multitude laughed</div><div class='line' id='LC893'>till the tears flowed, and some fell out of their chairs and</div><div class='line' id='LC894'>wallowed on the floor in ecstasy.  It was just like so many children.</div><div class='line' id='LC895'>Sir Dinadan was so proud of his exploit that he could not keep</div><div class='line' id='LC896'>from telling over and over again, to weariness, how the immortal</div><div class='line' id='LC897'>idea happened to occur to him; and as is the way with humorists</div><div class='line' id='LC898'>of his breed, he was still laughing at it after everybody else had</div><div class='line' id='LC899'>got through.  He was so set up that he concluded to make a speech</div><div class='line' id='LC900'>--of course a humorous speech.  I think I never heard so many old</div><div class='line' id='LC901'>played-out jokes strung together in my life.  He was worse than</div><div class='line' id='LC902'>the minstrels, worse than the clown in the circus.  It seemed</div><div class='line' id='LC903'>peculiarly sad to sit here, thirteen hundred years before I was</div><div class='line' id='LC904'>born, and listen again to poor, flat, worm-eaten jokes that had</div><div class='line' id='LC905'>given me the dry gripes when I was a boy thirteen hundred years</div><div class='line' id='LC906'>afterwards.  It about convinced me that there isn&#39;t any such thing</div><div class='line' id='LC907'>as a new joke possible.  Everybody laughed at these antiquities</div><div class='line' id='LC908'>--but then they always do; I had noticed that, centuries later.</div><div class='line' id='LC909'>However, of course the scoffer didn&#39;t laugh--I mean the boy.  No,</div><div class='line' id='LC910'>he scoffed; there wasn&#39;t anything he wouldn&#39;t scoff at. He said</div><div class='line' id='LC911'>the most of Sir Dinadan&#39;s jokes were rotten and the rest were</div><div class='line' id='LC912'>petrified.  I said &quot;petrified&quot; was good; as I believed, myself,</div><div class='line' id='LC913'>that the only right way to classify the majestic ages of some of</div><div class='line' id='LC914'>those jokes was by geologic periods.  But that neat idea hit</div><div class='line' id='LC915'>the boy in a blank place, for geology hadn&#39;t been invented yet.</div><div class='line' id='LC916'>However, I made a note of the remark, and calculated to educate</div><div class='line' id='LC917'>the commonwealth up to it if I pulled through.  It is no use</div><div class='line' id='LC918'>to throw a good thing away merely because the market isn&#39;t ripe yet.</div><div class='line' id='LC919'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC920'>Now Sir Kay arose and began to fire up on his history-mill with me</div><div class='line' id='LC921'>for fuel.  It was time for me to feel serious, and I did.  Sir Kay</div><div class='line' id='LC922'>told how he had encountered me in a far land of barbarians, who</div><div class='line' id='LC923'>all wore the same ridiculous garb that I did--a garb that was a work</div><div class='line' id='LC924'>of enchantment, and intended to make the wearer secure from hurt</div><div class='line' id='LC925'>by human hands.  However he had nullified the force of the</div><div class='line' id='LC926'>enchantment by prayer, and had killed my thirteen knights in</div><div class='line' id='LC927'>a three hours&#39; battle, and taken me prisoner, sparing my life</div><div class='line' id='LC928'>in order that so strange a curiosity as I was might be exhibited</div><div class='line' id='LC929'>to the wonder and admiration of the king and the court.
