He spoke</div><div class='line' id='LC930'>of me all the time, in the blandest way, as &quot;this prodigious giant,&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC931'>and &quot;this horrible sky-towering monster,&quot; and &quot;this tusked and</div><div class='line' id='LC932'>taloned man-devouring ogre&quot;, and everybody took in all this bosh</div><div class='line' id='LC933'>in the naivest way, and never smiled or seemed to notice that</div><div class='line' id='LC934'>there was any discrepancy between these watered statistics and me.</div><div class='line' id='LC935'>He said that in trying to escape from him I sprang into the top of</div><div class='line' id='LC936'>a tree two hundred cubits high at a single bound, but he dislodged</div><div class='line' id='LC937'>me with a stone the size of a cow, which &quot;all-to brast&quot; the most</div><div class='line' id='LC938'>of my bones, and then swore me to appear at Arthur&#39;s court for</div><div class='line' id='LC939'>sentence.  He ended by condemning me to die at noon on the 21st;</div><div class='line' id='LC940'>and was so little concerned about it that he stopped to yawn before</div><div class='line' id='LC941'>he named the date.</div><div class='line' id='LC942'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC943'>I was in a dismal state by this time; indeed, I was hardly enough</div><div class='line' id='LC944'>in my right mind to keep the run of a dispute that sprung up as</div><div class='line' id='LC945'>to how I had better be killed, the possibility of the killing being</div><div class='line' id='LC946'>doubted by some, because of the enchantment in my clothes. And yet</div><div class='line' id='LC947'>it was nothing but an ordinary suit of fifteen-dollar slop-shops.</div><div class='line' id='LC948'>Still, I was sane enough to notice this detail, to wit: many of</div><div class='line' id='LC949'>the terms used in the most matter-of-fact way by this great</div><div class='line' id='LC950'>assemblage of the first ladies and gentlemen in the land would</div><div class='line' id='LC951'>have made a Comanche blush.  Indelicacy is too mild a term to convey</div><div class='line' id='LC952'>the idea.  However, I had read &quot;Tom Jones,&quot; and &quot;Roderick Random,&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC953'>and other books of that kind, and knew that the highest and first</div><div class='line' id='LC954'>ladies and gentlemen in England had remained little or no cleaner</div><div class='line' id='LC955'>in their talk, and in the morals and conduct which such talk</div><div class='line' id='LC956'>implies, clear up to a hundred years ago; in fact clear into our</div><div class='line' id='LC957'>own nineteenth century--in which century, broadly speaking,</div><div class='line' id='LC958'>the earliest samples of the real lady and real gentleman discoverable</div><div class='line' id='LC959'>in English history--or in European history, for that matter--may be</div><div class='line' id='LC960'>said to have made their appearance.  Suppose Sir Walter, instead</div><div class='line' id='LC961'>of putting the conversations into the mouths of his characters,</div><div class='line' id='LC962'>had allowed the characters to speak for themselves?  We should</div><div class='line' id='LC963'>have had talk from Rebecca and Ivanhoe and the soft lady Rowena</div><div class='line' id='LC964'>which would embarrass a tramp in our day.  However, to the</div><div class='line' id='LC965'>unconsciously indelicate all things are delicate.  King Arthur&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC966'>people were not aware that they were indecent and I had presence</div><div class='line' id='LC967'>of mind enough not to mention it.</div><div class='line' id='LC968'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC969'>They were so troubled about my enchanted clothes that they were</div><div class='line' id='LC970'>mightily relieved, at last, when old Merlin swept the difficulty</div><div class='line' id='LC971'>away for them with a common-sense hint.  He asked them why they</div><div class='line' id='LC972'>were so dull--why didn&#39;t it occur to them to strip me.  In half a</div><div class='line' id='LC973'>minute I was as naked as a pair of tongs!  And dear, dear, to think</div><div class='line' id='LC974'>of it: I was the only embarrassed person there.  Everybody discussed</div><div class='line' id='LC975'>me; and did it as unconcernedly as if I had been a cabbage.</div><div class='line' id='LC976'>Queen Guenever was as naively interested as the rest, and said</div><div class='line' id='LC977'>she had never seen anybody with legs just like mine before.  It was</div><div class='line' id='LC978'>the only compliment I got--if it was a compliment.</div><div class='line' id='LC979'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC980'>Finally I was carried off in one direction, and my perilous clothes</div><div class='line' id='LC981'>in another.  I was shoved into a dark and narrow cell in a dungeon,</div><div class='line' id='LC982'>with some scant remnants for dinner, some moldy straw for a bed,</div><div class='line' id='LC983'>and no end of rats for company.</div><div class='line' id='LC984'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC985'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC986'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC987'>CHAPTER V</div><div class='line' id='LC988'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC989'>AN INSPIRATION</div><div class='line' id='LC990'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC991'>I was so tired that even my fears were not able to keep me awake long.</div><div class='line' id='LC992'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC993'>When I next came to myself, I seemed to have been asleep a very</div><div class='line' id='LC994'>long time.  My first thought was, &quot;Well, what an astonishing dream</div><div class='line' id='LC995'>I&#39;ve had!  I reckon I&#39;ve waked only just in time to keep from</div><div class='line' id='LC996'>being hanged or drowned or burned or something....  I&#39;ll nap again</div><div class='line' id='LC997'>till the whistle blows, and then I&#39;ll go down to the arms factory</div><div class='line' id='LC998'>and have it out with Hercules.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC999'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1000'>But just then I heard the harsh music of rusty chains and bolts,</div><div class='line' id='LC1001'>a light flashed in my eyes, and that butterfly, Clarence, stood</div><div class='line' id='LC1002'>before me!  I gasped with surprise; my breath almost got away from me.</div><div class='line' id='LC1003'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1004'>&quot;What!&quot; I said, &quot;you here yet?  Go along with the rest of</div><div class='line' id='LC1005'>the dream! scatter!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1006'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1007'>But he only laughed, in his light-hearted way, and fell to making</div><div class='line' id='LC1008'>fun of my sorry plight.</div><div class='line' id='LC1009'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1010'>&quot;All right,&quot; I said resignedly, &quot;let the dream go on; I&#39;m in no hurry.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1011'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1012'>&quot;Prithee what dream?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1013'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1014'>&quot;What dream?  Why, the dream that I am in Arthur&#39;s court--a person</div><div class='line' id='LC1015'>who never existed; and that I am talking to you, who are nothing</div><div class='line' id='LC1016'>but a work of the imagination.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1017'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1018'>&quot;Oh, la, indeed! and is it a dream that you&#39;re to be burned</div><div class='line' id='LC1019'>to-morrow?  Ho-ho--answer me that!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1020'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1021'>The shock that went through me was distressing.  I now began</div><div class='line' id='LC1022'>to reason that my situation was in the last degree serious, dream</div><div class='line' id='LC1023'>or no dream; for I knew by past experience of the lifelike intensity</div><div class='line' id='LC1024'>of dreams, that to be burned to death, even in a dream, would be</div><div class='line' id='LC1025'>very far from being a jest, and was a thing to be avoided, by any</div><div class='line' id='LC1026'>means, fair or foul, that I could contrive.  So I said beseechingly:</div><div class='line' id='LC1027'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1028'>&quot;Ah, Clarence, good boy, only friend I&#39;ve got,--for you _are_ my</div><div class='line' id='LC1029'>friend, aren&#39;t you?--don&#39;t fail me; help me to devise some way</div><div class='line' id='LC1030'>of escaping from this place!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1031'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1032'>&quot;Now do but hear thyself!  Escape?  Why, man, the corridors are</div><div class='line' id='LC1033'>in guard and keep of men-at-arms.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1034'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1035'>&quot;No doubt, no doubt.  But how many, Clarence?  Not many, I hope?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1036'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1037'>&quot;Full a score.  One may not hope to escape.&quot;  After a pause</div><div class='line' id='LC1038'>--hesitatingly: &quot;and there be other reasons--and weightier.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1039'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1040'>&quot;Other ones? What are they?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1041'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1042'>&quot;Well, they say--oh, but I daren&#39;t, indeed daren&#39;t!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1043'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1044'>&quot;Why, poor lad, what is the matter?  Why do you blench?  Why do</div><div class='line' id='LC1045'>you tremble so?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1046'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1047'>&quot;Oh, in sooth, there is need!  I do want to tell you, but--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1048'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1049'>&quot;Come, come, be brave, be a man--speak out, there&#39;s a good lad!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1050'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1051'>He hesitated, pulled one way by desire, the other way by fear;</div><div class='line' id='LC1052'>then he stole to the door and peeped out, listening; and finally</div><div class='line' id='LC1053'>crept close to me and put his mouth to my ear and told me his</div><div class='line' id='LC1054'>fearful news in a whisper, and with all the cowering apprehension</div><div class='line' id='LC1055'>of one who was venturing upon awful ground and speaking of things</div><div class='line' id='LC1056'>whose very mention might be freighted with death.</div><div class='line' id='LC1057'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1058'>&quot;Merlin, in his malice, has woven a spell about this dungeon, and</div><div class='line' id='LC1059'>there bides not the man in these kingdoms that would be desperate</div><div class='line' id='LC1060'>enough to essay to cross its lines with you!  Now God pity me,</div><div class='line' id='LC1061'>I have told it!  Ah, be kind to me, be merciful to a poor boy who</div><div class='line' id='LC1062'>means thee well; for an thou betray me I am lost!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1063'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1064'>I laughed the only really refreshing laugh I had had for some time;</div><div class='line' id='LC1065'>and shouted:</div><div class='line' id='LC1066'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1067'>&quot;Merlin has wrought a spell!  _Merlin_, forsooth!  That cheap old</div><div class='line' id='LC1068'>humbug, that maundering old ass?  Bosh, pure bosh, the silliest bosh</div><div class='line' id='LC1069'>in the world!  Why, it does seem to me that of all the childish,</div><div class='line' id='LC1070'>idiotic, chuckle-headed, chicken-livered superstitions that ev</div><div class='line' id='LC1071'>--oh, damn Merlin!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1072'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1073'>But Clarence had slumped to his knees before I had half finished,</div><div class='line' id='LC1074'>and he was like to go out of his mind with fright.</div><div class='line' id='LC1075'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1076'>&quot;Oh, beware!  These are awful words!  Any moment these walls</div><div class='line' id='LC1077'>may crumble upon us if you say such things.  Oh call them back</div><div class='line' id='LC1078'>before it is too late!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1079'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1080'>Now this strange exhibition gave me a good idea and set me to</div><div class='line' id='LC1081'>thinking.  If everybody about here was so honestly and sincerely</div><div class='line' id='LC1082'>afraid of Merlin&#39;s pretended magic as Clarence was, certainly</div><div class='line' id='LC1083'>a superior man like me ought to be shrewd enough to contrive</div><div class='line' id='LC1084'>some way to take advantage of such a state of things.  I went</div><div class='line' id='LC1085'>on thinking, and worked out a plan. Then I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1086'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1087'>&quot;Get up.  Pull yourself together; look me in the eye.  Do you</div><div class='line' id='LC1088'>know why I laughed?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1089'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1090'>&quot;No--but for our blessed Lady&#39;s sake, do it no more.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1091'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1092'>&quot;Well, I&#39;ll tell you why I laughed.  Because I&#39;m a magician myself.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1093'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1094'>&quot;Thou!&quot;  The boy recoiled a step, and caught his breath, for</div><div class='line' id='LC1095'>the thing hit him rather sudden; but the aspect which he took</div><div class='line' id='LC1096'>on was very, very respectful.  I took quick note of that; it</div><div class='line' id='LC1097'>indicated that a humbug didn&#39;t need to have a reputation in this</div><div class='line' id='LC1098'>asylum; people stood ready to take him at his word, without that.</div><div class='line' id='LC1099'>I resumed.</div><div class='line' id='LC1100'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1101'>&quot;I&#39;ve known Merlin seven hundred years, and he--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1102'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1103'>&quot;Seven hun--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1104'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1105'>&quot;Don&#39;t interrupt me.  He has died and come alive again thirteen</div><div class='line' id='LC1106'>times, and traveled under a new name every time: Smith, Jones,</div><div class='line' id='LC1107'>Robinson, Jackson, Peters, Haskins, Merlin--a new alias every</div><div class='line' id='LC1108'>time he turns up.  I knew him in Egypt three hundred years ago;</div><div class='line' id='LC1109'>I knew him in India five hundred years ago--he is always blethering</div><div class='line' id='LC1110'>around in my way, everywhere I go; he makes me tired.  He don&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC1111'>amount to shucks, as a magician; knows some of the old common</div><div class='line' id='LC1112'>tricks, but has never got beyond the rudiments, and never will.</div><div class='line' id='LC1113'>He is well enough for the provinces--one-night stands and that</div><div class='line' id='LC1114'>sort of thing, you know--but dear me, _he_ oughtn&#39;t to set up for</div><div class='line' id='LC1115'>an expert--anyway not where there&#39;s a real artist.  Now look here,</div><div class='line' id='LC1116'>Clarence, I am going to stand your friend, right along, and in</div><div class='line' id='LC1117'>return you must be mine.  I want you to do me a favor.  I want</div><div class='line' id='LC1118'>you to get word to the king that I am a magician myself--and the</div><div class='line' id='LC1119'>Supreme Grand High-yu-Muck-amuck and head of the tribe, at that;</div><div class='line' id='LC1120'>and I want him to be made to understand that I am just quietly</div><div class='line' id='LC1121'>arranging a little calamity here that will make the fur fly in these</div><div class='line' id='LC1122'>realms if Sir Kay&#39;s project is carried out and any harm comes</div><div class='line' id='LC1123'>to me.  Will you get that to the king for me?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1124'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1125'>The poor boy was in such a state that he could hardly answer me.</div><div class='line' id='LC1126'>It was pitiful to see a creature so terrified, so unnerved, so</div><div class='line' id='LC1127'>demoralized.  But he promised everything; and on my side he made</div><div class='line' id='LC1128'>me promise over and over again that I would remain his friend, and</div><div class='line' id='LC1129'>never turn against him or cast any enchantments upon him. Then</div><div class='line' id='LC1130'>he worked his way out, staying himself with his hand along the</div><div class='line' id='LC1131'>wall, like a sick person.</div><div class='line' id='LC1132'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1133'>Presently this thought occurred to me: how heedless I have been!</div><div class='line' id='LC1134'>When the boy gets calm, he will wonder why a great magician like me</div><div class='line' id='LC1135'>should have begged a boy like him to help me get out of this place;</div><div class='line' id='LC1136'>he will put this and that together, and will see that I am a humbug.</div><div class='line' id='LC1137'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1138'>I worried over that heedless blunder for an hour, and called myself</div><div class='line' id='LC1139'>a great many hard names, meantime.  But finally it occurred to me</div><div class='line' id='LC1140'>all of a sudden that these animals didn&#39;t reason; that _they_ never</div><div class='line' id='LC1141'>put this and that together; that all their talk showed that they</div><div class='line' id='LC1142'>didn&#39;t know a discrepancy when they saw it.  I was at rest, then.</div><div class='line' id='LC1143'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1144'>But as soon as one is at rest, in this world, off he goes on</div><div class='line' id='LC1145'>something else to worry about.  It occurred to me that I had made</div><div class='line' id='LC1146'>another blunder: I had sent the boy off to alarm his betters with</div><div class='line' id='LC1147'>a threat--I intending to invent a calamity at my leisure; now</div><div class='line' id='LC1148'>the people who are the readiest and eagerest and willingest to</div><div class='line' id='LC1149'>swallow miracles are the very ones who are hungriest to see you</div><div class='line' id='LC1150'>perform them; suppose I should be called on for a sample?  Suppose</div><div class='line' id='LC1151'>I should be asked to name my calamity?  Yes, I had made a blunder;</div><div class='line' id='LC1152'>I ought to have invented my calamity first.  &quot;What shall I do?</div><div class='line' id='LC1153'>what can I say, to gain a little time?&quot;  I was in trouble again;</div><div class='line' id='LC1154'>in the deepest kind of trouble...</div><div class='line' id='LC1155'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1156'>&quot;There&#39;s a footstep!--they&#39;re coming.  If I had only just a moment</div><div class='line' id='LC1157'>to think....  Good, I&#39;ve got it.  I&#39;m all right.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1158'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1159'>You see, it was the eclipse.  It came into my mind in the nick</div><div class='line' id='LC1160'>of time, how Columbus, or Cortez, or one of those people, played</div><div class='line' id='LC1161'>an eclipse as a saving trump once, on some savages, and I saw my</div><div class='line' id='LC1162'>chance.  I could play it myself, now, and it wouldn&#39;t be any</div><div class='line' id='LC1163'>plagiarism, either, because I should get it in nearly a thousand</div><div class='line' id='LC1164'>years ahead of those parties.</div><div class='line' id='LC1165'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1166'>Clarence came in, subdued, distressed, and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1167'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1168'>&quot;I hasted the message to our liege the king, and straightway he</div><div class='line' id='LC1169'>had me to his presence.  He was frighted even to the marrow,</div><div class='line' id='LC1170'>and was minded to give order for your instant enlargement, and</div><div class='line' id='LC1171'>that you be clothed in fine raiment and lodged as befitted one so</div><div class='line' id='LC1172'>great; but then came Merlin and spoiled all; for he persuaded</div><div class='line' id='LC1173'>the king that you are mad, and know not whereof you speak; and</div><div class='line' id='LC1174'>said your threat is but foolishness and idle vaporing.  They</div><div class='line' id='LC1175'>disputed long, but in the end, Merlin, scoffing, said, &#39;Wherefore</div><div class='line' id='LC1176'>hath he not _named_ his brave calamity?  Verily it is because he</div><div class='line' id='LC1177'>cannot.&#39;  This thrust did in a most sudden sort close the king&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC1178'>mouth, and he could offer naught to turn the argument; and so,</div><div class='line' id='LC1179'>reluctant, and full loth to do you the discourtesy, he yet prayeth</div><div class='line' id='LC1180'>you to consider his perplexed case, as noting how the matter stands,</div><div class='line' id='LC1181'>and name the calamity--if so be you have determined the nature</div><div class='line' id='LC1182'>of it and the time of its coming.  Oh, prithee delay not; to delay</div><div class='line' id='LC1183'>at such a time were to double and treble the perils that already</div><div class='line' id='LC1184'>compass thee about.  Oh, be thou wise--name the calamity!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1185'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1186'>I allowed silence to accumulate while I got my impressiveness</div><div class='line' id='LC1187'>together, and then said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1188'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1189'>&quot;How long have I been shut up in this hole?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1190'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1191'>&quot;Ye were shut up when yesterday was well spent.  It is 9 of</div><div class='line' id='LC1192'>the morning now.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1193'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1194'>&quot;No!  Then I have slept well, sure enough.  Nine in the morning</div><div class='line' id='LC1195'>now!  And yet it is the very complexion of midnight, to a shade.</div><div class='line' id='LC1196'>This is the 20th, then?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1197'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1198'>&quot;The 20th--yes.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1199'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1200'>&quot;And I am to be burned alive to-morrow.&quot;  The boy shuddered.</div><div class='line' id='LC1201'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1202'>&quot;At what hour?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1203'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1204'>&quot;At high noon.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1205'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1206'>&quot;Now then, I will tell you what to say.&quot;  I paused, and stood over</div><div class='line' id='LC1207'>that cowering lad a whole minute in awful silence; then, in a voice</div><div class='line' id='LC1208'>deep, measured, charged with doom, I began, and rose by dramatically</div><div class='line' id='LC1209'>graded stages to my colossal climax, which I delivered in as sublime</div><div class='line' id='LC1210'>and noble a way as ever I did such a thing in my life: &quot;Go back</div><div class='line' id='LC1211'>and tell the king that at that hour I will smother the whole world</div><div class='line' id='LC1212'>in the dead blackness of midnight; I will blot out the sun, and he</div><div class='line' id='LC1213'>shall never shine again; the fruits of the earth shall rot for lack</div><div class='line' id='LC1214'>of light and warmth, and the peoples of the earth shall famish</div><div class='line' id='LC1215'>and die, to the last man!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1216'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1217'>I had to carry the boy out myself, he sunk into such a collapse.</div><div class='line' id='LC1218'>I handed him over to the soldiers, and went back.</div><div class='line' id='LC1219'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1220'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1221'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1222'>CHAPTER VI</div><div class='line' id='LC1223'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1224'>THE ECLIPSE</div><div class='line' id='LC1225'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1226'>In the stillness and the darkness, realization soon began to</div><div class='line' id='LC1227'>supplement knowledge.  The mere knowledge of a fact is pale; but</div><div class='line' id='LC1228'>when you come to _realize_ your fact, it takes on color. It is</div><div class='line' id='LC1229'>all the difference between hearing of a man being stabbed to</div><div class='line' id='LC1230'>the heart, and seeing it done.  In the stillness and the darkness,</div><div class='line' id='LC1231'>the knowledge that I was in deadly danger took to itself deeper</div><div class='line' id='LC1232'>and deeper meaning all the time; a something which was realization</div><div class='line' id='LC1233'>crept inch by inch through my veins and turned me cold.</div><div class='line' id='LC1234'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1235'>But it is a blessed provision of nature that at times like these,</div><div class='line' id='LC1236'>as soon as a man&#39;s mercury has got down to a certain point there</div><div class='line' id='LC1237'>comes a revulsion, and he rallies.  Hope springs up, and cheerfulness</div><div class='line' id='LC1238'>along with it, and then he is in good shape to do something for</div><div class='line' id='LC1239'>himself, if anything can be done.  When my rally came, it came with</div><div class='line' id='LC1240'>a bound.  I said to myself that my eclipse would be sure to save me,</div><div class='line' id='LC1241'>and make me the greatest man in the kingdom besides; and straightway</div><div class='line' id='LC1242'>my mercury went up to the top of the tube, and my solicitudes</div><div class='line' id='LC1243'>all vanished.  I was as happy a man as there was in the world.</div><div class='line' id='LC1244'>I was even impatient for to-morrow to come, I so wanted to gather</div><div class='line' id='LC1245'>in that great triumph and be the center of all the nation&#39;s wonder</div><div class='line' id='LC1246'>and reverence.  Besides, in a business way it would be the making</div><div class='line' id='LC1247'>of me; I knew that.</div><div class='line' id='LC1248'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1249'>Meantime there was one thing which had got pushed into the background</div><div class='line' id='LC1250'>of my mind.  That was the half-conviction that when the nature</div><div class='line' id='LC1251'>of my proposed calamity should be reported to those superstitious</div><div class='line' id='LC1252'>people, it would have such an effect that they would want to</div><div class='line' id='LC1253'>compromise.  So, by and by when I heard footsteps coming, that</div><div class='line' id='LC1254'>thought was recalled to me, and I said to myself, &quot;As sure as</div><div class='line' id='LC1255'>anything, it&#39;s the compromise.  Well, if it is good, all right,</div><div class='line' id='LC1256'>I will accept; but if it isn&#39;t, I mean to stand my ground and play</div><div class='line' id='LC1257'>my hand for all it is worth.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1258'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1259'>The door opened, and some men-at-arms appeared.  The leader said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1260'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1261'>&quot;The stake is ready. Come!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1262'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1263'>The stake!  The strength went out of me, and I almost fell down.</div><div class='line' id='LC1264'>It is hard to get one&#39;s breath at such a time, such lumps come into</div><div class='line' id='LC1265'>one&#39;s throat, and such gaspings; but as soon as I could speak, I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1266'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1267'>&quot;But this is a mistake--the execution is to-morrow.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1268'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1269'>&quot;Order changed; been set forward a day.  Haste thee!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1270'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1271'>I was lost.  There was no help for me.  I was dazed, stupefied;</div><div class='line' id='LC1272'>I had no command over myself, I only wandered purposely about,</div><div class='line' id='LC1273'>like one out of his mind; so the soldiers took hold of me, and</div><div class='line' id='LC1274'>pulled me along with them, out of the cell and along the maze of</div><div class='line' id='LC1275'>underground corridors, and finally into the fierce glare of daylight</div><div class='line' id='LC1276'>and the upper world.  As we stepped into the vast enclosed court</div><div class='line' id='LC1277'>of the castle I got a shock; for the first thing I saw was the stake,</div><div class='line' id='LC1278'>standing in the center, and near it the piled fagots and a monk.</div><div class='line' id='LC1279'>On all four sides of the court the seated multitudes rose rank</div><div class='line' id='LC1280'>above rank, forming sloping terraces that were rich with color.</div><div class='line' id='LC1281'>The king and the queen sat in their thrones, the most conspicuous</div><div class='line' id='LC1282'>figures there, of course.</div><div class='line' id='LC1283'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1284'>To note all this, occupied but a second.  The next second Clarence</div><div class='line' id='LC1285'>had slipped from some place of concealment and was pouring news</div><div class='line' id='LC1286'>into my ear, his eyes beaming with triumph and gladness.  He said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1287'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1288'>&quot;Tis through _me_ the change was wrought!  And main hard have I worked</div><div class='line' id='LC1289'>to do it, too.  But when I revealed to them the calamity in store,</div><div class='line' id='LC1290'>and saw how mighty was the terror it did engender, then saw I also</div><div class='line' id='LC1291'>that this was the time to strike!  Wherefore I diligently pretended,</div><div class='line' id='LC1292'>unto this and that and the other one, that your power against the sun</div><div class='line' id='LC1293'>could not reach its full until the morrow; and so if any would save</div><div class='line' id='LC1294'>the sun and the world, you must be slain to-day, while your</div><div class='line' id='LC1295'>enchantments are but in the weaving and lack potency.  Odsbodikins,</div><div class='line' id='LC1296'>it was but a dull lie, a most indifferent invention, but you should</div><div class='line' id='LC1297'>have seen them seize it and swallow it, in the frenzy of their</div><div class='line' id='LC1298'>fright, as it were salvation sent from heaven; and all the while</div><div class='line' id='LC1299'>was I laughing in my sleeve the one moment, to see them so cheaply</div><div class='line' id='LC1300'>deceived, and glorifying God the next, that He was content to let</div><div class='line' id='LC1301'>the meanest of His creatures be His instrument to the saving of</div><div class='line' id='LC1302'>thy life.  Ah how happy has the matter sped!  You will not need</div><div class='line' id='LC1303'>to do the sun a _real_ hurt--ah, forget not that, on your soul forget</div><div class='line' id='LC1304'>it not!  Only make a little darkness--only the littlest little</div><div class='line' id='LC1305'>darkness, mind, and cease with that.  It will be sufficient.  They</div><div class='line' id='LC1306'>will see that I spoke falsely,--being ignorant, as they will fancy</div><div class='line' id='LC1307'>--and with the falling of the first shadow of that darkness you</div><div class='line' id='LC1308'>shall see them go mad with fear; and they will set you free and</div><div class='line' id='LC1309'>make you great!  Go to thy triumph, now!  But remember--ah, good</div><div class='line' id='LC1310'>friend, I implore thee remember my supplication, and do the blessed</div><div class='line' id='LC1311'>sun no hurt.  For _my_ sake, thy true friend.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1312'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1313'>I choked out some words through my grief and misery; as much as</div><div class='line' id='LC1314'>to say I would spare the sun; for which the lad&#39;s eyes paid me back</div><div class='line' id='LC1315'>with such deep and loving gratitude that I had not the heart</div><div class='line' id='LC1316'>to tell him his good-hearted foolishness had ruined me and sent me</div><div class='line' id='LC1317'>to my death.</div><div class='line' id='LC1318'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1319'>As the soldiers assisted me across the court the stillness was</div><div class='line' id='LC1320'>so profound that if I had been blindfold I should have supposed</div><div class='line' id='LC1321'>I was in a solitude instead of walled in by four thousand people.</div><div class='line' id='LC1322'>There was not a movement perceptible in those masses of humanity;</div><div class='line' id='LC1323'>they were as rigid as stone images, and as pale; and dread sat</div><div class='line' id='LC1324'>upon every countenance.  This hush continued while I was being</div><div class='line' id='LC1325'>chained to the stake; it still continued while the fagots were</div><div class='line' id='LC1326'>carefully and tediously piled about my ankles, my knees, my thighs,</div><div class='line' id='LC1327'>my body.  Then there was a pause, and a deeper hush, if possible,</div><div class='line' id='LC1328'>and a man knelt down at my feet with a blazing torch; the multitude</div><div class='line' id='LC1329'>strained forward, gazing, and parting slightly from their seats</div><div class='line' id='LC1330'>without knowing it; the monk raised his hands above my head, and</div><div class='line' id='LC1331'>his eyes toward the blue sky, and began some words in Latin; in</div><div class='line' id='LC1332'>this attitude he droned on and on, a little while, and then stopped.</div><div class='line' id='LC1333'>I waited two or three moments; then looked up; he was standing</div><div class='line' id='LC1334'>there petrified.  With a common impulse the multitude rose slowly</div><div class='line' id='LC1335'>up and stared into the sky.  I followed their eyes, as sure as guns,</div><div class='line' id='LC1336'>there was my eclipse beginning!  The life went boiling through</div><div class='line' id='LC1337'>my veins; I was a new man!  The rim of black spread slowly into</div><div class='line' id='LC1338'>the sun&#39;s disk, my heart beat higher and higher, and still the</div><div class='line' id='LC1339'>assemblage and the priest stared into the sky, motionless.  I knew</div><div class='line' id='LC1340'>that this gaze would be turned upon me, next.  When it was, I was</div><div class='line' id='LC1341'>ready.  I was in one of the most grand attitudes I ever struck,</div><div class='line' id='LC1342'>with my arm stretched up pointing to the sun.  It was a noble</div><div class='line' id='LC1343'>effect.  You could _see_ the shudder sweep the mass like a wave.</div><div class='line' id='LC1344'>Two shouts rang out, one close upon the heels of the other:</div><div class='line' id='LC1345'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1346'>&quot;Apply the torch!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1347'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1348'>&quot;I forbid it!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1349'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1350'>The one was from Merlin, the other from the king.  Merlin started</div><div class='line' id='LC1351'>from his place--to apply the torch himself, I judged.  I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1352'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1353'>&quot;Stay where you are.  If any man moves--even the king--before</div><div class='line' id='LC1354'>I give him leave, I will blast him with thunder, I will consume</div><div class='line' id='LC1355'>him with lightnings!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1356'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1357'>The multitude sank meekly into their seats, and I was just expecting</div><div class='line' id='LC1358'>they would.  Merlin hesitated a moment or two, and I was on pins</div><div class='line' id='LC1359'>and needles during that little while.  Then he sat down, and I took</div><div class='line' id='LC1360'>a good breath; for I knew I was master of the situation now.</div><div class='line' id='LC1361'>The king said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1362'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1363'>&quot;Be merciful, fair sir, and essay no further in this perilous matter,</div><div class='line' id='LC1364'>lest disaster follow.  It was reported to us that your powers could</div><div class='line' id='LC1365'>not attain unto their full strength until the morrow; but--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1366'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1367'>&quot;Your Majesty thinks the report may have been a lie?  It _was_ a lie.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1368'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1369'>That made an immense effect; up went appealing hands everywhere,</div><div class='line' id='LC1370'>and the king was assailed with a storm of supplications that</div><div class='line' id='LC1371'>I might be bought off at any price, and the calamity stayed.</div><div class='line' id='LC1372'>The king was eager to comply. He said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1373'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1374'>&quot;Name any terms, reverend sir, even to the halving of my kingdom;</div><div class='line' id='LC1375'>but banish this calamity, spare the sun!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1376'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1377'>My fortune was made.  I would have taken him up in a minute, but</div><div class='line' id='LC1378'>I couldn&#39;t stop an eclipse; the thing was out of the question.  So</div><div class='line' id='LC1379'>I asked time to consider.  The king said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1380'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1381'>&quot;How long--ah, how long, good sir?  Be merciful; look, it groweth</div><div class='line' id='LC1382'>darker, moment by moment.  Prithee how long?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1383'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1384'>&quot;Not long.  Half an hour--maybe an hour.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1385'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1386'>There were a thousand pathetic protests, but I couldn&#39;t shorten up</div><div class='line' id='LC1387'>any, for I couldn&#39;t remember how long a total eclipse lasts.  I was</div><div class='line' id='LC1388'>in a puzzled condition, anyway, and wanted to think.  Something</div><div class='line' id='LC1389'>was wrong about that eclipse, and the fact was very unsettling.</div><div class='line' id='LC1390'>If this wasn&#39;t the one I was after, how was I to tell whether this</div><div class='line' id='LC1391'>was the sixth century, or nothing but a dream?  Dear me, if I could</div><div class='line' id='LC1392'>only prove it was the latter!  Here was a glad new hope.  If the boy</div><div class='line' id='LC1393'>was right about the date, and this was surely the 20th, it _wasn&#39;t_</div><div class='line' id='LC1394'>the sixth century.  I reached for the monk&#39;s sleeve, in considerable</div><div class='line' id='LC1395'>excitement, and asked him what day of the month it was.</div><div class='line' id='LC1396'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1397'>Hang him, he said it was the _twenty-first_!  It made me turn cold</div><div class='line' id='LC1398'>to hear him.  I begged him not to make any mistake about it; but</div><div class='line' id='LC1399'>he was sure; he knew it was the 21st.  So, that feather-headed</div><div class='line' id='LC1400'>boy had botched things again!  The time of the day was right</div><div class='line' id='LC1401'>for the eclipse; I had seen that for myself, in the beginning,</div><div class='line' id='LC1402'>by the dial that was near by.  Yes, I was in King Arthur&#39;s court,</div><div class='line' id='LC1403'>and I might as well make the most out of it I could.</div><div class='line' id='LC1404'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1405'>The darkness was steadily growing, the people becoming more and</div><div class='line' id='LC1406'>more distressed.  I now said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1407'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1408'>&quot;I have reflected, Sir King.  For a lesson, I will let this darkness</div><div class='line' id='LC1409'>proceed, and spread night in the world; but whether I blot out</div><div class='line' id='LC1410'>the sun for good, or restore it, shall rest with you.  These are</div><div class='line' id='LC1411'>the terms, to wit: You shall remain king over all your dominions,</div><div class='line' id='LC1412'>and receive all the glories and honors that belong to the kingship;</div><div class='line' id='LC1413'>but you shall appoint me your perpetual minister and executive,</div><div class='line' id='LC1414'>and give me for my services one per cent of such actual increase</div><div class='line' id='LC1415'>of revenue over and above its present amount as I may succeed</div><div class='line' id='LC1416'>in creating for the state.  If I can&#39;t live on that, I sha&#39;n&#39;t ask</div><div class='line' id='LC1417'>anybody to give me a lift.  Is it satisfactory?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1418'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1419'>There was a prodigious roar of applause, and out of the midst</div><div class='line' id='LC1420'>of it the king&#39;s voice rose, saying:</div><div class='line' id='LC1421'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1422'>&quot;Away with his bonds, and set him free! and do him homage, high</div><div class='line' id='LC1423'>and low, rich and poor, for he is become the king&#39;s right hand,</div><div class='line' id='LC1424'>is clothed with power and authority, and his seat is upon the highest</div><div class='line' id='LC1425'>step of the throne!  Now sweep away this creeping night, and bring</div><div class='line' id='LC1426'>the light and cheer again, that all the world may bless thee.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1427'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1428'>But I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1429'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1430'>&quot;That a common man should be shamed before the world, is nothing;</div><div class='line' id='LC1431'>but it were dishonor to the _king_ if any that saw his minister naked</div><div class='line' id='LC1432'>should not also see him delivered from his shame.  If I might ask</div><div class='line' id='LC1433'>that my clothes be brought again--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1434'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1435'>&quot;They are not meet,&quot; the king broke in.  &quot;Fetch raiment of another</div><div class='line' id='LC1436'>sort; clothe him like a prince!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1437'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1438'>My idea worked.  I wanted to keep things as they were till the</div><div class='line' id='LC1439'>eclipse was total, otherwise they would be trying again to get</div><div class='line' id='LC1440'>me to dismiss the darkness, and of course I couldn&#39;t do it.  Sending</div><div class='line' id='LC1441'>for the clothes gained some delay, but not enough.  So I had to make</div><div class='line' id='LC1442'>another excuse.  I said it would be but natural if the king should</div><div class='line' id='LC1443'>change his mind and repent to some extent of what he had done</div><div class='line' id='LC1444'>under excitement; therefore I would let the darkness grow a while,</div><div class='line' id='LC1445'>and if at the end of a reasonable time the king had kept his mind</div><div class='line' id='LC1446'>the same, the darkness should be dismissed.  Neither the king nor</div><div class='line' id='LC1447'>anybody else was satisfied with that arrangement, but I had</div><div class='line' id='LC1448'>to stick to my point.</div><div class='line' id='LC1449'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1450'>It grew darker and darker and blacker and blacker, while I struggled</div><div class='line' id='LC1451'>with those awkward sixth-century clothes.  It got to be pitch dark,</div><div class='line' id='LC1452'>at last, and the multitude groaned with horror to feel the cold</div><div class='line' id='LC1453'>uncanny night breezes fan through the place and see the stars</div><div class='line' id='LC1454'>come out and twinkle in the sky.  At last the eclipse was total,</div><div class='line' id='LC1455'>and I was very glad of it, but everybody else was in misery; which</div><div class='line' id='LC1456'>was quite natural. I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1457'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1458'>&quot;The king, by his silence, still stands to the terms.&quot;  Then</div><div class='line' id='LC1459'>I lifted up my hands--stood just so a moment--then I said, with</div><div class='line' id='LC1460'>the most awful solemnity: &quot;Let the enchantment dissolve and</div><div class='line' id='LC1461'>pass harmless away!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1462'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1463'>There was no response, for a moment, in that deep darkness and</div><div class='line' id='LC1464'>that graveyard hush.  But when the silver rim of the sun pushed</div><div class='line' id='LC1465'>itself out, a moment or two later, the assemblage broke loose with</div><div class='line' id='LC1466'>a vast shout and came pouring down like a deluge to smother me</div><div class='line' id='LC1467'>with blessings and gratitude; and Clarence was not the last of</div><div class='line' id='LC1468'>the wash, to be sure.</div><div class='line' id='LC1469'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1470'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1471'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1472'>CHAPTER VII</div><div class='line' id='LC1473'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1474'>MERLIN&#39;S TOWER</div><div class='line' id='LC1475'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1476'>Inasmuch as I was now the second personage in the Kingdom, as far</div><div class='line' id='LC1477'>as political power and authority were concerned, much was made</div><div class='line' id='LC1478'>of me.  My raiment was of silks and velvets and cloth of gold,</div><div class='line' id='LC1479'>and by consequence was very showy, also uncomfortable.  But habit</div><div class='line' id='LC1480'>would soon reconcile me to my clothes; I was aware of that.  I was</div><div class='line' id='LC1481'>given the choicest suite of apartments in the castle, after</div><div class='line' id='LC1482'>the king&#39;s.  They were aglow with loud-colored silken hangings,</div><div class='line' id='LC1483'>but the stone floors had nothing but rushes on them for a carpet,</div><div class='line' id='LC1484'>and they were misfit rushes at that, being not all of one breed.</div><div class='line' id='LC1485'>As for conveniences, properly speaking, there weren&#39;t any.  I mean</div><div class='line' id='LC1486'>_little_ conveniences; it is the little conveniences that make</div><div class='line' id='LC1487'>the real comfort of life.  The big oaken chairs, graced with rude</div><div class='line' id='LC1488'>carvings, were well enough, but that was the stopping place.</div><div class='line' id='LC1489'>There was no soap, no matches, no looking-glass--except a metal</div><div class='line' id='LC1490'>one, about as powerful as a pail of water.  And not a chromo.</div><div class='line' id='LC1491'>I had been used to chromos for years, and I saw now that without</div><div class='line' id='LC1492'>my suspecting it a passion for art had got worked into the fabric</div><div class='line' id='LC1493'>of my being, and was become a part of me.  It made me homesick</div><div class='line' id='LC1494'>to look around over this proud and gaudy but heartless barrenness</div><div class='line' id='LC1495'>and remember that in our house in East Hartford, all unpretending</div><div class='line' id='LC1496'>as it was, you couldn&#39;t go into a room but you would find an</div><div class='line' id='LC1497'>insurance-chromo, or at least a three-color God-Bless-Our-Home</div><div class='line' id='LC1498'>over the door; and in the parlor we had nine.  But here, even in</div><div class='line' id='LC1499'>my grand room of state, there wasn&#39;t anything in the nature of</div><div class='line' id='LC1500'>a picture except a thing the size of a bedquilt, which was either</div><div class='line' id='LC1501'>woven or knitted (it had darned places in it), and nothing in it</div><div class='line' id='LC1502'>was the right color or the right shape; and as for proportions,</div><div class='line' id='LC1503'>even Raphael himself couldn&#39;t have botched them more formidably,</div><div class='line' id='LC1504'>after all his practice on those nightmares they call his &quot;celebrated</div><div class='line' id='LC1505'>Hampton Court cartoons.&quot;  Raphael was a bird.  We had several</div><div class='line' id='LC1506'>of his chromos; one was his &quot;Miraculous Draught of Fishes,&quot; where</div><div class='line' id='LC1507'>he puts in a miracle of his own--puts three men into a canoe which</div><div class='line' id='LC1508'>wouldn&#39;t have held a dog without upsetting.  I always admired</div><div class='line' id='LC1509'>to study R.&#39;s art, it was so fresh and unconventional.</div><div class='line' id='LC1510'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1511'>There wasn&#39;t even a bell or a speaking-tube in the castle.  I had</div><div class='line' id='LC1512'>a great many servants, and those that were on duty lolled in the</div><div class='line' id='LC1513'>anteroom; and when I wanted one of them I had to go and call for him.</div><div class='line' id='LC1514'>There was no gas, there were no candles; a bronze dish half full</div><div class='line' id='LC1515'>of boarding-house butter with a blazing rag floating in it was</div><div class='line' id='LC1516'>the thing that produced what was regarded as light.  A lot of</div><div class='line' id='LC1517'>these hung along the walls and modified the dark, just toned it</div><div class='line' id='LC1518'>down enough to make it dismal.  If you went out at night, your</div><div class='line' id='LC1519'>servants carried torches.  There were no books, pens, paper or</div><div class='line' id='LC1520'>ink, and no glass in the openings they believed to be windows.</div><div class='line' id='LC1521'>It is a little thing--glass is--until it is absent, then it becomes</div><div class='line' id='LC1522'>a big thing.  But perhaps the worst of all was, that there wasn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC1523'>any sugar, coffee, tea, or tobacco.  I saw that I was just another</div><div class='line' id='LC1524'>Robinson Crusoe cast away on an uninhabited island, with no society</div><div class='line' id='LC1525'>but some more or less tame animals, and if I wanted to make life</div><div class='line' id='LC1526'>bearable I must do as he did--invent, contrive, create, reorganize</div><div class='line' id='LC1527'>things; set brain and hand to work, and keep them busy.  Well,</div><div class='line' id='LC1528'>that was in my line.</div><div class='line' id='LC1529'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1530'>One thing troubled me along at first--the immense interest which</div><div class='line' id='LC1531'>people took in me.  Apparently the whole nation wanted a look</div><div class='line' id='LC1532'>at me.  It soon transpired that the eclipse had scared the British</div><div class='line' id='LC1533'>world almost to death; that while it lasted the whole country,</div><div class='line' id='LC1534'>from one end to the other, was in a pitiable state of panic, and</div><div class='line' id='LC1535'>the churches, hermitages, and monkeries overflowed with praying</div><div class='line' id='LC1536'>and weeping poor creatures who thought the end of the world was</div><div class='line' id='LC1537'>come.  Then had followed the news that the producer of this awful</div><div class='line' id='LC1538'>event was a stranger, a mighty magician at Arthur&#39;s court; that he</div><div class='line' id='LC1539'>could have blown out the sun like a candle, and was just going</div><div class='line' id='LC1540'>to do it when his mercy was purchased, and he then dissolved</div><div class='line' id='LC1541'>his enchantments, and was now recognized and honored as the man</div><div class='line' id='LC1542'>who had by his unaided might saved the globe from destruction and</div><div class='line' id='LC1543'>its peoples from extinction.  Now if you consider that everybody</div><div class='line' id='LC1544'>believed that, and not only believed it, but never even dreamed</div><div class='line' id='LC1545'>of doubting it, you will easily understand that there was not</div><div class='line' id='LC1546'>a person in all Britain that would not have walked fifty miles</div><div class='line' id='LC1547'>to get a sight of me.  Of course I was all the talk--all other</div><div class='line' id='LC1548'>subjects were dropped; even the king became suddenly a person of</div><div class='line' id='LC1549'>minor interest and notoriety.  Within twenty-four hours the</div><div class='line' id='LC1550'>delegations began to arrive, and from that time onward for a fortnight</div><div class='line' id='LC1551'>they kept coming.  The village was crowded, and all the countryside.</div><div class='line' id='LC1552'>I had to go out a dozen times a day and show myself to these</div><div class='line' id='LC1553'>reverent and awe-stricken multitudes.  It came to be a great burden,</div><div class='line' id='LC1554'>as to time and trouble, but of course it was at the same time</div><div class='line' id='LC1555'>compensatingly agreeable to be so celebrated and such a center</div><div class='line' id='LC1556'>of homage.  It turned Brer Merlin green with envy and spite, which</div><div class='line' id='LC1557'>was a great satisfaction to me.  But there was one thing I couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC1558'>understand--nobody had asked for an autograph.  I spoke to Clarence</div><div class='line' id='LC1559'>about it.  By George!  I had to explain to him what it was.  Then</div><div class='line' id='LC1560'>he said nobody in the country could read or write but a few dozen</div><div class='line' id='LC1561'>priests.  Land! think of that.</div><div class='line' id='LC1562'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1563'>There was another thing that troubled me a little.  Those multitudes</div><div class='line' id='LC1564'>presently began to agitate for another miracle.  That was natural.</div><div class='line' id='LC1565'>To be able to carry back to their far homes the boast that they</div><div class='line' id='LC1566'>had seen the man who could command the sun, riding in the heavens,</div><div class='line' id='LC1567'>and be obeyed, would make them great in the eyes of their neighbors,</div><div class='line' id='LC1568'>and envied by them all; but to be able to also say they had seen</div><div class='line' id='LC1569'>him work a miracle themselves--why, people would come a distance</div><div class='line' id='LC1570'>to see _them_.  The pressure got to be pretty strong.  There was</div><div class='line' id='LC1571'>going to be an eclipse of the moon, and I knew the date and hour,</div><div class='line' id='LC1572'>but it was too far away.  Two years.  I would have given a good</div><div class='line' id='LC1573'>deal for license to hurry it up and use it now when there was</div><div class='line' id='LC1574'>a big market for it.  It seemed a great pity to have it wasted so,</div><div class='line' id='LC1575'>and come lagging along at a time when a body wouldn&#39;t have any</div><div class='line' id='LC1576'>use for it, as like as not.  If it had been booked for only a month</div><div class='line' id='LC1577'>away, I could have sold it short; but, as matters stood, I couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC1578'>seem to cipher out any way to make it do me any good, so I gave up</div><div class='line' id='LC1579'>trying.  Next, Clarence found that old Merlin was making himself</div><div class='line' id='LC1580'>busy on the sly among those people.  He was spreading a report that</div><div class='line' id='LC1581'>I was a humbug, and that the reason I didn&#39;t accommodate the people</div><div class='line' id='LC1582'>with a miracle was because I couldn&#39;t.  I saw that I must do</div><div class='line' id='LC1583'>something.  I presently thought out a plan.</div><div class='line' id='LC1584'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1585'>By my authority as executive I threw Merlin into prison--the same</div><div class='line' id='LC1586'>cell I had occupied myself.  Then I gave public notice by herald</div><div class='line' id='LC1587'>and trumpet that I should be busy with affairs of state for</div><div class='line' id='LC1588'>a fortnight, but about the end of that time I would take a moment&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC1589'>leisure and blow up Merlin&#39;s stone tower by fires from heaven;</div><div class='line' id='LC1590'>in the meantime, whoso listened to evil reports about me, let him</div><div class='line' id='LC1591'>beware.  Furthermore, I would perform but this one miracle at</div><div class='line' id='LC1592'>this time, and no more; if it failed to satisfy and any murmured,</div><div class='line' id='LC1593'>I would turn the murmurers into horses, and make them useful.</div><div class='line' id='LC1594'>Quiet ensued.</div><div class='line' id='LC1595'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1596'>I took Clarence into my confidence, to a certain degree, and we</div><div class='line' id='LC1597'>went to work privately.  I told him that this was a sort of miracle</div><div class='line' id='LC1598'>that required a trifle of preparation, and that it would be sudden</div><div class='line' id='LC1599'>death to ever talk about these preparations to anybody.  That made</div><div class='line' id='LC1600'>his mouth safe enough.  Clandestinely we made a few bushels of</div><div class='line' id='LC1601'>first-rate blasting powder, and I superintended my armorers while</div><div class='line' id='LC1602'>they constructed a lightning-rod and some wires.  This old stone</div><div class='line' id='LC1603'>tower was very massive--and rather ruinous, too, for it was Roman,</div><div class='line' id='LC1604'>and four hundred years old.  Yes, and handsome, after a rude</div><div class='line' id='LC1605'>fashion, and clothed with ivy from base to summit, as with a shirt</div><div class='line' id='LC1606'>of scale mail.  It stood on a lonely eminence, in good view from</div><div class='line' id='LC1607'>the castle, and about half a mile away.</div><div class='line' id='LC1608'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1609'>Working by night, we stowed the powder in the tower--dug stones</div><div class='line' id='LC1610'>out, on the inside, and buried the powder in the walls themselves,</div><div class='line' id='LC1611'>which were fifteen feet thick at the base.  We put in a peck</div><div class='line' id='LC1612'>at a time, in a dozen places.  We could have blown up the Tower</div><div class='line' id='LC1613'>of London with these charges.  When the thirteenth night was come</div><div class='line' id='LC1614'>we put up our lightning-rod, bedded it in one of the batches of</div><div class='line' id='LC1615'>powder, and ran wires from it to the other batches.  Everybody</div><div class='line' id='LC1616'>had shunned that locality from the day of my proclamation, but</div><div class='line' id='LC1617'>on the morning of the fourteenth I thought best to warn the people,</div><div class='line' id='LC1618'>through the heralds, to keep clear away--a quarter of a mile away.</div><div class='line' id='LC1619'>Then added, by command, that at some time during the twenty-four</div><div class='line' id='LC1620'>hours I would consummate the miracle, but would first give a brief</div><div class='line' id='LC1621'>notice; by flags on the castle towers if in the daytime, by</div><div class='line' id='LC1622'>torch-baskets in the same places if at night.</div><div class='line' id='LC1623'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1624'>Thunder-showers had been tolerably frequent of late, and I was</div><div class='line' id='LC1625'>not much afraid of a failure; still, I shouldn&#39;t have cared for</div><div class='line' id='LC1626'>a delay of a day or two; I should have explained that I was busy</div><div class='line' id='LC1627'>with affairs of state yet, and the people must wait.</div><div class='line' id='LC1628'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1629'>Of course, we had a blazing sunny day--almost the first one without</div><div class='line' id='LC1630'>a cloud for three weeks; things always happen so.  I kept secluded,</div><div class='line' id='LC1631'>and watched the weather.  Clarence dropped in from time to time</div><div class='line' id='LC1632'>and said the public excitement was growing and growing all the</div><div class='line' id='LC1633'>time, and the whole country filling up with human masses as far</div><div class='line' id='LC1634'>as one could see from the battlements.  At last the wind sprang up</div><div class='line' id='LC1635'>and a cloud appeared--in the right quarter, too, and just at</div><div class='line' id='LC1636'>nightfall.  For a little while I watched that distant cloud spread</div><div class='line' id='LC1637'>and blacken, then I judged it was time for me to appear.  I ordered</div><div class='line' id='LC1638'>the torch-baskets to be lit, and Merlin liberated and sent to me.</div><div class='line' id='LC1639'>A quarter of an hour later I ascended the parapet and there found</div><div class='line' id='LC1640'>the king and the court assembled and gazing off in the darkness</div><div class='line' id='LC1641'>toward Merlin&#39;s Tower.  Already the darkness was so heavy that</div><div class='line' id='LC1642'>one could not see far; these people and the old turrets, being</div><div class='line' id='LC1643'>partly in deep shadow and partly in the red glow from the great</div><div class='line' id='LC1644'>torch-baskets overhead, made a good deal of a picture.</div><div class='line' id='LC1645'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1646'>Merlin arrived in a gloomy mood.  I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1647'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1648'>&quot;You wanted to burn me alive when I had not done you any harm,</div><div class='line' id='LC1649'>and latterly you have been trying to injure my professional</div><div class='line' id='LC1650'>reputation.  Therefore I am going to call down fire and blow up</div><div class='line' id='LC1651'>your tower, but it is only fair to give you a chance; now if you</div><div class='line' id='LC1652'>think you can break my enchantments and ward off the fires, step</div><div class='line' id='LC1653'>to the bat, it&#39;s your innings.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1654'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1655'>&quot;I can, fair sir, and I will. Doubt it not.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1656'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1657'>He drew an imaginary circle on the stones of the roof, and burnt</div><div class='line' id='LC1658'>a pinch of powder in it, which sent up a small cloud of aromatic</div><div class='line' id='LC1659'>smoke, whereat everybody fell back and began to cross themselves</div><div class='line' id='LC1660'>and get uncomfortable.  Then he began to mutter and make passes</div><div class='line' id='LC1661'>in the air with his hands.  He worked himself up slowly and</div><div class='line' id='LC1662'>gradually into a sort of frenzy, and got to thrashing around with</div><div class='line' id='LC1663'>his arms like the sails of a windmill.  By this time the storm had</div><div class='line' id='LC1664'>about reached us; the gusts of wind were flaring the torches and</div><div class='line' id='LC1665'>making the shadows swash about, the first heavy drops of rain</div><div class='line' id='LC1666'>were falling, the world abroad was black as pitch, the lightning</div><div class='line' id='LC1667'>began to wink fitfully.  Of course, my rod would be loading itself</div><div class='line' id='LC1668'>now.  In fact, things were imminent. So I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC1669'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1670'>&quot;You have had time enough.  I have given you every advantage,</div><div class='line' id='LC1671'>and not interfered.  It is plain your magic is weak. It is only</div><div class='line' id='LC1672'>fair that I begin now.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1673'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1674'>I made about three passes in the air, and then there was an awful</div><div class='line' id='LC1675'>crash and that old tower leaped into the sky in chunks, along</div><div class='line' id='LC1676'>with a vast volcanic fountain of fire that turned night to noonday,</div><div class='line' id='LC1677'>and showed a thousand acres of human beings groveling on the ground</div><div class='line' id='LC1678'>in a general collapse of consternation.  Well, it rained mortar and</div><div class='line' id='LC1679'>masonry the rest of the week.  This was the report; but probably</div><div class='line' id='LC1680'>the facts would have modified it.</div><div class='line' id='LC1681'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1682'>It was an effective miracle.  The great bothersome temporary</div><div class='line' id='LC1683'>population vanished.  There were a good many thousand tracks</div><div class='line' id='LC1684'>in the mud the next morning, but they were all outward bound.</div><div class='line' id='LC1685'>If I had advertised another miracle I couldn&#39;t have raised an</div><div class='line' id='LC1686'>audience with a sheriff.</div><div class='line' id='LC1687'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1688'>Merlin&#39;s stock was flat.  The king wanted to stop his wages; he</div><div class='line' id='LC1689'>even wanted to banish him, but I interfered.  I said he would be</div><div class='line' id='LC1690'>useful to work the weather, and attend to small matters like that,</div><div class='line' id='LC1691'>and I would give him a lift now and then when his poor little</div><div class='line' id='LC1692'>parlor-magic soured on him.  There wasn&#39;t a rag of his tower left,</div><div class='line' id='LC1693'>but I had the government rebuild it for him, and advised him</div><div class='line' id='LC1694'>to take boarders; but he was too high-toned for that.  And as for</div><div class='line' id='LC1695'>being grateful, he never even said thank you.  He was a rather</div><div class='line' id='LC1696'>hard lot, take him how you might; but then you couldn&#39;t fairly</div><div class='line' id='LC1697'>expect a man to be sweet that had been set back so.</div><div class='line' id='LC1698'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1699'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1700'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1701'>CHAPTER VIII</div><div class='line' id='LC1702'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1703'>THE BOSS</div><div class='line' id='LC1704'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1705'>To be vested with enormous authority is a fine thing; but to have</div><div class='line' id='LC1706'>the on-looking world consent to it is a finer.  The tower episode</div><div class='line' id='LC1707'>solidified my power, and made it impregnable.  If any were perchance</div><div class='line' id='LC1708'>disposed to be jealous and critical before that, they experienced</div><div class='line' id='LC1709'>a change of heart, now.  There was not any one in the kingdom</div><div class='line' id='LC1710'>who would have considered it good judgment to meddle with my matters.</div><div class='line' id='LC1711'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1712'>I was fast getting adjusted to my situation and circumstances.</div><div class='line' id='LC1713'>For a time, I used to wake up, mornings, and smile at my &quot;dream,&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1714'>and listen for the Colt&#39;s factory whistle; but that sort of thing</div><div class='line' id='LC1715'>played itself out, gradually, and at last I was fully able to realize</div><div class='line' id='LC1716'>that I was actually living in the sixth century, and in Arthur&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC1717'>court, not a lunatic asylum.  After that, I was just as much</div><div class='line' id='LC1718'>at home in that century as I could have been in any other; and</div><div class='line' id='LC1719'>as for preference, I wouldn&#39;t have traded it for the twentieth.</div><div class='line' id='LC1720'>Look at the opportunities here for a man of knowledge, brains,</div><div class='line' id='LC1721'>pluck, and enterprise to sail in and grow up with the country.</div><div class='line' id='LC1722'>The grandest field that ever was; and all my own; not a competitor;</div><div class='line' id='LC1723'>not a man who wasn&#39;t a baby to me in acquirements and capacities;</div><div class='line' id='LC1724'>whereas, what would I amount to in the twentieth century?  I should</div><div class='line' id='LC1725'>be foreman of a factory, that is about all; and could drag a seine</div><div class='line' id='LC1726'>down street any day and catch a hundred better men than myself.</div><div class='line' id='LC1727'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1728'>What a jump I had made!  I couldn&#39;t keep from thinking about it,</div><div class='line' id='LC1729'>and contemplating it, just as one does who has struck oil.  There</div><div class='line' id='LC1730'>was nothing back of me that could approach it, unless it might be</div><div class='line' id='LC1731'>Joseph&#39;s case; and Joseph&#39;s only approached it, it didn&#39;t equal</div><div class='line' id='LC1732'>it, quite.  For it stands to reason that as Joseph&#39;s splendid</div><div class='line' id='LC1733'>financial ingenuities advantaged nobody but the king, the general</div><div class='line' id='LC1734'>public must have regarded him with a good deal of disfavor, whereas</div><div class='line' id='LC1735'>I had done my entire public a kindness in sparing the sun, and was</div><div class='line' id='LC1736'>popular by reason of it.</div><div class='line' id='LC1737'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1738'>I was no shadow of a king; I was the substance; the king himself</div><div class='line' id='LC1739'>was the shadow.  My power was colossal; and it was not a mere</div><div class='line' id='LC1740'>name, as such things have generally been, it was the genuine</div><div class='line' id='LC1741'>article.  I stood here, at the very spring and source of the second</div><div class='line' id='LC1742'>great period of the world&#39;s history; and could see the trickling</div><div class='line' id='LC1743'>stream of that history gather and deepen and broaden, and roll</div><div class='line' id='LC1744'>its mighty tides down the far centuries; and I could note the</div><div class='line' id='LC1745'>upspringing of adventurers like myself in the shelter of its long</div><div class='line' id='LC1746'>array of thrones: De Montforts, Gavestons, Mortimers, Villierses;</div><div class='line' id='LC1747'>the war-making, campaign-directing wantons of France, and Charles</div><div class='line' id='LC1748'>the Second&#39;s scepter-wielding drabs; but nowhere in the procession</div><div class='line' id='LC1749'>was my full-sized fellow visible.  I was a Unique; and glad to know</div><div class='line' id='LC1750'>that that fact could not be dislodged or challenged for thirteen</div><div class='line' id='LC1751'>centuries and a half, for sure.  Yes, in power I was equal to</div><div class='line' id='LC1752'>the king.  At the same time there was another power that was</div><div class='line' id='LC1753'>a trifle stronger than both of us put together.  That was the Church.</div><div class='line' id='LC1754'>I do not wish to disguise that fact.  I couldn&#39;t, if I wanted to.</div><div class='line' id='LC1755'>But never mind about that, now; it will show up, in its proper</div><div class='line' id='LC1756'>place, later on.  It didn&#39;t cause me any trouble in the beginning</div><div class='line' id='LC1757'>--at least any of consequence.</div><div class='line' id='LC1758'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1759'>Well, it was a curious country, and full of interest.  And the</div><div class='line' id='LC1760'>people!  They were the quaintest and simplest and trustingest race;</div><div class='line' id='LC1761'>why, they were nothing but rabbits.  It was pitiful for a person</div><div class='line' id='LC1762'>born in a wholesome free atmosphere to listen to their humble</div><div class='line' id='LC1763'>and hearty outpourings of loyalty toward their king and Church</div><div class='line' id='LC1764'>and nobility; as if they had any more occasion to love and honor</div><div class='line' id='LC1765'>king and Church and noble than a slave has to love and honor</div><div class='line' id='LC1766'>the lash, or a dog has to love and honor the stranger that kicks him!</div><div class='line' id='LC1767'>Why, dear me, _any_ kind of royalty, howsoever modified, _any_ kind</div><div class='line' id='LC1768'>of aristocracy, howsoever pruned, is rightly an insult; but if you</div><div class='line' id='LC1769'>are born and brought up under that sort of arrangement you probably</div><div class='line' id='LC1770'>never find it out for yourself, and don&#39;t believe it when somebody</div><div class='line' id='LC1771'>else tells you.  It is enough to make a body ashamed of his race</div><div class='line' id='LC1772'>to think of the sort of froth that has always occupied its thrones</div><div class='line' id='LC1773'>without shadow of right or reason, and the seventh-rate people</div><div class='line' id='LC1774'>that have always figured as its aristocracies--a company of monarchs</div><div class='line' id='LC1775'>and nobles who, as a rule, would have achieved only poverty and</div><div class='line' id='LC1776'>obscurity if left, like their betters, to their own exertions.</div><div class='line' id='LC1777'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1778'>The most of King Arthur&#39;s British nation were slaves, pure and</div><div class='line' id='LC1779'>simple, and bore that name, and wore the iron collar on their</div><div class='line' id='LC1780'>necks; and the rest were slaves in fact, but without the name;</div><div class='line' id='LC1781'>they imagined themselves men and freemen, and called themselves</div><div class='line' id='LC1782'>so.  The truth was, the nation as a body was in the world for one</div><div class='line' id='LC1783'>object, and one only: to grovel before king and Church and noble;</div><div class='line' id='LC1784'>to slave for them, sweat blood for them, starve that they might</div><div class='line' id='LC1785'>be fed, work that they might play, drink misery to the dregs that</div><div class='line' id='LC1786'>they might be happy, go naked that they might wear silks and</div><div class='line' id='LC1787'>jewels, pay taxes that they might be spared from paying them,</div><div class='line' id='LC1788'>be familiar all their lives with the degrading language and postures</div><div class='line' id='LC1789'>of adulation that they might walk in pride and think themselves</div><div class='line' id='LC1790'>the gods of this world.  And for all this, the thanks they got were</div><div class='line' id='LC1791'>cuffs and contempt; and so poor-spirited were they that they took</div><div class='line' id='LC1792'>even this sort of attention as an honor.</div><div class='line' id='LC1793'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1794'>Inherited ideas are a curious thing, and interesting to observe</div><div class='line' id='LC1795'>and examine.  I had mine, the king and his people had theirs.</div><div class='line' id='LC1796'>In both cases they flowed in ruts worn deep by time and habit,</div><div class='line' id='LC1797'>and the man who should have proposed to divert them by reason</div><div class='line' id='LC1798'>and argument would have had a long contract on his hands.  For</div><div class='line' id='LC1799'>instance, those people had inherited the idea that all men without</div><div class='line' id='LC1800'>title and a long pedigree, whether they had great natural gifts</div><div class='line' id='LC1801'>and acquirements or hadn&#39;t, were creatures of no more consideration</div><div class='line' id='LC1802'>than so many animals, bugs, insects; whereas I had inherited the idea</div><div class='line' id='LC1803'>that human daws who can consent to masquerade in the peacock-shams</div><div class='line' id='LC1804'>of inherited dignities and unearned titles, are of no good but</div><div class='line' id='LC1805'>to be laughed at.  The way I was looked upon was odd, but it was</div><div class='line' id='LC1806'>natural.  You know how the keeper and the public regard the elephant</div><div class='line' id='LC1807'>in the menagerie: well, that is the idea.  They are full of</div><div class='line' id='LC1808'>admiration of his vast bulk and his prodigious strength; they</div><div class='line' id='LC1809'>speak with pride of the fact that he can do a hundred marvels</div><div class='line' id='LC1810'>which are far and away beyond their own powers; and they speak</div><div class='line' id='LC1811'>with the same pride of the fact that in his wrath he is able</div><div class='line' id='LC1812'>to drive a thousand men before him.  But does that make him one</div><div class='line' id='LC1813'>of _them_?  No; the raggedest tramp in the pit would smile at</div><div class='line' id='LC1814'>the idea.  He couldn&#39;t comprehend it; couldn&#39;t take it in; couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC1815'>in any remote way conceive of it.  Well, to the king, the nobles,</div><div class='line' id='LC1816'>and all the nation, down to the very slaves and tramps, I was</div><div class='line' id='LC1817'>just that kind of an elephant, and nothing more.  I was admired,</div><div class='line' id='LC1818'>also feared; but it was as an animal is admired and feared.</div><div class='line' id='LC1819'>The animal is not reverenced, neither was I; I was not even</div><div class='line' id='LC1820'>respected.  I had no pedigree, no inherited title; so in the king&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC1821'>and nobles&#39; eyes I was mere dirt; the people regarded me with</div><div class='line' id='LC1822'>wonder and awe, but there was no reverence mixed with it; through</div><div class='line' id='LC1823'>the force of inherited ideas they were not able to conceive of</div><div class='line' id='LC1824'>anything being entitled to that except pedigree and lordship.</div><div class='line' id='LC1825'>There you see the hand of that awful power, the Roman Catholic</div><div class='line' id='LC1826'>Church.  In two or three little centuries it had converted a nation</div><div class='line' id='LC1827'>of men to a nation of worms.
