Before the day of the Church&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC1828'>supremacy in the world, men were men, and held their heads up,</div><div class='line' id='LC1829'>and had a man&#39;s pride and spirit and independence; and what</div><div class='line' id='LC1830'>of greatness and position a person got, he got mainly by achievement,</div><div class='line' id='LC1831'>not by birth.  But then the Church came to the front, with an axe</div><div class='line' id='LC1832'>to grind; and she was wise, subtle, and knew more than one way</div><div class='line' id='LC1833'>to skin a cat--or a nation; she invented &quot;divine right of kings,&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC1834'>and propped it all around, brick by brick, with the Beatitudes</div><div class='line' id='LC1835'>--wrenching them from their good purpose to make them fortify</div><div class='line' id='LC1836'>an evil one; she preached (to the commoner) humility, obedience</div><div class='line' id='LC1837'>to superiors, the beauty of self-sacrifice; she preached (to the</div><div class='line' id='LC1838'>commoner) meekness under insult; preached (still to the commoner,</div><div class='line' id='LC1839'>always to the commoner) patience, meanness of spirit, non-resistance</div><div class='line' id='LC1840'>under oppression; and she introduced heritable ranks and</div><div class='line' id='LC1841'>aristocracies, and taught all the Christian populations of the earth</div><div class='line' id='LC1842'>to bow down to them and worship them.  Even down to my birth-century</div><div class='line' id='LC1843'>that poison was still in the blood of Christendom, and the best</div><div class='line' id='LC1844'>of English commoners was still content to see his inferiors</div><div class='line' id='LC1845'>impudently continuing to hold a number of positions, such as</div><div class='line' id='LC1846'>lordships and the throne, to which the grotesque laws of his country</div><div class='line' id='LC1847'>did not allow him to aspire; in fact, he was not merely contented</div><div class='line' id='LC1848'>with this strange condition of things, he was even able to persuade</div><div class='line' id='LC1849'>himself that he was proud of it.  It seems to show that there isn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC1850'>anything you can&#39;t stand, if you are only born and bred to it.</div><div class='line' id='LC1851'>Of course that taint, that reverence for rank and title, had been</div><div class='line' id='LC1852'>in our American blood, too--I know that; but when I left America</div><div class='line' id='LC1853'>it had disappeared--at least to all intents and purposes.  The</div><div class='line' id='LC1854'>remnant of it was restricted to the dudes and dudesses.  When</div><div class='line' id='LC1855'>a disease has worked its way down to that level, it may fairly</div><div class='line' id='LC1856'>be said to be out of the system.</div><div class='line' id='LC1857'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1858'>But to return to my anomalous position in King Arthur&#39;s kingdom.</div><div class='line' id='LC1859'>Here I was, a giant among pigmies, a man among children, a master</div><div class='line' id='LC1860'>intelligence among intellectual moles: by all rational measurement</div><div class='line' id='LC1861'>the one and only actually great man in that whole British world;</div><div class='line' id='LC1862'>and yet there and then, just as in the remote England of my</div><div class='line' id='LC1863'>birth-time, the sheep-witted earl who could claim long descent</div><div class='line' id='LC1864'>from a king&#39;s leman, acquired at second-hand from the slums of</div><div class='line' id='LC1865'>London, was a better man than I was.  Such a personage was fawned</div><div class='line' id='LC1866'>upon in Arthur&#39;s realm and reverently looked up to by everybody,</div><div class='line' id='LC1867'>even though his dispositions were as mean as his intelligence,</div><div class='line' id='LC1868'>and his morals as base as his lineage.  There were times when</div><div class='line' id='LC1869'>_he_ could sit down in the king&#39;s presence, but I couldn&#39;t.  I could</div><div class='line' id='LC1870'>have got a title easily enough, and that would have raised me</div><div class='line' id='LC1871'>a large step in everybody&#39;s eyes; even in the king&#39;s, the giver</div><div class='line' id='LC1872'>of it.  But I didn&#39;t ask for it; and I declined it when it was</div><div class='line' id='LC1873'>offered.  I couldn&#39;t have enjoyed such a thing with my notions;</div><div class='line' id='LC1874'>and it wouldn&#39;t have been fair, anyway, because as far back as</div><div class='line' id='LC1875'>I could go, our tribe had always been short of the bar sinister.</div><div class='line' id='LC1876'>I couldn&#39;t have felt really and satisfactorily fine and proud</div><div class='line' id='LC1877'>and set-up over any title except one that should come from the nation</div><div class='line' id='LC1878'>itself, the only legitimate source; and such an one I hoped to win;</div><div class='line' id='LC1879'>and in the course of years of honest and honorable endeavor, I did</div><div class='line' id='LC1880'>win it and did wear it with a high and clean pride.  This title</div><div class='line' id='LC1881'>fell casually from the lips of a blacksmith, one day, in a village,</div><div class='line' id='LC1882'>was caught up as a happy thought and tossed from mouth to mouth</div><div class='line' id='LC1883'>with a laugh and an affirmative vote; in ten days it had swept</div><div class='line' id='LC1884'>the kingdom, and was become as familiar as the king&#39;s name.  I was</div><div class='line' id='LC1885'>never known by any other designation afterward, whether in the</div><div class='line' id='LC1886'>nation&#39;s talk or in grave debate upon matters of state at the</div><div class='line' id='LC1887'>council-board of the sovereign.  This title, translated into modern</div><div class='line' id='LC1888'>speech, would be THE BOSS.  Elected by the nation.  That suited me.</div><div class='line' id='LC1889'>And it was a pretty high title.  There were very few THE&#39;S, and</div><div class='line' id='LC1890'>I was one of them.  If you spoke of the duke, or the earl, or</div><div class='line' id='LC1891'>the bishop, how could anybody tell which one you meant?  But if</div><div class='line' id='LC1892'>you spoke of The King or The Queen or The Boss, it was different.</div><div class='line' id='LC1893'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1894'>Well, I liked the king, and as king I respected him--respected</div><div class='line' id='LC1895'>the office; at least respected it as much as I was capable of</div><div class='line' id='LC1896'>respecting any unearned supremacy; but as MEN I looked down upon</div><div class='line' id='LC1897'>him and his nobles--privately.  And he and they liked me, and</div><div class='line' id='LC1898'>respected my office; but as an animal, without birth or sham title,</div><div class='line' id='LC1899'>they looked down upon me--and were not particularly private about it,</div><div class='line' id='LC1900'>either.  I didn&#39;t charge for my opinion about them, and they didn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC1901'>charge for their opinion about me: the account was square, the</div><div class='line' id='LC1902'>books balanced, everybody was satisfied.</div><div class='line' id='LC1903'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1904'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1905'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1906'>CHAPTER IX</div><div class='line' id='LC1907'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1908'>THE TOURNAMENT</div><div class='line' id='LC1909'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1910'>They were always having grand tournaments there at Camelot; and</div><div class='line' id='LC1911'>very stirring and picturesque and ridiculous human bull-fights</div><div class='line' id='LC1912'>they were, too, but just a little wearisome to the practical mind.</div><div class='line' id='LC1913'>However, I was generally on hand--for two reasons: a man must</div><div class='line' id='LC1914'>not hold himself aloof from the things which his friends and his</div><div class='line' id='LC1915'>community have at heart if he would be liked--especially as</div><div class='line' id='LC1916'>a statesman; and both as business man and statesman I wanted</div><div class='line' id='LC1917'>to study the tournament and see if I couldn&#39;t invent an improvement</div><div class='line' id='LC1918'>on it.  That reminds me to remark, in passing, that the very first</div><div class='line' id='LC1919'>official thing I did, in my administration--and it was on the very</div><div class='line' id='LC1920'>first day of it, too--was to start a patent office; for I knew</div><div class='line' id='LC1921'>that a country without a patent office and good patent laws was</div><div class='line' id='LC1922'>just a crab, and couldn&#39;t travel any way but sideways or backways.</div><div class='line' id='LC1923'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1924'>Things ran along, a tournament nearly every week; and now and then</div><div class='line' id='LC1925'>the boys used to want me to take a hand--I mean Sir Launcelot and</div><div class='line' id='LC1926'>the rest--but I said I would by and by; no hurry yet, and too much</div><div class='line' id='LC1927'>government machinery to oil up and set to rights and start a-going.</div><div class='line' id='LC1928'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1929'>We had one tournament which was continued from day to day during</div><div class='line' id='LC1930'>more than a week, and as many as five hundred knights took part</div><div class='line' id='LC1931'>in it, from first to last.  They were weeks gathering.  They came</div><div class='line' id='LC1932'>on horseback from everywhere; from the very ends of the country,</div><div class='line' id='LC1933'>and even from beyond the sea; and many brought ladies, and all</div><div class='line' id='LC1934'>brought squires and troops of servants.  It was a most gaudy and</div><div class='line' id='LC1935'>gorgeous crowd, as to costumery, and very characteristic of the</div><div class='line' id='LC1936'>country and the time, in the way of high animal spirits, innocent</div><div class='line' id='LC1937'>indecencies of language, and happy-hearted indifference to morals.</div><div class='line' id='LC1938'>It was fight or look on, all day and every day; and sing, gamble,</div><div class='line' id='LC1939'>dance, carouse half the night every night.  They had a most noble</div><div class='line' id='LC1940'>good time.  You never saw such people.  Those banks of beautiful</div><div class='line' id='LC1941'>ladies, shining in their barbaric splendors, would see a knight</div><div class='line' id='LC1942'>sprawl from his horse in the lists with a lanceshaft the thickness</div><div class='line' id='LC1943'>of your ankle clean through him and the blood spouting, and instead</div><div class='line' id='LC1944'>of fainting they would clap their hands and crowd each other for a</div><div class='line' id='LC1945'>better view; only sometimes one would dive into her handkerchief,</div><div class='line' id='LC1946'>and look ostentatiously broken-hearted, and then you could lay</div><div class='line' id='LC1947'>two to one that there was a scandal there somewhere and she was</div><div class='line' id='LC1948'>afraid the public hadn&#39;t found it out.</div><div class='line' id='LC1949'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1950'>The noise at night would have been annoying to me ordinarily, but</div><div class='line' id='LC1951'>I didn&#39;t mind it in the present circumstances, because it kept me</div><div class='line' id='LC1952'>from hearing the quacks detaching legs and arms from the day&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC1953'>cripples.  They ruined an uncommon good old cross-cut saw for me,</div><div class='line' id='LC1954'>and broke the saw-buck, too, but I let it pass.  And as for my</div><div class='line' id='LC1955'>axe--well, I made up my mind that the next time I lent an axe</div><div class='line' id='LC1956'>to a surgeon I would pick my century.</div><div class='line' id='LC1957'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1958'>I not only watched this tournament from day to day, but detailed</div><div class='line' id='LC1959'>an intelligent priest from my Department of Public Morals and</div><div class='line' id='LC1960'>Agriculture, and ordered him to report it; for it was my purpose</div><div class='line' id='LC1961'>by and by, when I should have gotten the people along far enough,</div><div class='line' id='LC1962'>to start a newspaper.  The first thing you want in a new country,</div><div class='line' id='LC1963'>is a patent office; then work up your school system; and after that,</div><div class='line' id='LC1964'>out with your paper.  A newspaper has its faults, and plenty of them,</div><div class='line' id='LC1965'>but no matter, it&#39;s hark from the tomb for a dead nation, and don&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC1966'>you forget it.  You can&#39;t resurrect a dead nation without it; there</div><div class='line' id='LC1967'>isn&#39;t any way.  So I wanted to sample things, and be finding out</div><div class='line' id='LC1968'>what sort of reporter-material I might be able to rake together out</div><div class='line' id='LC1969'>of the sixth century when I should come to need it.</div><div class='line' id='LC1970'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1971'>Well, the priest did very well, considering.  He got in all</div><div class='line' id='LC1972'>the details, and that is a good thing in a local item: you see,</div><div class='line' id='LC1973'>he had kept books for the undertaker-department of his church</div><div class='line' id='LC1974'>when he was younger, and there, you know, the money&#39;s in the details;</div><div class='line' id='LC1975'>the more details, the more swag: bearers, mutes, candles, prayers</div><div class='line' id='LC1976'>--everything counts; and if the bereaved don&#39;t buy prayers enough</div><div class='line' id='LC1977'>you mark up your candles with a forked pencil, and your bill</div><div class='line' id='LC1978'>shows up all right.  And he had a good knack at getting in the</div><div class='line' id='LC1979'>complimentary thing here and there about a knight that was likely</div><div class='line' id='LC1980'>to advertise--no, I mean a knight that had influence; and he also</div><div class='line' id='LC1981'>had a neat gift of exaggeration, for in his time he had kept door</div><div class='line' id='LC1982'>for a pious hermit who lived in a sty and worked miracles.</div><div class='line' id='LC1983'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1984'>Of course this novice&#39;s report lacked whoop and crash and lurid</div><div class='line' id='LC1985'>description, and therefore wanted the true ring; but its antique</div><div class='line' id='LC1986'>wording was quaint and sweet and simple, and full of the fragrances</div><div class='line' id='LC1987'>and flavors of the time, and these little merits made up in a measure</div><div class='line' id='LC1988'>for its more important lacks.  Here is an extract from it:</div><div class='line' id='LC1989'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC1990'>&nbsp;&nbsp;Then Sir Brian de les Isles and Grummore Grummorsum,</div><div class='line' id='LC1991'>&nbsp;&nbsp;knights of the castle, encountered with Sir Aglovale and</div><div class='line' id='LC1992'>&nbsp;&nbsp;Sir Tor, and Sir Tor smote down Sir Grummore Grummorsum</div><div class='line' id='LC1993'>&nbsp;&nbsp;to the earth.  Then came Sir Carados of the dolorous</div><div class='line' id='LC1994'>&nbsp;&nbsp;tower, and Sir Turquine, knights of the castle, and</div><div class='line' id='LC1995'>&nbsp;&nbsp;there encountered with them Sir Percivale de Galis</div><div class='line' id='LC1996'>&nbsp;&nbsp;and Sir Lamorak de Galis, that were two brethren, and</div><div class='line' id='LC1997'>&nbsp;&nbsp;there encountered Sir Percivale with Sir Carados, and</div><div class='line' id='LC1998'>&nbsp;&nbsp;either brake their spears unto their hands, and then</div><div class='line' id='LC1999'>&nbsp;&nbsp;Sir Turquine with Sir Lamorak, and either of them smote</div><div class='line' id='LC2000'>&nbsp;&nbsp;down other, horse and all, to the earth, and either</div><div class='line' id='LC2001'>&nbsp;&nbsp;parties rescued other and horsed them again.  And Sir</div><div class='line' id='LC2002'>&nbsp;&nbsp;Arnold, and Sir Gauter, knights of the castle,</div><div class='line' id='LC2003'>&nbsp;&nbsp;encountered with Sir Brandiles and Sir Kay, and these</div><div class='line' id='LC2004'>&nbsp;&nbsp;four knights encountered mightily, and brake their</div><div class='line' id='LC2005'>&nbsp;&nbsp;spears to their hands.  Then came Sir Pertolope from</div><div class='line' id='LC2006'>&nbsp;&nbsp;the castle, and there encountered with him Sir Lionel,</div><div class='line' id='LC2007'>&nbsp;&nbsp;and there Sir Pertolope the green knight smote down Sir</div><div class='line' id='LC2008'>&nbsp;&nbsp;Lionel, brother to Sir Launcelot.  All this was marked</div><div class='line' id='LC2009'>&nbsp;&nbsp;by noble heralds, who bare him best, and their names.</div><div class='line' id='LC2010'>&nbsp;&nbsp;Then Sir Bleobaris brake his spear upon Sir Gareth,</div><div class='line' id='LC2011'>&nbsp;&nbsp;but of that stroke Sir Bleobaris fell to the earth.</div><div class='line' id='LC2012'>&nbsp;&nbsp;When Sir Galihodin saw that, he bad Sir Gareth keep him,</div><div class='line' id='LC2013'>&nbsp;&nbsp;and Sir Gareth smote him to the earth.  Then Sir Galihud</div><div class='line' id='LC2014'>&nbsp;&nbsp;gat a spear to avenge his brother, and in the same wise</div><div class='line' id='LC2015'>&nbsp;&nbsp;Sir Gareth served him, and Sir Dinadan and his brother</div><div class='line' id='LC2016'>&nbsp;&nbsp;La Cote Male Taile, and Sir Sagramore le Disirous, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2017'>&nbsp;&nbsp;Sir Dodinas le Savage; all these he bare down with one</div><div class='line' id='LC2018'>&nbsp;&nbsp;spear.  When King Aswisance of Ireland saw Sir Gareth</div><div class='line' id='LC2019'>&nbsp;&nbsp;fare so he marvelled what he might be, that one time</div><div class='line' id='LC2020'>&nbsp;&nbsp;seemed green, and another time, at his again coming,</div><div class='line' id='LC2021'>&nbsp;&nbsp;he seemed blue.  And thus at every course that he rode</div><div class='line' id='LC2022'>&nbsp;&nbsp;to and fro he changed his color, so that there might</div><div class='line' id='LC2023'>&nbsp;&nbsp;neither king nor knight have ready cognizance of him.</div><div class='line' id='LC2024'>&nbsp;&nbsp;Then Sir Agwisance the King of Ireland encountered</div><div class='line' id='LC2025'>&nbsp;&nbsp;with Sir Gareth, and there Sir Gareth smote him from</div><div class='line' id='LC2026'>&nbsp;&nbsp;his horse, saddle and all.  And then came King Carados</div><div class='line' id='LC2027'>&nbsp;&nbsp;of Scotland, and Sir Gareth smote him down horse and</div><div class='line' id='LC2028'>&nbsp;&nbsp;man.  And in the same wise he served King Uriens of the</div><div class='line' id='LC2029'>&nbsp;&nbsp;land of Gore.  And then there came in Sir Bagdemagus,</div><div class='line' id='LC2030'>&nbsp;&nbsp;and Sir Gareth smote him down horse and man to the</div><div class='line' id='LC2031'>&nbsp;&nbsp;earth.  And Bagdemagus&#39;s son Meliganus brake a spear</div><div class='line' id='LC2032'>&nbsp;&nbsp;upon Sir Gareth mightily and knightly.  And then Sir</div><div class='line' id='LC2033'>&nbsp;&nbsp;Galahault the noble prince cried on high, Knight with</div><div class='line' id='LC2034'>&nbsp;&nbsp;the many colors, well hast thou justed; now make thee</div><div class='line' id='LC2035'>&nbsp;&nbsp;ready that I may just with thee.  Sir Gareth heard him,</div><div class='line' id='LC2036'>&nbsp;&nbsp;and he gat a great spear, and so they encountered</div><div class='line' id='LC2037'>&nbsp;&nbsp;together, and there the prince brake his spear; but Sir</div><div class='line' id='LC2038'>&nbsp;&nbsp;Gareth smote him upon the left side of the helm, that</div><div class='line' id='LC2039'>&nbsp;&nbsp;he reeled here and there, and he had fallen down had not</div><div class='line' id='LC2040'>&nbsp;&nbsp;his men recovered him.  Truly, said King Arthur, that</div><div class='line' id='LC2041'>&nbsp;&nbsp;knight with the many colors is a good knight.  Wherefore</div><div class='line' id='LC2042'>&nbsp;&nbsp;the king called unto him Sir Launcelot, and prayed him</div><div class='line' id='LC2043'>&nbsp;&nbsp;to encounter with that knight.  Sir, said Launcelot, I</div><div class='line' id='LC2044'>&nbsp;&nbsp;may as well find in my heart for to forbear him at</div><div class='line' id='LC2045'>&nbsp;&nbsp;this time, for he hath had travail enough this day, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2046'>&nbsp;&nbsp;when a good knight doth so well upon some day, it is</div><div class='line' id='LC2047'>&nbsp;&nbsp;no good knight&#39;s part to let him of his worship, and,</div><div class='line' id='LC2048'>&nbsp;&nbsp;namely, when he seeth a knight hath done so great</div><div class='line' id='LC2049'>&nbsp;&nbsp;labour; for peradventure, said Sir Launcelot, his</div><div class='line' id='LC2050'>&nbsp;&nbsp;quarrel is here this day, and peradventure he is best</div><div class='line' id='LC2051'>&nbsp;&nbsp;beloved with this lady of all that be here, for I see</div><div class='line' id='LC2052'>&nbsp;&nbsp;well he paineth himself and enforceth him to do great</div><div class='line' id='LC2053'>&nbsp;&nbsp;deeds, and therefore, said Sir Launcelot, as for me,</div><div class='line' id='LC2054'>&nbsp;&nbsp;this day he shall have the honour; though it lay in my</div><div class='line' id='LC2055'>&nbsp;&nbsp;power to put him from it, I would not.</div><div class='line' id='LC2056'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2057'>There was an unpleasant little episode that day, which for reasons</div><div class='line' id='LC2058'>of state I struck out of my priest&#39;s report.  You will have noticed</div><div class='line' id='LC2059'>that Garry was doing some great fighting in the engagement.  When</div><div class='line' id='LC2060'>I say Garry I mean Sir Gareth.  Garry was my private pet name</div><div class='line' id='LC2061'>for him; it suggests that I had a deep affection for him, and that</div><div class='line' id='LC2062'>was the case.  But it was a private pet name only, and never spoken</div><div class='line' id='LC2063'>aloud to any one, much less to him; being a noble, he would not</div><div class='line' id='LC2064'>have endured a familiarity like that from me.  Well, to proceed:</div><div class='line' id='LC2065'>I sat in the private box set apart for me as the king&#39;s minister.</div><div class='line' id='LC2066'>While Sir Dinadan was waiting for his turn to enter the lists,</div><div class='line' id='LC2067'>he came in there and sat down and began to talk; for he was always</div><div class='line' id='LC2068'>making up to me, because I was a stranger and he liked to have</div><div class='line' id='LC2069'>a fresh market for his jokes, the most of them having reached that</div><div class='line' id='LC2070'>stage of wear where the teller has to do the laughing himself while</div><div class='line' id='LC2071'>the other person looks sick.  I had always responded to his efforts</div><div class='line' id='LC2072'>as well as I could, and felt a very deep and real kindness for him,</div><div class='line' id='LC2073'>too, for the reason that if by malice of fate he knew the one</div><div class='line' id='LC2074'>particular anecdote which I had heard oftenest and had most hated</div><div class='line' id='LC2075'>and most loathed all my life, he had at least spared it me.  It was</div><div class='line' id='LC2076'>one which I had heard attributed to every humorous person who</div><div class='line' id='LC2077'>had ever stood on American soil, from Columbus down to Artemus Ward.</div><div class='line' id='LC2078'>It was about a humorous lecturer who flooded an ignorant audience</div><div class='line' id='LC2079'>with the killingest jokes for an hour and never got a laugh; and</div><div class='line' id='LC2080'>then when he was leaving, some gray simpletons wrung him gratefully</div><div class='line' id='LC2081'>by the hand and said it had been the funniest thing they had ever</div><div class='line' id='LC2082'>heard, and &quot;it was all they could do to keep from laughin&#39; right</div><div class='line' id='LC2083'>out in meetin&#39;.&quot;  That anecdote never saw the day that it was</div><div class='line' id='LC2084'>worth the telling; and yet I had sat under the telling of it</div><div class='line' id='LC2085'>hundreds and thousands and millions and billions of times, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2086'>cried and cursed all the way through.  Then who can hope to know</div><div class='line' id='LC2087'>what my feelings were, to hear this armor-plated ass start in on</div><div class='line' id='LC2088'>it again, in the murky twilight of tradition, before the dawn of</div><div class='line' id='LC2089'>history, while even Lactantius might be referred to as &quot;the late</div><div class='line' id='LC2090'>Lactantius,&quot; and the Crusades wouldn&#39;t be born for five hundred</div><div class='line' id='LC2091'>years yet?  Just as he finished, the call-boy came; so, haw-hawing</div><div class='line' id='LC2092'>like a demon, he went rattling and clanking out like a crate of</div><div class='line' id='LC2093'>loose castings, and I knew nothing more.  It was some minutes</div><div class='line' id='LC2094'>before I came to, and then I opened my eyes just in time to see</div><div class='line' id='LC2095'>Sir Gareth fetch him an awful welt, and I unconsciously out with</div><div class='line' id='LC2096'>the prayer, &quot;I hope to gracious he&#39;s killed!&quot;  But by ill-luck,</div><div class='line' id='LC2097'>before I had got half through with the words, Sir Gareth crashed</div><div class='line' id='LC2098'>into Sir Sagramor le Desirous and sent him thundering over his</div><div class='line' id='LC2099'>horse&#39;s crupper, and Sir Sagramor caught my remark and thought</div><div class='line' id='LC2100'>I meant it for _him_.</div><div class='line' id='LC2101'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2102'>Well, whenever one of those people got a thing into his head,</div><div class='line' id='LC2103'>there was no getting it out again.  I knew that, so I saved my</div><div class='line' id='LC2104'>breath, and offered no explanations.  As soon as Sir Sagramor</div><div class='line' id='LC2105'>got well, he notified me that there was a little account to settle</div><div class='line' id='LC2106'>between us, and he named a day three or four years in the future;</div><div class='line' id='LC2107'>place of settlement, the lists where the offense had been given.</div><div class='line' id='LC2108'>I said I would be ready when he got back.  You see, he was going</div><div class='line' id='LC2109'>for the Holy Grail.  The boys all took a flier at the Holy Grail</div><div class='line' id='LC2110'>now and then.  It was a several years&#39; cruise.  They always put in</div><div class='line' id='LC2111'>the long absence snooping around, in the most conscientious way,</div><div class='line' id='LC2112'>though none of them had any idea where the Holy Grail really was,</div><div class='line' id='LC2113'>and I don&#39;t think any of them actually expected to find it, or</div><div class='line' id='LC2114'>would have known what to do with it if he _had_ run across it.</div><div class='line' id='LC2115'>You see, it was just the Northwest Passage of that day, as you may</div><div class='line' id='LC2116'>say; that was all.  Every year expeditions went out holy grailing,</div><div class='line' id='LC2117'>and next year relief expeditions went out to hunt for _them_.  There</div><div class='line' id='LC2118'>was worlds of reputation in it, but no money.  Why, they actually</div><div class='line' id='LC2119'>wanted _me_ to put in!  Well, I should smile.</div><div class='line' id='LC2120'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2121'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2122'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2123'>CHAPTER X</div><div class='line' id='LC2124'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2125'>BEGINNINGS OF CIVILIZATION</div><div class='line' id='LC2126'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2127'>The Round Table soon heard of the challenge, and of course it was</div><div class='line' id='LC2128'>a good deal discussed, for such things interested the boys.</div><div class='line' id='LC2129'>The king thought I ought now to set forth in quest of adventures,</div><div class='line' id='LC2130'>so that I might gain renown and be the more worthy to meet</div><div class='line' id='LC2131'>Sir Sagramor when the several years should have rolled away.</div><div class='line' id='LC2132'>I excused myself for the present; I said it would take me three</div><div class='line' id='LC2133'>or four years yet to get things well fixed up and going smoothly;</div><div class='line' id='LC2134'>then I should be ready; all the chances were that at the end of</div><div class='line' id='LC2135'>that time Sir Sagramor would still be out grailing, so no valuable</div><div class='line' id='LC2136'>time would be lost by the postponement; I should then have been</div><div class='line' id='LC2137'>in office six or seven years, and I believed my system and machinery</div><div class='line' id='LC2138'>would be so well developed that I could take a holiday without</div><div class='line' id='LC2139'>its working any harm.</div><div class='line' id='LC2140'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2141'>I was pretty well satisfied with what I had already accomplished.</div><div class='line' id='LC2142'>In various quiet nooks and corners I had the beginnings of all</div><div class='line' id='LC2143'>sorts of industries under way--nuclei of future vast factories,</div><div class='line' id='LC2144'>the iron and steel missionaries of my future civilization.  In these</div><div class='line' id='LC2145'>were gathered together the brightest young minds I could find,</div><div class='line' id='LC2146'>and I kept agents out raking the country for more, all the time.</div><div class='line' id='LC2147'>I was training a crowd of ignorant folk into experts--experts</div><div class='line' id='LC2148'>in every sort of handiwork and scientific calling.  These nurseries</div><div class='line' id='LC2149'>of mine went smoothly and privately along undisturbed in their</div><div class='line' id='LC2150'>obscure country retreats, for nobody was allowed to come into their</div><div class='line' id='LC2151'>precincts without a special permit--for I was afraid of the Church.</div><div class='line' id='LC2152'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2153'>I had started a teacher-factory and a lot of Sunday-schools the</div><div class='line' id='LC2154'>first thing; as a result, I now had an admirable system of graded</div><div class='line' id='LC2155'>schools in full blast in those places, and also a complete variety</div><div class='line' id='LC2156'>of Protestant congregations all in a prosperous and growing</div><div class='line' id='LC2157'>condition.  Everybody could be any kind of a Christian he wanted</div><div class='line' id='LC2158'>to; there was perfect freedom in that matter.  But I confined public</div><div class='line' id='LC2159'>religious teaching to the churches and the Sunday-schools, permitting</div><div class='line' id='LC2160'>nothing of it in my other educational buildings.  I could have</div><div class='line' id='LC2161'>given my own sect the preference and made everybody a Presbyterian</div><div class='line' id='LC2162'>without any trouble, but that would have been to affront a law</div><div class='line' id='LC2163'>of human nature: spiritual wants and instincts are as various in</div><div class='line' id='LC2164'>the human family as are physical appetites, complexions, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2165'>features, and a man is only at his best, morally, when he is</div><div class='line' id='LC2166'>equipped with the religious garment whose color and shape and</div><div class='line' id='LC2167'>size most nicely accommodate themselves to the spiritual complexion,</div><div class='line' id='LC2168'>angularities, and stature of the individual who wears it; and,</div><div class='line' id='LC2169'>besides, I was afraid of a united Church; it makes a mighty power,</div><div class='line' id='LC2170'>the mightiest conceivable, and then when it by and by gets into</div><div class='line' id='LC2171'>selfish hands, as it is always bound to do, it means death to</div><div class='line' id='LC2172'>human liberty and paralysis to human thought.</div><div class='line' id='LC2173'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2174'>All mines were royal property, and there were a good many of them.</div><div class='line' id='LC2175'>They had formerly been worked as savages always work mines--holes</div><div class='line' id='LC2176'>grubbed in the earth and the mineral brought up in sacks of hide by</div><div class='line' id='LC2177'>hand, at the rate of a ton a day; but I had begun to put the mining</div><div class='line' id='LC2178'>on a scientific basis as early as I could.</div><div class='line' id='LC2179'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2180'>Yes, I had made pretty handsome progress when Sir Sagramor&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC2181'>challenge struck me.</div><div class='line' id='LC2182'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2183'>Four years rolled by--and then!  Well, you would never imagine</div><div class='line' id='LC2184'>it in the world.  Unlimited power is the ideal thing when it is in</div><div class='line' id='LC2185'>safe hands.  The despotism of heaven is the one absolutely perfect</div><div class='line' id='LC2186'>government.  An earthly despotism would be the absolutely perfect</div><div class='line' id='LC2187'>earthly government, if the conditions were the same, namely, the</div><div class='line' id='LC2188'>despot the perfectest individual of the human race, and his lease</div><div class='line' id='LC2189'>of life perpetual.  But as a perishable perfect man must die, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2190'>leave his despotism in the hands of an imperfect successor, an</div><div class='line' id='LC2191'>earthly despotism is not merely a bad form of government, it is</div><div class='line' id='LC2192'>the worst form that is possible.</div><div class='line' id='LC2193'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2194'>My works showed what a despot could do with the resources of</div><div class='line' id='LC2195'>a kingdom at his command.  Unsuspected by this dark land, I had</div><div class='line' id='LC2196'>the civilization of the nineteenth century booming under its very</div><div class='line' id='LC2197'>nose!  It was fenced away from the public view, but there it was,</div><div class='line' id='LC2198'>a gigantic and unassailable fact--and to be heard from, yet, if</div><div class='line' id='LC2199'>I lived and had luck.  There it was, as sure a fact and as substantial</div><div class='line' id='LC2200'>a fact as any serene volcano, standing innocent with its smokeless</div><div class='line' id='LC2201'>summit in the blue sky and giving no sign of the rising hell in its</div><div class='line' id='LC2202'>bowels.  My schools and churches were children four years before;</div><div class='line' id='LC2203'>they were grown-up now; my shops of that day were vast factories</div><div class='line' id='LC2204'>now; where I had a dozen trained men then, I had a thousand now;</div><div class='line' id='LC2205'>where I had one brilliant expert then, I had fifty now.  I stood</div><div class='line' id='LC2206'>with my hand on the cock, so to speak, ready to turn it on and</div><div class='line' id='LC2207'>flood the midnight world with light at any moment.  But I was not</div><div class='line' id='LC2208'>going to do the thing in that sudden way.  It was not my policy.</div><div class='line' id='LC2209'>The people could not have stood it; and, moreover, I should have</div><div class='line' id='LC2210'>had the Established Roman Catholic Church on my back in a minute.</div><div class='line' id='LC2211'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2212'>No, I had been going cautiously all the while.  I had had confidential</div><div class='line' id='LC2213'>agents trickling through the country some time, whose office was</div><div class='line' id='LC2214'>to undermine knighthood by imperceptible degrees, and to gnaw</div><div class='line' id='LC2215'>a little at this and that and the other superstition, and so prepare</div><div class='line' id='LC2216'>the way gradually for a better order of things.  I was turning on</div><div class='line' id='LC2217'>my light one-candle-power at a time, and meant to continue to do so.</div><div class='line' id='LC2218'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2219'>I had scattered some branch schools secretly about the kingdom,</div><div class='line' id='LC2220'>and they were doing very well.  I meant to work this racket more</div><div class='line' id='LC2221'>and more, as time wore on, if nothing occurred to frighten me.</div><div class='line' id='LC2222'>One of my deepest secrets was my West Point--my military academy.</div><div class='line' id='LC2223'>I kept that most jealously out of sight; and I did the same with my</div><div class='line' id='LC2224'>naval academy which I had established at a remote seaport.  Both</div><div class='line' id='LC2225'>were prospering to my satisfaction.</div><div class='line' id='LC2226'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2227'>Clarence was twenty-two now, and was my head executive, my right</div><div class='line' id='LC2228'>hand.  He was a darling; he was equal to anything; there wasn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC2229'>anything he couldn&#39;t turn his hand to.  Of late I had been training</div><div class='line' id='LC2230'>him for journalism, for the time seemed about right for a start</div><div class='line' id='LC2231'>in the newspaper line; nothing big, but just a small weekly for</div><div class='line' id='LC2232'>experimental circulation in my civilization-nurseries.  He took</div><div class='line' id='LC2233'>to it like a duck; there was an editor concealed in him, sure.</div><div class='line' id='LC2234'>Already he had doubled himself in one way; he talked sixth century</div><div class='line' id='LC2235'>and wrote nineteenth.  His journalistic style was climbing,</div><div class='line' id='LC2236'>steadily; it was already up to the back settlement Alabama mark,</div><div class='line' id='LC2237'>and couldn&#39;t be told from the editorial output of that region</div><div class='line' id='LC2238'>either by matter or flavor.</div><div class='line' id='LC2239'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2240'>We had another large departure on hand, too.  This was a telegraph</div><div class='line' id='LC2241'>and a telephone; our first venture in this line.  These wires were</div><div class='line' id='LC2242'>for private service only, as yet, and must be kept private until</div><div class='line' id='LC2243'>a riper day should come.  We had a gang of men on the road, working</div><div class='line' id='LC2244'>mainly by night.  They were stringing ground wires; we were afraid</div><div class='line' id='LC2245'>to put up poles, for they would attract too much inquiry.  Ground</div><div class='line' id='LC2246'>wires were good enough, in both instances, for my wires were</div><div class='line' id='LC2247'>protected by an insulation of my own invention which was perfect.</div><div class='line' id='LC2248'>My men had orders to strike across country, avoiding roads, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2249'>establishing connection with any considerable towns whose lights</div><div class='line' id='LC2250'>betrayed their presence, and leaving experts in charge. Nobody</div><div class='line' id='LC2251'>could tell you how to find any place in the kingdom, for nobody</div><div class='line' id='LC2252'>ever went intentionally to any place, but only struck it by</div><div class='line' id='LC2253'>accident in his wanderings, and then generally left it without</div><div class='line' id='LC2254'>thinking to inquire what its name was.  At one time and another</div><div class='line' id='LC2255'>we had sent out topographical expeditions to survey and map the</div><div class='line' id='LC2256'>kingdom, but the priests had always interfered and raised trouble.</div><div class='line' id='LC2257'>So we had given the thing up, for the present; it would be poor</div><div class='line' id='LC2258'>wisdom to antagonize the Church.</div><div class='line' id='LC2259'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2260'>As for the general condition of the country, it was as it had been</div><div class='line' id='LC2261'>when I arrived in it, to all intents and purposes.  I had made</div><div class='line' id='LC2262'>changes, but they were necessarily slight, and they were not</div><div class='line' id='LC2263'>noticeable.  Thus far, I had not even meddled with taxation,</div><div class='line' id='LC2264'>outside of the taxes which provided the royal revenues.  I had</div><div class='line' id='LC2265'>systematized those, and put the service on an effective and</div><div class='line' id='LC2266'>righteous basis.  As a result, these revenues were already quadrupled,</div><div class='line' id='LC2267'>and yet the burden was so much more equably distributed than</div><div class='line' id='LC2268'>before, that all the kingdom felt a sense of relief, and the praises</div><div class='line' id='LC2269'>of my administration were hearty and general.</div><div class='line' id='LC2270'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2271'>Personally, I struck an interruption, now, but I did not mind it,</div><div class='line' id='LC2272'>it could not have happened at a better time.  Earlier it could</div><div class='line' id='LC2273'>have annoyed me, but now everything was in good hands and swimming</div><div class='line' id='LC2274'>right along.  The king had reminded me several times, of late, that</div><div class='line' id='LC2275'>the postponement I had asked for, four years before, had about</div><div class='line' id='LC2276'>run out now.  It was a hint that I ought to be starting out to seek</div><div class='line' id='LC2277'>adventures and get up a reputation of a size to make me worthy</div><div class='line' id='LC2278'>of the honor of breaking a lance with Sir Sagramor, who was still</div><div class='line' id='LC2279'>out grailing, but was being hunted for by various relief expeditions,</div><div class='line' id='LC2280'>and might be found any year, now.  So you see I was expecting</div><div class='line' id='LC2281'>this interruption; it did not take me by surprise.</div><div class='line' id='LC2282'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2283'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2284'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2285'>CHAPTER XI</div><div class='line' id='LC2286'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2287'>THE YANKEE IN SEARCH OF ADVENTURES</div><div class='line' id='LC2288'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2289'>There never was such a country for wandering liars; and they were</div><div class='line' id='LC2290'>of both sexes.  Hardly a month went by without one of these tramps</div><div class='line' id='LC2291'>arriving; and generally loaded with a tale about some princess or</div><div class='line' id='LC2292'>other wanting help to get her out of some far-away castle where</div><div class='line' id='LC2293'>she was held in captivity by a lawless scoundrel, usually a giant.</div><div class='line' id='LC2294'>Now you would think that the first thing the king would do after</div><div class='line' id='LC2295'>listening to such a novelette from an entire stranger, would be</div><div class='line' id='LC2296'>to ask for credentials--yes, and a pointer or two as to locality</div><div class='line' id='LC2297'>of castle, best route to it, and so on.  But nobody ever thought</div><div class='line' id='LC2298'>of so simple and common-sense a thing at that.  No, everybody</div><div class='line' id='LC2299'>swallowed these people&#39;s lies whole, and never asked a question</div><div class='line' id='LC2300'>of any sort or about anything.  Well, one day when I was not</div><div class='line' id='LC2301'>around, one of these people came along--it was a she one, this</div><div class='line' id='LC2302'>time--and told a tale of the usual pattern.  Her mistress was</div><div class='line' id='LC2303'>a captive in a vast and gloomy castle, along with forty-four other</div><div class='line' id='LC2304'>young and beautiful girls, pretty much all of them princesses;</div><div class='line' id='LC2305'>they had been languishing in that cruel captivity for twenty-six</div><div class='line' id='LC2306'>years; the masters of the castle were three stupendous brothers,</div><div class='line' id='LC2307'>each with four arms and one eye--the eye in the center of the</div><div class='line' id='LC2308'>forehead, and as big as a fruit.  Sort of fruit not mentioned;</div><div class='line' id='LC2309'>their usual slovenliness in statistics.</div><div class='line' id='LC2310'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2311'>Would you believe it?  The king and the whole Round Table were</div><div class='line' id='LC2312'>in raptures over this preposterous opportunity for adventure.</div><div class='line' id='LC2313'>Every knight of the Table jumped for the chance, and begged for it;</div><div class='line' id='LC2314'>but to their vexation and chagrin the king conferred it upon me,</div><div class='line' id='LC2315'>who had not asked for it at all.</div><div class='line' id='LC2316'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2317'>By an effort, I contained my joy when Clarence brought me the news.</div><div class='line' id='LC2318'>But he--he could not contain his.  His mouth gushed delight and</div><div class='line' id='LC2319'>gratitude in a steady discharge--delight in my good fortune,</div><div class='line' id='LC2320'>gratitude to the king for this splendid mark of his favor for me.</div><div class='line' id='LC2321'>He could keep neither his legs nor his body still, but pirouetted</div><div class='line' id='LC2322'>about the place in an airy ecstasy of happiness.</div><div class='line' id='LC2323'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2324'>On my side, I could have cursed the kindness that conferred upon</div><div class='line' id='LC2325'>me this benefaction, but I kept my vexation under the surface</div><div class='line' id='LC2326'>for policy&#39;s sake, and did what I could to let on to be glad.</div><div class='line' id='LC2327'>Indeed, I _said_ I was glad.  And in a way it was true; I was as</div><div class='line' id='LC2328'>glad as a person is when he is scalped.</div><div class='line' id='LC2329'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2330'>Well, one must make the best of things, and not waste time with</div><div class='line' id='LC2331'>useless fretting, but get down to business and see what can be</div><div class='line' id='LC2332'>done.  In all lies there is wheat among the chaff; I must get at</div><div class='line' id='LC2333'>the wheat in this case: so I sent for the girl and she came.  She</div><div class='line' id='LC2334'>was a comely enough creature, and soft and modest, but, if signs</div><div class='line' id='LC2335'>went for anything, she didn&#39;t know as much as a lady&#39;s watch.  I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC2336'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2337'>&quot;My dear, have you been questioned as to particulars?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2338'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2339'>She said she hadn&#39;t.</div><div class='line' id='LC2340'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2341'>&quot;Well, I didn&#39;t expect you had, but I thought I would ask, to make</div><div class='line' id='LC2342'>sure; it&#39;s the way I&#39;ve been raised.  Now you mustn&#39;t take it</div><div class='line' id='LC2343'>unkindly if I remind you that as we don&#39;t know you, we must go</div><div class='line' id='LC2344'>a little slow.  You may be all right, of course, and we&#39;ll hope</div><div class='line' id='LC2345'>that you are; but to take it for granted isn&#39;t business.  _You_</div><div class='line' id='LC2346'>understand that.  I&#39;m obliged to ask you a few questions; just</div><div class='line' id='LC2347'>answer up fair and square, and don&#39;t be afraid.  Where do you</div><div class='line' id='LC2348'>live, when you are at home?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2349'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2350'>&quot;In the land of Moder, fair sir.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2351'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2352'>&quot;Land of Moder.  I don&#39;t remember hearing of it before.</div><div class='line' id='LC2353'>Parents living?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2354'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2355'>&quot;As to that, I know not if they be yet on live, sith it is many</div><div class='line' id='LC2356'>years that I have lain shut up in the castle.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2357'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2358'>&quot;Your name, please?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2359'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2360'>&quot;I hight the Demoiselle Alisande la Carteloise, an it please you.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2361'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2362'>&quot;Do you know anybody here who can identify you?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2363'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2364'>&quot;That were not likely, fair lord, I being come hither now for</div><div class='line' id='LC2365'>the first time.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2366'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2367'>&quot;Have you brought any letters--any documents--any proofs that</div><div class='line' id='LC2368'>you are trustworthy and truthful?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2369'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2370'>&quot;Of a surety, no; and wherefore should I?  Have I not a tongue,</div><div class='line' id='LC2371'>and cannot I say all that myself?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2372'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2373'>&quot;But _your_ saying it, you know, and somebody else&#39;s saying it,</div><div class='line' id='LC2374'>is different.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2375'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2376'>&quot;Different?  How might that be?  I fear me I do not understand.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2377'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2378'>&quot;Don&#39;t _understand_?  Land of--why, you see--you see--why, great Scott,</div><div class='line' id='LC2379'>can&#39;t you understand a little thing like that?  Can&#39;t you understand</div><div class='line' id='LC2380'>the difference between your--_why_ do you look so innocent and idiotic!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2381'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2382'>&quot;I?  In truth I know not, but an it were the will of God.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2383'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2384'>&quot;Yes, yes, I reckon that&#39;s about the size of it.  Don&#39;t mind my</div><div class='line' id='LC2385'>seeming excited; I&#39;m not.  Let us change the subject.  Now as</div><div class='line' id='LC2386'>to this castle, with forty-five princesses in it, and three ogres</div><div class='line' id='LC2387'>at the head of it, tell me--where is this harem?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2388'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2389'>&quot;Harem?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2390'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2391'>&quot;The _castle_, you understand; where is the castle?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2392'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2393'>&quot;Oh, as to that, it is great, and strong, and well beseen, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2394'>lieth in a far country.  Yes, it is many leagues.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2395'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2396'>&quot;_How_ many?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2397'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2398'>&quot;Ah, fair sir, it were woundily hard to tell, they are so many,</div><div class='line' id='LC2399'>and do so lap the one upon the other, and being made all in the</div><div class='line' id='LC2400'>same image and tincted with the same color, one may not know</div><div class='line' id='LC2401'>the one league from its fellow, nor how to count them except</div><div class='line' id='LC2402'>they be taken apart, and ye wit well it were God&#39;s work to do</div><div class='line' id='LC2403'>that, being not within man&#39;s capacity; for ye will note--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2404'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2405'>&quot;Hold on, hold on, never mind about the distance; _whereabouts_</div><div class='line' id='LC2406'>does the castle lie?  What&#39;s the direction from here?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2407'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2408'>&quot;Ah, please you sir, it hath no direction from here; by reason</div><div class='line' id='LC2409'>that the road lieth not straight, but turneth evermore; wherefore</div><div class='line' id='LC2410'>the direction of its place abideth not, but is some time under</div><div class='line' id='LC2411'>the one sky and anon under another, whereso if ye be minded that</div><div class='line' id='LC2412'>it is in the east, and wend thitherward, ye shall observe that</div><div class='line' id='LC2413'>the way of the road doth yet again turn upon itself by the space</div><div class='line' id='LC2414'>of half a circle, and this marvel happing again and yet again and</div><div class='line' id='LC2415'>still again, it will grieve you that you had thought by vanities</div><div class='line' id='LC2416'>of the mind to thwart and bring to naught the will of Him that</div><div class='line' id='LC2417'>giveth not a castle a direction from a place except it pleaseth</div><div class='line' id='LC2418'>Him, and if it please Him not, will the rather that even all castles</div><div class='line' id='LC2419'>and all directions thereunto vanish out of the earth, leaving the</div><div class='line' id='LC2420'>places wherein they tarried desolate and vacant, so warning His</div><div class='line' id='LC2421'>creatures that where He will He will, and where He will not He--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2422'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2423'>&quot;Oh, that&#39;s all right, that&#39;s all right, give us a rest; never mind</div><div class='line' id='LC2424'>about the direction, _hang_ the direction--I beg pardon, I beg</div><div class='line' id='LC2425'>a thousand pardons, I am not well to-day; pay no attention when</div><div class='line' id='LC2426'>I soliloquize, it is an old habit, an old, bad habit, and hard</div><div class='line' id='LC2427'>to get rid of when one&#39;s digestion is all disordered with eating</div><div class='line' id='LC2428'>food that was raised forever and ever before he was born; good</div><div class='line' id='LC2429'>land! a man can&#39;t keep his functions regular on spring chickens</div><div class='line' id='LC2430'>thirteen hundred years old.  But come--never mind about that;</div><div class='line' id='LC2431'>let&#39;s--have you got such a thing as a map of that region about</div><div class='line' id='LC2432'>you?  Now a good map--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2433'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2434'>&quot;Is it peradventure that manner of thing which of late the unbelievers</div><div class='line' id='LC2435'>have brought from over the great seas, which, being boiled in oil,</div><div class='line' id='LC2436'>and an onion and salt added thereto, doth--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2437'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2438'>&quot;What, a map?  What are you talking about?  Don&#39;t you know what</div><div class='line' id='LC2439'>a map is?  There, there, never mind, don&#39;t explain, I hate</div><div class='line' id='LC2440'>explanations; they fog a thing up so that you can&#39;t tell anything</div><div class='line' id='LC2441'>about it.  Run along, dear; good-day; show her the way, Clarence.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2442'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2443'>Oh, well, it was reasonably plain, now, why these donkeys didn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC2444'>prospect these liars for details.  It may be that this girl had</div><div class='line' id='LC2445'>a fact in her somewhere, but I don&#39;t believe you could have sluiced</div><div class='line' id='LC2446'>it out with a hydraulic; nor got it with the earlier forms of</div><div class='line' id='LC2447'>blasting, even; it was a case for dynamite.  Why, she was a perfect</div><div class='line' id='LC2448'>ass; and yet the king and his knights had listened to her as if</div><div class='line' id='LC2449'>she had been a leaf out of the gospel.  It kind of sizes up the</div><div class='line' id='LC2450'>whole party.  And think of the simple ways of this court: this</div><div class='line' id='LC2451'>wandering wench hadn&#39;t any more trouble to get access to the king</div><div class='line' id='LC2452'>in his palace than she would have had to get into the poorhouse</div><div class='line' id='LC2453'>in my day and country.  In fact, he was glad to see her, glad</div><div class='line' id='LC2454'>to hear her tale; with that adventure of hers to offer, she was</div><div class='line' id='LC2455'>as welcome as a corpse is to a coroner.</div><div class='line' id='LC2456'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2457'>Just as I was ending-up these reflections, Clarence came back.</div><div class='line' id='LC2458'>I remarked upon the barren result of my efforts with the girl;</div><div class='line' id='LC2459'>hadn&#39;t got hold of a single point that could help me to find</div><div class='line' id='LC2460'>the castle.  The youth looked a little surprised, or puzzled,</div><div class='line' id='LC2461'>or something, and intimated that he had been wondering to himself</div><div class='line' id='LC2462'>what I had wanted to ask the girl all those questions for.</div><div class='line' id='LC2463'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2464'>&quot;Why, great guns,&quot; I said, &quot;don&#39;t I want to find the castle?  And</div><div class='line' id='LC2465'>how else would I go about it?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2466'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2467'>&quot;La, sweet your worship, one may lightly answer that, I ween.</div><div class='line' id='LC2468'>She will go with thee.  They always do.  She will ride with thee.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2469'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2470'>&quot;Ride with me?  Nonsense!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2471'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2472'>&quot;But of a truth she will.  She will ride with thee.  Thou shalt see.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2473'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2474'>&quot;What?  She browse around the hills and scour the woods with me</div><div class='line' id='LC2475'>--alone--and I as good as engaged to be married?  Why, it&#39;s scandalous.</div><div class='line' id='LC2476'>Think how it would look.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2477'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2478'>My, the dear face that rose before me!  The boy was eager to know</div><div class='line' id='LC2479'>all about this tender matter.  I swore him to secrecy and then</div><div class='line' id='LC2480'>whispered her name--&quot;Puss Flanagan.&quot;  He looked disappointed,</div><div class='line' id='LC2481'>and said he didn&#39;t remember the countess.  How natural it was for</div><div class='line' id='LC2482'>the little courtier to give her a rank.  He asked me where she lived.</div><div class='line' id='LC2483'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2484'>&quot;In East Har--&quot; I came to myself and stopped, a little confused;</div><div class='line' id='LC2485'>then I said, &quot;Never mind, now; I&#39;ll tell you some time.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2486'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2487'>And might he see her?  Would I let him see her some day?</div><div class='line' id='LC2488'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2489'>It was but a little thing to promise--thirteen hundred years</div><div class='line' id='LC2490'>or so--and he so eager; so I said Yes.  But I sighed; I couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC2491'>help it.  And yet there was no sense in sighing, for she wasn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC2492'>born yet.  But that is the way we are made: we don&#39;t reason,</div><div class='line' id='LC2493'>where we feel; we just feel.</div><div class='line' id='LC2494'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2495'>My expedition was all the talk that day and that night, and the</div><div class='line' id='LC2496'>boys were very good to me, and made much of me, and seemed to have</div><div class='line' id='LC2497'>forgotten their vexation and disappointment, and come to be as</div><div class='line' id='LC2498'>anxious for me to hive those ogres and set those ripe old virgins</div><div class='line' id='LC2499'>loose as if it were themselves that had the contract.  Well, they</div><div class='line' id='LC2500'>_were_ good children--but just children, that is all.  And they</div><div class='line' id='LC2501'>gave me no end of points about how to scout for giants, and how</div><div class='line' id='LC2502'>to scoop them in; and they told me all sorts of charms against</div><div class='line' id='LC2503'>enchantments, and gave me salves and other rubbish to put on my</div><div class='line' id='LC2504'>wounds.  But it never occurred to one of them to reflect that if</div><div class='line' id='LC2505'>I was such a wonderful necromancer as I was pretending to be,</div><div class='line' id='LC2506'>I ought not to need salves or instructions, or charms against</div><div class='line' id='LC2507'>enchantments, and, least of all, arms and armor, on a foray of any</div><div class='line' id='LC2508'>kind--even against fire-spouting dragons, and devils hot from</div><div class='line' id='LC2509'>perdition, let alone such poor adversaries as these I was after,</div><div class='line' id='LC2510'>these commonplace ogres of the back settlements.</div><div class='line' id='LC2511'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2512'>I was to have an early breakfast, and start at dawn, for that was</div><div class='line' id='LC2513'>the usual way; but I had the demon&#39;s own time with my armor,</div><div class='line' id='LC2514'>and this delayed me a little.  It is troublesome to get into, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2515'>there is so much detail.  First you wrap a layer or two of blanket</div><div class='line' id='LC2516'>around your body, for a sort of cushion and to keep off the cold</div><div class='line' id='LC2517'>iron; then you put on your sleeves and shirt of chain mail--these</div><div class='line' id='LC2518'>are made of small steel links woven together, and they form a fabric</div><div class='line' id='LC2519'>so flexible that if you toss your shirt onto the floor, it slumps</div><div class='line' id='LC2520'>into a pile like a peck of wet fish-net; it is very heavy and</div><div class='line' id='LC2521'>is nearly the uncomfortablest material in the world for a night</div><div class='line' id='LC2522'>shirt, yet plenty used it for that--tax collectors, and reformers,</div><div class='line' id='LC2523'>and one-horse kings with a defective title, and those sorts of</div><div class='line' id='LC2524'>people; then you put on your shoes--flat-boats roofed over with</div><div class='line' id='LC2525'>interleaving bands of steel--and screw your clumsy spurs into</div><div class='line' id='LC2526'>the heels.  Next you buckle your greaves on your legs, and your</div><div class='line' id='LC2527'>cuisses on your thighs; then come your backplate and your breastplate,</div><div class='line' id='LC2528'>and you begin to feel crowded; then you hitch onto the breastplate</div><div class='line' id='LC2529'>the half-petticoat of broad overlapping bands of steel which hangs</div><div class='line' id='LC2530'>down in front but is scolloped out behind so you can sit down,</div><div class='line' id='LC2531'>and isn&#39;t any real improvement on an inverted coal scuttle, either</div><div class='line' id='LC2532'>for looks or for wear, or to wipe your hands on; next you belt</div><div class='line' id='LC2533'>on your sword; then you put your stove-pipe joints onto your arms,</div><div class='line' id='LC2534'>your iron gauntlets onto your hands, your iron rat-trap onto your</div><div class='line' id='LC2535'>head, with a rag of steel web hitched onto it to hang over the back</div><div class='line' id='LC2536'>of your neck--and there you are, snug as a candle in a candle-mould.</div><div class='line' id='LC2537'>This is no time to dance.  Well, a man that is packed away like</div><div class='line' id='LC2538'>that is a nut that isn&#39;t worth the cracking, there is so little of</div><div class='line' id='LC2539'>the meat, when you get down to it, by comparison with the shell.</div><div class='line' id='LC2540'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2541'>The boys helped me, or I never could have got in.  Just as we</div><div class='line' id='LC2542'>finished, Sir Bedivere happened in, and I saw that as like as not</div><div class='line' id='LC2543'>I hadn&#39;t chosen the most convenient outfit for a long trip.  How</div><div class='line' id='LC2544'>stately he looked; and tall and broad and grand.  He had on his</div><div class='line' id='LC2545'>head a conical steel casque that only came down to his ears, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2546'>for visor had only a narrow steel bar that extended down to his</div><div class='line' id='LC2547'>upper lip and protected his nose; and all the rest of him, from</div><div class='line' id='LC2548'>neck to heel, was flexible chain mail, trousers and all.  But</div><div class='line' id='LC2549'>pretty much all of him was hidden under his outside garment, which</div><div class='line' id='LC2550'>of course was of chain mail, as I said, and hung straight from his</div><div class='line' id='LC2551'>shoulders to his ankles; and from his middle to the bottom, both</div><div class='line' id='LC2552'>before and behind, was divided, so that he could ride and let the</div><div class='line' id='LC2553'>skirts hang down on each side.  He was going grailing, and it was</div><div class='line' id='LC2554'>just the outfit for it, too.  I would have given a good deal for</div><div class='line' id='LC2555'>that ulster, but it was too late now to be fooling around.  The sun</div><div class='line' id='LC2556'>was just up, the king and the court were all on hand to see me off</div><div class='line' id='LC2557'>and wish me luck; so it wouldn&#39;t be etiquette for me to tarry.</div><div class='line' id='LC2558'>You don&#39;t get on your horse yourself; no, if you tried it you</div><div class='line' id='LC2559'>would get disappointed.  They carry you out, just as they carry</div><div class='line' id='LC2560'>a sun-struck man to the drug store, and put you on, and help get</div><div class='line' id='LC2561'>you to rights, and fix your feet in the stirrups; and all the while</div><div class='line' id='LC2562'>you do feel so strange and stuffy and like somebody else--like</div><div class='line' id='LC2563'>somebody that has been married on a sudden, or struck by lightning,</div><div class='line' id='LC2564'>or something like that, and hasn&#39;t quite fetched around yet, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2565'>is sort of numb, and can&#39;t just get his bearings.  Then they</div><div class='line' id='LC2566'>stood up the mast they called a spear, in its socket by my left</div><div class='line' id='LC2567'>foot, and I gripped it with my hand; lastly they hung my shield</div><div class='line' id='LC2568'>around my neck, and I was all complete and ready to up anchor</div><div class='line' id='LC2569'>and get to sea.  Everybody was as good to me as they could be,</div><div class='line' id='LC2570'>and a maid of honor gave me the stirrup-cup her own self.  There was</div><div class='line' id='LC2571'>nothing more to do now, but for that damsel to get up behind me on</div><div class='line' id='LC2572'>a pillion, which she did, and put an arm or so around me to hold on.</div><div class='line' id='LC2573'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2574'>And so we started, and everybody gave us a goodbye and waved their</div><div class='line' id='LC2575'>handkerchiefs or helmets.  And everybody we met, going down the hill</div><div class='line' id='LC2576'>and through the village was respectful to us, except some shabby</div><div class='line' id='LC2577'>little boys on the outskirts.  They said:</div><div class='line' id='LC2578'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2579'>&quot;Oh, what a guy!&quot;  And hove clods at us.</div><div class='line' id='LC2580'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2581'>In my experience boys are the same in all ages.  They don&#39;t respect</div><div class='line' id='LC2582'>anything, they don&#39;t care for anything or anybody.  They say</div><div class='line' id='LC2583'>&quot;Go up, baldhead&quot; to the prophet going his unoffending way in</div><div class='line' id='LC2584'>the gray of antiquity; they sass me in the holy gloom of the</div><div class='line' id='LC2585'>Middle Ages; and I had seen them act the same way in Buchanan&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC2586'>administration; I remember, because I was there and helped.  The</div><div class='line' id='LC2587'>prophet had his bears and settled with his boys; and I wanted</div><div class='line' id='LC2588'>to get down and settle with mine, but it wouldn&#39;t answer, because</div><div class='line' id='LC2589'>I couldn&#39;t have got up again.  I hate a country without a derrick.</div><div class='line' id='LC2590'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2591'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2592'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2593'>CHAPTER XII</div><div class='line' id='LC2594'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2595'>SLOW TORTURE</div><div class='line' id='LC2596'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2597'>Straight off, we were in the country.  It was most lovely and</div><div class='line' id='LC2598'>pleasant in those sylvan solitudes in the early cool morning</div><div class='line' id='LC2599'>in the first freshness of autumn.  From hilltops we saw fair</div><div class='line' id='LC2600'>green valleys lying spread out below, with streams winding through</div><div class='line' id='LC2601'>them, and island groves of trees here and there, and huge lonely</div><div class='line' id='LC2602'>oaks scattered about and casting black blots of shade; and beyond</div><div class='line' id='LC2603'>the valleys we saw the ranges of hills, blue with haze, stretching</div><div class='line' id='LC2604'>away in billowy perspective to the horizon, with at wide intervals</div><div class='line' id='LC2605'>a dim fleck of white or gray on a wave-summit, which we knew was</div><div class='line' id='LC2606'>a castle.  We crossed broad natural lawns sparkling with dew,</div><div class='line' id='LC2607'>and we moved like spirits, the cushioned turf giving out no sound</div><div class='line' id='LC2608'>of footfall; we dreamed along through glades in a mist of green</div><div class='line' id='LC2609'>light that got its tint from the sun-drenched roof of leaves</div><div class='line' id='LC2610'>overhead, and by our feet the clearest and coldest of runlets</div><div class='line' id='LC2611'>went frisking and gossiping over its reefs and making a sort of</div><div class='line' id='LC2612'>whispering music, comfortable to hear; and at times we left the</div><div class='line' id='LC2613'>world behind and entered into the solemn great deeps and rich</div><div class='line' id='LC2614'>gloom of the forest, where furtive wild things whisked and scurried</div><div class='line' id='LC2615'>by and were gone before you could even get your eye on the place</div><div class='line' id='LC2616'>where the noise was; and where only the earliest birds were turning</div><div class='line' id='LC2617'>out and getting to business with a song here and a quarrel yonder</div><div class='line' id='LC2618'>and a mysterious far-off hammering and drumming for worms on</div><div class='line' id='LC2619'>a tree trunk away somewhere in the impenetrable remotenesses of</div><div class='line' id='LC2620'>the woods.  And by and by out we would swing again into the glare.</div><div class='line' id='LC2621'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2622'>About the third or fourth or fifth time that we swung out into</div><div class='line' id='LC2623'>the glare--it was along there somewhere, a couple of hours or so</div><div class='line' id='LC2624'>after sun-up--it wasn&#39;t as pleasant as it had been.  It was</div><div class='line' id='LC2625'>beginning to get hot.  This was quite noticeable.  We had a very</div><div class='line' id='LC2626'>long pull, after that, without any shade.  Now it is curious how</div><div class='line' id='LC2627'>progressively little frets grow and multiply after they once get</div><div class='line' id='LC2628'>a start.  Things which I didn&#39;t mind at all, at first, I began</div><div class='line' id='LC2629'>to mind now--and more and more, too, all the time.  The first</div><div class='line' id='LC2630'>ten or fifteen times I wanted my handkerchief I didn&#39;t seem to care;</div><div class='line' id='LC2631'>I got along, and said never mind, it isn&#39;t any matter, and dropped</div><div class='line' id='LC2632'>it out of my mind.  But now it was different; I wanted it all</div><div class='line' id='LC2633'>the time; it was nag, nag, nag, right along, and no rest; I couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC2634'>get it out of my mind; and so at last I lost my temper and said</div><div class='line' id='LC2635'>hang a man that would make a suit of armor without any pockets</div><div class='line' id='LC2636'>in it.  You see I had my handkerchief in my helmet; and some other</div><div class='line' id='LC2637'>things; but it was that kind of a helmet that you can&#39;t take off</div><div class='line' id='LC2638'>by yourself.  That hadn&#39;t occurred to me when I put it there;</div><div class='line' id='LC2639'>and in fact I didn&#39;t know it.  I supposed it would be particularly</div><div class='line' id='LC2640'>convenient there.  And so now, the thought of its being there,</div><div class='line' id='LC2641'>so handy and close by, and yet not get-at-able, made it all the</div><div class='line' id='LC2642'>worse and the harder to bear.  Yes, the thing that you can&#39;t get</div><div class='line' id='LC2643'>is the thing that you want, mainly; every one has noticed that.</div><div class='line' id='LC2644'>Well, it took my mind off from everything else; took it clear off,</div><div class='line' id='LC2645'>and centered it in my helmet; and mile after mile, there it stayed,</div><div class='line' id='LC2646'>imagining the handkerchief, picturing the handkerchief; and it</div><div class='line' id='LC2647'>was bitter and aggravating to have the salt sweat keep trickling</div><div class='line' id='LC2648'>down into my eyes, and I couldn&#39;t get at it.  It seems like a little</div><div class='line' id='LC2649'>thing, on paper, but it was not a little thing at all; it was</div><div class='line' id='LC2650'>the most real kind of misery.  I would not say it if it was not so.</div><div class='line' id='LC2651'>I made up my mind that I would carry along a reticule next time,</div><div class='line' id='LC2652'>let it look how it might, and people say what they would.  Of course</div><div class='line' id='LC2653'>these iron dudes of the Round Table would think it was scandalous,</div><div class='line' id='LC2654'>and maybe raise Sheol about it, but as for me, give me comfort</div><div class='line' id='LC2655'>first, and style afterwards.  So we jogged along, and now and then</div><div class='line' id='LC2656'>we struck a stretch of dust, and it would tumble up in clouds and</div><div class='line' id='LC2657'>get into my nose and make me sneeze and cry; and of course I said</div><div class='line' id='LC2658'>things I oughtn&#39;t to have said, I don&#39;t deny that.  I am not</div><div class='line' id='LC2659'>better than others.</div><div class='line' id='LC2660'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2661'>We couldn&#39;t seem to meet anybody in this lonesome Britain, not</div><div class='line' id='LC2662'>even an ogre; and, in the mood I was in then, it was well for</div><div class='line' id='LC2663'>the ogre; that is, an ogre with a handkerchief.  Most knights</div><div class='line' id='LC2664'>would have thought of nothing but getting his armor; but so I got</div><div class='line' id='LC2665'>his bandanna, he could keep his hardware, for all of me.</div><div class='line' id='LC2666'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2667'>Meantime, it was getting hotter and hotter in there.  You see,</div><div class='line' id='LC2668'>the sun was beating down and warming up the iron more and more</div><div class='line' id='LC2669'>all the time.  Well, when you are hot, that way, every little thing</div><div class='line' id='LC2670'>irritates you.  When I trotted, I rattled like a crate of dishes,</div><div class='line' id='LC2671'>and that annoyed me; and moreover I couldn&#39;t seem to stand that</div><div class='line' id='LC2672'>shield slatting and banging, now about my breast, now around my</div><div class='line' id='LC2673'>back; and if I dropped into a walk my joints creaked and screeched</div><div class='line' id='LC2674'>in that wearisome way that a wheelbarrow does, and as we didn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC2675'>create any breeze at that gait, I was like to get fried in that</div><div class='line' id='LC2676'>stove; and besides, the quieter you went the heavier the iron</div><div class='line' id='LC2677'>settled down on you and the more and more tons you seemed to weigh</div><div class='line' id='LC2678'>every minute.  And you had to be always changing hands, and passing</div><div class='line' id='LC2679'>your spear over to the other foot, it got so irksome for one hand</div><div class='line' id='LC2680'>to hold it long at a time.</div><div class='line' id='LC2681'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2682'>Well, you know, when you perspire that way, in rivers, there comes</div><div class='line' id='LC2683'>a time when you--when you--well, when you itch.  You are inside,</div><div class='line' id='LC2684'>your hands are outside; so there you are; nothing but iron between.</div><div class='line' id='LC2685'>It is not a light thing, let it sound as it may.  First it is one</div><div class='line' id='LC2686'>place; then another; then some more; and it goes on spreading and</div><div class='line' id='LC2687'>spreading, and at last the territory is all occupied, and nobody</div><div class='line' id='LC2688'>can imagine what you feel like, nor how unpleasant it is.
