And</div><div class='line' id='LC2689'>when it had got to the worst, and it seemed to me that I could</div><div class='line' id='LC2690'>not stand anything more, a fly got in through the bars and settled</div><div class='line' id='LC2691'>on my nose, and the bars were stuck and wouldn&#39;t work, and I</div><div class='line' id='LC2692'>couldn&#39;t get the visor up; and I could only shake my head, which</div><div class='line' id='LC2693'>was baking hot by this time, and the fly--well, you know how a fly</div><div class='line' id='LC2694'>acts when he has got a certainty--he only minded the shaking enough</div><div class='line' id='LC2695'>to change from nose to lip, and lip to ear, and buzz and buzz</div><div class='line' id='LC2696'>all around in there, and keep on lighting and biting, in a way</div><div class='line' id='LC2697'>that a person, already so distressed as I was, simply could not</div><div class='line' id='LC2698'>stand.  So I gave in, and got Alisande to unship the helmet and</div><div class='line' id='LC2699'>relieve me of it.  Then she emptied the conveniences out of it</div><div class='line' id='LC2700'>and fetched it full of water, and I drank and then stood up, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2701'>she poured the rest down inside the armor. One cannot think how</div><div class='line' id='LC2702'>refreshing it was.  She continued to fetch and pour until I was</div><div class='line' id='LC2703'>well soaked and thoroughly comfortable.</div><div class='line' id='LC2704'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2705'>It was good to have a rest--and peace.  But nothing is quite</div><div class='line' id='LC2706'>perfect in this life, at any time.  I had made a pipe a while back,</div><div class='line' id='LC2707'>and also some pretty fair tobacco; not the real thing, but what</div><div class='line' id='LC2708'>some of the Indians use: the inside bark of the willow, dried.</div><div class='line' id='LC2709'>These comforts had been in the helmet, and now I had them again,</div><div class='line' id='LC2710'>but no matches.</div><div class='line' id='LC2711'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2712'>Gradually, as the time wore along, one annoying fact was borne in</div><div class='line' id='LC2713'>upon my understanding--that we were weather-bound.  An armed novice</div><div class='line' id='LC2714'>cannot mount his horse without help and plenty of it.  Sandy was</div><div class='line' id='LC2715'>not enough; not enough for me, anyway.  We had to wait until</div><div class='line' id='LC2716'>somebody should come along.  Waiting, in silence, would have been</div><div class='line' id='LC2717'>agreeable enough, for I was full of matter for reflection, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2718'>wanted to give it a chance to work.  I wanted to try and think out</div><div class='line' id='LC2719'>how it was that rational or even half-rational men could ever</div><div class='line' id='LC2720'>have learned to wear armor, considering its inconveniences; and</div><div class='line' id='LC2721'>how they had managed to keep up such a fashion for generations</div><div class='line' id='LC2722'>when it was plain that what I had suffered to-day they had had</div><div class='line' id='LC2723'>to suffer all the days of their lives.  I wanted to think that out;</div><div class='line' id='LC2724'>and moreover I wanted to think out some way to reform this evil</div><div class='line' id='LC2725'>and persuade the people to let the foolish fashion die out; but</div><div class='line' id='LC2726'>thinking was out of the question in the circumstances.  You couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC2727'>think, where Sandy was.</div><div class='line' id='LC2728'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2729'>She was a quite biddable creature and good-hearted, but she had</div><div class='line' id='LC2730'>a flow of talk that was as steady as a mill, and made your head</div><div class='line' id='LC2731'>sore like the drays and wagons in a city.  If she had had a cork</div><div class='line' id='LC2732'>she would have been a comfort.  But you can&#39;t cork that kind;</div><div class='line' id='LC2733'>they would die.  Her clack was going all day, and you would think</div><div class='line' id='LC2734'>something would surely happen to her works, by and by; but no,</div><div class='line' id='LC2735'>they never got out of order; and she never had to slack up for</div><div class='line' id='LC2736'>words.  She could grind, and pump, and churn, and buzz by the week,</div><div class='line' id='LC2737'>and never stop to oil up or blow out.  And yet the result was just</div><div class='line' id='LC2738'>nothing but wind.  She never had any ideas, any more than a fog</div><div class='line' id='LC2739'>has.  She was a perfect blatherskite; I mean for jaw, jaw, jaw,</div><div class='line' id='LC2740'>talk, talk, talk, jabber, jabber, jabber; but just as good as she</div><div class='line' id='LC2741'>could be.  I hadn&#39;t minded her mill that morning, on account of</div><div class='line' id='LC2742'>having that hornets&#39; nest of other troubles; but more than once</div><div class='line' id='LC2743'>in the afternoon I had to say:</div><div class='line' id='LC2744'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2745'>&quot;Take a rest, child; the way you are using up all the domestic air,</div><div class='line' id='LC2746'>the kingdom will have to go to importing it by to-morrow, and it&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC2747'>a low enough treasury without that.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2748'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2749'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2750'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2751'>CHAPTER XIII</div><div class='line' id='LC2752'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2753'>FREEMEN</div><div class='line' id='LC2754'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2755'>Yes, it is strange how little a while at a time a person can be</div><div class='line' id='LC2756'>contented.  Only a little while back, when I was riding and</div><div class='line' id='LC2757'>suffering, what a heaven this peace, this rest, this sweet serenity</div><div class='line' id='LC2758'>in this secluded shady nook by this purling stream would have</div><div class='line' id='LC2759'>seemed, where I could keep perfectly comfortable all the time</div><div class='line' id='LC2760'>by pouring a dipper of water into my armor now and then; yet</div><div class='line' id='LC2761'>already I was getting dissatisfied; partly because I could not</div><div class='line' id='LC2762'>light my pipe--for, although I had long ago started a match factory,</div><div class='line' id='LC2763'>I had forgotten to bring matches with me--and partly because we</div><div class='line' id='LC2764'>had nothing to eat.  Here was another illustration of the childlike</div><div class='line' id='LC2765'>improvidence of this age and people.  A man in armor always trusted</div><div class='line' id='LC2766'>to chance for his food on a journey, and would have been scandalized</div><div class='line' id='LC2767'>at the idea of hanging a basket of sandwiches on his spear.  There</div><div class='line' id='LC2768'>was probably not a knight of all the Round Table combination who</div><div class='line' id='LC2769'>would not rather have died than been caught carrying such a thing</div><div class='line' id='LC2770'>as that on his flagstaff.  And yet there could not be anything more</div><div class='line' id='LC2771'>sensible.  It had been my intention to smuggle a couple of sandwiches</div><div class='line' id='LC2772'>into my helmet, but I was interrupted in the act, and had to make</div><div class='line' id='LC2773'>an excuse and lay them aside, and a dog got them.</div><div class='line' id='LC2774'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2775'>Night approached, and with it a storm.  The darkness came on fast.</div><div class='line' id='LC2776'>We must camp, of course.  I found a good shelter for the demoiselle</div><div class='line' id='LC2777'>under a rock, and went off and found another for myself.  But</div><div class='line' id='LC2778'>I was obliged to remain in my armor, because I could not get it off</div><div class='line' id='LC2779'>by myself and yet could not allow Alisande to help, because it</div><div class='line' id='LC2780'>would have seemed so like undressing before folk.  It would not</div><div class='line' id='LC2781'>have amounted to that in reality, because I had clothes on</div><div class='line' id='LC2782'>underneath; but the prejudices of one&#39;s breeding are not gotten</div><div class='line' id='LC2783'>rid of just at a jump, and I knew that when it came to stripping</div><div class='line' id='LC2784'>off that bob-tailed iron petticoat I should be embarrassed.</div><div class='line' id='LC2785'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2786'>With the storm came a change of weather; and the stronger the wind</div><div class='line' id='LC2787'>blew, and the wilder the rain lashed around, the colder and colder</div><div class='line' id='LC2788'>it got.  Pretty soon, various kinds of bugs and ants and worms</div><div class='line' id='LC2789'>and things began to flock in out of the wet and crawl down inside</div><div class='line' id='LC2790'>my armor to get warm; and while some of them behaved well enough,</div><div class='line' id='LC2791'>and snuggled up amongst my clothes and got quiet, the majority</div><div class='line' id='LC2792'>were of a restless, uncomfortable sort, and never stayed still,</div><div class='line' id='LC2793'>but went on prowling and hunting for they did not know what;</div><div class='line' id='LC2794'>especially the ants, which went tickling along in wearisome</div><div class='line' id='LC2795'>procession from one end of me to the other by the hour, and are</div><div class='line' id='LC2796'>a kind of creatures which I never wish to sleep with again.</div><div class='line' id='LC2797'>It would be my advice to persons situated in this way, to not roll</div><div class='line' id='LC2798'>or thrash around, because this excites the interest of all the</div><div class='line' id='LC2799'>different sorts of animals and makes every last one of them want</div><div class='line' id='LC2800'>to turn out and see what is going on, and this makes things worse</div><div class='line' id='LC2801'>than they were before, and of course makes you objurgate harder,</div><div class='line' id='LC2802'>too, if you can.  Still, if one did not roll and thrash around</div><div class='line' id='LC2803'>he would die; so perhaps it is as well to do one way as the other;</div><div class='line' id='LC2804'>there is no real choice.  Even after I was frozen solid I could</div><div class='line' id='LC2805'>still distinguish that tickling, just as a corpse does when he is</div><div class='line' id='LC2806'>taking electric treatment.  I said I would never wear armor</div><div class='line' id='LC2807'>after this trip.</div><div class='line' id='LC2808'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2809'>All those trying hours whilst I was frozen and yet was in a living</div><div class='line' id='LC2810'>fire, as you may say, on account of that swarm of crawlers, that</div><div class='line' id='LC2811'>same unanswerable question kept circling and circling through my</div><div class='line' id='LC2812'>tired head: How do people stand this miserable armor?  How have</div><div class='line' id='LC2813'>they managed to stand it all these generations?  How can they sleep</div><div class='line' id='LC2814'>at night for dreading the tortures of next day?</div><div class='line' id='LC2815'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2816'>When the morning came at last, I was in a bad enough plight: seedy,</div><div class='line' id='LC2817'>drowsy, fagged, from want of sleep; weary from thrashing around,</div><div class='line' id='LC2818'>famished from long fasting; pining for a bath, and to get rid of</div><div class='line' id='LC2819'>the animals; and crippled with rheumatism.  And how had it fared</div><div class='line' id='LC2820'>with the nobly born, the titled aristocrat, the Demoiselle Alisande</div><div class='line' id='LC2821'>la Carteloise?  Why, she was as fresh as a squirrel; she had slept</div><div class='line' id='LC2822'>like the dead; and as for a bath, probably neither she nor any</div><div class='line' id='LC2823'>other noble in the land had ever had one, and so she was not</div><div class='line' id='LC2824'>missing it.  Measured by modern standards, they were merely modified</div><div class='line' id='LC2825'>savages, those people.  This noble lady showed no impatience to get</div><div class='line' id='LC2826'>to breakfast--and that smacks of the savage, too.  On their journeys</div><div class='line' id='LC2827'>those Britons were used to long fasts, and knew how to bear them;</div><div class='line' id='LC2828'>and also how to freight up against probable fasts before starting,</div><div class='line' id='LC2829'>after the style of the Indian and the anaconda.  As like as not,</div><div class='line' id='LC2830'>Sandy was loaded for a three-day stretch.</div><div class='line' id='LC2831'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2832'>We were off before sunrise, Sandy riding and I limping along</div><div class='line' id='LC2833'>behind.  In half an hour we came upon a group of ragged poor</div><div class='line' id='LC2834'>creatures who had assembled to mend the thing which was regarded</div><div class='line' id='LC2835'>as a road.  They were as humble as animals to me; and when I</div><div class='line' id='LC2836'>proposed to breakfast with them, they were so flattered, so</div><div class='line' id='LC2837'>overwhelmed by this extraordinary condescension of mine that</div><div class='line' id='LC2838'>at first they were not able to believe that I was in earnest.</div><div class='line' id='LC2839'>My lady put up her scornful lip and withdrew to one side; she said</div><div class='line' id='LC2840'>in their hearing that she would as soon think of eating with the</div><div class='line' id='LC2841'>other cattle--a remark which embarrassed these poor devils merely</div><div class='line' id='LC2842'>because it referred to them, and not because it insulted or offended</div><div class='line' id='LC2843'>them, for it didn&#39;t.  And yet they were not slaves, not chattels.</div><div class='line' id='LC2844'>By a sarcasm of law and phrase they were freemen.  Seven-tenths</div><div class='line' id='LC2845'>of the free population of the country were of just their class and</div><div class='line' id='LC2846'>degree: small &quot;independent&quot; farmers, artisans, etc.; which is</div><div class='line' id='LC2847'>to say, they were the nation, the actual Nation; they were about</div><div class='line' id='LC2848'>all of it that was useful, or worth saving, or really respect-worthy,</div><div class='line' id='LC2849'>and to subtract them would have been to subtract the Nation and</div><div class='line' id='LC2850'>leave behind some dregs, some refuse, in the shape of a king,</div><div class='line' id='LC2851'>nobility and gentry, idle, unproductive, acquainted mainly with</div><div class='line' id='LC2852'>the arts of wasting and destroying, and of no sort of use or value</div><div class='line' id='LC2853'>in any rationally constructed world.  And yet, by ingenious</div><div class='line' id='LC2854'>contrivance, this gilded minority, instead of being in the tail</div><div class='line' id='LC2855'>of the procession where it belonged, was marching head up and</div><div class='line' id='LC2856'>banners flying, at the other end of it; had elected itself to be</div><div class='line' id='LC2857'>the Nation, and these innumerable clams had permitted it so long</div><div class='line' id='LC2858'>that they had come at last to accept it as a truth; and not only</div><div class='line' id='LC2859'>that, but to believe it right and as it should be.  The priests</div><div class='line' id='LC2860'>had told their fathers and themselves that this ironical state</div><div class='line' id='LC2861'>of things was ordained of God; and so, not reflecting upon how</div><div class='line' id='LC2862'>unlike God it would be to amuse himself with sarcasms, and especially</div><div class='line' id='LC2863'>such poor transparent ones as this, they had dropped the matter</div><div class='line' id='LC2864'>there and become respectfully quiet.</div><div class='line' id='LC2865'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2866'>The talk of these meek people had a strange enough sound in</div><div class='line' id='LC2867'>a formerly American ear.  They were freemen, but they could not</div><div class='line' id='LC2868'>leave the estates of their lord or their bishop without his</div><div class='line' id='LC2869'>permission; they could not prepare their own bread, but must have</div><div class='line' id='LC2870'>their corn ground and their bread baked at his mill and his bakery,</div><div class='line' id='LC2871'>and pay roundly for the same; they could not sell a piece of their</div><div class='line' id='LC2872'>own property without paying him a handsome percentage of the</div><div class='line' id='LC2873'>proceeds, nor buy a piece of somebody else&#39;s without remembering</div><div class='line' id='LC2874'>him in cash for the privilege; they had to harvest his grain for him</div><div class='line' id='LC2875'>gratis, and be ready to come at a moment&#39;s notice, leaving their</div><div class='line' id='LC2876'>own crop to destruction by the threatened storm; they had to let</div><div class='line' id='LC2877'>him plant fruit trees in their fields, and then keep their indignation</div><div class='line' id='LC2878'>to themselves when his heedless fruit-gatherers trampled the grain</div><div class='line' id='LC2879'>around the trees; they had to smother their anger when his hunting</div><div class='line' id='LC2880'>parties galloped through their fields laying waste the result of</div><div class='line' id='LC2881'>their patient toil; they were not allowed to keep doves themselves,</div><div class='line' id='LC2882'>and when the swarms from my lord&#39;s dovecote settled on their crops</div><div class='line' id='LC2883'>they must not lose their temper and kill a bird, for awful would</div><div class='line' id='LC2884'>the penalty be; when the harvest was at last gathered, then came</div><div class='line' id='LC2885'>the procession of robbers to levy their blackmail upon it: first</div><div class='line' id='LC2886'>the Church carted off its fat tenth, then the king&#39;s commissioner</div><div class='line' id='LC2887'>took his twentieth, then my lord&#39;s people made a mighty inroad</div><div class='line' id='LC2888'>upon the remainder; after which, the skinned freeman had liberty</div><div class='line' id='LC2889'>to bestow the remnant in his barn, in case it was worth the trouble;</div><div class='line' id='LC2890'>there were taxes, and taxes, and taxes, and more taxes, and taxes</div><div class='line' id='LC2891'>again, and yet other taxes--upon this free and independent pauper,</div><div class='line' id='LC2892'>but none upon his lord the baron or the bishop, none upon the</div><div class='line' id='LC2893'>wasteful nobility or the all-devouring Church; if the baron would</div><div class='line' id='LC2894'>sleep unvexed, the freeman must sit up all night after his day&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC2895'>work and whip the ponds to keep the frogs quiet; if the freeman&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC2896'>daughter--but no, that last infamy of monarchical government is</div><div class='line' id='LC2897'>unprintable; and finally, if the freeman, grown desperate with his</div><div class='line' id='LC2898'>tortures, found his life unendurable under such conditions, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2899'>sacrificed it and fled to death for mercy and refuge, the gentle</div><div class='line' id='LC2900'>Church condemned him to eternal fire, the gentle law buried him</div><div class='line' id='LC2901'>at midnight at the cross-roads with a stake through his back,</div><div class='line' id='LC2902'>and his master the baron or the bishop confiscated all his property</div><div class='line' id='LC2903'>and turned his widow and his orphans out of doors.</div><div class='line' id='LC2904'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2905'>And here were these freemen assembled in the early morning to work</div><div class='line' id='LC2906'>on their lord the bishop&#39;s road three days each--gratis; every</div><div class='line' id='LC2907'>head of a family, and every son of a family, three days each,</div><div class='line' id='LC2908'>gratis, and a day or so added for their servants.  Why, it was</div><div class='line' id='LC2909'>like reading about France and the French, before the ever memorable</div><div class='line' id='LC2910'>and blessed Revolution, which swept a thousand years of such</div><div class='line' id='LC2911'>villany away in one swift tidal-wave of blood--one: a settlement</div><div class='line' id='LC2912'>of that hoary debt in the proportion of half a drop of blood for</div><div class='line' id='LC2913'>each hogshead of it that had been pressed by slow tortures out of</div><div class='line' id='LC2914'>that people in the weary stretch of ten centuries of wrong and</div><div class='line' id='LC2915'>shame and misery the like of which was not to be mated but in hell.</div><div class='line' id='LC2916'>There were two &quot;Reigns of Terror,&quot; if we would but remember it</div><div class='line' id='LC2917'>and consider it; the one wrought murder in hot passion, the other</div><div class='line' id='LC2918'>in heartless cold blood; the one lasted mere months, the other had</div><div class='line' id='LC2919'>lasted a thousand years; the one inflicted death upon ten thousand</div><div class='line' id='LC2920'>persons, the other upon a hundred millions; but our shudders are</div><div class='line' id='LC2921'>all for the &quot;horrors&quot; of the minor Terror, the momentary Terror,</div><div class='line' id='LC2922'>so to speak; whereas, what is the horror of swift death by the axe,</div><div class='line' id='LC2923'>compared with lifelong death from hunger, cold, insult, cruelty,</div><div class='line' id='LC2924'>and heart-break?  What is swift death by lightning compared with</div><div class='line' id='LC2925'>death by slow fire at the stake?  A city cemetery could contain the</div><div class='line' id='LC2926'>coffins filled by that brief Terror which we have all been so</div><div class='line' id='LC2927'>diligently taught to shiver at and mourn over; but all France could</div><div class='line' id='LC2928'>hardly contain the coffins filled by that older and real Terror</div><div class='line' id='LC2929'>--that unspeakably bitter and awful Terror which none of us has</div><div class='line' id='LC2930'>been taught to see in its vastness or pity as it deserves.</div><div class='line' id='LC2931'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2932'>These poor ostensible freemen who were sharing their breakfast</div><div class='line' id='LC2933'>and their talk with me, were as full of humble reverence for their</div><div class='line' id='LC2934'>king and Church and nobility as their worst enemy could desire.</div><div class='line' id='LC2935'>There was something pitifully ludicrous about it.  I asked them</div><div class='line' id='LC2936'>if they supposed a nation of people ever existed, who, with a free</div><div class='line' id='LC2937'>vote in every man&#39;s hand, would elect that a single family and its</div><div class='line' id='LC2938'>descendants should reign over it forever, whether gifted or boobies,</div><div class='line' id='LC2939'>to the exclusion of all other families--including the voter&#39;s; and</div><div class='line' id='LC2940'>would also elect that a certain hundred families should be raised</div><div class='line' id='LC2941'>to dizzy summits of rank, and clothed on with offensive transmissible</div><div class='line' id='LC2942'>glories and privileges to the exclusion of the rest of the nation&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC2943'>families--_including his own_.</div><div class='line' id='LC2944'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2945'>They all looked unhit, and said they didn&#39;t know; that they had</div><div class='line' id='LC2946'>never thought about it before, and it hadn&#39;t ever occurred to them</div><div class='line' id='LC2947'>that a nation could be so situated that every man _could_ have</div><div class='line' id='LC2948'>a say in the government.  I said I had seen one--and that it would</div><div class='line' id='LC2949'>last until it had an Established Church.  Again they were all</div><div class='line' id='LC2950'>unhit--at first.  But presently one man looked up and asked me</div><div class='line' id='LC2951'>to state that proposition again; and state it slowly, so it could</div><div class='line' id='LC2952'>soak into his understanding.  I did it; and after a little he had</div><div class='line' id='LC2953'>the idea, and he brought his fist down and said _he_ didn&#39;t believe</div><div class='line' id='LC2954'>a nation where every man had a vote would voluntarily get down</div><div class='line' id='LC2955'>in the mud and dirt in any such way; and that to steal from a nation</div><div class='line' id='LC2956'>its will and preference must be a crime and the first of all crimes.</div><div class='line' id='LC2957'>I said to myself:</div><div class='line' id='LC2958'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2959'>&quot;This one&#39;s a man.  If I were backed by enough of his sort, I would</div><div class='line' id='LC2960'>make a strike for the welfare of this country, and try to prove</div><div class='line' id='LC2961'>myself its loyalest citizen by making a wholesome change in its</div><div class='line' id='LC2962'>system of government.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2963'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2964'>You see my kind of loyalty was loyalty to one&#39;s country, not to</div><div class='line' id='LC2965'>its institutions or its office-holders.  The country is the real</div><div class='line' id='LC2966'>thing, the substantial thing, the eternal thing; it is the thing</div><div class='line' id='LC2967'>to watch over, and care for, and be loyal to; institutions are</div><div class='line' id='LC2968'>extraneous, they are its mere clothing, and clothing can wear out,</div><div class='line' id='LC2969'>become ragged, cease to be comfortable, cease to protect the body</div><div class='line' id='LC2970'>from winter, disease, and death.  To be loyal to rags, to shout</div><div class='line' id='LC2971'>for rags, to worship rags, to die for rags--that is a loyalty</div><div class='line' id='LC2972'>of unreason, it is pure animal; it belongs to monarchy, was invented</div><div class='line' id='LC2973'>by monarchy; let monarchy keep it.  I was from Connecticut, whose</div><div class='line' id='LC2974'>Constitution declares &quot;that all political power is inherent in</div><div class='line' id='LC2975'>the people, and all free governments are founded on their authority</div><div class='line' id='LC2976'>and instituted for their benefit; and that they have _at all times_</div><div class='line' id='LC2977'>an undeniable and indefeasible right to _alter their form of</div><div class='line' id='LC2978'>government_ in such a manner as they may think expedient.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC2979'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2980'>Under that gospel, the citizen who thinks he sees that the</div><div class='line' id='LC2981'>commonwealth&#39;s political clothes are worn out, and yet holds his</div><div class='line' id='LC2982'>peace and does not agitate for a new suit, is disloyal; he is</div><div class='line' id='LC2983'>a traitor.  That he may be the only one who thinks he sees this</div><div class='line' id='LC2984'>decay, does not excuse him; it is his duty to agitate anyway, and</div><div class='line' id='LC2985'>it is the duty of the others to vote him down if they do not see</div><div class='line' id='LC2986'>the matter as he does.</div><div class='line' id='LC2987'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC2988'>And now here I was, in a country where a right to say how the</div><div class='line' id='LC2989'>country should be governed was restricted to six persons in each</div><div class='line' id='LC2990'>thousand of its population.  For the nine hundred and ninety-four</div><div class='line' id='LC2991'>to express dissatisfaction with the regnant system and propose</div><div class='line' id='LC2992'>to change it, would have made the whole six shudder as one man,</div><div class='line' id='LC2993'>it would have been so disloyal, so dishonorable, such putrid black</div><div class='line' id='LC2994'>treason.  So to speak, I was become a stockholder in a corporation</div><div class='line' id='LC2995'>where nine hundred and ninety-four of the members furnished all</div><div class='line' id='LC2996'>the money and did all the work, and the other six elected themselves</div><div class='line' id='LC2997'>a permanent board of direction and took all the dividends.  It seemed</div><div class='line' id='LC2998'>to me that what the nine hundred and ninety-four dupes needed was</div><div class='line' id='LC2999'>a new deal.  The thing that would have best suited the circus side</div><div class='line' id='LC3000'>of my nature would have been to resign the Boss-ship and get up</div><div class='line' id='LC3001'>an insurrection and turn it into a revolution; but I knew that the</div><div class='line' id='LC3002'>Jack Cade or the Wat Tyler who tries such a thing without first</div><div class='line' id='LC3003'>educating his materials up to revolution grade is almost absolutely</div><div class='line' id='LC3004'>certain to get left.  I had never been accustomed to getting left,</div><div class='line' id='LC3005'>even if I do say it myself.  Wherefore, the &quot;deal&quot; which had been</div><div class='line' id='LC3006'>for some time working into shape in my mind was of a quite different</div><div class='line' id='LC3007'>pattern from the Cade-Tyler sort.</div><div class='line' id='LC3008'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3009'>So I did not talk blood and insurrection to that man there who sat</div><div class='line' id='LC3010'>munching black bread with that abused and mistaught herd of human</div><div class='line' id='LC3011'>sheep, but took him aside and talked matter of another sort to him.</div><div class='line' id='LC3012'>After I had finished, I got him to lend me a little ink from his</div><div class='line' id='LC3013'>veins; and with this and a sliver I wrote on a piece of bark--</div><div class='line' id='LC3014'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3015'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Put him in the Man-factory--</div><div class='line' id='LC3016'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3017'>and gave it to him, and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC3018'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3019'>&quot;Take it to the palace at Camelot and give it into the hands of</div><div class='line' id='LC3020'>Amyas le Poulet, whom I call Clarence, and he will understand.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3021'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3022'>&quot;He is a priest, then,&quot; said the man, and some of the enthusiasm</div><div class='line' id='LC3023'>went out of his face.</div><div class='line' id='LC3024'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3025'>&quot;How--a priest?  Didn&#39;t I tell you that no chattel of the Church,</div><div class='line' id='LC3026'>no bond-slave of pope or bishop can enter my Man-Factory?  Didn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC3027'>I tell you that _you_ couldn&#39;t enter unless your religion, whatever</div><div class='line' id='LC3028'>it might be, was your own free property?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3029'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3030'>&quot;Marry, it is so, and for that I was glad; wherefore it liked me not,</div><div class='line' id='LC3031'>and bred in me a cold doubt, to hear of this priest being there.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3032'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3033'>&quot;But he isn&#39;t a priest, I tell you.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3034'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3035'>The man looked far from satisfied.  He said:</div><div class='line' id='LC3036'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3037'>&quot;He is not a priest, and yet can read?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3038'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3039'>&quot;He is not a priest and yet can read--yes, and write, too, for that</div><div class='line' id='LC3040'>matter.  I taught him myself.&quot; The man&#39;s face cleared.  &quot;And it is</div><div class='line' id='LC3041'>the first thing that you yourself will be taught in that Factory--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3042'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3043'>&quot;I?  I would give blood out of my heart to know that art.  Why,</div><div class='line' id='LC3044'>I will be your slave, your--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3045'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3046'>&quot;No you won&#39;t, you won&#39;t be anybody&#39;s slave.  Take your family</div><div class='line' id='LC3047'>and go along.  Your lord the bishop will confiscate your small</div><div class='line' id='LC3048'>property, but no matter.  Clarence will fix you all right.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3049'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3050'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3051'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3052'>CHAPTER XIV</div><div class='line' id='LC3053'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3054'>&quot;DEFEND THEE, LORD&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3055'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3056'>I paid three pennies for my breakfast, and a most extravagant</div><div class='line' id='LC3057'>price it was, too, seeing that one could have breakfasted a dozen</div><div class='line' id='LC3058'>persons for that money; but I was feeling good by this time, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3059'>I had always been a kind of spendthrift anyway; and then these</div><div class='line' id='LC3060'>people had wanted to give me the food for nothing, scant as</div><div class='line' id='LC3061'>their provision was, and so it was a grateful pleasure to emphasize</div><div class='line' id='LC3062'>my appreciation and sincere thankfulness with a good big financial</div><div class='line' id='LC3063'>lift where the money would do so much more good than it would</div><div class='line' id='LC3064'>in my helmet, where, these pennies being made of iron and not</div><div class='line' id='LC3065'>stinted in weight, my half-dollar&#39;s worth was a good deal of a</div><div class='line' id='LC3066'>burden to me.  I spent money rather too freely in those days,</div><div class='line' id='LC3067'>it is true; but one reason for it was that I hadn&#39;t got the</div><div class='line' id='LC3068'>proportions of things entirely adjusted, even yet, after so long</div><div class='line' id='LC3069'>a sojourn in Britain--hadn&#39;t got along to where I was able to</div><div class='line' id='LC3070'>absolutely realize that a penny in Arthur&#39;s land and a couple of</div><div class='line' id='LC3071'>dollars in Connecticut were about one and the same thing: just</div><div class='line' id='LC3072'>twins, as you may say, in purchasing power.  If my start from</div><div class='line' id='LC3073'>Camelot could have been delayed a very few days I could have paid</div><div class='line' id='LC3074'>these people in beautiful new coins from our own mint, and that</div><div class='line' id='LC3075'>would have pleased me; and them, too, not less.  I had adopted</div><div class='line' id='LC3076'>the American values exclusively.  In a week or two now, cents,</div><div class='line' id='LC3077'>nickels, dimes, quarters, and half-dollars, and also a trifle of</div><div class='line' id='LC3078'>gold, would be trickling in thin but steady streams all through</div><div class='line' id='LC3079'>the commercial veins of the kingdom, and I looked to see this</div><div class='line' id='LC3080'>new blood freshen up its life.</div><div class='line' id='LC3081'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3082'>The farmers were bound to throw in something, to sort of offset</div><div class='line' id='LC3083'>my liberality, whether I would or no; so I let them give me a flint</div><div class='line' id='LC3084'>and steel; and as soon as they had comfortably bestowed Sandy</div><div class='line' id='LC3085'>and me on our horse, I lit my pipe.  When the first blast of smoke</div><div class='line' id='LC3086'>shot out through the bars of my helmet, all those people broke</div><div class='line' id='LC3087'>for the woods, and Sandy went over backwards and struck the ground</div><div class='line' id='LC3088'>with a dull thud.  They thought I was one of those fire-belching</div><div class='line' id='LC3089'>dragons they had heard so much about from knights and other</div><div class='line' id='LC3090'>professional liars.  I had infinite trouble to persuade those people</div><div class='line' id='LC3091'>to venture back within explaining distance.  Then I told them that</div><div class='line' id='LC3092'>this was only a bit of enchantment which would work harm to none</div><div class='line' id='LC3093'>but my enemies.  And I promised, with my hand on my heart, that</div><div class='line' id='LC3094'>if all who felt no enmity toward me would come forward and pass</div><div class='line' id='LC3095'>before me they should see that only those who remained behind would</div><div class='line' id='LC3096'>be struck dead.  The procession moved with a good deal of promptness.</div><div class='line' id='LC3097'>There were no casualties to report, for nobody had curiosity enough</div><div class='line' id='LC3098'>to remain behind to see what would happen.</div><div class='line' id='LC3099'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3100'>I lost some time, now, for these big children, their fears gone,</div><div class='line' id='LC3101'>became so ravished with wonder over my awe-compelling fireworks</div><div class='line' id='LC3102'>that I had to stay there and smoke a couple of pipes out before</div><div class='line' id='LC3103'>they would let me go.  Still the delay was not wholly unproductive,</div><div class='line' id='LC3104'>for it took all that time to get Sandy thoroughly wonted to the new</div><div class='line' id='LC3105'>thing, she being so close to it, you know.  It plugged up her</div><div class='line' id='LC3106'>conversation mill, too, for a considerable while, and that was</div><div class='line' id='LC3107'>a gain.  But above all other benefits accruing, I had learned</div><div class='line' id='LC3108'>something.  I was ready for any giant or any ogre that might come</div><div class='line' id='LC3109'>along, now.</div><div class='line' id='LC3110'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3111'>We tarried with a holy hermit, that night, and my opportunity</div><div class='line' id='LC3112'>came about the middle of the next afternoon.  We were crossing</div><div class='line' id='LC3113'>a vast meadow by way of short-cut, and I was musing absently,</div><div class='line' id='LC3114'>hearing nothing, seeing nothing, when Sandy suddenly interrupted</div><div class='line' id='LC3115'>a remark which she had begun that morning, with the cry:</div><div class='line' id='LC3116'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3117'>&quot;Defend thee, lord!--peril of life is toward!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3118'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3119'>And she slipped down from the horse and ran a little way and stood.</div><div class='line' id='LC3120'>I looked up and saw, far off in the shade of a tree, half a dozen</div><div class='line' id='LC3121'>armed knights and their squires; and straightway there was bustle</div><div class='line' id='LC3122'>among them and tightening of saddle-girths for the mount.  My pipe</div><div class='line' id='LC3123'>was ready and would have been lit, if I had not been lost in</div><div class='line' id='LC3124'>thinking about how to banish oppression from this land and restore</div><div class='line' id='LC3125'>to all its people their stolen rights and manhood without disobliging</div><div class='line' id='LC3126'>anybody.  I lit up at once, and by the time I had got a good head</div><div class='line' id='LC3127'>of reserved steam on, here they came.  All together, too; none of</div><div class='line' id='LC3128'>those chivalrous magnanimities which one reads so much about</div><div class='line' id='LC3129'>--one courtly rascal at a time, and the rest standing by to see fair</div><div class='line' id='LC3130'>play.  No, they came in a body, they came with a whirr and a rush,</div><div class='line' id='LC3131'>they came like a volley from a battery; came with heads low down,</div><div class='line' id='LC3132'>plumes streaming out behind, lances advanced at a level.  It was</div><div class='line' id='LC3133'>a handsome sight, a beautiful sight--for a man up a tree.  I laid</div><div class='line' id='LC3134'>my lance in rest and waited, with my heart beating, till the iron</div><div class='line' id='LC3135'>wave was just ready to break over me, then spouted a column of</div><div class='line' id='LC3136'>white smoke through the bars of my helmet.  You should have seen</div><div class='line' id='LC3137'>the wave go to pieces and scatter!  This was a finer sight than</div><div class='line' id='LC3138'>the other one.</div><div class='line' id='LC3139'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3140'>But these people stopped, two or three hundred yards away, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3141'>this troubled me.  My satisfaction collapsed, and fear came;</div><div class='line' id='LC3142'>I judged I was a lost man.  But Sandy was radiant; and was going</div><div class='line' id='LC3143'>to be eloquent--but I stopped her, and told her my magic had</div><div class='line' id='LC3144'>miscarried, somehow or other, and she must mount, with all despatch,</div><div class='line' id='LC3145'>and we must ride for life.  No, she wouldn&#39;t.  She said that my</div><div class='line' id='LC3146'>enchantment had disabled those knights; they were not riding on,</div><div class='line' id='LC3147'>because they couldn&#39;t; wait, they would drop out of their saddles</div><div class='line' id='LC3148'>presently, and we would get their horses and harness.  I could not</div><div class='line' id='LC3149'>deceive such trusting simplicity, so I said it was a mistake; that</div><div class='line' id='LC3150'>when my fireworks killed at all, they killed instantly; no, the men</div><div class='line' id='LC3151'>would not die, there was something wrong about my apparatus,</div><div class='line' id='LC3152'>I couldn&#39;t tell what; but we must hurry and get away, for those</div><div class='line' id='LC3153'>people would attack us again, in a minute.  Sandy laughed, and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC3154'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3155'>&quot;Lack-a-day, sir, they be not of that breed!  Sir Launcelot will</div><div class='line' id='LC3156'>give battle to dragons, and will abide by them, and will assail</div><div class='line' id='LC3157'>them again, and yet again, and still again, until he do conquer</div><div class='line' id='LC3158'>and destroy them; and so likewise will Sir Pellinore and Sir Aglovale</div><div class='line' id='LC3159'>and Sir Carados, and mayhap others, but there be none else that</div><div class='line' id='LC3160'>will venture it, let the idle say what the idle will.  And, la,</div><div class='line' id='LC3161'>as to yonder base rufflers, think ye they have not their fill,</div><div class='line' id='LC3162'>but yet desire more?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3163'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3164'>&quot;Well, then, what are they waiting for?  Why don&#39;t they leave?</div><div class='line' id='LC3165'>Nobody&#39;s hindering.  Good land, I&#39;m willing to let bygones be</div><div class='line' id='LC3166'>bygones, I&#39;m sure.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3167'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3168'>&quot;Leave, is it?  Oh, give thyself easement as to that.  They dream</div><div class='line' id='LC3169'>not of it, no, not they.  They wait to yield them.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3170'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3171'>&quot;Come--really, is that &#39;sooth&#39;--as you people say?  If they want to,</div><div class='line' id='LC3172'>why don&#39;t they?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3173'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3174'>&quot;It would like them much; but an ye wot how dragons are esteemed,</div><div class='line' id='LC3175'>ye would not hold them blamable. They fear to come.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3176'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3177'>&quot;Well, then, suppose I go to them instead, and--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3178'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3179'>&quot;Ah, wit ye well they would not abide your coming.  I will go.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3180'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3181'>And she did.  She was a handy person to have along on a raid.</div><div class='line' id='LC3182'>I would have considered this a doubtful errand, myself.  I presently</div><div class='line' id='LC3183'>saw the knights riding away, and Sandy coming back.  That was</div><div class='line' id='LC3184'>a relief.  I judged she had somehow failed to get the first innings</div><div class='line' id='LC3185'>--I mean in the conversation; otherwise the interview wouldn&#39;t have</div><div class='line' id='LC3186'>been so short.  But it turned out that she had managed the business</div><div class='line' id='LC3187'>well; in fact, admirably.  She said that when she told those people</div><div class='line' id='LC3188'>I was The Boss, it hit them where they lived: &quot;smote them sore</div><div class='line' id='LC3189'>with fear and dread&quot; was her word; and then they were ready to</div><div class='line' id='LC3190'>put up with anything she might require.  So she swore them to appear</div><div class='line' id='LC3191'>at Arthur&#39;s court within two days and yield them, with horse and</div><div class='line' id='LC3192'>harness, and be my knights henceforth, and subject to my command.</div><div class='line' id='LC3193'>How much better she managed that thing than I should have done</div><div class='line' id='LC3194'>it myself!  She was a daisy.</div><div class='line' id='LC3195'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3196'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3197'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3198'>CHAPTER XV</div><div class='line' id='LC3199'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3200'>SANDY&#39;S TALE</div><div class='line' id='LC3201'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3202'>&quot;And so I&#39;m proprietor of some knights,&quot; said I, as we rode off.</div><div class='line' id='LC3203'>&quot;Who would ever have supposed that I should live to list up assets</div><div class='line' id='LC3204'>of that sort.  I shan&#39;t know what to do with them; unless I raffle</div><div class='line' id='LC3205'>them off.  How many of them are there, Sandy?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3206'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3207'>&quot;Seven, please you, sir, and their squires.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3208'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3209'>&quot;It is a good haul.  Who are they?  Where do they hang out?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3210'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3211'>&quot;Where do they hang out?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3212'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3213'>&quot;Yes, where do they live?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3214'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3215'>&quot;Ah, I understood thee not.  That will I tell eftsoons.&quot;  Then she</div><div class='line' id='LC3216'>said musingly, and softly, turning the words daintily over her</div><div class='line' id='LC3217'>tongue: &quot;Hang they out--hang they out--where hang--where do they</div><div class='line' id='LC3218'>hang out; eh, right so; where do they hang out.  Of a truth the</div><div class='line' id='LC3219'>phrase hath a fair and winsome grace, and is prettily worded</div><div class='line' id='LC3220'>withal.  I will repeat it anon and anon in mine idlesse, whereby</div><div class='line' id='LC3221'>I may peradventure learn it.  Where do they hang out.  Even so!</div><div class='line' id='LC3222'>already it falleth trippingly from my tongue, and forasmuch as--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3223'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3224'>&quot;Don&#39;t forget the cowboys, Sandy.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3225'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3226'>&quot;Cowboys?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3227'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3228'>&quot;Yes; the knights, you know: You were going to tell me about them.</div><div class='line' id='LC3229'>A while back, you remember.  Figuratively speaking, game&#39;s called.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3230'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3231'>&quot;Game--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3232'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3233'>&quot;Yes, yes, yes!  Go to the bat.  I mean, get to work on your</div><div class='line' id='LC3234'>statistics, and don&#39;t burn so much kindling getting your fire</div><div class='line' id='LC3235'>started.  Tell me about the knights.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3236'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3237'>&quot;I will well, and lightly will begin.  So they two departed and</div><div class='line' id='LC3238'>rode into a great forest.  And--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3239'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3240'>&quot;Great Scott!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3241'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3242'>You see, I recognized my mistake at once.  I had set her works</div><div class='line' id='LC3243'>a-going; it was my own fault; she would be thirty days getting down</div><div class='line' id='LC3244'>to those facts.  And she generally began without a preface and</div><div class='line' id='LC3245'>finished without a result.  If you interrupted her she would either</div><div class='line' id='LC3246'>go right along without noticing, or answer with a couple of words,</div><div class='line' id='LC3247'>and go back and say the sentence over again.  So, interruptions</div><div class='line' id='LC3248'>only did harm; and yet I had to interrupt, and interrupt pretty</div><div class='line' id='LC3249'>frequently, too, in order to save my life; a person would die if</div><div class='line' id='LC3250'>he let her monotony drip on him right along all day.</div><div class='line' id='LC3251'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3252'>&quot;Great Scott!&quot; I said in my distress.  She went right back and</div><div class='line' id='LC3253'>began over again:</div><div class='line' id='LC3254'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3255'>&quot;So they two departed and rode into a great forest.  And--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3256'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3257'>&quot;_Which_ two?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3258'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3259'>&quot;Sir Gawaine and Sir Uwaine.  And so they came to an abbey of monks,</div><div class='line' id='LC3260'>and there were well lodged.  So on the morn they heard their masses</div><div class='line' id='LC3261'>in the abbey, and so they rode forth till they came to a great</div><div class='line' id='LC3262'>forest; then was Sir Gawaine ware in a valley by a turret, of</div><div class='line' id='LC3263'>twelve fair damsels, and two knights armed on great horses, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3264'>the damsels went to and fro by a tree.  And then was Sir Gawaine</div><div class='line' id='LC3265'>ware how there hung a white shield on that tree, and ever as the</div><div class='line' id='LC3266'>damsels came by it they spit upon it, and some threw mire upon</div><div class='line' id='LC3267'>the shield--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3268'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3269'>&quot;Now, if I hadn&#39;t seen the like myself in this country, Sandy,</div><div class='line' id='LC3270'>I wouldn&#39;t believe it.  But I&#39;ve seen it, and I can just see those</div><div class='line' id='LC3271'>creatures now, parading before that shield and acting like that.</div><div class='line' id='LC3272'>The women here do certainly act like all possessed.  Yes, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3273'>I mean your best, too, society&#39;s very choicest brands.  The humblest</div><div class='line' id='LC3274'>hello-girl along ten thousand miles of wire could teach gentleness,</div><div class='line' id='LC3275'>patience, modesty, manners, to the highest duchess in Arthur&#39;s land.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3276'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3277'>&quot;Hello-girl?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3278'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3279'>&quot;Yes, but don&#39;t you ask me to explain; it&#39;s a new kind of a girl;</div><div class='line' id='LC3280'>they don&#39;t have them here; one often speaks sharply to them when</div><div class='line' id='LC3281'>they are not the least in fault, and he can&#39;t get over feeling</div><div class='line' id='LC3282'>sorry for it and ashamed of himself in thirteen hundred years,</div><div class='line' id='LC3283'>it&#39;s such shabby mean conduct and so unprovoked; the fact is,</div><div class='line' id='LC3284'>no gentleman ever does it--though I--well, I myself, if I&#39;ve got</div><div class='line' id='LC3285'>to confess--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3286'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3287'>&quot;Peradventure she--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3288'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3289'>&quot;Never mind her; never mind her; I tell you I couldn&#39;t ever explain</div><div class='line' id='LC3290'>her so you would understand.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3291'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3292'>&quot;Even so be it, sith ye are so minded.  Then Sir Gawaine and</div><div class='line' id='LC3293'>Sir Uwaine went and saluted them, and asked them why they did that</div><div class='line' id='LC3294'>despite to the shield.  Sirs, said the damsels, we shall tell you.</div><div class='line' id='LC3295'>There is a knight in this country that owneth this white shield,</div><div class='line' id='LC3296'>and he is a passing good man of his hands, but he hateth all</div><div class='line' id='LC3297'>ladies and gentlewomen, and therefore we do all this despite to</div><div class='line' id='LC3298'>the shield.  I will say you, said Sir Gawaine, it beseemeth evil</div><div class='line' id='LC3299'>a good knight to despise all ladies and gentlewomen, and peradventure</div><div class='line' id='LC3300'>though he hate you he hath some cause, and peradventure he loveth</div><div class='line' id='LC3301'>in some other places ladies and gentlewomen, and to be loved again,</div><div class='line' id='LC3302'>and he such a man of prowess as ye speak of--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3303'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3304'>&quot;Man of prowess--yes, that is the man to please them, Sandy.</div><div class='line' id='LC3305'>Man of brains--that is a thing they never think of.  Tom Sayers</div><div class='line' id='LC3306'>--John Heenan--John L. Sullivan--pity but you could be here.  You</div><div class='line' id='LC3307'>would have your legs under the Round Table and a &#39;Sir&#39; in front</div><div class='line' id='LC3308'>of your names within the twenty-four hours; and you could bring</div><div class='line' id='LC3309'>about a new distribution of the married princesses and duchesses</div><div class='line' id='LC3310'>of the Court in another twenty-four.  The fact is, it is just</div><div class='line' id='LC3311'>a sort of polished-up court of Comanches, and there isn&#39;t a squaw</div><div class='line' id='LC3312'>in it who doesn&#39;t stand ready at the dropping of a hat to desert</div><div class='line' id='LC3313'>to the buck with the biggest string of scalps at his belt.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3314'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3315'>&quot;--and he be such a man of prowess as ye speak of, said Sir Gawaine.</div><div class='line' id='LC3316'>Now, what is his name?  Sir, said they, his name is Marhaus the</div><div class='line' id='LC3317'>king&#39;s son of Ireland.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3318'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3319'>&quot;Son of the king of Ireland, you mean; the other form doesn&#39;t mean</div><div class='line' id='LC3320'>anything.  And look out and hold on tight, now, we must jump</div><div class='line' id='LC3321'>this gully....  There, we are all right now.  This horse belongs in</div><div class='line' id='LC3322'>the circus; he is born before his time.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3323'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3324'>&quot;I know him well, said Sir Uwaine, he is a passing good knight as</div><div class='line' id='LC3325'>any is on live.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3326'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3327'>&quot;_On live_.  If you&#39;ve got a fault in the world, Sandy, it is that</div><div class='line' id='LC3328'>you are a shade too archaic.  But it isn&#39;t any matter.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3329'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3330'>&quot;--for I saw him once proved at a justs where many knights were</div><div class='line' id='LC3331'>gathered, and that time there might no man withstand him.  Ah, said</div><div class='line' id='LC3332'>Sir Gawaine, damsels, methinketh ye are to blame, for it is to</div><div class='line' id='LC3333'>suppose he that hung that shield there will not be long therefrom,</div><div class='line' id='LC3334'>and then may those knights match him on horseback, and that is</div><div class='line' id='LC3335'>more your worship than thus; for I will abide no longer to see</div><div class='line' id='LC3336'>a knight&#39;s shield dishonored.  And therewith Sir Uwaine and</div><div class='line' id='LC3337'>Sir Gawaine departed a little from them, and then were they ware</div><div class='line' id='LC3338'>where Sir Marhaus came riding on a great horse straight toward</div><div class='line' id='LC3339'>them.  And when the twelve damsels saw Sir Marhaus they fled into</div><div class='line' id='LC3340'>the turret as they were wild, so that some of them fell by the way.</div><div class='line' id='LC3341'>Then the one of the knights of the tower dressed his shield, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3342'>said on high, Sir Marhaus defend thee.  And so they ran together</div><div class='line' id='LC3343'>that the knight brake his spear on Marhaus, and Sir Marhaus smote</div><div class='line' id='LC3344'>him so hard that he brake his neck and the horse&#39;s back--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3345'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3346'>&quot;Well, that is just the trouble about this state of things,</div><div class='line' id='LC3347'>it ruins so many horses.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3348'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3349'>&quot;That saw the other knight of the turret, and dressed him toward</div><div class='line' id='LC3350'>Marhaus, and they went so eagerly together, that the knight of</div><div class='line' id='LC3351'>the turret was soon smitten down, horse and man, stark dead--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3352'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3353'>&quot;_Another_ horse gone; I tell you it is a custom that ought to be</div><div class='line' id='LC3354'>broken up.  I don&#39;t see how people with any feeling can applaud</div><div class='line' id='LC3355'>and support it.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3356'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3357'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;.   .   .   .</div><div class='line' id='LC3358'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3359'>&quot;So these two knights came together with great random--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3360'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3361'>I saw that I had been asleep and missed a chapter, but I didn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC3362'>say anything.  I judged that the Irish knight was in trouble with</div><div class='line' id='LC3363'>the visitors by this time, and this turned out to be the case.</div><div class='line' id='LC3364'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3365'>&quot;--that Sir Uwaine smote Sir Marhaus that his spear brast in pieces</div><div class='line' id='LC3366'>on the shield, and Sir Marhaus smote him so sore that horse and</div><div class='line' id='LC3367'>man he bare to the earth, and hurt Sir Uwaine on the left side--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3368'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3369'>&quot;The truth is, Alisande, these archaics are a little _too_ simple;</div><div class='line' id='LC3370'>the vocabulary is too limited, and so, by consequence, descriptions</div><div class='line' id='LC3371'>suffer in the matter of variety; they run too much to level Saharas</div><div class='line' id='LC3372'>of fact, and not enough to picturesque detail; this throws about</div><div class='line' id='LC3373'>them a certain air of the monotonous; in fact the fights are all</div><div class='line' id='LC3374'>alike: a couple of people come together with great random</div><div class='line' id='LC3375'>--random is a good word, and so is exegesis, for that matter, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3376'>so is holocaust, and defalcation, and usufruct and a hundred others,</div><div class='line' id='LC3377'>but land! a body ought to discriminate--they come together with</div><div class='line' id='LC3378'>great random, and a spear is brast, and one party brake his shield</div><div class='line' id='LC3379'>and the other one goes down, horse and man, over his horse-tail</div><div class='line' id='LC3380'>and brake his neck, and then the next candidate comes randoming in,</div><div class='line' id='LC3381'>and brast _his_ spear, and the other man brast his shield, and down</div><div class='line' id='LC3382'>_he_ goes, horse and man, over his horse-tail, and brake _his_ neck,</div><div class='line' id='LC3383'>and then there&#39;s another elected, and another and another and still</div><div class='line' id='LC3384'>another, till the material is all used up; and when you come to</div><div class='line' id='LC3385'>figure up results, you can&#39;t tell one fight from another, nor who</div><div class='line' id='LC3386'>whipped; and as a _picture_, of living, raging, roaring battle,</div><div class='line' id='LC3387'>sho! why, it&#39;s pale and noiseless--just ghosts scuffling in a fog.</div><div class='line' id='LC3388'>Dear me, what would this barren vocabulary get out of the mightiest</div><div class='line' id='LC3389'>spectacle?--the burning of Rome in Nero&#39;s time, for instance?</div><div class='line' id='LC3390'>Why, it would merely say, &#39;Town burned down; no insurance; boy</div><div class='line' id='LC3391'>brast a window, fireman brake his neck!&#39;  Why, _that_ ain&#39;t a picture!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3392'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3393'>It was a good deal of a lecture, I thought, but it didn&#39;t disturb</div><div class='line' id='LC3394'>Sandy, didn&#39;t turn a feather; her steam soared steadily up again,</div><div class='line' id='LC3395'>the minute I took off the lid:</div><div class='line' id='LC3396'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3397'>&quot;Then Sir Marhaus turned his horse and rode toward Gawaine with</div><div class='line' id='LC3398'>his spear.  And when Sir Gawaine saw that, he dressed his shield,</div><div class='line' id='LC3399'>and they aventred their spears, and they came together with all</div><div class='line' id='LC3400'>the might of their horses, that either knight smote other so hard</div><div class='line' id='LC3401'>in the midst of their shields, but Sir Gawaine&#39;s spear brake--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3402'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3403'>&quot;I knew it would.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3404'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3405'>--&quot;but Sir Marhaus&#39;s spear held; and therewith Sir Gawaine and</div><div class='line' id='LC3406'>his horse rushed down to the earth--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3407'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3408'>&quot;Just so--and brake his back.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3409'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3410'>--&quot;and lightly Sir Gawaine rose upon his feet and pulled out</div><div class='line' id='LC3411'>his sword, and dressed him toward Sir Marhaus on foot, and therewith</div><div class='line' id='LC3412'>either came unto other eagerly, and smote together with their</div><div class='line' id='LC3413'>swords, that their shields flew in cantels, and they bruised their</div><div class='line' id='LC3414'>helms and their hauberks, and wounded either other.  But Sir Gawaine,</div><div class='line' id='LC3415'>fro it passed nine of the clock, waxed by the space of three hours</div><div class='line' id='LC3416'>ever stronger and stronger and thrice his might was increased.</div><div class='line' id='LC3417'>All this espied Sir Marhaus, and had great wonder how his might</div><div class='line' id='LC3418'>increased, and so they wounded other passing sore; and then when</div><div class='line' id='LC3419'>it was come noon--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3420'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3421'>The pelting sing-song of it carried me forward to scenes and</div><div class='line' id='LC3422'>sounds of my boyhood days:</div><div class='line' id='LC3423'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3424'>&quot;N-e-e-ew Haven! ten minutes for refreshments--knductr&#39;ll strike</div><div class='line' id='LC3425'>the gong-bell two minutes before train leaves--passengers for</div><div class='line' id='LC3426'>the Shore line please take seats in the rear k&#39;yar, this k&#39;yar</div><div class='line' id='LC3427'>don&#39;t go no furder--_ahh_-pls, _aw_-rnjz, b&#39;_nan_ners,</div><div class='line' id='LC3428'>_s-a-n-d_&#39;ches, p--_op_-corn!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3429'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3430'>--&quot;and waxed past noon and drew toward evensong.  Sir Gawaine&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC3431'>strength feebled and waxed passing faint, that unnethes he might</div><div class='line' id='LC3432'>dure any longer, and Sir Marhaus was then bigger and bigger--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3433'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3434'>&quot;Which strained his armor, of course; and yet little would one</div><div class='line' id='LC3435'>of these people mind a small thing like that.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3436'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3437'>--&quot;and so, Sir Knight, said Sir Marhaus, I have well felt that</div><div class='line' id='LC3438'>ye are a passing good knight, and a marvelous man of might as ever</div><div class='line' id='LC3439'>I felt any, while it lasteth, and our quarrels are not great, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3440'>therefore it were a pity to do you hurt, for I feel you are passing</div><div class='line' id='LC3441'>feeble.  Ah, said Sir Gawaine, gentle knight, ye say the word</div><div class='line' id='LC3442'>that I should say.  And therewith they took off their helms and</div><div class='line' id='LC3443'>either kissed other, and there they swore together either to love</div><div class='line' id='LC3444'>other as brethren--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3445'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3446'>But I lost the thread there, and dozed off to slumber, thinking</div><div class='line' id='LC3447'>about what a pity it was that men with such superb strength</div><div class='line' id='LC3448'>--strength enabling them to stand up cased in cruelly burdensome</div><div class='line' id='LC3449'>iron and drenched with perspiration, and hack and batter and bang</div><div class='line' id='LC3450'>each other for six hours on a stretch--should not have been born</div><div class='line' id='LC3451'>at a time when they could put it to some useful purpose.  Take</div><div class='line' id='LC3452'>a jackass, for instance: a jackass has that kind of strength, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3453'>puts it to a useful purpose, and is valuable to this world because</div><div class='line' id='LC3454'>he is a jackass; but a nobleman is not valuable because he is</div><div class='line' id='LC3455'>a jackass.  It is a mixture that is always ineffectual, and should</div><div class='line' id='LC3456'>never have been attempted in the first place.  And yet, once you</div><div class='line' id='LC3457'>start a mistake, the trouble is done and you never know what is</div><div class='line' id='LC3458'>going to come of it.</div><div class='line' id='LC3459'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3460'>When I came to myself again and began to listen, I perceived that</div><div class='line' id='LC3461'>I had lost another chapter, and that Alisande had wandered a long</div><div class='line' id='LC3462'>way off with her people.</div><div class='line' id='LC3463'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3464'>&quot;And so they rode and came into a deep valley full of stones,</div><div class='line' id='LC3465'>and thereby they saw a fair stream of water; above thereby was</div><div class='line' id='LC3466'>the head of the stream, a fair fountain, and three damsels sitting</div><div class='line' id='LC3467'>thereby. In this country, said Sir Marhaus, came never knight</div><div class='line' id='LC3468'>since it was christened, but he found strange adventures--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3469'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3470'>&quot;This is not good form, Alisande.  Sir Marhaus the king&#39;s son of</div><div class='line' id='LC3471'>Ireland talks like all the rest; you ought to give him a brogue,</div><div class='line' id='LC3472'>or at least a characteristic expletive; by this means one would</div><div class='line' id='LC3473'>recognize him as soon as he spoke, without his ever being named.</div><div class='line' id='LC3474'>It is a common literary device with the great authors.  You should</div><div class='line' id='LC3475'>make him say, &#39;In this country, be jabers, came never knight since</div><div class='line' id='LC3476'>it was christened, but he found strange adventures, be jabers.&#39;</div><div class='line' id='LC3477'>You see how much better that sounds.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3478'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3479'>--&quot;came never knight but he found strange adventures, be jabers.</div><div class='line' id='LC3480'>Of a truth it doth indeed, fair lord, albeit &#39;tis passing hard</div><div class='line' id='LC3481'>to say, though peradventure that will not tarry but better speed</div><div class='line' id='LC3482'>with usage.  And then they rode to the damsels, and either saluted</div><div class='line' id='LC3483'>other, and the eldest had a garland of gold about her head, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3484'>she was threescore winter of age or more--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3485'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3486'>&quot;The _damsel_ was?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3487'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3488'>&quot;Even so, dear lord--and her hair was white under the garland--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3489'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3490'>&quot;Celluloid teeth, nine dollars a set, as like as not--the loose-fit</div><div class='line' id='LC3491'>kind, that go up and down like a portcullis when you eat, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3492'>fall out when you laugh.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3493'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3494'>&quot;The second damsel was of thirty winter of age, with a circlet of</div><div class='line' id='LC3495'>gold about her head.  The third damsel was but fifteen year of age--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3496'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3497'>Billows of thought came rolling over my soul, and the voice faded</div><div class='line' id='LC3498'>out of my hearing!</div><div class='line' id='LC3499'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3500'>Fifteen!  Break--my heart! oh, my lost darling!  Just her age</div><div class='line' id='LC3501'>who was so gentle, and lovely, and all the world to me, and whom</div><div class='line' id='LC3502'>I shall never see again!  How the thought of her carries me back</div><div class='line' id='LC3503'>over wide seas of memory to a vague dim time, a happy time, so many,</div><div class='line' id='LC3504'>many centuries hence, when I used to wake in the soft summer</div><div class='line' id='LC3505'>mornings, out of sweet dreams of her, and say &quot;Hello, Central!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3506'>just to hear her dear voice come melting back to me with a</div><div class='line' id='LC3507'>&quot;Hello, Hank!&quot; that was music of the spheres to my enchanted ear.</div><div class='line' id='LC3508'>She got three dollars a week, but she was worth it.</div><div class='line' id='LC3509'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3510'>I could not follow Alisande&#39;s further explanation of who our</div><div class='line' id='LC3511'>captured knights were, now--I mean in case she should ever get</div><div class='line' id='LC3512'>to explaining who they were.  My interest was gone, my thoughts</div><div class='line' id='LC3513'>were far away, and sad.  By fitful glimpses of the drifting tale,</div><div class='line' id='LC3514'>caught here and there and now and then, I merely noted in a vague</div><div class='line' id='LC3515'>way that each of these three knights took one of these three damsels</div><div class='line' id='LC3516'>up behind him on his horse, and one rode north, another east,</div><div class='line' id='LC3517'>the other south, to seek adventures, and meet again and lie, after</div><div class='line' id='LC3518'>year and day.  Year and day--and without baggage.  It was of</div><div class='line' id='LC3519'>a piece with the general simplicity of the country.</div><div class='line' id='LC3520'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3521'>The sun was now setting.  It was about three in the afternoon when</div><div class='line' id='LC3522'>Alisande had begun to tell me who the cowboys were; so she had made</div><div class='line' id='LC3523'>pretty good progress with it--for her.  She would arrive some time</div><div class='line' id='LC3524'>or other, no doubt, but she was not a person who could be hurried.</div><div class='line' id='LC3525'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3526'>We were approaching a castle which stood on high ground; a huge,</div><div class='line' id='LC3527'>strong, venerable structure, whose gray towers and battlements were</div><div class='line' id='LC3528'>charmingly draped with ivy, and whose whole majestic mass was</div><div class='line' id='LC3529'>drenched with splendors flung from the sinking sun.  It was the</div><div class='line' id='LC3530'>largest castle we had seen, and so I thought it might be the one</div><div class='line' id='LC3531'>we were after, but Sandy said no.  She did not know who owned it;</div><div class='line' id='LC3532'>she said she had passed it without calling, when she went down</div><div class='line' id='LC3533'>to Camelot.</div><div class='line' id='LC3534'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3535'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3536'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3537'>CHAPTER XVI</div><div class='line' id='LC3538'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3539'>MORGAN LE FAY</div><div class='line' id='LC3540'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3541'>If knights errant were to be believed, not all castles were desirable</div><div class='line' id='LC3542'>places to seek hospitality in.  As a matter of fact, knights errant</div><div class='line' id='LC3543'>were _not_ persons to be believed--that is, measured by modern</div><div class='line' id='LC3544'>standards of veracity; yet, measured by the standards of their own</div><div class='line' id='LC3545'>time, and scaled accordingly, you got the truth.  It was very</div><div class='line' id='LC3546'>simple: you discounted a statement ninety-seven per cent; the rest</div><div class='line' id='LC3547'>was fact.  Now after making this allowance, the truth remained</div><div class='line' id='LC3548'>that if I could find out something about a castle before ringing</div><div class='line' id='LC3549'>the door-bell--I mean hailing the warders--it was the sensible</div><div class='line' id='LC3550'>thing to do.  So I was pleased when I saw in the distance a horseman</div><div class='line' id='LC3551'>making the bottom turn of the road that wound down from this castle.</div><div class='line' id='LC3552'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3553'>As we approached each other, I saw that he wore a plumed helmet,</div><div class='line' id='LC3554'>and seemed to be otherwise clothed in steel, but bore a curious</div><div class='line' id='LC3555'>addition also--a stiff square garment like a herald&#39;s tabard.</div><div class='line' id='LC3556'>However, I had to smile at my own forgetfulness when I got nearer</div><div class='line' id='LC3557'>and read this sign on his tabard:</div><div class='line' id='LC3558'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3559'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&quot;Persimmon&#39;s Soap -- All the Prime-Donna Use It.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3560'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3561'>That was a little idea of my own, and had several wholesome purposes</div><div class='line' id='LC3562'>in view toward the civilizing and uplifting of this nation.  In the</div><div class='line' id='LC3563'>first place, it was a furtive, underhand blow at this nonsense</div><div class='line' id='LC3564'>of knight errantry, though nobody suspected that but me.  I had</div><div class='line' id='LC3565'>started a number of these people out--the bravest knights I could</div><div class='line' id='LC3566'>get--each sandwiched between bulletin-boards bearing one device</div><div class='line' id='LC3567'>or another, and I judged that by and by when they got to be numerous</div><div class='line' id='LC3568'>enough they would begin to look ridiculous; and then, even the</div><div class='line' id='LC3569'>steel-clad ass that _hadn&#39;t_ any board would himself begin to look</div><div class='line' id='LC3570'>ridiculous because he was out of the fashion.</div><div class='line' id='LC3571'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3572'>Secondly, these missionaries would gradually, and without creating</div><div class='line' id='LC3573'>suspicion or exciting alarm, introduce a rudimentary cleanliness</div><div class='line' id='LC3574'>among the nobility, and from them it would work down to the people,</div><div class='line' id='LC3575'>if the priests could be kept quiet.  This would undermine the Church.</div><div class='line' id='LC3576'>I mean would be a step toward that.  Next, education--next, freedom</div><div class='line' id='LC3577'>--and then she would begin to crumble.  It being my conviction that</div><div class='line' id='LC3578'>any Established Church is an established crime, an established</div><div class='line' id='LC3579'>slave-pen, I had no scruples, but was willing to assail it in</div><div class='line' id='LC3580'>any way or with any weapon that promised to hurt it.
