Why, in my</div><div class='line' id='LC3581'>own former day--in remote centuries not yet stirring in the womb</div><div class='line' id='LC3582'>of time--there were old Englishmen who imagined that they had been</div><div class='line' id='LC3583'>born in a free country: a &quot;free&quot; country with the Corporation Act</div><div class='line' id='LC3584'>and the Test still in force in it--timbers propped against men&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC3585'>liberties and dishonored consciences to shore up an Established</div><div class='line' id='LC3586'>Anachronism with.</div><div class='line' id='LC3587'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3588'>My missionaries were taught to spell out the gilt signs on their</div><div class='line' id='LC3589'>tabards--the showy gilding was a neat idea, I could have got the</div><div class='line' id='LC3590'>king to wear a bulletin-board for the sake of that barbaric</div><div class='line' id='LC3591'>splendor--they were to spell out these signs and then explain to</div><div class='line' id='LC3592'>the lords and ladies what soap was; and if the lords and ladies</div><div class='line' id='LC3593'>were afraid of it, get them to try it on a dog.  The missionary&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC3594'>next move was to get the family together and try it on himself;</div><div class='line' id='LC3595'>he was to stop at no experiment, however desperate, that could</div><div class='line' id='LC3596'>convince the nobility that soap was harmless; if any final doubt</div><div class='line' id='LC3597'>remained, he must catch a hermit--the woods were full of them;</div><div class='line' id='LC3598'>saints they called themselves, and saints they were believed to be.</div><div class='line' id='LC3599'>They were unspeakably holy, and worked miracles, and everybody</div><div class='line' id='LC3600'>stood in awe of them.  If a hermit could survive a wash, and that</div><div class='line' id='LC3601'>failed to convince a duke, give him up, let him alone.</div><div class='line' id='LC3602'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3603'>Whenever my missionaries overcame a knight errant on the road</div><div class='line' id='LC3604'>they washed him, and when he got well they swore him to go and</div><div class='line' id='LC3605'>get a bulletin-board and disseminate soap and civilization the rest</div><div class='line' id='LC3606'>of his days.  As a consequence the workers in the field were</div><div class='line' id='LC3607'>increasing by degrees, and the reform was steadily spreading.</div><div class='line' id='LC3608'>My soap factory felt the strain early.  At first I had only two</div><div class='line' id='LC3609'>hands; but before I had left home I was already employing fifteen,</div><div class='line' id='LC3610'>and running night and day; and the atmospheric result was getting</div><div class='line' id='LC3611'>so pronounced that the king went sort of fainting and gasping</div><div class='line' id='LC3612'>around and said he did not believe he could stand it much longer,</div><div class='line' id='LC3613'>and Sir Launcelot got so that he did hardly anything but walk up</div><div class='line' id='LC3614'>and down the roof and swear, although I told him it was worse up</div><div class='line' id='LC3615'>there than anywhere else, but he said he wanted plenty of air; and</div><div class='line' id='LC3616'>he was always complaining that a palace was no place for a soap</div><div class='line' id='LC3617'>factory anyway, and said if a man was to start one in his house</div><div class='line' id='LC3618'>he would be damned if he wouldn&#39;t strangle him.  There were ladies</div><div class='line' id='LC3619'>present, too, but much these people ever cared for that; they would</div><div class='line' id='LC3620'>swear before children, if the wind was their way when the factory</div><div class='line' id='LC3621'>was going.</div><div class='line' id='LC3622'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3623'>This missionary knight&#39;s name was La Cote Male Taile, and he said</div><div class='line' id='LC3624'>that this castle was the abode of Morgan le Fay, sister of</div><div class='line' id='LC3625'>King Arthur, and wife of King Uriens, monarch of a realm about</div><div class='line' id='LC3626'>as big as the District of Columbia--you could stand in the middle</div><div class='line' id='LC3627'>of it and throw bricks into the next kingdom.  &quot;Kings&quot; and &quot;Kingdoms&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3628'>were as thick in Britain as they had been in little Palestine in</div><div class='line' id='LC3629'>Joshua&#39;s time, when people had to sleep with their knees pulled up</div><div class='line' id='LC3630'>because they couldn&#39;t stretch out without a passport.</div><div class='line' id='LC3631'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3632'>La Cote was much depressed, for he had scored here the worst</div><div class='line' id='LC3633'>failure of his campaign.  He had not worked off a cake; yet he had</div><div class='line' id='LC3634'>tried all the tricks of the trade, even to the washing of a hermit;</div><div class='line' id='LC3635'>but the hermit died.  This was, indeed, a bad failure, for this</div><div class='line' id='LC3636'>animal would now be dubbed a martyr, and would take his place</div><div class='line' id='LC3637'>among the saints of the Roman calendar.  Thus made he his moan,</div><div class='line' id='LC3638'>this poor Sir La Cote Male Taile, and sorrowed passing sore.  And</div><div class='line' id='LC3639'>so my heart bled for him, and I was moved to comfort and stay him.</div><div class='line' id='LC3640'>Wherefore I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC3641'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3642'>&quot;Forbear to grieve, fair knight, for this is not a defeat.  We have</div><div class='line' id='LC3643'>brains, you and I; and for such as have brains there are no defeats,</div><div class='line' id='LC3644'>but only victories.  Observe how we will turn this seeming disaster</div><div class='line' id='LC3645'>into an advertisement; an advertisement for our soap; and the</div><div class='line' id='LC3646'>biggest one, to draw, that was ever thought of; an advertisement</div><div class='line' id='LC3647'>that will transform that Mount Washington defeat into a Matterhorn</div><div class='line' id='LC3648'>victory.  We will put on your bulletin-board, &#39;_Patronized by the</div><div class='line' id='LC3649'>elect_.&#39;  How does that strike you?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3650'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3651'>&quot;Verily, it is wonderly bethought!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3652'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3653'>&quot;Well, a body is bound to admit that for just a modest little</div><div class='line' id='LC3654'>one-line ad, it&#39;s a corker.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3655'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3656'>So the poor colporteur&#39;s griefs vanished away.  He was a brave</div><div class='line' id='LC3657'>fellow, and had done mighty feats of arms in his time.  His chief</div><div class='line' id='LC3658'>celebrity rested upon the events of an excursion like this one</div><div class='line' id='LC3659'>of mine, which he had once made with a damsel named Maledisant,</div><div class='line' id='LC3660'>who was as handy with her tongue as was Sandy, though in a different</div><div class='line' id='LC3661'>way, for her tongue churned forth only railings and insult, whereas</div><div class='line' id='LC3662'>Sandy&#39;s music was of a kindlier sort.  I knew his story well, and so</div><div class='line' id='LC3663'>I knew how to interpret the compassion that was in his face when he</div><div class='line' id='LC3664'>bade me farewell.  He supposed I was having a bitter hard time of it.</div><div class='line' id='LC3665'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3666'>Sandy and I discussed his story, as we rode along, and she said</div><div class='line' id='LC3667'>that La Cote&#39;s bad luck had begun with the very beginning of that</div><div class='line' id='LC3668'>trip; for the king&#39;s fool had overthrown him on the first day,</div><div class='line' id='LC3669'>and in such cases it was customary for the girl to desert to the</div><div class='line' id='LC3670'>conqueror, but Maledisant didn&#39;t do it; and also persisted afterward</div><div class='line' id='LC3671'>in sticking to him, after all his defeats.  But, said I, suppose</div><div class='line' id='LC3672'>the victor should decline to accept his spoil?  She said that that</div><div class='line' id='LC3673'>wouldn&#39;t answer--he must.  He couldn&#39;t decline; it wouldn&#39;t be</div><div class='line' id='LC3674'>regular.  I made a note of that.  If Sandy&#39;s music got to be too</div><div class='line' id='LC3675'>burdensome, some time, I would let a knight defeat me, on the chance</div><div class='line' id='LC3676'>that she would desert to him.</div><div class='line' id='LC3677'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3678'>In due time we were challenged by the warders, from the castle</div><div class='line' id='LC3679'>walls, and after a parley admitted.  I have nothing pleasant to</div><div class='line' id='LC3680'>tell about that visit.  But it was not a disappointment, for I knew</div><div class='line' id='LC3681'>Mrs. le Fay by reputation, and was not expecting anything pleasant.</div><div class='line' id='LC3682'>She was held in awe by the whole realm, for she had made everybody</div><div class='line' id='LC3683'>believe she was a great sorceress.  All her ways were wicked, all</div><div class='line' id='LC3684'>her instincts devilish.  She was loaded to the eyelids with cold</div><div class='line' id='LC3685'>malice.  All her history was black with crime; and among her crimes</div><div class='line' id='LC3686'>murder was common.  I was most curious to see her; as curious as</div><div class='line' id='LC3687'>I could have been to see Satan.  To my surprise she was beautiful;</div><div class='line' id='LC3688'>black thoughts had failed to make her expression repulsive, age</div><div class='line' id='LC3689'>had failed to wrinkle her satin skin or mar its bloomy freshness.</div><div class='line' id='LC3690'>She could have passed for old Uriens&#39; granddaughter, she could</div><div class='line' id='LC3691'>have been mistaken for sister to her own son.</div><div class='line' id='LC3692'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3693'>As soon as we were fairly within the castle gates we were ordered</div><div class='line' id='LC3694'>into her presence.  King Uriens was there, a kind-faced old man</div><div class='line' id='LC3695'>with a subdued look; and also the son, Sir Uwaine le Blanchemains,</div><div class='line' id='LC3696'>in whom I was, of course, interested on account of the tradition</div><div class='line' id='LC3697'>that he had once done battle with thirty knights, and also on</div><div class='line' id='LC3698'>account of his trip with Sir Gawaine and Sir Marhaus, which Sandy</div><div class='line' id='LC3699'>had been aging me with.  But Morgan was the main attraction, the</div><div class='line' id='LC3700'>conspicuous personality here; she was head chief of this household,</div><div class='line' id='LC3701'>that was plain.  She caused us to be seated, and then she began,</div><div class='line' id='LC3702'>with all manner of pretty graces and graciousnesses, to ask me</div><div class='line' id='LC3703'>questions.  Dear me, it was like a bird or a flute, or something,</div><div class='line' id='LC3704'>talking.  I felt persuaded that this woman must have been</div><div class='line' id='LC3705'>misrepresented, lied about.  She trilled along, and trilled along,</div><div class='line' id='LC3706'>and presently a handsome young page, clothed like the rainbow, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3707'>as easy and undulatory of movement as a wave, came with something</div><div class='line' id='LC3708'>on a golden salver, and, kneeling to present it to her, overdid</div><div class='line' id='LC3709'>his graces and lost his balance, and so fell lightly against her</div><div class='line' id='LC3710'>knee.  She slipped a dirk into him in as matter-of-course a way as</div><div class='line' id='LC3711'>another person would have harpooned a rat!</div><div class='line' id='LC3712'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3713'>Poor child! he slumped to the floor, twisted his silken limbs in</div><div class='line' id='LC3714'>one great straining contortion of pain, and was dead.  Out of the</div><div class='line' id='LC3715'>old king was wrung an involuntary &quot;O-h!&quot; of compassion.  The look</div><div class='line' id='LC3716'>he got, made him cut it suddenly short and not put any more hyphens</div><div class='line' id='LC3717'>in it.  Sir Uwaine, at a sign from his mother, went to the anteroom</div><div class='line' id='LC3718'>and called some servants, and meanwhile madame went rippling sweetly</div><div class='line' id='LC3719'>along with her talk.</div><div class='line' id='LC3720'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3721'>I saw that she was a good housekeeper, for while she talked she</div><div class='line' id='LC3722'>kept a corner of her eye on the servants to see that they made</div><div class='line' id='LC3723'>no balks in handling the body and getting it out; when they came</div><div class='line' id='LC3724'>with fresh clean towels, she sent back for the other kind; and</div><div class='line' id='LC3725'>when they had finished wiping the floor and were going, she indicated</div><div class='line' id='LC3726'>a crimson fleck the size of a tear which their duller eyes had</div><div class='line' id='LC3727'>overlooked.  It was plain to me that La Cote Male Taile had failed</div><div class='line' id='LC3728'>to see the mistress of the house.  Often, how louder and clearer</div><div class='line' id='LC3729'>than any tongue, does dumb circumstantial evidence speak.</div><div class='line' id='LC3730'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3731'>Morgan le Fay rippled along as musically as ever.  Marvelous woman.</div><div class='line' id='LC3732'>And what a glance she had: when it fell in reproof upon those</div><div class='line' id='LC3733'>servants, they shrunk and quailed as timid people do when the</div><div class='line' id='LC3734'>lightning flashes out of a cloud.  I could have got the habit</div><div class='line' id='LC3735'>myself.  It was the same with that poor old Brer Uriens; he was</div><div class='line' id='LC3736'>always on the ragged edge of apprehension; she could not even turn</div><div class='line' id='LC3737'>toward him but he winced.</div><div class='line' id='LC3738'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3739'>In the midst of the talk I let drop a complimentary word about</div><div class='line' id='LC3740'>King Arthur, forgetting for the moment how this woman hated her</div><div class='line' id='LC3741'>brother.  That one little compliment was enough.  She clouded up</div><div class='line' id='LC3742'>like storm; she called for her guards, and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC3743'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3744'>&quot;Hale me these varlets to the dungeons.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3745'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3746'>That struck cold on my ears, for her dungeons had a reputation.</div><div class='line' id='LC3747'>Nothing occurred to me to say--or do.  But not so with Sandy.</div><div class='line' id='LC3748'>As the guard laid a hand upon me, she piped up with the tranquilest</div><div class='line' id='LC3749'>confidence, and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC3750'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3751'>&quot;God&#39;s wounds, dost thou covet destruction, thou maniac?  It is</div><div class='line' id='LC3752'>The Boss!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3753'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3754'>Now what a happy idea that was!--and so simple; yet it would never</div><div class='line' id='LC3755'>have occurred to me.  I was born modest; not all over, but in spots;</div><div class='line' id='LC3756'>and this was one of the spots.</div><div class='line' id='LC3757'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3758'>The effect upon madame was electrical.  It cleared her countenance</div><div class='line' id='LC3759'>and brought back her smiles and all her persuasive graces and</div><div class='line' id='LC3760'>blandishments; but nevertheless she was not able to entirely cover up</div><div class='line' id='LC3761'>with them the fact that she was in a ghastly fright. She said:</div><div class='line' id='LC3762'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3763'>&quot;La, but do list to thine handmaid! as if one gifted with powers</div><div class='line' id='LC3764'>like to mine might say the thing which I have said unto one who</div><div class='line' id='LC3765'>has vanquished Merlin, and not be jesting.  By mine enchantments</div><div class='line' id='LC3766'>I foresaw your coming, and by them I knew you when you entered</div><div class='line' id='LC3767'>here.  I did but play this little jest with hope to surprise you</div><div class='line' id='LC3768'>into some display of your art, as not doubting you would blast</div><div class='line' id='LC3769'>the guards with occult fires, consuming them to ashes on the spot,</div><div class='line' id='LC3770'>a marvel much beyond mine own ability, yet one which I have long</div><div class='line' id='LC3771'>been childishly curious to see.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3772'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3773'>The guards were less curious, and got out as soon as they got permission.</div><div class='line' id='LC3774'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3775'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3776'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3777'>CHAPTER XVII</div><div class='line' id='LC3778'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3779'>A ROYAL BANQUET</div><div class='line' id='LC3780'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3781'>Madame, seeing me pacific and unresentful, no doubt judged that</div><div class='line' id='LC3782'>I was deceived by her excuse; for her fright dissolved away, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3783'>she was soon so importunate to have me give an exhibition and kill</div><div class='line' id='LC3784'>somebody, that the thing grew to be embarrassing.  However, to my</div><div class='line' id='LC3785'>relief she was presently interrupted by the call to prayers.  I will</div><div class='line' id='LC3786'>say this much for the nobility: that, tyrannical, murderous,</div><div class='line' id='LC3787'>rapacious, and morally rotten as they were, they were deeply and</div><div class='line' id='LC3788'>enthusiastically religious.  Nothing could divert them from the</div><div class='line' id='LC3789'>regular and faithful performance of the pieties enjoined by the</div><div class='line' id='LC3790'>Church.  More than once I had seen a noble who had gotten his</div><div class='line' id='LC3791'>enemy at a disadvantage, stop to pray before cutting his throat;</div><div class='line' id='LC3792'>more than once I had seen a noble, after ambushing and despatching</div><div class='line' id='LC3793'>his enemy, retire to the nearest wayside shrine and humbly give</div><div class='line' id='LC3794'>thanks, without even waiting to rob the body.  There was to be</div><div class='line' id='LC3795'>nothing finer or sweeter in the life of even Benvenuto Cellini,</div><div class='line' id='LC3796'>that rough-hewn saint, ten centuries later.  All the nobles of</div><div class='line' id='LC3797'>Britain, with their families, attended divine service morning and</div><div class='line' id='LC3798'>night daily, in their private chapels, and even the worst of them</div><div class='line' id='LC3799'>had family worship five or six times a day besides.  The credit</div><div class='line' id='LC3800'>of this belonged entirely to the Church.  Although I was no friend</div><div class='line' id='LC3801'>to that Catholic Church, I was obliged to admit this.  And often,</div><div class='line' id='LC3802'>in spite of me, I found myself saying, &quot;What would this country</div><div class='line' id='LC3803'>be without the Church?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3804'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3805'>After prayers we had dinner in a great banqueting hall which was</div><div class='line' id='LC3806'>lighted by hundreds of grease-jets, and everything was as fine and</div><div class='line' id='LC3807'>lavish and rudely splendid as might become the royal degree of the</div><div class='line' id='LC3808'>hosts.  At the head of the hall, on a dais, was the table of the</div><div class='line' id='LC3809'>king, queen, and their son, Prince Uwaine.  Stretching down the hall</div><div class='line' id='LC3810'>from this, was the general table, on the floor.  At this, above</div><div class='line' id='LC3811'>the salt, sat the visiting nobles and the grown members of their</div><div class='line' id='LC3812'>families, of both sexes,--the resident Court, in effect--sixty-one</div><div class='line' id='LC3813'>persons; below the salt sat minor officers of the household, with</div><div class='line' id='LC3814'>their principal subordinates: altogether a hundred and eighteen</div><div class='line' id='LC3815'>persons sitting, and about as many liveried servants standing</div><div class='line' id='LC3816'>behind their chairs, or serving in one capacity or another.  It was</div><div class='line' id='LC3817'>a very fine show.  In a gallery a band with cymbals, horns, harps,</div><div class='line' id='LC3818'>and other horrors, opened the proceedings with what seemed to be</div><div class='line' id='LC3819'>the crude first-draft or original agony of the wail known to later</div><div class='line' id='LC3820'>centuries as &quot;In the Sweet Bye and Bye.&quot;  It was new, and ought</div><div class='line' id='LC3821'>to have been rehearsed a little more.  For some reason or other</div><div class='line' id='LC3822'>the queen had the composer hanged, after dinner.</div><div class='line' id='LC3823'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3824'>After this music, the priest who stood behind the royal table said</div><div class='line' id='LC3825'>a noble long grace in ostensible Latin.  Then the battalion of</div><div class='line' id='LC3826'>waiters broke away from their posts, and darted, rushed, flew,</div><div class='line' id='LC3827'>fetched and carried, and the mighty feeding began; no words</div><div class='line' id='LC3828'>anywhere, but absorbing attention to business.  The rows of chops</div><div class='line' id='LC3829'>opened and shut in vast unison, and the sound of it was like to</div><div class='line' id='LC3830'>the muffled burr of subterranean machinery.</div><div class='line' id='LC3831'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3832'>The havoc continued an hour and a half, and unimaginable was the</div><div class='line' id='LC3833'>destruction of substantials.  Of the chief feature of the feast</div><div class='line' id='LC3834'>--the huge wild boar that lay stretched out so portly and imposing</div><div class='line' id='LC3835'>at the start--nothing was left but the semblance of a hoop-skirt;</div><div class='line' id='LC3836'>and he was but the type and symbol of what had happened to all</div><div class='line' id='LC3837'>the other dishes.</div><div class='line' id='LC3838'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3839'>With the pastries and so on, the heavy drinking began--and the talk.</div><div class='line' id='LC3840'>Gallon after gallon of wine and mead disappeared, and everybody</div><div class='line' id='LC3841'>got comfortable, then happy, then sparklingly joyous--both sexes,</div><div class='line' id='LC3842'>--and by and by pretty noisy.  Men told anecdotes that were terrific</div><div class='line' id='LC3843'>to hear, but nobody blushed; and when the nub was sprung, the</div><div class='line' id='LC3844'>assemblage let go with a horse-laugh that shook the fortress.</div><div class='line' id='LC3845'>Ladies answered back with historiettes that would almost have made</div><div class='line' id='LC3846'>Queen Margaret of Navarre or even the great Elizabeth of England</div><div class='line' id='LC3847'>hide behind a handkerchief, but nobody hid here, but only laughed</div><div class='line' id='LC3848'>--howled, you may say.  In pretty much all of these dreadful stories,</div><div class='line' id='LC3849'>ecclesiastics were the hardy heroes, but that didn&#39;t worry the</div><div class='line' id='LC3850'>chaplain any, he had his laugh with the rest; more than that, upon</div><div class='line' id='LC3851'>invitation he roared out a song which was of as daring a sort as</div><div class='line' id='LC3852'>any that was sung that night.</div><div class='line' id='LC3853'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3854'>By midnight everybody was fagged out, and sore with laughing; and,</div><div class='line' id='LC3855'>as a rule, drunk: some weepingly, some affectionately, some</div><div class='line' id='LC3856'>hilariously, some quarrelsomely, some dead and under the table.</div><div class='line' id='LC3857'>Of the ladies, the worst spectacle was a lovely young duchess, whose</div><div class='line' id='LC3858'>wedding-eve this was; and indeed she was a spectacle, sure enough.</div><div class='line' id='LC3859'>Just as she was she could have sat in advance for the portrait of the</div><div class='line' id='LC3860'>young daughter of the Regent d&#39;Orleans, at the famous dinner whence</div><div class='line' id='LC3861'>she was carried, foul-mouthed, intoxicated, and helpless, to her bed,</div><div class='line' id='LC3862'>in the lost and lamented days of the Ancient Regime.</div><div class='line' id='LC3863'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3864'>Suddenly, even while the priest was lifting his hands, and all</div><div class='line' id='LC3865'>conscious heads were bowed in reverent expectation of the coming</div><div class='line' id='LC3866'>blessing, there appeared under the arch of the far-off door at</div><div class='line' id='LC3867'>the bottom of the hall an old and bent and white-haired lady,</div><div class='line' id='LC3868'>leaning upon a crutch-stick; and she lifted the stick and pointed it</div><div class='line' id='LC3869'>toward the queen and cried out:</div><div class='line' id='LC3870'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3871'>&quot;The wrath and curse of God fall upon you, woman without pity,</div><div class='line' id='LC3872'>who have slain mine innocent grandchild and made desolate this</div><div class='line' id='LC3873'>old heart that had nor chick, nor friend nor stay nor comfort in</div><div class='line' id='LC3874'>all this world but him!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3875'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3876'>Everybody crossed himself in a grisly fright, for a curse was an</div><div class='line' id='LC3877'>awful thing to those people; but the queen rose up majestic, with</div><div class='line' id='LC3878'>the death-light in her eye, and flung back this ruthless command:</div><div class='line' id='LC3879'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3880'>&quot;Lay hands on her!  To the stake with her!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3881'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3882'>The guards left their posts to obey.  It was a shame; it was a</div><div class='line' id='LC3883'>cruel thing to see.  What could be done?  Sandy gave me a look;</div><div class='line' id='LC3884'>I knew she had another inspiration.  I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC3885'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3886'>&quot;Do what you choose.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3887'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3888'>She was up and facing toward the queen in a moment.  She indicated</div><div class='line' id='LC3889'>me, and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC3890'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3891'>&quot;Madame, _he_ saith this may not be.  Recall the commandment, or he</div><div class='line' id='LC3892'>will dissolve the castle and it shall vanish away like the instable</div><div class='line' id='LC3893'>fabric of a dream!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3894'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3895'>Confound it, what a crazy contract to pledge a person to!  What if</div><div class='line' id='LC3896'>the queen--</div><div class='line' id='LC3897'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3898'>But my consternation subsided there, and my panic passed off;</div><div class='line' id='LC3899'>for the queen, all in a collapse, made no show of resistance but</div><div class='line' id='LC3900'>gave a countermanding sign and sunk into her seat.  When she reached</div><div class='line' id='LC3901'>it she was sober.  So were many of the others.  The assemblage rose,</div><div class='line' id='LC3902'>whiffed ceremony to the winds, and rushed for the door like a mob;</div><div class='line' id='LC3903'>overturning chairs, smashing crockery, tugging, struggling,</div><div class='line' id='LC3904'>shouldering, crowding--anything to get out before I should change</div><div class='line' id='LC3905'>my mind and puff the castle into the measureless dim vacancies of</div><div class='line' id='LC3906'>space.  Well, well, well, they _were_ a superstitious lot.  It is</div><div class='line' id='LC3907'>all a body can do to conceive of it.</div><div class='line' id='LC3908'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3909'>The poor queen was so scared and humbled that she was even afraid</div><div class='line' id='LC3910'>to hang the composer without first consulting me.  I was very sorry</div><div class='line' id='LC3911'>for her--indeed, any one would have been, for she was really</div><div class='line' id='LC3912'>suffering; so I was willing to do anything that was reasonable, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3913'>had no desire to carry things to wanton extremities.  I therefore</div><div class='line' id='LC3914'>considered the matter thoughtfully, and ended by having the</div><div class='line' id='LC3915'>musicians ordered into our presence to play that Sweet Bye and</div><div class='line' id='LC3916'>Bye again, which they did.  Then I saw that she was right, and</div><div class='line' id='LC3917'>gave her permission to hang the whole band.  This little relaxation</div><div class='line' id='LC3918'>of sternness had a good effect upon the queen.  A statesman gains</div><div class='line' id='LC3919'>little by the arbitrary exercise of iron-clad authority upon all</div><div class='line' id='LC3920'>occasions that offer, for this wounds the just pride of his</div><div class='line' id='LC3921'>subordinates, and thus tends to undermine his strength.  A little</div><div class='line' id='LC3922'>concession, now and then, where it can do no harm, is the wiser policy.</div><div class='line' id='LC3923'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3924'>Now that the queen was at ease in her mind once more, and measurably</div><div class='line' id='LC3925'>happy, her wine naturally began to assert itself again, and it got</div><div class='line' id='LC3926'>a little the start of her.  I mean it set her music going--her silver</div><div class='line' id='LC3927'>bell of a tongue.  Dear me, she was a master talker.  It would not</div><div class='line' id='LC3928'>become me to suggest that it was pretty late and that I was a tired</div><div class='line' id='LC3929'>man and very sleepy.  I wished I had gone off to bed when I had</div><div class='line' id='LC3930'>the chance.  Now I must stick it out; there was no other way.  So</div><div class='line' id='LC3931'>she tinkled along and along, in the otherwise profound and ghostly</div><div class='line' id='LC3932'>hush of the sleeping castle, until by and by there came, as if</div><div class='line' id='LC3933'>from deep down under us, a far-away sound, as of a muffled shriek</div><div class='line' id='LC3934'>--with an expression of agony about it that made my flesh crawl.</div><div class='line' id='LC3935'>The queen stopped, and her eyes lighted with pleasure; she tilted</div><div class='line' id='LC3936'>her graceful head as a bird does when it listens.  The sound bored</div><div class='line' id='LC3937'>its way up through the stillness again.</div><div class='line' id='LC3938'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3939'>&quot;What is it?&quot; I said.</div><div class='line' id='LC3940'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3941'>&quot;It is truly a stubborn soul, and endureth long.  It is many hours now.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3942'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3943'>&quot;Endureth what?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3944'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3945'>&quot;The rack.  Come--ye shall see a blithe sight.  An he yield not</div><div class='line' id='LC3946'>his secret now, ye shall see him torn asunder.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3947'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3948'>What a silky smooth hellion she was; and so composed and serene,</div><div class='line' id='LC3949'>when the cords all down my legs were hurting in sympathy with that</div><div class='line' id='LC3950'>man&#39;s pain.  Conducted by mailed guards bearing flaring torches,</div><div class='line' id='LC3951'>we tramped along echoing corridors, and down stone stairways dank</div><div class='line' id='LC3952'>and dripping, and smelling of mould and ages of imprisoned night</div><div class='line' id='LC3953'>--a chill, uncanny journey and a long one, and not made the shorter</div><div class='line' id='LC3954'>or the cheerier by the sorceress&#39;s talk, which was about this</div><div class='line' id='LC3955'>sufferer and his crime.  He had been accused by an anonymous</div><div class='line' id='LC3956'>informer, of having killed a stag in the royal preserves.  I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC3957'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3958'>&quot;Anonymous testimony isn&#39;t just the right thing, your Highness.</div><div class='line' id='LC3959'>It were fairer to confront the accused with the accuser.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3960'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3961'>&quot;I had not thought of that, it being but of small consequence.</div><div class='line' id='LC3962'>But an I would, I could not, for that the accuser came masked by</div><div class='line' id='LC3963'>night, and told the forester, and straightway got him hence again,</div><div class='line' id='LC3964'>and so the forester knoweth him not.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3965'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3966'>&quot;Then is this Unknown the only person who saw the stag killed?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3967'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3968'>&quot;Marry, _no_ man _saw_ the killing, but this Unknown saw this hardy</div><div class='line' id='LC3969'>wretch near to the spot where the stag lay, and came with right</div><div class='line' id='LC3970'>loyal zeal and betrayed him to the forester.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3971'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3972'>&quot;So the Unknown was near the dead stag, too?  Isn&#39;t it just possible</div><div class='line' id='LC3973'>that he did the killing himself?  His loyal zeal--in a mask--looks</div><div class='line' id='LC3974'>just a shade suspicious.  But what is your highness&#39;s idea for</div><div class='line' id='LC3975'>racking the prisoner?  Where is the profit?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3976'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3977'>&quot;He will not confess, else; and then were his soul lost.  For his</div><div class='line' id='LC3978'>crime his life is forfeited by the law--and of a surety will I see</div><div class='line' id='LC3979'>that he payeth it!--but it were peril to my own soul to let him</div><div class='line' id='LC3980'>die unconfessed and unabsolved.  Nay, I were a fool to fling me</div><div class='line' id='LC3981'>into hell for _his_ accommodation.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3982'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3983'>&quot;But, your Highness, suppose he has nothing to confess?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3984'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3985'>&quot;As to that, we shall see, anon.  An I rack him to death and he</div><div class='line' id='LC3986'>confess not, it will peradventure show that he had indeed naught</div><div class='line' id='LC3987'>to confess--ye will grant that that is sooth?  Then shall I not be</div><div class='line' id='LC3988'>damned for an unconfessed man that had naught to confess</div><div class='line' id='LC3989'>--wherefore, I shall be safe.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC3990'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3991'>It was the stubborn unreasoning of the time.  It was useless to</div><div class='line' id='LC3992'>argue with her.  Arguments have no chance against petrified</div><div class='line' id='LC3993'>training; they wear it as little as the waves wear a cliff.  And</div><div class='line' id='LC3994'>her training was everybody&#39;s.  The brightest intellect in the land</div><div class='line' id='LC3995'>would not have been able to see that her position was defective.</div><div class='line' id='LC3996'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC3997'>As we entered the rack-cell I caught a picture that will not go</div><div class='line' id='LC3998'>from me; I wish it would.  A native young giant of thirty or</div><div class='line' id='LC3999'>thereabouts lay stretched upon the frame on his back, with his</div><div class='line' id='LC4000'>wrists and ankles tied to ropes which led over windlasses at either</div><div class='line' id='LC4001'>end.  There was no color in him; his features were contorted and</div><div class='line' id='LC4002'>set, and sweat-drops stood upon his forehead.  A priest bent over</div><div class='line' id='LC4003'>him on each side; the executioner stood by; guards were on duty;</div><div class='line' id='LC4004'>smoking torches stood in sockets along the walls; in a corner</div><div class='line' id='LC4005'>crouched a poor young creature, her face drawn with anguish,</div><div class='line' id='LC4006'>a half-wild and hunted look in her eyes, and in her lap lay a little</div><div class='line' id='LC4007'>child asleep.  Just as we stepped across the threshold the</div><div class='line' id='LC4008'>executioner gave his machine a slight turn, which wrung a cry</div><div class='line' id='LC4009'>from both the prisoner and the woman; but I shouted, and the</div><div class='line' id='LC4010'>executioner released the strain without waiting to see who spoke.</div><div class='line' id='LC4011'>I could not let this horror go on; it would have killed me to</div><div class='line' id='LC4012'>see it.  I asked the queen to let me clear the place and speak</div><div class='line' id='LC4013'>to the prisoner privately; and when she was going to object I spoke</div><div class='line' id='LC4014'>in a low voice and said I did not want to make a scene before</div><div class='line' id='LC4015'>her servants, but I must have my way; for I was King Arthur&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC4016'>representative, and was speaking in his name.  She saw she had</div><div class='line' id='LC4017'>to yield.  I asked her to indorse me to these people, and then</div><div class='line' id='LC4018'>leave me.  It was not pleasant for her, but she took the pill;</div><div class='line' id='LC4019'>and even went further than I was meaning to require.  I only wanted</div><div class='line' id='LC4020'>the backing of her own authority; but she said:</div><div class='line' id='LC4021'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4022'>&quot;Ye will do in all things as this lord shall command.  It is The Boss.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4023'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4024'>It was certainly a good word to conjure with: you could see it</div><div class='line' id='LC4025'>by the squirming of these rats.  The queen&#39;s guards fell into line,</div><div class='line' id='LC4026'>and she and they marched away, with their torch-bearers, and woke</div><div class='line' id='LC4027'>the echoes of the cavernous tunnels with the measured beat of their</div><div class='line' id='LC4028'>retreating footfalls.  I had the prisoner taken from the rack and</div><div class='line' id='LC4029'>placed upon his bed, and medicaments applied to his hurts, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4030'>wine given him to drink.  The woman crept near and looked on,</div><div class='line' id='LC4031'>eagerly, lovingly, but timorously,--like one who fears a repulse;</div><div class='line' id='LC4032'>indeed, she tried furtively to touch the man&#39;s forehead, and jumped</div><div class='line' id='LC4033'>back, the picture of fright, when I turned unconsciously toward</div><div class='line' id='LC4034'>her.  It was pitiful to see.</div><div class='line' id='LC4035'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4036'>&quot;Lord,&quot; I said, &quot;stroke him, lass, if you want to.  Do anything</div><div class='line' id='LC4037'>you&#39;re a mind to; don&#39;t mind me.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4038'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4039'>Why, her eyes were as grateful as an animal&#39;s, when you do it</div><div class='line' id='LC4040'>a kindness that it understands.  The baby was out of her way and</div><div class='line' id='LC4041'>she had her cheek against the man&#39;s in a minute and her hands</div><div class='line' id='LC4042'>fondling his hair, and her happy tears running down.  The man</div><div class='line' id='LC4043'>revived and caressed his wife with his eyes, which was all he</div><div class='line' id='LC4044'>could do.  I judged I might clear the den, now, and I did; cleared</div><div class='line' id='LC4045'>it of all but the family and myself.  Then I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC4046'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4047'>&quot;Now, my friend, tell me your side of this matter; I know</div><div class='line' id='LC4048'>the other side.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4049'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4050'>The man moved his head in sign of refusal.  But the woman looked</div><div class='line' id='LC4051'>pleased--as it seemed to me--pleased with my suggestion.  I went on--</div><div class='line' id='LC4052'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4053'>&quot;You know of me?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4054'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4055'>&quot;Yes.  All do, in Arthur&#39;s realms.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4056'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4057'>&quot;If my reputation has come to you right and straight, you should</div><div class='line' id='LC4058'>not be afraid to speak.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4059'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4060'>The woman broke in, eagerly:</div><div class='line' id='LC4061'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4062'>&quot;Ah, fair my lord, do thou persuade him!  Thou canst an thou wilt.</div><div class='line' id='LC4063'>Ah, he suffereth so; and it is for me--for _me_!  And how can I bear it?</div><div class='line' id='LC4064'>I would I might see him die--a sweet, swift death; oh, my Hugo,</div><div class='line' id='LC4065'>I cannot bear this one!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4066'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4067'>And she fell to sobbing and grovelling about my feet, and still</div><div class='line' id='LC4068'>imploring.  Imploring what?  The man&#39;s death?  I could not quite</div><div class='line' id='LC4069'>get the bearings of the thing.  But Hugo interrupted her and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC4070'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4071'>&quot;Peace!  Ye wit not what ye ask.  Shall I starve whom I love,</div><div class='line' id='LC4072'>to win a gentle death?  I wend thou knewest me better.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4073'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4074'>&quot;Well,&quot; I said, &quot;I can&#39;t quite make this out.  It is a puzzle.  Now--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4075'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4076'>&quot;Ah, dear my lord, an ye will but persuade him!  Consider how</div><div class='line' id='LC4077'>these his tortures wound me!  Oh, and he will not speak!--whereas,</div><div class='line' id='LC4078'>the healing, the solace that lie in a blessed swift death--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4079'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4080'>&quot;What _are_ you maundering about?  He&#39;s going out from here a free</div><div class='line' id='LC4081'>man and whole--he&#39;s not going to die.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4082'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4083'>The man&#39;s white face lit up, and the woman flung herself at me</div><div class='line' id='LC4084'>in a most surprising explosion of joy, and cried out:</div><div class='line' id='LC4085'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4086'>&quot;He is saved!--for it is the king&#39;s word by the mouth of the king&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC4087'>servant--Arthur, the king whose word is gold!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4088'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4089'>&quot;Well, then you do believe I can be trusted, after all.  Why</div><div class='line' id='LC4090'>didn&#39;t you before?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4091'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4092'>&quot;Who doubted?  Not I, indeed; and not she.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4093'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4094'>&quot;Well, why wouldn&#39;t you tell me your story, then?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4095'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4096'>&quot;Ye had made no promise; else had it been otherwise.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4097'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4098'>&quot;I see, I see....  And yet I believe I don&#39;t quite see, after all.</div><div class='line' id='LC4099'>You stood the torture and refused to confess; which shows plain</div><div class='line' id='LC4100'>enough to even the dullest understanding that you had nothing</div><div class='line' id='LC4101'>to confess--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4102'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4103'>&quot;I, my lord?  How so?  It was I that killed the deer!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4104'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4105'>&quot;You _did_?  Oh, dear, this is the most mixed-up business that ever--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4106'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4107'>&quot;Dear lord, I begged him on my knees to confess, but--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4108'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4109'>&quot;You _did_!  It gets thicker and thicker.  What did you want him</div><div class='line' id='LC4110'>to do that for?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4111'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4112'>&quot;Sith it would bring him a quick death and save him all this</div><div class='line' id='LC4113'>cruel pain.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4114'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4115'>&quot;Well--yes, there is reason in that.  But _he_ didn&#39;t want the</div><div class='line' id='LC4116'>quick death.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4117'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4118'>&quot;He?  Why, of a surety he _did_.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4119'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4120'>&quot;Well, then, why in the world _didn&#39;t_ he confess?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4121'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4122'>&quot;Ah, sweet sir, and leave my wife and chick without bread and shelter?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4123'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4124'>&quot;Oh, heart of gold, now I see it!  The bitter law takes the convicted</div><div class='line' id='LC4125'>man&#39;s estate and beggars his widow and his orphans.  They could</div><div class='line' id='LC4126'>torture you to death, but without conviction or confession they</div><div class='line' id='LC4127'>could not rob your wife and baby.  You stood by them like a man;</div><div class='line' id='LC4128'>and _you_--true wife and the woman that you are--you would have</div><div class='line' id='LC4129'>bought him release from torture at cost to yourself of slow</div><div class='line' id='LC4130'>starvation and death--well, it humbles a body to think what your</div><div class='line' id='LC4131'>sex can do when it comes to self-sacrifice.  I&#39;ll book you both</div><div class='line' id='LC4132'>for my colony; you&#39;ll like it there; it&#39;s a Factory where I&#39;m going</div><div class='line' id='LC4133'>to turn groping and grubbing automata into _men_.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4134'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4135'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4136'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4137'>CHAPTER XVIII</div><div class='line' id='LC4138'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4139'>IN THE QUEEN&#39;S DUNGEONS</div><div class='line' id='LC4140'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4141'>Well, I arranged all that; and I had the man sent to his home.</div><div class='line' id='LC4142'>I had a great desire to rack the executioner; not because he was</div><div class='line' id='LC4143'>a good, painstaking and paingiving official,--for surely it was</div><div class='line' id='LC4144'>not to his discredit that he performed his functions well--but to</div><div class='line' id='LC4145'>pay him back for wantonly cuffing and otherwise distressing that</div><div class='line' id='LC4146'>young woman.  The priests told me about this, and were generously</div><div class='line' id='LC4147'>hot to have him punished.  Something of this disagreeable sort</div><div class='line' id='LC4148'>was turning up every now and then.  I mean, episodes that showed</div><div class='line' id='LC4149'>that not all priests were frauds and self-seekers, but that many,</div><div class='line' id='LC4150'>even the great majority, of these that were down on the ground</div><div class='line' id='LC4151'>among the common people, were sincere and right-hearted, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4152'>devoted to the alleviation of human troubles and sufferings.</div><div class='line' id='LC4153'>Well, it was a thing which could not be helped, so I seldom fretted</div><div class='line' id='LC4154'>about it, and never many minutes at a time; it has never been my</div><div class='line' id='LC4155'>way to bother much about things which you can&#39;t cure.  But I did</div><div class='line' id='LC4156'>not like it, for it was just the sort of thing to keep people</div><div class='line' id='LC4157'>reconciled to an Established Church.  We _must_ have a religion</div><div class='line' id='LC4158'>--it goes without saying--but my idea is, to have it cut up into</div><div class='line' id='LC4159'>forty free sects, so that they will police each other, as had been</div><div class='line' id='LC4160'>the case in the United States in my time.  Concentration of power</div><div class='line' id='LC4161'>in a political machine is bad; and an Established Church is</div><div class='line' id='LC4162'>only a political machine; it was invented for that; it is nursed,</div><div class='line' id='LC4163'>cradled, preserved for that; it is an enemy to human liberty, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4164'>does no good which it could not better do in a split-up and scattered</div><div class='line' id='LC4165'>condition.  That wasn&#39;t law; it wasn&#39;t gospel: it was only</div><div class='line' id='LC4166'>an opinion--my opinion, and I was only a man, one man: so it wasn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC4167'>worth any more than the pope&#39;s--or any less, for that matter.</div><div class='line' id='LC4168'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4169'>Well, I couldn&#39;t rack the executioner, neither would I overlook</div><div class='line' id='LC4170'>the just complaint of the priests.  The man must be punished</div><div class='line' id='LC4171'>somehow or other, so I degraded him from his office and made him</div><div class='line' id='LC4172'>leader of the band--the new one that was to be started.  He begged</div><div class='line' id='LC4173'>hard, and said he couldn&#39;t play--a plausible excuse, but too thin;</div><div class='line' id='LC4174'>there wasn&#39;t a musician in the country that could.</div><div class='line' id='LC4175'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4176'>The queen was a good deal outraged, next morning when she found</div><div class='line' id='LC4177'>she was going to have neither Hugo&#39;s life nor his property.  But</div><div class='line' id='LC4178'>I told her she must bear this cross; that while by law and custom</div><div class='line' id='LC4179'>she certainly was entitled to both the man&#39;s life and his property,</div><div class='line' id='LC4180'>there were extenuating circumstances, and so in Arthur the king&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC4181'>name I had pardoned him.  The deer was ravaging the man&#39;s fields,</div><div class='line' id='LC4182'>and he had killed it in sudden passion, and not for gain; and he</div><div class='line' id='LC4183'>had carried it into the royal forest in the hope that that might make</div><div class='line' id='LC4184'>detection of the misdoer impossible.  Confound her, I couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC4185'>make her see that sudden passion is an extenuating circumstance</div><div class='line' id='LC4186'>in the killing of venison--or of a person--so I gave it up and let</div><div class='line' id='LC4187'>her sulk it out.  I _did_ think I was going to make her see it by</div><div class='line' id='LC4188'>remarking that her own sudden passion in the case of the page</div><div class='line' id='LC4189'>modified that crime.</div><div class='line' id='LC4190'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4191'>&quot;Crime!&quot; she exclaimed.  &quot;How thou talkest!  Crime, forsooth!</div><div class='line' id='LC4192'>Man, I am going to _pay_ for him!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4193'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4194'>Oh, it was no use to waste sense on her.  Training--training is</div><div class='line' id='LC4195'>everything; training is all there is _to_ a person.  We speak of</div><div class='line' id='LC4196'>nature; it is folly; there is no such thing as nature; what we</div><div class='line' id='LC4197'>call by that misleading name is merely heredity and training.</div><div class='line' id='LC4198'>We have no thoughts of our own, no opinions of our own; they are</div><div class='line' id='LC4199'>transmitted to us, trained into us.  All that is original in us,</div><div class='line' id='LC4200'>and therefore fairly creditable or discreditable to us, can be</div><div class='line' id='LC4201'>covered up and hidden by the point of a cambric needle, all the</div><div class='line' id='LC4202'>rest being atoms contributed by, and inherited from, a procession</div><div class='line' id='LC4203'>of ancestors that stretches back a billion years to the Adam-clam</div><div class='line' id='LC4204'>or grasshopper or monkey from whom our race has been so tediously</div><div class='line' id='LC4205'>and ostentatiously and unprofitably developed.  And as for me,</div><div class='line' id='LC4206'>all that I think about in this plodding sad pilgrimage, this</div><div class='line' id='LC4207'>pathetic drift between the eternities, is to look out and humbly</div><div class='line' id='LC4208'>live a pure and high and blameless life, and save that one</div><div class='line' id='LC4209'>microscopic atom in me that is truly _me_: the rest may land in</div><div class='line' id='LC4210'>Sheol and welcome for all I care.</div><div class='line' id='LC4211'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4212'>No, confound her, her intellect was good, she had brains enough,</div><div class='line' id='LC4213'>but her training made her an ass--that is, from a many-centuries-later</div><div class='line' id='LC4214'>point of view.  To kill the page was no crime--it was her right;</div><div class='line' id='LC4215'>and upon her right she stood, serenely and unconscious of offense.</div><div class='line' id='LC4216'>She was a result of generations of training in the unexamined and</div><div class='line' id='LC4217'>unassailed belief that the law which permitted her to kill a subject</div><div class='line' id='LC4218'>when she chose was a perfectly right and righteous one.</div><div class='line' id='LC4219'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4220'>Well, we must give even Satan his due.  She deserved a compliment</div><div class='line' id='LC4221'>for one thing; and I tried to pay it, but the words stuck in my</div><div class='line' id='LC4222'>throat.  She had a right to kill the boy, but she was in no wise</div><div class='line' id='LC4223'>obliged to pay for him.  That was law for some other people, but</div><div class='line' id='LC4224'>not for her.  She knew quite well that she was doing a large and</div><div class='line' id='LC4225'>generous thing to pay for that lad, and that I ought in common</div><div class='line' id='LC4226'>fairness to come out with something handsome about it, but I</div><div class='line' id='LC4227'>couldn&#39;t--my mouth refused.  I couldn&#39;t help seeing, in my fancy,</div><div class='line' id='LC4228'>that poor old grandma with the broken heart, and that fair young</div><div class='line' id='LC4229'>creature lying butchered, his little silken pomps and vanities</div><div class='line' id='LC4230'>laced with his golden blood.  How could she _pay_ for him!  _Whom_</div><div class='line' id='LC4231'>could she pay?  And so, well knowing that this woman, trained</div><div class='line' id='LC4232'>as she had been, deserved praise, even adulation, I was yet not</div><div class='line' id='LC4233'>able to utter it, trained as I had been.  The best I could do was</div><div class='line' id='LC4234'>to fish up a compliment from outside, so to speak--and the pity</div><div class='line' id='LC4235'>of it was, that it was true:</div><div class='line' id='LC4236'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4237'>&quot;Madame, your people will adore you for this.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4238'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4239'>Quite true, but I meant to hang her for it some day if I lived.</div><div class='line' id='LC4240'>Some of those laws were too bad, altogether too bad.  A master</div><div class='line' id='LC4241'>might kill his slave for nothing--for mere spite, malice, or</div><div class='line' id='LC4242'>to pass the time--just as we have seen that the crowned head could</div><div class='line' id='LC4243'>do it with _his_ slave, that is to say, anybody.  A gentleman could</div><div class='line' id='LC4244'>kill a free commoner, and pay for him--cash or garden-truck.</div><div class='line' id='LC4245'>A noble could kill a noble without expense, as far as the law was</div><div class='line' id='LC4246'>concerned, but reprisals in kind were to be expected.  _Any_body</div><div class='line' id='LC4247'>could kill _some_body, except the commoner and the slave; these had</div><div class='line' id='LC4248'>no privileges.  If they killed, it was murder, and the law wouldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC4249'>stand murder.  It made short work of the experimenter--and of</div><div class='line' id='LC4250'>his family, too, if he murdered somebody who belonged up among</div><div class='line' id='LC4251'>the ornamental ranks.  If a commoner gave a noble even so much</div><div class='line' id='LC4252'>as a Damiens-scratch which didn&#39;t kill or even hurt, he got Damiens&#39;</div><div class='line' id='LC4253'>dose for it just the same; they pulled him to rags and tatters</div><div class='line' id='LC4254'>with horses, and all the world came to see the show, and crack</div><div class='line' id='LC4255'>jokes, and have a good time; and some of the performances of the</div><div class='line' id='LC4256'>best people present were as tough, and as properly unprintable,</div><div class='line' id='LC4257'>as any that have been printed by the pleasant Casanova in his</div><div class='line' id='LC4258'>chapter about the dismemberment of Louis XV&#39;s poor awkward enemy.</div><div class='line' id='LC4259'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4260'>I had had enough of this grisly place by this time, and wanted</div><div class='line' id='LC4261'>to leave, but I couldn&#39;t, because I had something on my mind that</div><div class='line' id='LC4262'>my conscience kept prodding me about, and wouldn&#39;t let me forget.</div><div class='line' id='LC4263'>If I had the remaking of man, he wouldn&#39;t have any conscience.</div><div class='line' id='LC4264'>It is one of the most disagreeable things connected with a person;</div><div class='line' id='LC4265'>and although it certainly does a great deal of good, it cannot</div><div class='line' id='LC4266'>be said to pay, in the long run; it would be much better to have</div><div class='line' id='LC4267'>less good and more comfort.  Still, this is only my opinion, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4268'>I am only one man; others, with less experience, may think</div><div class='line' id='LC4269'>differently.  They have a right to their view.  I only stand</div><div class='line' id='LC4270'>to this: I have noticed my conscience for many years, and I know</div><div class='line' id='LC4271'>it is more trouble and bother to me than anything else I started</div><div class='line' id='LC4272'>with.  I suppose that in the beginning I prized it, because we</div><div class='line' id='LC4273'>prize anything that is ours; and yet how foolish it was to think so.</div><div class='line' id='LC4274'>If we look at it in another way, we see how absurd it is: if I had</div><div class='line' id='LC4275'>an anvil in me would I prize it?  Of course not.  And yet when you</div><div class='line' id='LC4276'>come to think, there is no real difference between a conscience</div><div class='line' id='LC4277'>and an anvil--I mean for comfort.  I have noticed it a thousand</div><div class='line' id='LC4278'>times.  And you could dissolve an anvil with acids, when you</div><div class='line' id='LC4279'>couldn&#39;t stand it any longer; but there isn&#39;t any way that you can</div><div class='line' id='LC4280'>work off a conscience--at least so it will stay worked off; not</div><div class='line' id='LC4281'>that I know of, anyway.</div><div class='line' id='LC4282'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4283'>There was something I wanted to do before leaving, but it was</div><div class='line' id='LC4284'>a disagreeable matter, and I hated to go at it.  Well, it bothered</div><div class='line' id='LC4285'>me all the morning.  I could have mentioned it to the old king,</div><div class='line' id='LC4286'>but what would be the use?--he was but an extinct volcano; he had</div><div class='line' id='LC4287'>been active in his time, but his fire was out, this good while,</div><div class='line' id='LC4288'>he was only a stately ash-pile now; gentle enough, and kindly</div><div class='line' id='LC4289'>enough for my purpose, without doubt, but not usable.  He was</div><div class='line' id='LC4290'>nothing, this so-called king: the queen was the only power there.</div><div class='line' id='LC4291'>And she was a Vesuvius.  As a favor, she might consent to warm</div><div class='line' id='LC4292'>a flock of sparrows for you, but then she might take that very</div><div class='line' id='LC4293'>opportunity to turn herself loose and bury a city.  However,</div><div class='line' id='LC4294'>I reflected that as often as any other way, when you are expecting</div><div class='line' id='LC4295'>the worst, you get something that is not so bad, after all.</div><div class='line' id='LC4296'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4297'>So I braced up and placed my matter before her royal Highness.</div><div class='line' id='LC4298'>I said I had been having a general jail-delivery at Camelot and</div><div class='line' id='LC4299'>among neighboring castles, and with her permission I would like</div><div class='line' id='LC4300'>to examine her collection, her bric-a-brac--that is to say, her</div><div class='line' id='LC4301'>prisoners.  She resisted; but I was expecting that.  But she finally</div><div class='line' id='LC4302'>consented.  I was expecting that, too, but not so soon.  That about</div><div class='line' id='LC4303'>ended my discomfort.  She called her guards and torches, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4304'>we went down into the dungeons.  These were down under the castle&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC4305'>foundations, and mainly were small cells hollowed out of the living</div><div class='line' id='LC4306'>rock.  Some of these cells had no light at all.  In one of them was</div><div class='line' id='LC4307'>a woman, in foul rags, who sat on the ground, and would not answer</div><div class='line' id='LC4308'>a question or speak a word, but only looked up at us once or twice,</div><div class='line' id='LC4309'>through a cobweb of tangled hair, as if to see what casual thing</div><div class='line' id='LC4310'>it might be that was disturbing with sound and light the meaningless</div><div class='line' id='LC4311'>dull dream that was become her life; after that, she sat bowed,</div><div class='line' id='LC4312'>with her dirt-caked fingers idly interlocked in her lap, and gave</div><div class='line' id='LC4313'>no further sign.  This poor rack of bones was a woman of middle</div><div class='line' id='LC4314'>age, apparently; but only apparently; she had been there nine</div><div class='line' id='LC4315'>years, and was eighteen when she entered.  She was a commoner,</div><div class='line' id='LC4316'>and had been sent here on her bridal night by Sir Breuse Sance Pite,</div><div class='line' id='LC4317'>a neighboring lord whose vassal her father was, and to which said</div><div class='line' id='LC4318'>lord she had refused what has since been called le droit du</div><div class='line' id='LC4319'>seigneur, and, moreover, had opposed violence to violence and spilt</div><div class='line' id='LC4320'>half a gill of his almost sacred blood.  The young husband had</div><div class='line' id='LC4321'>interfered at that point, believing the bride&#39;s life in danger,</div><div class='line' id='LC4322'>and had flung the noble out into the midst of the humble and</div><div class='line' id='LC4323'>trembling wedding guests, in the parlor, and left him there</div><div class='line' id='LC4324'>astonished at this strange treatment, and implacably embittered</div><div class='line' id='LC4325'>against both bride and groom.  The said lord being cramped for</div><div class='line' id='LC4326'>dungeon-room had asked the queen to accommodate his two criminals,</div><div class='line' id='LC4327'>and here in her bastile they had been ever since; hither, indeed,</div><div class='line' id='LC4328'>they had come before their crime was an hour old, and had never</div><div class='line' id='LC4329'>seen each other since.  Here they were, kenneled like toads in the</div><div class='line' id='LC4330'>same rock; they had passed nine pitch dark years within fifty feet</div><div class='line' id='LC4331'>of each other, yet neither knew whether the other was alive or not.</div><div class='line' id='LC4332'>All the first years, their only question had been--asked with</div><div class='line' id='LC4333'>beseechings and tears that might have moved stones, in time,</div><div class='line' id='LC4334'>perhaps, but hearts are not stones: &quot;Is he alive?&quot;  &quot;Is she alive?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4335'>But they had never got an answer; and at last that question was</div><div class='line' id='LC4336'>not asked any more--or any other.</div><div class='line' id='LC4337'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4338'>I wanted to see the man, after hearing all this.  He was thirty-four</div><div class='line' id='LC4339'>years old, and looked sixty.  He sat upon a squared block of</div><div class='line' id='LC4340'>stone, with his head bent down, his forearms resting on his knees,</div><div class='line' id='LC4341'>his long hair hanging like a fringe before his face, and he was</div><div class='line' id='LC4342'>muttering to himself.  He raised his chin and looked us slowly</div><div class='line' id='LC4343'>over, in a listless dull way, blinking with the distress of the</div><div class='line' id='LC4344'>torchlight, then dropped his head and fell to muttering again</div><div class='line' id='LC4345'>and took no further notice of us.  There were some pathetically</div><div class='line' id='LC4346'>suggestive dumb witnesses present.  On his wrists and ankles were</div><div class='line' id='LC4347'>cicatrices, old smooth scars, and fastened to the stone on which</div><div class='line' id='LC4348'>he sat was a chain with manacles and fetters attached; but this</div><div class='line' id='LC4349'>apparatus lay idle on the ground, and was thick with rust.  Chains</div><div class='line' id='LC4350'>cease to be needed after the spirit has gone out of a prisoner.</div><div class='line' id='LC4351'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4352'>I could not rouse the man; so I said we would take him to her,</div><div class='line' id='LC4353'>and see--to the bride who was the fairest thing in the earth to him,</div><div class='line' id='LC4354'>once--roses, pearls, and dew made flesh, for him; a wonder-work,</div><div class='line' id='LC4355'>the master-work of nature: with eyes like no other eyes, and voice</div><div class='line' id='LC4356'>like no other voice, and a freshness, and lithe young grace, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4357'>beauty, that belonged properly to the creatures of dreams--as he</div><div class='line' id='LC4358'>thought--and to no other.  The sight of her would set his stagnant</div><div class='line' id='LC4359'>blood leaping; the sight of her--</div><div class='line' id='LC4360'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4361'>But it was a disappointment.  They sat together on the ground and</div><div class='line' id='LC4362'>looked dimly wondering into each other&#39;s faces a while, with a</div><div class='line' id='LC4363'>sort of weak animal curiosity; then forgot each other&#39;s presence,</div><div class='line' id='LC4364'>and dropped their eyes, and you saw that they were away again and</div><div class='line' id='LC4365'>wandering in some far land of dreams and shadows that we know</div><div class='line' id='LC4366'>nothing about.</div><div class='line' id='LC4367'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4368'>I had them taken out and sent to their friends.  The queen did not</div><div class='line' id='LC4369'>like it much.  Not that she felt any personal interest in the matter,</div><div class='line' id='LC4370'>but she thought it disrespectful to Sir Breuse Sance Pite.  However,</div><div class='line' id='LC4371'>I assured her that if he found he couldn&#39;t stand it I would fix him</div><div class='line' id='LC4372'>so that he could.</div><div class='line' id='LC4373'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4374'>I set forty-seven prisoners loose out of those awful rat-holes,</div><div class='line' id='LC4375'>and left only one in captivity.  He was a lord, and had killed</div><div class='line' id='LC4376'>another lord, a sort of kinsman of the queen.  That other lord</div><div class='line' id='LC4377'>had ambushed him to assassinate him, but this fellow had got the</div><div class='line' id='LC4378'>best of him and cut his throat.  However, it was not for that that</div><div class='line' id='LC4379'>I left him jailed, but for maliciously destroying the only public</div><div class='line' id='LC4380'>well in one of his wretched villages.  The queen was bound to hang</div><div class='line' id='LC4381'>him for killing her kinsman, but I would not allow it: it was no</div><div class='line' id='LC4382'>crime to kill an assassin.  But I said I was willing to let her</div><div class='line' id='LC4383'>hang him for destroying the well; so she concluded to put up with</div><div class='line' id='LC4384'>that, as it was better than nothing.</div><div class='line' id='LC4385'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4386'>Dear me, for what trifling offenses the most of those forty-seven</div><div class='line' id='LC4387'>men and women were shut up there!  Indeed, some were there for</div><div class='line' id='LC4388'>no distinct offense at all, but only to gratify somebody&#39;s spite;</div><div class='line' id='LC4389'>and not always the queen&#39;s by any means, but a friend&#39;s.  The newest</div><div class='line' id='LC4390'>prisoner&#39;s crime was a mere remark which he had made.  He said</div><div class='line' id='LC4391'>he believed that men were about all alike, and one man as good</div><div class='line' id='LC4392'>as another, barring clothes.  He said he believed that if you were</div><div class='line' id='LC4393'>to strip the nation naked and send a stranger through the crowd, he</div><div class='line' id='LC4394'>couldn&#39;t tell the king from a quack doctor, nor a duke from a hotel</div><div class='line' id='LC4395'>clerk.  Apparently here was a man whose brains had not been reduced</div><div class='line' id='LC4396'>to an ineffectual mush by idiotic training.  I set him loose and</div><div class='line' id='LC4397'>sent him to the Factory.</div><div class='line' id='LC4398'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4399'>Some of the cells carved in the living rock were just behind the</div><div class='line' id='LC4400'>face of the precipice, and in each of these an arrow-slit had been</div><div class='line' id='LC4401'>pierced outward to the daylight, and so the captive had a thin</div><div class='line' id='LC4402'>ray from the blessed sun for his comfort.  The case of one of</div><div class='line' id='LC4403'>these poor fellows was particularly hard.  From his dusky swallow&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC4404'>hole high up in that vast wall of native rock he could peer out</div><div class='line' id='LC4405'>through the arrow-slit and see his own home off yonder in the</div><div class='line' id='LC4406'>valley; and for twenty-two years he had watched it, with heartache</div><div class='line' id='LC4407'>and longing, through that crack.  He could see the lights shine</div><div class='line' id='LC4408'>there at night, and in the daytime he could see figures go in and</div><div class='line' id='LC4409'>come out--his wife and children, some of them, no doubt, though</div><div class='line' id='LC4410'>he could not make out at that distance.  In the course of years</div><div class='line' id='LC4411'>he noted festivities there, and tried to rejoice, and wondered</div><div class='line' id='LC4412'>if they were weddings or what they might be.  And he noted funerals;</div><div class='line' id='LC4413'>and they wrung his heart.  He could make out the coffin, but he</div><div class='line' id='LC4414'>could not determine its size, and so could not tell whether it was</div><div class='line' id='LC4415'>wife or child.  He could see the procession form, with priests</div><div class='line' id='LC4416'>and mourners, and move solemnly away, bearing the secret with</div><div class='line' id='LC4417'>them.  He had left behind him five children and a wife; and in</div><div class='line' id='LC4418'>nineteen years he had seen five funerals issue, and none of them</div><div class='line' id='LC4419'>humble enough in pomp to denote a servant.  So he had lost five</div><div class='line' id='LC4420'>of his treasures; there must still be one remaining--one now</div><div class='line' id='LC4421'>infinitely, unspeakably precious,--but _which_ one? wife, or child?</div><div class='line' id='LC4422'>That was the question that tortured him, by night and by day,</div><div class='line' id='LC4423'>asleep and awake.  Well, to have an interest, of some sort, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4424'>half a ray of light, when you are in a dungeon, is a great support</div><div class='line' id='LC4425'>to the body and preserver of the intellect.  This man was in pretty</div><div class='line' id='LC4426'>good condition yet.  By the time he had finished telling me his</div><div class='line' id='LC4427'>distressful tale, I was in the same state of mind that you would</div><div class='line' id='LC4428'>have been in yourself, if you have got average human curiosity;</div><div class='line' id='LC4429'>that is to say, I was as burning up as he was to find out which</div><div class='line' id='LC4430'>member of the family it was that was left.  So I took him over</div><div class='line' id='LC4431'>home myself; and an amazing kind of a surprise party it was, too</div><div class='line' id='LC4432'>--typhoons and cyclones of frantic joy, and whole Niagaras of happy</div><div class='line' id='LC4433'>tears; and by George! we found the aforetime young matron graying</div><div class='line' id='LC4434'>toward the imminent verge of her half century, and the babies all</div><div class='line' id='LC4435'>men and women, and some of them married and experimenting familywise</div><div class='line' id='LC4436'>themselves--for not a soul of the tribe was dead!  Conceive of the</div><div class='line' id='LC4437'>ingenious devilishness of that queen: she had a special hatred for</div><div class='line' id='LC4438'>this prisoner, and she had _invented_ all those funerals herself,</div><div class='line' id='LC4439'>to scorch his heart with; and the sublimest stroke of genius of</div><div class='line' id='LC4440'>the whole thing was leaving the family-invoice a funeral _short_,</div><div class='line' id='LC4441'>so as to let him wear his poor old soul out guessing.</div><div class='line' id='LC4442'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4443'>But for me, he never would have got out.  Morgan le Fay hated him</div><div class='line' id='LC4444'>with her whole heart, and she never would have softened toward him.</div><div class='line' id='LC4445'>And yet his crime was committed more in thoughtlessness than</div><div class='line' id='LC4446'>deliberate depravity.  He had said she had red hair.  Well, she</div><div class='line' id='LC4447'>had; but that was no way to speak of it.  When red-headed people</div><div class='line' id='LC4448'>are above a certain social grade their hair is auburn.</div><div class='line' id='LC4449'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4450'>Consider it: among these forty-seven captives there were five</div><div class='line' id='LC4451'>whose names, offenses, and dates of incarceration were no longer</div><div class='line' id='LC4452'>known!  One woman and four men--all bent, and wrinkled, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4453'>mind-extinguished patriarchs.  They themselves had long ago forgotten</div><div class='line' id='LC4454'>these details; at any rate they had mere vague theories about them,</div><div class='line' id='LC4455'>nothing definite and nothing that they repeated twice in the same</div><div class='line' id='LC4456'>way.  The succession of priests whose office it had been to pray</div><div class='line' id='LC4457'>daily with the captives and remind them that God had put them</div><div class='line' id='LC4458'>there, for some wise purpose or other, and teach them that patience,</div><div class='line' id='LC4459'>humbleness, and submission to oppression was what He loved to see</div><div class='line' id='LC4460'>in parties of a subordinate rank, had traditions about these poor</div><div class='line' id='LC4461'>old human ruins, but nothing more.  These traditions went but</div><div class='line' id='LC4462'>little way, for they concerned the length of the incarceration only,</div><div class='line' id='LC4463'>and not the names of the offenses.  And even by the help of</div><div class='line' id='LC4464'>tradition the only thing that could be proven was that none of</div><div class='line' id='LC4465'>the five had seen daylight for thirty-five years: how much longer</div><div class='line' id='LC4466'>this privation has lasted was not guessable.
