The king and the queen</div><div class='line' id='LC4467'>knew nothing about these poor creatures, except that they were</div><div class='line' id='LC4468'>heirlooms, assets inherited, along with the throne, from the former</div><div class='line' id='LC4469'>firm.  Nothing of their history had been transmitted with their</div><div class='line' id='LC4470'>persons, and so the inheriting owners had considered them of no</div><div class='line' id='LC4471'>value, and had felt no interest in them.  I said to the queen:</div><div class='line' id='LC4472'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4473'>&quot;Then why in the world didn&#39;t you set them free?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4474'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4475'>The question was a puzzler.  She didn&#39;t know _why_ she hadn&#39;t, the</div><div class='line' id='LC4476'>thing had never come up in her mind.  So here she was, forecasting</div><div class='line' id='LC4477'>the veritable history of future prisoners of the Castle d&#39;If,</div><div class='line' id='LC4478'>without knowing it.  It seemed plain to me now, that with her</div><div class='line' id='LC4479'>training, those inherited prisoners were merely property--nothing</div><div class='line' id='LC4480'>more, nothing less.  Well, when we inherit property, it does not</div><div class='line' id='LC4481'>occur to us to throw it away, even when we do not value it.</div><div class='line' id='LC4482'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4483'>When I brought my procession of human bats up into the open world</div><div class='line' id='LC4484'>and the glare of the afternoon sun--previously blindfolding them,</div><div class='line' id='LC4485'>in charity for eyes so long untortured by light--they were a</div><div class='line' id='LC4486'>spectacle to look at.  Skeletons, scarecrows, goblins, pathetic</div><div class='line' id='LC4487'>frights, every one; legitimatest possible children of Monarchy</div><div class='line' id='LC4488'>by the Grace of God and the Established Church.  I muttered absently:</div><div class='line' id='LC4489'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4490'>&quot;I _wish_ I could photograph them!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4491'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4492'>You have seen that kind of people who will never let on that they</div><div class='line' id='LC4493'>don&#39;t know the meaning of a new big word.  The more ignorant they</div><div class='line' id='LC4494'>are, the more pitifully certain they are to pretend you haven&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC4495'>shot over their heads.  The queen was just one of that sort, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4496'>was always making the stupidest blunders by reason of it.  She</div><div class='line' id='LC4497'>hesitated a moment; then her face brightened up with sudden</div><div class='line' id='LC4498'>comprehension, and she said she would do it for me.</div><div class='line' id='LC4499'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4500'>I thought to myself: She? why what can she know about photography?</div><div class='line' id='LC4501'>But it was a poor time to be thinking.  When I looked around, she</div><div class='line' id='LC4502'>was moving on the procession with an axe!</div><div class='line' id='LC4503'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4504'>Well, she certainly was a curious one, was Morgan le Fay.  I have</div><div class='line' id='LC4505'>seen a good many kinds of women in my time, but she laid over them</div><div class='line' id='LC4506'>all for variety.  And how sharply characteristic of her this episode</div><div class='line' id='LC4507'>was.  She had no more idea than a horse of how to photograph</div><div class='line' id='LC4508'>a procession; but being in doubt, it was just like her to try</div><div class='line' id='LC4509'>to do it with an axe.</div><div class='line' id='LC4510'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4511'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4512'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4513'>CHAPTER XIX</div><div class='line' id='LC4514'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4515'>KNIGHT-ERRANTRY AS A TRADE</div><div class='line' id='LC4516'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4517'>Sandy and I were on the road again, next morning, bright and early.</div><div class='line' id='LC4518'>It was so good to open up one&#39;s lungs and take in whole luscious</div><div class='line' id='LC4519'>barrels-ful of the blessed God&#39;s untainted, dew-fashioned,</div><div class='line' id='LC4520'>woodland-scented air once more, after suffocating body and mind for two</div><div class='line' id='LC4521'>days and nights in the moral and physical stenches of that intolerable</div><div class='line' id='LC4522'>old buzzard-roost!  I mean, for me: of course the place was all</div><div class='line' id='LC4523'>right and agreeable enough for Sandy, for she had been used to</div><div class='line' id='LC4524'>high life all her days.</div><div class='line' id='LC4525'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4526'>Poor girl, her jaws had had a wearisome rest now for a while,</div><div class='line' id='LC4527'>and I was expecting to get the consequences.  I was right; but she</div><div class='line' id='LC4528'>had stood by me most helpfully in the castle, and had mightily</div><div class='line' id='LC4529'>supported and reinforced me with gigantic foolishnesses which were</div><div class='line' id='LC4530'>worth more for the occasion than wisdoms double their size; so</div><div class='line' id='LC4531'>I thought she had earned a right to work her mill for a while,</div><div class='line' id='LC4532'>if she wanted to, and I felt not a pang when she started it up:</div><div class='line' id='LC4533'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4534'>&quot;Now turn we unto Sir Marhaus that rode with the damsel of thirty</div><div class='line' id='LC4535'>winter of age southward--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4536'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4537'>&quot;Are you going to see if you can work up another half-stretch on</div><div class='line' id='LC4538'>the trail of the cowboys, Sandy?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4539'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4540'>&quot;Even so, fair my lord.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4541'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4542'>&quot;Go ahead, then.  I won&#39;t interrupt this time, if I can help it.</div><div class='line' id='LC4543'>Begin over again; start fair, and shake out all your reefs, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4544'>I will load my pipe and give good attention.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4545'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4546'>&quot;Now turn we unto Sir Marhaus that rode with the damsel of thirty</div><div class='line' id='LC4547'>winter of age southward.  And so they came into a deep forest,</div><div class='line' id='LC4548'>and by fortune they were nighted, and rode along in a deep way,</div><div class='line' id='LC4549'>and at the last they came into a courtelage where abode the duke</div><div class='line' id='LC4550'>of South Marches, and there they asked harbour.  And on the morn</div><div class='line' id='LC4551'>the duke sent unto Sir Marhaus, and bad him make him ready.  And</div><div class='line' id='LC4552'>so Sir Marhaus arose and armed him, and there was a mass sung</div><div class='line' id='LC4553'>afore him, and he brake his fast, and so mounted on horseback in</div><div class='line' id='LC4554'>the court of the castle, there they should do the battle.  So there</div><div class='line' id='LC4555'>was the duke already on horseback, clean armed, and his six sons</div><div class='line' id='LC4556'>by him, and every each had a spear in his hand, and so they</div><div class='line' id='LC4557'>encountered, whereas the duke and his two sons brake their spears</div><div class='line' id='LC4558'>upon him, but Sir Marhaus held up his spear and touched none of</div><div class='line' id='LC4559'>them.  Then came the four sons by couples, and two of them brake</div><div class='line' id='LC4560'>their spears, and so did the other two.  And all this while</div><div class='line' id='LC4561'>Sir Marhaus touched them not.  Then Sir Marhaus ran to the duke,</div><div class='line' id='LC4562'>and smote him with his spear that horse and man fell to the earth.</div><div class='line' id='LC4563'>And so he served his sons.  And then Sir Marhaus alight down, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4564'>bad the duke yield him or else he would slay him.  And then some</div><div class='line' id='LC4565'>of his sons recovered, and would have set upon Sir Marhaus.  Then</div><div class='line' id='LC4566'>Sir Marhaus said to the duke, Cease thy sons, or else I will do</div><div class='line' id='LC4567'>the uttermost to you all.  When the duke saw he might not escape</div><div class='line' id='LC4568'>the death, he cried to his sons, and charged them to yield them</div><div class='line' id='LC4569'>to Sir Marhaus.  And they kneeled all down and put the pommels</div><div class='line' id='LC4570'>of their swords to the knight, and so he received them.  And then</div><div class='line' id='LC4571'>they holp up their father, and so by their common assent promised</div><div class='line' id='LC4572'>unto Sir Marhaus never to be foes unto King Arthur, and thereupon</div><div class='line' id='LC4573'>at Whitsuntide after, to come he and his sons, and put them in</div><div class='line' id='LC4574'>the king&#39;s grace.*</div><div class='line' id='LC4575'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4576'>[*Footnote: The story is borrowed, language and all, from the</div><div class='line' id='LC4577'>Morte d&#39;Arthur.--M.T.]</div><div class='line' id='LC4578'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4579'>&quot;Even so standeth the history, fair Sir Boss.  Now ye shall wit</div><div class='line' id='LC4580'>that that very duke and his six sons are they whom but few days</div><div class='line' id='LC4581'>past you also did overcome and send to Arthur&#39;s court!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4582'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4583'>&quot;Why, Sandy, you can&#39;t mean it!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4584'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4585'>&quot;An I speak not sooth, let it be the worse for me.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4586'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4587'>&quot;Well, well, well,--now who would ever have thought it?  One</div><div class='line' id='LC4588'>whole duke and six dukelets; why, Sandy, it was an elegant haul.</div><div class='line' id='LC4589'>Knight-errantry is a most chuckle-headed trade, and it is tedious</div><div class='line' id='LC4590'>hard work, too, but I begin to see that there _is_ money in it,</div><div class='line' id='LC4591'>after all, if you have luck.  Not that I would ever engage in it</div><div class='line' id='LC4592'>as a business, for I wouldn&#39;t.  No sound and legitimate business</div><div class='line' id='LC4593'>can be established on a basis of speculation.  A successful whirl</div><div class='line' id='LC4594'>in the knight-errantry line--now what is it when you blow away</div><div class='line' id='LC4595'>the nonsense and come down to the cold facts?  It&#39;s just a corner</div><div class='line' id='LC4596'>in pork, that&#39;s all, and you can&#39;t make anything else out of it.</div><div class='line' id='LC4597'>You&#39;re rich--yes,--suddenly rich--for about a day, maybe a week;</div><div class='line' id='LC4598'>then somebody corners the market on _you_, and down goes your</div><div class='line' id='LC4599'>bucket-shop; ain&#39;t that so, Sandy?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4600'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4601'>&quot;Whethersoever it be that my mind miscarrieth, bewraying simple</div><div class='line' id='LC4602'>language in such sort that the words do seem to come endlong</div><div class='line' id='LC4603'>and overthwart--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4604'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4605'>&quot;There&#39;s no use in beating about the bush and trying to get around</div><div class='line' id='LC4606'>it that way, Sandy, it&#39;s _so_, just as I say.  I _know_ it&#39;s so.  And,</div><div class='line' id='LC4607'>moreover, when you come right down to the bedrock, knight-errantry</div><div class='line' id='LC4608'>is _worse_ than pork; for whatever happens, the pork&#39;s left, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4609'>so somebody&#39;s benefited anyway; but when the market breaks, in a</div><div class='line' id='LC4610'>knight-errantry whirl, and every knight in the pool passes in his</div><div class='line' id='LC4611'>checks, what have you got for assets?  Just a rubbish-pile of</div><div class='line' id='LC4612'>battered corpses and a barrel or two of busted hardware.  Can you</div><div class='line' id='LC4613'>call _those_ assets?  Give me pork, every time.  Am I right?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4614'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4615'>&quot;Ah, peradventure my head being distraught by the manifold matters</div><div class='line' id='LC4616'>whereunto the confusions of these but late adventured haps and</div><div class='line' id='LC4617'>fortunings whereby not I alone nor you alone, but every each of us,</div><div class='line' id='LC4618'>meseemeth--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4619'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4620'>&quot;No, it&#39;s not your head, Sandy.  Your head&#39;s all right, as far as</div><div class='line' id='LC4621'>it goes, but you don&#39;t know business; that&#39;s where the trouble</div><div class='line' id='LC4622'>is.  It unfits you to argue about business, and you&#39;re wrong</div><div class='line' id='LC4623'>to be always trying.  However, that aside, it was a good haul,</div><div class='line' id='LC4624'>anyway, and will breed a handsome crop of reputation in Arthur&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC4625'>court.  And speaking of the cowboys, what a curious country this</div><div class='line' id='LC4626'>is for women and men that never get old.  Now there&#39;s Morgan le Fay,</div><div class='line' id='LC4627'>as fresh and young as a Vassar pullet, to all appearances, and</div><div class='line' id='LC4628'>here is this old duke of the South Marches still slashing away with</div><div class='line' id='LC4629'>sword and lance at his time of life, after raising such a family</div><div class='line' id='LC4630'>as he has raised.  As I understand it, Sir Gawaine killed seven</div><div class='line' id='LC4631'>of his sons, and still he had six left for Sir Marhaus and me to</div><div class='line' id='LC4632'>take into camp.  And then there was that damsel of sixty winter</div><div class='line' id='LC4633'>of age still excursioning around in her frosty bloom--How old</div><div class='line' id='LC4634'>are you, Sandy?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4635'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4636'>It was the first time I ever struck a still place in her.  The mill</div><div class='line' id='LC4637'>had shut down for repairs, or something.</div><div class='line' id='LC4638'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4639'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4640'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4641'>CHAPTER XX</div><div class='line' id='LC4642'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4643'>THE OGRE&#39;S CASTLE</div><div class='line' id='LC4644'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4645'>Between six and nine we made ten miles, which was plenty for a</div><div class='line' id='LC4646'>horse carrying triple--man, woman, and armor; then we stopped</div><div class='line' id='LC4647'>for a long nooning under some trees by a limpid brook.</div><div class='line' id='LC4648'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4649'>Right so came by and by a knight riding; and as he drew near he</div><div class='line' id='LC4650'>made dolorous moan, and by the words of it I perceived that he</div><div class='line' id='LC4651'>was cursing and swearing; yet nevertheless was I glad of his</div><div class='line' id='LC4652'>coming, for that I saw he bore a bulletin-board whereon in letters</div><div class='line' id='LC4653'>all of shining gold was writ:</div><div class='line' id='LC4654'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4655'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&quot;USE PETERSON&#39;S PROPHYLACTIC TOOTH-BRUSH--ALL THE GO.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4656'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4657'>I was glad of his coming, for even by this token I knew him for</div><div class='line' id='LC4658'>knight of mine.  It was Sir Madok de la Montaine, a burly great</div><div class='line' id='LC4659'>fellow whose chief distinction was that he had come within an ace</div><div class='line' id='LC4660'>of sending Sir Launcelot down over his horse-tail once.  He was</div><div class='line' id='LC4661'>never long in a stranger&#39;s presence without finding some pretext</div><div class='line' id='LC4662'>or other to let out that great fact.  But there was another fact</div><div class='line' id='LC4663'>of nearly the same size, which he never pushed upon anybody unasked,</div><div class='line' id='LC4664'>and yet never withheld when asked: that was, that the reason he</div><div class='line' id='LC4665'>didn&#39;t quite succeed was, that he was interrupted and sent down</div><div class='line' id='LC4666'>over horse-tail himself.  This innocent vast lubber did not see</div><div class='line' id='LC4667'>any particular difference between the two facts.  I liked him,</div><div class='line' id='LC4668'>for he was earnest in his work, and very valuable.  And he was so</div><div class='line' id='LC4669'>fine to look at, with his broad mailed shoulders, and the grand</div><div class='line' id='LC4670'>leonine set of his plumed head, and his big shield with its quaint</div><div class='line' id='LC4671'>device of a gauntleted hand clutching a prophylactic tooth-brush,</div><div class='line' id='LC4672'>with motto: &quot;Try Noyoudont.&quot;  This was a tooth-wash that I was</div><div class='line' id='LC4673'>introducing.</div><div class='line' id='LC4674'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4675'>He was aweary, he said, and indeed he looked it; but he would not</div><div class='line' id='LC4676'>alight.  He said he was after the stove-polish man; and with this</div><div class='line' id='LC4677'>he broke out cursing and swearing anew.  The bulletin-boarder</div><div class='line' id='LC4678'>referred to was Sir Ossaise of Surluse, a brave knight, and of</div><div class='line' id='LC4679'>considerable celebrity on account of his having tried conclusions</div><div class='line' id='LC4680'>in a tournament once, with no less a Mogul than Sir Gaheris</div><div class='line' id='LC4681'>himself--although not successfully.  He was of a light and laughing</div><div class='line' id='LC4682'>disposition, and to him nothing in this world was serious.  It was</div><div class='line' id='LC4683'>for this reason that I had chosen him to work up a stove-polish</div><div class='line' id='LC4684'>sentiment.  There were no stoves yet, and so there could be nothing</div><div class='line' id='LC4685'>serious about stove-polish.  All that the agent needed to do was</div><div class='line' id='LC4686'>to deftly and by degrees prepare the public for the great change,</div><div class='line' id='LC4687'>and have them established in predilections toward neatness against</div><div class='line' id='LC4688'>the time when the stove should appear upon the stage.</div><div class='line' id='LC4689'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4690'>Sir Madok was very bitter, and brake out anew with cursings.  He</div><div class='line' id='LC4691'>said he had cursed his soul to rags; and yet he would not get down</div><div class='line' id='LC4692'>from his horse, neither would he take any rest, or listen to any</div><div class='line' id='LC4693'>comfort, until he should have found Sir Ossaise and settled this</div><div class='line' id='LC4694'>account.  It appeared, by what I could piece together of the</div><div class='line' id='LC4695'>unprofane fragments of his statement, that he had chanced upon</div><div class='line' id='LC4696'>Sir Ossaise at dawn of the morning, and been told that if he would</div><div class='line' id='LC4697'>make a short cut across the fields and swamps and broken hills and</div><div class='line' id='LC4698'>glades, he could head off a company of travelers who would be rare</div><div class='line' id='LC4699'>customers for prophylactics and tooth-wash.  With characteristic</div><div class='line' id='LC4700'>zeal Sir Madok had plunged away at once upon this quest, and after</div><div class='line' id='LC4701'>three hours of awful crosslot riding had overhauled his game.  And</div><div class='line' id='LC4702'>behold, it was the five patriarchs that had been released from the</div><div class='line' id='LC4703'>dungeons the evening before!  Poor old creatures, it was all of</div><div class='line' id='LC4704'>twenty years since any one of them had known what it was to be</div><div class='line' id='LC4705'>equipped with any remaining snag or remnant of a tooth.</div><div class='line' id='LC4706'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4707'>&quot;Blank-blank-blank him,&quot; said Sir Madok, &quot;an I do not stove-polish</div><div class='line' id='LC4708'>him an I may find him, leave it to me; for never no knight that</div><div class='line' id='LC4709'>hight Ossaise or aught else may do me this disservice and bide</div><div class='line' id='LC4710'>on live, an I may find him, the which I have thereunto sworn a</div><div class='line' id='LC4711'>great oath this day.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4712'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4713'>And with these words and others, he lightly took his spear and</div><div class='line' id='LC4714'>gat him thence.  In the middle of the afternoon we came upon one</div><div class='line' id='LC4715'>of those very patriarchs ourselves, in the edge of a poor village.</div><div class='line' id='LC4716'>He was basking in the love of relatives and friends whom he had not</div><div class='line' id='LC4717'>seen for fifty years; and about him and caressing him were also</div><div class='line' id='LC4718'>descendants of his own body whom he had never seen at all till now;</div><div class='line' id='LC4719'>but to him these were all strangers, his memory was gone, his mind</div><div class='line' id='LC4720'>was stagnant.  It seemed incredible that a man could outlast half</div><div class='line' id='LC4721'>a century shut up in a dark hole like a rat, but here were his old</div><div class='line' id='LC4722'>wife and some old comrades to testify to it.  They could remember</div><div class='line' id='LC4723'>him as he was in the freshness and strength of his young manhood,</div><div class='line' id='LC4724'>when he kissed his child and delivered it to its mother&#39;s hands</div><div class='line' id='LC4725'>and went away into that long oblivion.  The people at the castle</div><div class='line' id='LC4726'>could not tell within half a generation the length of time the man</div><div class='line' id='LC4727'>had been shut up there for his unrecorded and forgotten offense;</div><div class='line' id='LC4728'>but this old wife knew; and so did her old child, who stood there</div><div class='line' id='LC4729'>among her married sons and daughters trying to realize a father</div><div class='line' id='LC4730'>who had been to her a name, a thought, a formless image, a tradition,</div><div class='line' id='LC4731'>all her life, and now was suddenly concreted into actual flesh</div><div class='line' id='LC4732'>and blood and set before her face.</div><div class='line' id='LC4733'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4734'>It was a curious situation; yet it is not on that account that</div><div class='line' id='LC4735'>I have made room for it here, but on account of a thing which</div><div class='line' id='LC4736'>seemed to me still more curious.  To wit, that this dreadful matter</div><div class='line' id='LC4737'>brought from these downtrodden people no outburst of rage against</div><div class='line' id='LC4738'>these oppressors.  They had been heritors and subjects of cruelty</div><div class='line' id='LC4739'>and outrage so long that nothing could have startled them but</div><div class='line' id='LC4740'>a kindness.  Yes, here was a curious revelation, indeed, of the</div><div class='line' id='LC4741'>depth to which this people had been sunk in slavery.  Their entire</div><div class='line' id='LC4742'>being was reduced to a monotonous dead level of patience, resignation,</div><div class='line' id='LC4743'>dumb uncomplaining acceptance of whatever might befall them in</div><div class='line' id='LC4744'>this life.  Their very imagination was dead.  When you can say</div><div class='line' id='LC4745'>that of a man, he has struck bottom, I reckon; there is no lower</div><div class='line' id='LC4746'>deep for him.</div><div class='line' id='LC4747'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4748'>I rather wished I had gone some other road.  This was not the sort</div><div class='line' id='LC4749'>of experience for a statesman to encounter who was planning out</div><div class='line' id='LC4750'>a peaceful revolution in his mind.  For it could not help bringing</div><div class='line' id='LC4751'>up the unget-aroundable fact that, all gentle cant and philosophizing</div><div class='line' id='LC4752'>to the contrary notwithstanding, no people in the world ever did</div><div class='line' id='LC4753'>achieve their freedom by goody-goody talk and moral suasion:</div><div class='line' id='LC4754'>it being immutable law that all revolutions that will succeed must</div><div class='line' id='LC4755'>_begin_ in blood, whatever may answer afterward.  If history teaches</div><div class='line' id='LC4756'>anything, it teaches that.  What this folk needed, then, was a</div><div class='line' id='LC4757'>Reign of Terror and a guillotine, and I was the wrong man for them.</div><div class='line' id='LC4758'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4759'>Two days later, toward noon, Sandy began to show signs of excitement</div><div class='line' id='LC4760'>and feverish expectancy.  She said we were approaching the ogre&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC4761'>castle.  I was surprised into an uncomfortable shock.  The object</div><div class='line' id='LC4762'>of our quest had gradually dropped out of my mind; this sudden</div><div class='line' id='LC4763'>resurrection of it made it seem quite a real and startling thing</div><div class='line' id='LC4764'>for a moment, and roused up in me a smart interest.  Sandy&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC4765'>excitement increased every moment; and so did mine, for that sort</div><div class='line' id='LC4766'>of thing is catching.  My heart got to thumping.  You can&#39;t reason</div><div class='line' id='LC4767'>with your heart; it has its own laws, and thumps about things which</div><div class='line' id='LC4768'>the intellect scorns.  Presently, when Sandy slid from the horse,</div><div class='line' id='LC4769'>motioned me to stop, and went creeping stealthily, with her head</div><div class='line' id='LC4770'>bent nearly to her knees, toward a row of bushes that bordered</div><div class='line' id='LC4771'>a declivity, the thumpings grew stronger and quicker.  And they</div><div class='line' id='LC4772'>kept it up while she was gaining her ambush and getting her glimpse</div><div class='line' id='LC4773'>over the declivity; and also while I was creeping to her side on</div><div class='line' id='LC4774'>my knees.  Her eyes were burning now, as she pointed with her</div><div class='line' id='LC4775'>finger, and said in a panting whisper:</div><div class='line' id='LC4776'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4777'>&quot;The castle!  The castle!  Lo, where it looms!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4778'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4779'>What a welcome disappointment I experienced!  I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC4780'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4781'>&quot;Castle?  It is nothing but a pigsty; a pigsty with a wattled</div><div class='line' id='LC4782'>fence around it.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4783'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4784'>She looked surprised and distressed.  The animation faded out of</div><div class='line' id='LC4785'>her face; and during many moments she was lost in thought and</div><div class='line' id='LC4786'>silent.  Then:</div><div class='line' id='LC4787'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4788'>&quot;It was not enchanted aforetime,&quot; she said in a musing fashion,</div><div class='line' id='LC4789'>as if to herself.  &quot;And how strange is this marvel, and how awful</div><div class='line' id='LC4790'>--that to the one perception it is enchanted and dight in a base</div><div class='line' id='LC4791'>and shameful aspect; yet to the perception of the other it is not</div><div class='line' id='LC4792'>enchanted, hath suffered no change, but stands firm and stately</div><div class='line' id='LC4793'>still, girt with its moat and waving its banners in the blue air</div><div class='line' id='LC4794'>from its towers.  And God shield us, how it pricks the heart to</div><div class='line' id='LC4795'>see again these gracious captives, and the sorrow deepened in their</div><div class='line' id='LC4796'>sweet faces!  We have tarried along, and are to blame.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4797'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4798'>I saw my cue.  The castle was enchanted to _me_, not to her. It would</div><div class='line' id='LC4799'>be wasted time to try to argue her out of her delusion, it couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC4800'>be done; I must just humor it.  So I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC4801'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4802'>&quot;This is a common case--the enchanting of a thing to one eye and</div><div class='line' id='LC4803'>leaving it in its proper form to another.  You have heard of it</div><div class='line' id='LC4804'>before, Sandy, though you haven&#39;t happened to experience it.</div><div class='line' id='LC4805'>But no harm is done.  In fact, it is lucky the way it is.  If these</div><div class='line' id='LC4806'>ladies were hogs to everybody and to themselves, it would be</div><div class='line' id='LC4807'>necessary to break the enchantment, and that might be impossible</div><div class='line' id='LC4808'>if one failed to find out the particular process of the enchantment.</div><div class='line' id='LC4809'>And hazardous, too; for in attempting a disenchantment without the</div><div class='line' id='LC4810'>true key, you are liable to err, and turn your hogs into dogs,</div><div class='line' id='LC4811'>and the dogs into cats, the cats into rats, and so on, and end by</div><div class='line' id='LC4812'>reducing your materials to nothing finally, or to an odorless gas</div><div class='line' id='LC4813'>which you can&#39;t follow--which, of course, amounts to the same</div><div class='line' id='LC4814'>thing.  But here, by good luck, no one&#39;s eyes but mine are under</div><div class='line' id='LC4815'>the enchantment, and so it is of no consequence to dissolve it.</div><div class='line' id='LC4816'>These ladies remain ladies to you, and to themselves, and to</div><div class='line' id='LC4817'>everybody else; and at the same time they will suffer in no way</div><div class='line' id='LC4818'>from my delusion, for when I know that an ostensible hog is a</div><div class='line' id='LC4819'>lady, that is enough for me, I know how to treat her.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4820'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4821'>&quot;Thanks, oh, sweet my lord, thou talkest like an angel.  And I know</div><div class='line' id='LC4822'>that thou wilt deliver them, for that thou art minded to great</div><div class='line' id='LC4823'>deeds and art as strong a knight of your hands and as brave to will</div><div class='line' id='LC4824'>and to do, as any that is on live.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4825'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4826'>&quot;I will not leave a princess in the sty, Sandy.  Are those three</div><div class='line' id='LC4827'>yonder that to my disordered eyes are starveling swine-herds--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4828'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4829'>&quot;The ogres, Are _they_ changed also?  It is most wonderful.  Now</div><div class='line' id='LC4830'>am I fearful; for how canst thou strike with sure aim when five of</div><div class='line' id='LC4831'>their nine cubits of stature are to thee invisible?  Ah, go warily,</div><div class='line' id='LC4832'>fair sir; this is a mightier emprise than I wend.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4833'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4834'>&quot;You be easy, Sandy.  All I need to know is, how _much_ of an ogre</div><div class='line' id='LC4835'>is invisible; then I know how to locate his vitals.  Don&#39;t you be</div><div class='line' id='LC4836'>afraid, I will make short work of these bunco-steerers.  Stay</div><div class='line' id='LC4837'>where you are.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4838'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4839'>I left Sandy kneeling there, corpse-faced but plucky and hopeful,</div><div class='line' id='LC4840'>and rode down to the pigsty, and struck up a trade with the</div><div class='line' id='LC4841'>swine-herds.  I won their gratitude by buying out all the hogs</div><div class='line' id='LC4842'>at the lump sum of sixteen pennies, which was rather above latest</div><div class='line' id='LC4843'>quotations.  I was just in time; for the Church, the lord of the</div><div class='line' id='LC4844'>manor, and the rest of the tax-gatherers would have been along</div><div class='line' id='LC4845'>next day and swept off pretty much all the stock, leaving the</div><div class='line' id='LC4846'>swine-herds very short of hogs and Sandy out of princesses.  But</div><div class='line' id='LC4847'>now the tax people could be paid in cash, and there would be</div><div class='line' id='LC4848'>a stake left besides.  One of the men had ten children; and he</div><div class='line' id='LC4849'>said that last year when a priest came and of his ten pigs took</div><div class='line' id='LC4850'>the fattest one for tithes, the wife burst out upon him, and offered</div><div class='line' id='LC4851'>him a child and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC4852'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4853'>&quot;Thou beast without bowels of mercy, why leave me my child, yet</div><div class='line' id='LC4854'>rob me of the wherewithal to feed it?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4855'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4856'>How curious.  The same thing had happened in the Wales of my day,</div><div class='line' id='LC4857'>under this same old Established Church, which was supposed by many</div><div class='line' id='LC4858'>to have changed its nature when it changed its disguise.</div><div class='line' id='LC4859'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4860'>I sent the three men away, and then opened the sty gate and beckoned</div><div class='line' id='LC4861'>Sandy to come--which she did; and not leisurely, but with the rush</div><div class='line' id='LC4862'>of a prairie fire.  And when I saw her fling herself upon those</div><div class='line' id='LC4863'>hogs, with tears of joy running down her cheeks, and strain them</div><div class='line' id='LC4864'>to her heart, and kiss them, and caress them, and call them</div><div class='line' id='LC4865'>reverently by grand princely names, I was ashamed of her, ashamed</div><div class='line' id='LC4866'>of the human race.</div><div class='line' id='LC4867'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4868'>We had to drive those hogs home--ten miles; and no ladies were</div><div class='line' id='LC4869'>ever more fickle-minded or contrary.  They would stay in no road,</div><div class='line' id='LC4870'>no path; they broke out through the brush on all sides, and flowed</div><div class='line' id='LC4871'>away in all directions, over rocks, and hills, and the roughest</div><div class='line' id='LC4872'>places they could find.  And they must not be struck, or roughly</div><div class='line' id='LC4873'>accosted; Sandy could not bear to see them treated in ways unbecoming</div><div class='line' id='LC4874'>their rank.  The troublesomest old sow of the lot had to be called</div><div class='line' id='LC4875'>my Lady, and your Highness, like the rest.  It is annoying and</div><div class='line' id='LC4876'>difficult to scour around after hogs, in armor.  There was one</div><div class='line' id='LC4877'>small countess, with an iron ring in her snout and hardly any hair</div><div class='line' id='LC4878'>on her back, that was the devil for perversity.  She gave me a race</div><div class='line' id='LC4879'>of an hour, over all sorts of country, and then we were right where</div><div class='line' id='LC4880'>we had started from, having made not a rod of real progress.</div><div class='line' id='LC4881'>I seized her at last by the tail, and brought her along squealing.</div><div class='line' id='LC4882'>When I overtook Sandy she was horrified, and said it was in the</div><div class='line' id='LC4883'>last degree indelicate to drag a countess by her train.</div><div class='line' id='LC4884'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4885'>We got the hogs home just at dark--most of them.  The princess</div><div class='line' id='LC4886'>Nerovens de Morganore was missing, and two of her ladies in waiting:</div><div class='line' id='LC4887'>namely, Miss Angela Bohun, and the Demoiselle Elaine Courtemains,</div><div class='line' id='LC4888'>the former of these two being a young black sow with a white star</div><div class='line' id='LC4889'>in her forehead, and the latter a brown one with thin legs and a</div><div class='line' id='LC4890'>slight limp in the forward shank on the starboard side--a couple</div><div class='line' id='LC4891'>of the tryingest blisters to drive that I ever saw.  Also among</div><div class='line' id='LC4892'>the missing were several mere baronesses--and I wanted them to</div><div class='line' id='LC4893'>stay missing; but no, all that sausage-meat had to be found; so</div><div class='line' id='LC4894'>servants were sent out with torches to scour the woods and hills</div><div class='line' id='LC4895'>to that end.</div><div class='line' id='LC4896'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4897'>Of course, the whole drove was housed in the house, and, great</div><div class='line' id='LC4898'>guns!--well, I never saw anything like it.  Nor ever heard anything</div><div class='line' id='LC4899'>like it.  And never smelt anything like it.  It was like an</div><div class='line' id='LC4900'>insurrection in a gasometer.</div><div class='line' id='LC4901'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4902'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4903'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4904'>CHAPTER XXI</div><div class='line' id='LC4905'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4906'>THE PILGRIMS</div><div class='line' id='LC4907'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4908'>When I did get to bed at last I was unspeakably tired; the stretching</div><div class='line' id='LC4909'>out, and the relaxing of the long-tense muscles, how luxurious,</div><div class='line' id='LC4910'>how delicious! but that was as far as I could get--sleep was out of</div><div class='line' id='LC4911'>the question for the present.  The ripping and tearing and squealing</div><div class='line' id='LC4912'>of the nobility up and down the halls and corridors was pandemonium</div><div class='line' id='LC4913'>come again, and kept me broad awake.  Being awake, my thoughts</div><div class='line' id='LC4914'>were busy, of course; and mainly they busied themselves with Sandy&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC4915'>curious delusion.  Here she was, as sane a person as the kingdom</div><div class='line' id='LC4916'>could produce; and yet, from my point of view she was acting like</div><div class='line' id='LC4917'>a crazy woman.  My land, the power of training! of influence!</div><div class='line' id='LC4918'>of education!  It can bring a body up to believe anything.  I had</div><div class='line' id='LC4919'>to put myself in Sandy&#39;s place to realize that she was not a</div><div class='line' id='LC4920'>lunatic.  Yes, and put her in mine, to demonstrate how easy it is</div><div class='line' id='LC4921'>to seem a lunatic to a person who has not been taught as you have</div><div class='line' id='LC4922'>been taught.  If I had told Sandy I had seen a wagon, uninfluenced</div><div class='line' id='LC4923'>by enchantment, spin along fifty miles an hour; had seen a man,</div><div class='line' id='LC4924'>unequipped with magic powers, get into a basket and soar out of</div><div class='line' id='LC4925'>sight among the clouds; and had listened, without any necromancer&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC4926'>help, to the conversation of a person who was several hundred miles</div><div class='line' id='LC4927'>away, Sandy would not merely have supposed me to be crazy, she</div><div class='line' id='LC4928'>would have thought she knew it.  Everybody around her believed in</div><div class='line' id='LC4929'>enchantments; nobody had any doubts; to doubt that a castle could</div><div class='line' id='LC4930'>be turned into a sty, and its occupants into hogs, would have been</div><div class='line' id='LC4931'>the same as my doubting among Connecticut people the actuality</div><div class='line' id='LC4932'>of the telephone and its wonders,--and in both cases would be</div><div class='line' id='LC4933'>absolute proof of a diseased mind, an unsettled reason.  Yes, Sandy</div><div class='line' id='LC4934'>was sane; that must be admitted.  If I also would be sane--to Sandy</div><div class='line' id='LC4935'>--I must keep my superstitions about unenchanted and unmiraculous</div><div class='line' id='LC4936'>locomotives, balloons, and telephones, to myself.  Also, I believed</div><div class='line' id='LC4937'>that the world was not flat, and hadn&#39;t pillars under it to support</div><div class='line' id='LC4938'>it, nor a canopy over it to turn off a universe of water that</div><div class='line' id='LC4939'>occupied all space above; but as I was the only person in the kingdom</div><div class='line' id='LC4940'>afflicted with such impious and criminal opinions, I recognized</div><div class='line' id='LC4941'>that it would be good wisdom to keep quiet about this matter, too,</div><div class='line' id='LC4942'>if I did not wish to be suddenly shunned and forsaken by everybody</div><div class='line' id='LC4943'>as a madman.</div><div class='line' id='LC4944'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4945'>The next morning Sandy assembled the swine in the dining-room and</div><div class='line' id='LC4946'>gave them their breakfast, waiting upon them personally and</div><div class='line' id='LC4947'>manifesting in every way the deep reverence which the natives of</div><div class='line' id='LC4948'>her island, ancient and modern, have always felt for rank, let its</div><div class='line' id='LC4949'>outward casket and the mental and moral contents be what they may.</div><div class='line' id='LC4950'>I could have eaten with the hogs if I had had birth approaching my</div><div class='line' id='LC4951'>lofty official rank; but I hadn&#39;t, and so accepted the unavoidable</div><div class='line' id='LC4952'>slight and made no complaint.  Sandy and I had our breakfast at</div><div class='line' id='LC4953'>the second table.  The family were not at home.  I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC4954'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4955'>&quot;How many are in the family, Sandy, and where do they keep themselves?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4956'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4957'>&quot;Family?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4958'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4959'>&quot;Yes.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4960'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4961'>&quot;Which family, good my lord?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4962'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4963'>&quot;Why, this family; your own family.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4964'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4965'>&quot;Sooth to say, I understand you not.  I have no family.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4966'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4967'>&quot;No family?  Why, Sandy, isn&#39;t this your home?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4968'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4969'>&quot;Now how indeed might that be?  I have no home.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4970'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4971'>&quot;Well, then, whose house is this?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4972'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4973'>&quot;Ah, wit you well I would tell you an I knew myself.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4974'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4975'>&quot;Come--you don&#39;t even know these people?  Then who invited us here?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4976'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4977'>&quot;None invited us.  We but came; that is all.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4978'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4979'>&quot;Why, woman, this is a most extraordinary performance.  The</div><div class='line' id='LC4980'>effrontery of it is beyond admiration.  We blandly march into</div><div class='line' id='LC4981'>a man&#39;s house, and cram it full of the only really valuable nobility</div><div class='line' id='LC4982'>the sun has yet discovered in the earth, and then it turns out</div><div class='line' id='LC4983'>that we don&#39;t even know the man&#39;s name.  How did you ever venture</div><div class='line' id='LC4984'>to take this extravagant liberty?  I supposed, of course, it was</div><div class='line' id='LC4985'>your home.  What will the man say?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4986'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4987'>&quot;What will he say?  Forsooth what can he say but give thanks?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4988'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4989'>&quot;Thanks for what?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4990'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4991'>Her face was filled with a puzzled surprise:</div><div class='line' id='LC4992'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4993'>&quot;Verily, thou troublest mine understanding with strange words.</div><div class='line' id='LC4994'>Do ye dream that one of his estate is like to have the honor twice</div><div class='line' id='LC4995'>in his life to entertain company such as we have brought to grace</div><div class='line' id='LC4996'>his house withal?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC4997'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC4998'>&quot;Well, no--when you come to that.  No, it&#39;s an even bet that this</div><div class='line' id='LC4999'>is the first time he has had a treat like this.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5000'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5001'>&quot;Then let him be thankful, and manifest the same by grateful speech</div><div class='line' id='LC5002'>and due humility; he were a dog, else, and the heir and ancestor</div><div class='line' id='LC5003'>of dogs.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5004'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5005'>To my mind, the situation was uncomfortable.  It might become more so.</div><div class='line' id='LC5006'>It might be a good idea to muster the hogs and move on.  So I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC5007'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5008'>&quot;The day is wasting, Sandy.  It is time to get the nobility together</div><div class='line' id='LC5009'>and be moving.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5010'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5011'>&quot;Wherefore, fair sir and Boss?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5012'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5013'>&quot;We want to take them to their home, don&#39;t we?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5014'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5015'>&quot;La, but list to him!  They be of all the regions of the earth!</div><div class='line' id='LC5016'>Each must hie to her own home; wend you we might do all these</div><div class='line' id='LC5017'>journeys in one so brief life as He hath appointed that created</div><div class='line' id='LC5018'>life, and thereto death likewise with help of Adam, who by sin</div><div class='line' id='LC5019'>done through persuasion of his helpmeet, she being wrought upon</div><div class='line' id='LC5020'>and bewrayed by the beguilements of the great enemy of man, that</div><div class='line' id='LC5021'>serpent hight Satan, aforetime consecrated and set apart unto that</div><div class='line' id='LC5022'>evil work by overmastering spite and envy begotten in his heart</div><div class='line' id='LC5023'>through fell ambitions that did blight and mildew a nature erst</div><div class='line' id='LC5024'>so white and pure whenso it hove with the shining multitudes</div><div class='line' id='LC5025'>its brethren-born in glade and shade of that fair heaven wherein</div><div class='line' id='LC5026'>all such as native be to that rich estate and--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5027'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5028'>&quot;Great Scott!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5029'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5030'>&quot;My lord?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5031'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5032'>&quot;Well, you know we haven&#39;t got time for this sort of thing.  Don&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC5033'>you see, we could distribute these people around the earth in less</div><div class='line' id='LC5034'>time than it is going to take you to explain that we can&#39;t.  We</div><div class='line' id='LC5035'>mustn&#39;t talk now, we must act.  You want to be careful; you mustn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC5036'>let your mill get the start of you that way, at a time like this.</div><div class='line' id='LC5037'>To business now--and sharp&#39;s the word.  Who is to take the</div><div class='line' id='LC5038'>aristocracy home?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5039'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5040'>&quot;Even their friends.  These will come for them from the far parts</div><div class='line' id='LC5041'>of the earth.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5042'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5043'>This was lightning from a clear sky, for unexpectedness; and the</div><div class='line' id='LC5044'>relief of it was like pardon to a prisoner.  She would remain to</div><div class='line' id='LC5045'>deliver the goods, of course.</div><div class='line' id='LC5046'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5047'>&quot;Well, then, Sandy, as our enterprise is handsomely and successfully</div><div class='line' id='LC5048'>ended, I will go home and report; and if ever another one--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5049'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5050'>&quot;I also am ready; I will go with thee.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5051'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5052'>This was recalling the pardon.</div><div class='line' id='LC5053'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5054'>&quot;How?  You will go with me?  Why should you?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5055'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5056'>&quot;Will I be traitor to my knight, dost think?  That were dishonor.</div><div class='line' id='LC5057'>I may not part from thee until in knightly encounter in the field</div><div class='line' id='LC5058'>some overmatching champion shall fairly win and fairly wear me.</div><div class='line' id='LC5059'>I were to blame an I thought that that might ever hap.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5060'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5061'>&quot;Elected for the long term,&quot; I sighed to myself.  &quot;I may as well</div><div class='line' id='LC5062'>make the best of it.&quot;  So then I spoke up and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC5063'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5064'>&quot;All right; let us make a start.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5065'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5066'>While she was gone to cry her farewells over the pork, I gave that</div><div class='line' id='LC5067'>whole peerage away to the servants.  And I asked them to take</div><div class='line' id='LC5068'>a duster and dust around a little where the nobilities had mainly</div><div class='line' id='LC5069'>lodged and promenaded; but they considered that that would be</div><div class='line' id='LC5070'>hardly worth while, and would moreover be a rather grave departure</div><div class='line' id='LC5071'>from custom, and therefore likely to make talk.  A departure from</div><div class='line' id='LC5072'>custom--that settled it; it was a nation capable of committing any</div><div class='line' id='LC5073'>crime but that.  The servants said they would follow the fashion,</div><div class='line' id='LC5074'>a fashion grown sacred through immemorial observance; they would</div><div class='line' id='LC5075'>scatter fresh rushes in all the rooms and halls, and then the</div><div class='line' id='LC5076'>evidence of the aristocratic visitation would be no longer visible.</div><div class='line' id='LC5077'>It was a kind of satire on Nature: it was the scientific method,</div><div class='line' id='LC5078'>the geologic method; it deposited the history of the family in</div><div class='line' id='LC5079'>a stratified record; and the antiquary could dig through it and</div><div class='line' id='LC5080'>tell by the remains of each period what changes of diet the family</div><div class='line' id='LC5081'>had introduced successively for a hundred years.</div><div class='line' id='LC5082'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5083'>The first thing we struck that day was a procession of pilgrims.</div><div class='line' id='LC5084'>It was not going our way, but we joined it, nevertheless; for it</div><div class='line' id='LC5085'>was hourly being borne in upon me now, that if I would govern</div><div class='line' id='LC5086'>this country wisely, I must be posted in the details of its life,</div><div class='line' id='LC5087'>and not at second hand, but by personal observation and scrutiny.</div><div class='line' id='LC5088'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5089'>This company of pilgrims resembled Chaucer&#39;s in this: that it</div><div class='line' id='LC5090'>had in it a sample of about all the upper occupations and professions</div><div class='line' id='LC5091'>the country could show, and a corresponding variety of costume.</div><div class='line' id='LC5092'>There were young men and old men, young women and old women,</div><div class='line' id='LC5093'>lively folk and grave folk.  They rode upon mules and horses, and</div><div class='line' id='LC5094'>there was not a side-saddle in the party; for this specialty was</div><div class='line' id='LC5095'>to remain unknown in England for nine hundred years yet.</div><div class='line' id='LC5096'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5097'>It was a pleasant, friendly, sociable herd; pious, happy, merry and</div><div class='line' id='LC5098'>full of unconscious coarsenesses and innocent indecencies.  What</div><div class='line' id='LC5099'>they regarded as the merry tale went the continual round and caused</div><div class='line' id='LC5100'>no more embarrassment than it would have caused in the best English</div><div class='line' id='LC5101'>society twelve centuries later.  Practical jokes worthy of the</div><div class='line' id='LC5102'>English wits of the first quarter of the far-off nineteenth century</div><div class='line' id='LC5103'>were sprung here and there and yonder along the line, and compelled</div><div class='line' id='LC5104'>the delightedest applause; and sometimes when a bright remark was</div><div class='line' id='LC5105'>made at one end of the procession and started on its travels toward</div><div class='line' id='LC5106'>the other, you could note its progress all the way by the sparkling</div><div class='line' id='LC5107'>spray of laughter it threw off from its bows as it plowed along;</div><div class='line' id='LC5108'>and also by the blushes of the mules in its wake.</div><div class='line' id='LC5109'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5110'>Sandy knew the goal and purpose of this pilgrimage, and she posted</div><div class='line' id='LC5111'>me.  She said:</div><div class='line' id='LC5112'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5113'>&quot;They journey to the Valley of Holiness, for to be blessed of the</div><div class='line' id='LC5114'>godly hermits and drink of the miraculous waters and be cleansed</div><div class='line' id='LC5115'>from sin.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5116'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5117'>&quot;Where is this watering place?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5118'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5119'>&quot;It lieth a two-day journey hence, by the borders of the land that</div><div class='line' id='LC5120'>hight the Cuckoo Kingdom.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5121'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5122'>&quot;Tell me about it.  Is it a celebrated place?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5123'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5124'>&quot;Oh, of a truth, yes.  There be none more so.  Of old time there</div><div class='line' id='LC5125'>lived there an abbot and his monks.  Belike were none in the world</div><div class='line' id='LC5126'>more holy than these; for they gave themselves to study of pious</div><div class='line' id='LC5127'>books, and spoke not the one to the other, or indeed to any, and</div><div class='line' id='LC5128'>ate decayed herbs and naught thereto, and slept hard, and prayed</div><div class='line' id='LC5129'>much, and washed never; also they wore the same garment until it</div><div class='line' id='LC5130'>fell from their bodies through age and decay.  Right so came they</div><div class='line' id='LC5131'>to be known of all the world by reason of these holy austerities,</div><div class='line' id='LC5132'>and visited by rich and poor, and reverenced.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5133'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5134'>&quot;Proceed.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5135'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5136'>&quot;But always there was lack of water there.  Whereas, upon a time,</div><div class='line' id='LC5137'>the holy abbot prayed, and for answer a great stream of clear</div><div class='line' id='LC5138'>water burst forth by miracle in a desert place.  Now were the</div><div class='line' id='LC5139'>fickle monks tempted of the Fiend, and they wrought with their</div><div class='line' id='LC5140'>abbot unceasingly by beggings and beseechings that he would construct</div><div class='line' id='LC5141'>a bath; and when he was become aweary and might not resist more,</div><div class='line' id='LC5142'>he said have ye your will, then, and granted that they asked.</div><div class='line' id='LC5143'>Now mark thou what &#39;tis to forsake the ways of purity the which</div><div class='line' id='LC5144'>He loveth, and wanton with such as be worldly and an offense.</div><div class='line' id='LC5145'>These monks did enter into the bath and come thence washed as</div><div class='line' id='LC5146'>white as snow; and lo, in that moment His sign appeared, in</div><div class='line' id='LC5147'>miraculous rebuke! for His insulted waters ceased to flow, and</div><div class='line' id='LC5148'>utterly vanished away.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5149'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5150'>&quot;They fared mildly, Sandy, considering how that kind of crime</div><div class='line' id='LC5151'>is regarded in this country.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5152'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5153'>&quot;Belike; but it was their first sin; and they had been of perfect</div><div class='line' id='LC5154'>life for long, and differing in naught from the angels.  Prayers,</div><div class='line' id='LC5155'>tears, torturings of the flesh, all was vain to beguile that water</div><div class='line' id='LC5156'>to flow again.  Even processions; even burnt-offerings; even votive</div><div class='line' id='LC5157'>candles to the Virgin, did fail every each of them; and all in</div><div class='line' id='LC5158'>the land did marvel.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5159'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5160'>&quot;How odd to find that even this industry has its financial panics,</div><div class='line' id='LC5161'>and at times sees its assignats and greenbacks languish to zero,</div><div class='line' id='LC5162'>and everything come to a standstill.  Go on, Sandy.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5163'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5164'>&quot;And so upon a time, after year and day, the good abbot made humble</div><div class='line' id='LC5165'>surrender and destroyed the bath.  And behold, His anger was in that</div><div class='line' id='LC5166'>moment appeased, and the waters gushed richly forth again, and even</div><div class='line' id='LC5167'>unto this day they have not ceased to flow in that generous measure.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5168'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5169'>&quot;Then I take it nobody has washed since.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5170'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5171'>&quot;He that would essay it could have his halter free; yes, and</div><div class='line' id='LC5172'>swiftly would he need it, too.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5173'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5174'>&quot;The community has prospered since?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5175'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5176'>&quot;Even from that very day.  The fame of the miracle went abroad</div><div class='line' id='LC5177'>into all lands.  From every land came monks to join; they came</div><div class='line' id='LC5178'>even as the fishes come, in shoals; and the monastery added building</div><div class='line' id='LC5179'>to building, and yet others to these, and so spread wide its arms</div><div class='line' id='LC5180'>and took them in.  And nuns came, also; and more again, and yet</div><div class='line' id='LC5181'>more; and built over against the monastery on the yon side of the</div><div class='line' id='LC5182'>vale, and added building to building, until mighty was that nunnery.</div><div class='line' id='LC5183'>And these were friendly unto those, and they joined their loving</div><div class='line' id='LC5184'>labors together, and together they built a fair great foundling</div><div class='line' id='LC5185'>asylum midway of the valley between.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5186'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5187'>&quot;You spoke of some hermits, Sandy.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5188'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5189'>&quot;These have gathered there from the ends of the earth.  A hermit</div><div class='line' id='LC5190'>thriveth best where there be multitudes of pilgrims.  Ye shall not</div><div class='line' id='LC5191'>find no hermit of no sort wanting.  If any shall mention a hermit</div><div class='line' id='LC5192'>of a kind he thinketh new and not to be found but in some far</div><div class='line' id='LC5193'>strange land, let him but scratch among the holes and caves and</div><div class='line' id='LC5194'>swamps that line that Valley of Holiness, and whatsoever be his</div><div class='line' id='LC5195'>breed, it skills not, he shall find a sample of it there.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5196'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5197'>I closed up alongside of a burly fellow with a fat good-humored</div><div class='line' id='LC5198'>face, purposing to make myself agreeable and pick up some further</div><div class='line' id='LC5199'>crumbs of fact; but I had hardly more than scraped acquaintance</div><div class='line' id='LC5200'>with him when he began eagerly and awkwardly to lead up, in the</div><div class='line' id='LC5201'>immemorial way, to that same old anecdote--the one Sir Dinadan</div><div class='line' id='LC5202'>told me, what time I got into trouble with Sir Sagramor and was</div><div class='line' id='LC5203'>challenged of him on account of it.  I excused myself and dropped</div><div class='line' id='LC5204'>to the rear of the procession, sad at heart, willing to go hence</div><div class='line' id='LC5205'>from this troubled life, this vale of tears, this brief day of</div><div class='line' id='LC5206'>broken rest, of cloud and storm, of weary struggle and monotonous</div><div class='line' id='LC5207'>defeat; and yet shrinking from the change, as remembering how long</div><div class='line' id='LC5208'>eternity is, and how many have wended thither who know that anecdote.</div><div class='line' id='LC5209'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5210'>Early in the afternoon we overtook another procession of pilgrims;</div><div class='line' id='LC5211'>but in this one was no merriment, no jokes, no laughter, no playful</div><div class='line' id='LC5212'>ways, nor any happy giddiness, whether of youth or age.  Yet both</div><div class='line' id='LC5213'>were here, both age and youth; gray old men and women, strong men</div><div class='line' id='LC5214'>and women of middle age, young husbands, young wives, little boys</div><div class='line' id='LC5215'>and girls, and three babies at the breast.  Even the children were</div><div class='line' id='LC5216'>smileless; there was not a face among all these half a hundred</div><div class='line' id='LC5217'>people but was cast down, and bore that set expression of hopelessness</div><div class='line' id='LC5218'>which is bred of long and hard trials and old acquaintance with</div><div class='line' id='LC5219'>despair.  They were slaves.  Chains led from their fettered feet</div><div class='line' id='LC5220'>and their manacled hands to a sole-leather belt about their waists;</div><div class='line' id='LC5221'>and all except the children were also linked together in a file</div><div class='line' id='LC5222'>six feet apart, by a single chain which led from collar to collar</div><div class='line' id='LC5223'>all down the line.  They were on foot, and had tramped three</div><div class='line' id='LC5224'>hundred miles in eighteen days, upon the cheapest odds and ends</div><div class='line' id='LC5225'>of food, and stingy rations of that.  They had slept in these</div><div class='line' id='LC5226'>chains every night, bundled together like swine.  They had upon</div><div class='line' id='LC5227'>their bodies some poor rags, but they could not be said to be</div><div class='line' id='LC5228'>clothed.  Their irons had chafed the skin from their ankles and</div><div class='line' id='LC5229'>made sores which were ulcerated and wormy.  Their naked feet were</div><div class='line' id='LC5230'>torn, and none walked without a limp.  Originally there had been a</div><div class='line' id='LC5231'>hundred of these unfortunates, but about half had been sold on</div><div class='line' id='LC5232'>the trip.  The trader in charge of them rode a horse and carried</div><div class='line' id='LC5233'>a whip with a short handle and a long heavy lash divided into</div><div class='line' id='LC5234'>several knotted tails at the end.  With this whip he cut the</div><div class='line' id='LC5235'>shoulders of any that tottered from weariness and pain, and</div><div class='line' id='LC5236'>straightened them up.  He did not speak; the whip conveyed his</div><div class='line' id='LC5237'>desire without that.  None of these poor creatures looked up as</div><div class='line' id='LC5238'>we rode along by; they showed no consciousness of our presence.</div><div class='line' id='LC5239'>And they made no sound but one; that was the dull and awful clank</div><div class='line' id='LC5240'>of their chains from end to end of the long file, as forty-three</div><div class='line' id='LC5241'>burdened feet rose and fell in unison.  The file moved in a cloud</div><div class='line' id='LC5242'>of its own making.</div><div class='line' id='LC5243'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5244'>All these faces were gray with a coating of dust.  One has seen</div><div class='line' id='LC5245'>the like of this coating upon furniture in unoccupied houses, and</div><div class='line' id='LC5246'>has written his idle thought in it with his finger.  I was reminded</div><div class='line' id='LC5247'>of this when I noticed the faces of some of those women, young</div><div class='line' id='LC5248'>mothers carrying babes that were near to death and freedom, how</div><div class='line' id='LC5249'>a something in their hearts was written in the dust upon their</div><div class='line' id='LC5250'>faces, plain to see, and lord, how plain to read! for it was the</div><div class='line' id='LC5251'>track of tears.  One of these young mothers was but a girl, and</div><div class='line' id='LC5252'>it hurt me to the heart to read that writing, and reflect that it</div><div class='line' id='LC5253'>was come up out of the breast of such a child, a breast that ought</div><div class='line' id='LC5254'>not to know trouble yet, but only the gladness of the morning of</div><div class='line' id='LC5255'>life; and no doubt--</div><div class='line' id='LC5256'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5257'>She reeled just then, giddy with fatigue, and down came the lash</div><div class='line' id='LC5258'>and flicked a flake of skin from her naked shoulder.  It stung me</div><div class='line' id='LC5259'>as if I had been hit instead.  The master halted the file and</div><div class='line' id='LC5260'>jumped from his horse.  He stormed and swore at this girl, and</div><div class='line' id='LC5261'>said she had made annoyance enough with her laziness, and as this</div><div class='line' id='LC5262'>was the last chance he should have, he would settle the account now.</div><div class='line' id='LC5263'>She dropped on her knees and put up her hands and began to beg,</div><div class='line' id='LC5264'>and cry, and implore, in a passion of terror, but the master gave</div><div class='line' id='LC5265'>no attention.  He snatched the child from her, and then made the</div><div class='line' id='LC5266'>men-slaves who were chained before and behind her throw her on</div><div class='line' id='LC5267'>the ground and hold her there and expose her body; and then he</div><div class='line' id='LC5268'>laid on with his lash like a madman till her back was flayed, she</div><div class='line' id='LC5269'>shrieking and struggling the while piteously.  One of the men who</div><div class='line' id='LC5270'>was holding her turned away his face, and for this humanity he was</div><div class='line' id='LC5271'>reviled and flogged.</div><div class='line' id='LC5272'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5273'>All our pilgrims looked on and commented--on the expert way in</div><div class='line' id='LC5274'>which the whip was handled.  They were too much hardened by lifelong</div><div class='line' id='LC5275'>everyday familiarity with slavery to notice that there was anything</div><div class='line' id='LC5276'>else in the exhibition that invited comment.  This was what slavery</div><div class='line' id='LC5277'>could do, in the way of ossifying what one may call the superior</div><div class='line' id='LC5278'>lobe of human feeling; for these pilgrims were kind-hearted people,</div><div class='line' id='LC5279'>and they would not have allowed that man to treat a horse like that.</div><div class='line' id='LC5280'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5281'>I wanted to stop the whole thing and set the slaves free, but that</div><div class='line' id='LC5282'>would not do.  I must not interfere too much and get myself a name</div><div class='line' id='LC5283'>for riding over the country&#39;s laws and the citizen&#39;s rights</div><div class='line' id='LC5284'>roughshod.  If I lived and prospered I would be the death of</div><div class='line' id='LC5285'>slavery, that I was resolved upon; but I would try to fix it so</div><div class='line' id='LC5286'>that when I became its executioner it should be by command of</div><div class='line' id='LC5287'>the nation.</div><div class='line' id='LC5288'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5289'>Just here was the wayside shop of a smith; and now arrived a landed</div><div class='line' id='LC5290'>proprietor who had bought this girl a few miles back, deliverable</div><div class='line' id='LC5291'>here where her irons could be taken off.  They were removed; then</div><div class='line' id='LC5292'>there was a squabble between the gentleman and the dealer as to</div><div class='line' id='LC5293'>which should pay the blacksmith.  The moment the girl was delivered</div><div class='line' id='LC5294'>from her irons, she flung herself, all tears and frantic sobbings,</div><div class='line' id='LC5295'>into the arms of the slave who had turned away his face when she</div><div class='line' id='LC5296'>was whipped.  He strained her to his breast, and smothered her</div><div class='line' id='LC5297'>face and the child&#39;s with kisses, and washed them with the rain</div><div class='line' id='LC5298'>of his tears.  I suspected.  I inquired.  Yes, I was right; it was</div><div class='line' id='LC5299'>husband and wife.  They had to be torn apart by force; the girl</div><div class='line' id='LC5300'>had to be dragged away, and she struggled and fought and shrieked</div><div class='line' id='LC5301'>like one gone mad till a turn of the road hid her from sight; and</div><div class='line' id='LC5302'>even after that, we could still make out the fading plaint of those</div><div class='line' id='LC5303'>receding shrieks.  And the husband and father, with his wife and</div><div class='line' id='LC5304'>child gone, never to be seen by him again in life?--well, the look</div><div class='line' id='LC5305'>of him one might not bear at all, and so I turned away; but I knew</div><div class='line' id='LC5306'>I should never get his picture out of my mind again, and there</div><div class='line' id='LC5307'>it is to this day, to wring my heartstrings whenever I think of it.</div><div class='line' id='LC5308'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5309'>We put up at the inn in a village just at nightfall, and when</div><div class='line' id='LC5310'>I rose next morning and looked abroad, I was ware where a knight</div><div class='line' id='LC5311'>came riding in the golden glory of the new day, and recognized him</div><div class='line' id='LC5312'>for knight of mine--Sir Ozana le Cure Hardy.  He was in the</div><div class='line' id='LC5313'>gentlemen&#39;s furnishing line, and his missionarying specialty was</div><div class='line' id='LC5314'>plug hats.  He was clothed all in steel, in the beautifulest armor</div><div class='line' id='LC5315'>of the time--up to where his helmet ought to have been; but he</div><div class='line' id='LC5316'>hadn&#39;t any helmet, he wore a shiny stove-pipe hat, and was ridiculous</div><div class='line' id='LC5317'>a spectacle as one might want to see.  It was another of my</div><div class='line' id='LC5318'>surreptitious schemes for extinguishing knighthood by making it</div><div class='line' id='LC5319'>grotesque and absurd.  Sir Ozana&#39;s saddle was hung about with</div><div class='line' id='LC5320'>leather hat boxes, and every time he overcame a wandering knight</div><div class='line' id='LC5321'>he swore him into my service and fitted him with a plug and made</div><div class='line' id='LC5322'>him wear it.  I dressed and ran down to welcome Sir Ozana and</div><div class='line' id='LC5323'>get his news.</div><div class='line' id='LC5324'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5325'>&quot;How is trade?&quot; I asked.</div><div class='line' id='LC5326'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5327'>&quot;Ye will note that I have but these four left; yet were they sixteen</div><div class='line' id='LC5328'>whenas I got me from Camelot.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5329'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5330'>&quot;Why, you have certainly done nobly, Sir Ozana.  Where have you</div><div class='line' id='LC5331'>been foraging of late?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5332'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5333'>&quot;I am but now come from the Valley of Holiness, please you sir.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5334'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5335'>&quot;I am pointed for that place myself.  Is there anything stirring</div><div class='line' id='LC5336'>in the monkery, more than common?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5337'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5338'>&quot;By the mass ye may not question it!....  Give him good feed,</div><div class='line' id='LC5339'>boy, and stint it not, an thou valuest thy crown; so get ye lightly</div><div class='line' id='LC5340'>to the stable and do even as I bid....  Sir, it is parlous news</div><div class='line' id='LC5341'>I bring, and--be these pilgrims?  Then ye may not do better, good</div><div class='line' id='LC5342'>folk, than gather and hear the tale I have to tell, sith it</div><div class='line' id='LC5343'>concerneth you, forasmuch as ye go to find that ye will not find,</div><div class='line' id='LC5344'>and seek that ye will seek in vain, my life being hostage for my</div><div class='line' id='LC5345'>word, and my word and message being these, namely: That a hap</div><div class='line' id='LC5346'>has happened whereof the like has not been seen no more but once</div><div class='line' id='LC5347'>this two hundred years, which was the first and last time that</div><div class='line' id='LC5348'>that said misfortune strake the holy valley in that form by</div><div class='line' id='LC5349'>commandment of the Most High whereto by reasons just and causes</div><div class='line' id='LC5350'>thereunto contributing, wherein the matter--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5351'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5352'>&quot;The miraculous fount hath ceased to flow!&quot;  This shout burst from</div><div class='line' id='LC5353'>twenty pilgrim mouths at once.</div><div class='line' id='LC5354'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5355'>&quot;Ye say well, good people.  I was verging to it, even when ye spake.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5356'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5357'>&quot;Has somebody been washing again?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5358'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5359'>&quot;Nay, it is suspected, but none believe it.  It is thought to be</div><div class='line' id='LC5360'>some other sin, but none wit what.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5361'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5362'>&quot;How are they feeling about the calamity?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC5363'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC5364'>&quot;None may describe it in words.  The fount is these nine days dry.</div><div class='line' id='LC5365'>The prayers that did begin then, and the lamentations in sackcloth</div><div class='line' id='LC5366'>and ashes, and the holy processions, none of these have ceased</div><div class='line' id='LC5367'>nor night nor day; and so the monks and the nuns and the foundlings</div><div class='line' id='LC5368'>be all exhausted, and do hang up prayers writ upon parchment,</div><div class='line' id='LC5369'>sith that no strength is left in man to lift up voice.
