but the lads</div><div class='line' id='LC6295'>that holp you with your miracle will be his guide and lead the way,</div><div class='line' id='LC6296'>and appoint the places for rests at noons and sleeps at night.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6297'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6298'>&quot;This will bring them here--when?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6299'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6300'>&quot;Mid-afternoon, or later, the third day.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6301'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6302'>&quot;Anything else in the way of news?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6303'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6304'>&quot;The king hath begun the raising of the standing army ye suggested</div><div class='line' id='LC6305'>to him; one regiment is complete and officered.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6306'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6307'>&quot;The mischief!  I wanted a main hand in that myself.  There is</div><div class='line' id='LC6308'>only one body of men in the kingdom that are fitted to officer</div><div class='line' id='LC6309'>a regular army.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6310'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6311'>&quot;Yes--and now ye will marvel to know there&#39;s not so much as one</div><div class='line' id='LC6312'>West Pointer in that regiment.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6313'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6314'>&quot;What are you talking about?  Are you in earnest?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6315'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6316'>&quot;It is truly as I have said.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6317'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6318'>&quot;Why, this makes me uneasy.  Who were chosen, and what was the</div><div class='line' id='LC6319'>method?  Competitive examination?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6320'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6321'>&quot;Indeed, I know naught of the method.  I but know this--these</div><div class='line' id='LC6322'>officers be all of noble family, and are born--what is it you</div><div class='line' id='LC6323'>call it?--chuckleheads.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6324'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6325'>&quot;There&#39;s something wrong, Clarence.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6326'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6327'>&quot;Comfort yourself, then; for two candidates for a lieutenancy do</div><div class='line' id='LC6328'>travel hence with the king--young nobles both--and if you but wait</div><div class='line' id='LC6329'>where you are you will hear them questioned.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6330'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6331'>&quot;That is news to the purpose.  I will get one West Pointer in,</div><div class='line' id='LC6332'>anyway.  Mount a man and send him to that school with a message;</div><div class='line' id='LC6333'>let him kill horses, if necessary, but he must be there before</div><div class='line' id='LC6334'>sunset to-night and say--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6335'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6336'>&quot;There is no need.  I have laid a ground wire to the school.</div><div class='line' id='LC6337'>Prithee let me connect you with it.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6338'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6339'>It sounded good!  In this atmosphere of telephones and lightning</div><div class='line' id='LC6340'>communication with distant regions, I was breathing the breath</div><div class='line' id='LC6341'>of life again after long suffocation.  I realized, then, what a</div><div class='line' id='LC6342'>creepy, dull, inanimate horror this land had been to me all these</div><div class='line' id='LC6343'>years, and how I had been in such a stifled condition of mind as</div><div class='line' id='LC6344'>to have grown used to it almost beyond the power to notice it.</div><div class='line' id='LC6345'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6346'>I gave my order to the superintendent of the Academy personally.</div><div class='line' id='LC6347'>I also asked him to bring me some paper and a fountain pen and</div><div class='line' id='LC6348'>a box or so of safety matches.  I was getting tired of doing</div><div class='line' id='LC6349'>without these conveniences.  I could have them now, as I wasn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC6350'>going to wear armor any more at present, and therefore could get</div><div class='line' id='LC6351'>at my pockets.</div><div class='line' id='LC6352'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6353'>When I got back to the monastery, I found a thing of interest</div><div class='line' id='LC6354'>going on.  The abbot and his monks were assembled in the great</div><div class='line' id='LC6355'>hall, observing with childish wonder and faith the performances</div><div class='line' id='LC6356'>of a new magician, a fresh arrival.  His dress was the extreme of</div><div class='line' id='LC6357'>the fantastic; as showy and foolish as the sort of thing an Indian</div><div class='line' id='LC6358'>medicine-man wears.  He was mowing, and mumbling, and gesticulating,</div><div class='line' id='LC6359'>and drawing mystical figures in the air and on the floor,--the</div><div class='line' id='LC6360'>regular thing, you know.  He was a celebrity from Asia--so he</div><div class='line' id='LC6361'>said, and that was enough.  That sort of evidence was as good</div><div class='line' id='LC6362'>as gold, and passed current everywhere.</div><div class='line' id='LC6363'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6364'>How easy and cheap it was to be a great magician on this fellow&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC6365'>terms.  His specialty was to tell you what any individual on the</div><div class='line' id='LC6366'>face of the globe was doing at the moment; and what he had done</div><div class='line' id='LC6367'>at any time in the past, and what he would do at any time in the</div><div class='line' id='LC6368'>future.  He asked if any would like to know what the Emperor of</div><div class='line' id='LC6369'>the East was doing now?  The sparkling eyes and the delighted rubbing</div><div class='line' id='LC6370'>of hands made eloquent answer--this reverend crowd _would_ like to</div><div class='line' id='LC6371'>know what that monarch was at, just as this moment.  The fraud</div><div class='line' id='LC6372'>went through some more mummery, and then made grave announcement:</div><div class='line' id='LC6373'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6374'>&quot;The high and mighty Emperor of the East doth at this moment put</div><div class='line' id='LC6375'>money in the palm of a holy begging friar--one, two, three pieces,</div><div class='line' id='LC6376'>and they be all of silver.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6377'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6378'>A buzz of admiring exclamations broke out, all around:</div><div class='line' id='LC6379'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6380'>&quot;It is marvelous!&quot;  &quot;Wonderful!&quot;  &quot;What study, what labor, to have</div><div class='line' id='LC6381'>acquired a so amazing power as this!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6382'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6383'>Would they like to know what the Supreme Lord of Inde was doing?</div><div class='line' id='LC6384'>Yes.  He told them what the Supreme Lord of Inde was doing.  Then</div><div class='line' id='LC6385'>he told them what the Sultan of Egypt was at; also what the King</div><div class='line' id='LC6386'>of the Remote Seas was about.  And so on and so on; and with each</div><div class='line' id='LC6387'>new marvel the astonishment at his accuracy rose higher and higher.</div><div class='line' id='LC6388'>They thought he must surely strike an uncertain place some time;</div><div class='line' id='LC6389'>but no, he never had to hesitate, he always knew, and always with</div><div class='line' id='LC6390'>unerring precision.  I saw that if this thing went on I should lose</div><div class='line' id='LC6391'>my supremacy, this fellow would capture my following, I should</div><div class='line' id='LC6392'>be left out in the cold.  I must put a cog in his wheel, and do it</div><div class='line' id='LC6393'>right away, too.  I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC6394'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6395'>&quot;If I might ask, I should very greatly like to know what a certain</div><div class='line' id='LC6396'>person is doing.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6397'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6398'>&quot;Speak, and freely.  I will tell you.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6399'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6400'>&quot;It will be difficult--perhaps impossible.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6401'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6402'>&quot;My art knoweth not that word.  The more difficult it is, the more</div><div class='line' id='LC6403'>certainly will I reveal it to you.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6404'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6405'>You see, I was working up the interest.  It was getting pretty</div><div class='line' id='LC6406'>high, too; you could see that by the craning necks all around,</div><div class='line' id='LC6407'>and the half-suspended breathing.  So now I climaxed it:</div><div class='line' id='LC6408'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6409'>&quot;If you make no mistake--if you tell me truly what I want to</div><div class='line' id='LC6410'>know--I will give you two hundred silver pennies.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6411'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6412'>&quot;The fortune is mine!  I will tell you what you would know.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6413'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6414'>&quot;Then tell me what I am doing with my right hand.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6415'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6416'>&quot;Ah-h!&quot;  There was a general gasp of surprise.  It had not occurred</div><div class='line' id='LC6417'>to anybody in the crowd--that simple trick of inquiring about</div><div class='line' id='LC6418'>somebody who wasn&#39;t ten thousand miles away.  The magician was</div><div class='line' id='LC6419'>hit hard; it was an emergency that had never happened in his</div><div class='line' id='LC6420'>experience before, and it corked him; he didn&#39;t know how to meet</div><div class='line' id='LC6421'>it.  He looked stunned, confused; he couldn&#39;t say a word.  &quot;Come,&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6422'>I said, &quot;what are you waiting for?  Is it possible you can answer up,</div><div class='line' id='LC6423'>right off, and tell what anybody on the other side of the earth is</div><div class='line' id='LC6424'>doing, and yet can&#39;t tell what a person is doing who isn&#39;t three</div><div class='line' id='LC6425'>yards from you?  Persons behind me know what I am doing with my</div><div class='line' id='LC6426'>right hand--they will indorse you if you tell correctly.&quot;  He was</div><div class='line' id='LC6427'>still dumb.  &quot;Very well, I&#39;ll tell you why you don&#39;t speak up and</div><div class='line' id='LC6428'>tell; it is because you don&#39;t know.  _You_ a magician!  Good friends,</div><div class='line' id='LC6429'>this tramp is a mere fraud and liar.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6430'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6431'>This distressed the monks and terrified them.  They were not used</div><div class='line' id='LC6432'>to hearing these awful beings called names, and they did not know</div><div class='line' id='LC6433'>what might be the consequence.  There was a dead silence now;</div><div class='line' id='LC6434'>superstitious bodings were in every mind.  The magician began to</div><div class='line' id='LC6435'>pull his wits together, and when he presently smiled an easy,</div><div class='line' id='LC6436'>nonchalant smile, it spread a mighty relief around; for it indicated</div><div class='line' id='LC6437'>that his mood was not destructive.  He said:</div><div class='line' id='LC6438'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6439'>&quot;It hath struck me speechless, the frivolity of this person&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC6440'>speech.  Let all know, if perchance there be any who know it not,</div><div class='line' id='LC6441'>that enchanters of my degree deign not to concern themselves with</div><div class='line' id='LC6442'>the doings of any but kings, princes, emperors, them that be born</div><div class='line' id='LC6443'>in the purple and them only.  Had ye asked me what Arthur the great</div><div class='line' id='LC6444'>king is doing, it were another matter, and I had told ye; but the</div><div class='line' id='LC6445'>doings of a subject interest me not.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6446'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6447'>&quot;Oh, I misunderstood you.  I thought you said &#39;anybody,&#39; and so</div><div class='line' id='LC6448'>I supposed &#39;anybody&#39; included--well, anybody; that is, everybody.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6449'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6450'>&quot;It doth--anybody that is of lofty birth; and the better if</div><div class='line' id='LC6451'>he be royal.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6452'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6453'>&quot;That, it meseemeth, might well be,&quot; said the abbot, who saw his</div><div class='line' id='LC6454'>opportunity to smooth things and avert disaster, &quot;for it were not</div><div class='line' id='LC6455'>likely that so wonderful a gift as this would be conferred for</div><div class='line' id='LC6456'>the revelation of the concerns of lesser beings than such as be</div><div class='line' id='LC6457'>born near to the summits of greatness.  Our Arthur the king--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6458'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6459'>&quot;Would you know of him?&quot; broke in the enchanter.</div><div class='line' id='LC6460'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6461'>&quot;Most gladly, yea, and gratefully.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6462'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6463'>Everybody was full of awe and interest again right away, the</div><div class='line' id='LC6464'>incorrigible idiots.  They watched the incantations absorbingly,</div><div class='line' id='LC6465'>and looked at me with a &quot;There, now, what can you say to that?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6466'>air, when the announcement came:</div><div class='line' id='LC6467'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6468'>&quot;The king is weary with the chase, and lieth in his palace these</div><div class='line' id='LC6469'>two hours sleeping a dreamless sleep.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6470'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6471'>&quot;God&#39;s benison upon him!&quot; said the abbot, and crossed himself;</div><div class='line' id='LC6472'>&quot;may that sleep be to the refreshment of his body and his soul.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6473'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6474'>&quot;And so it might be, if he were sleeping,&quot; I said, &quot;but the king</div><div class='line' id='LC6475'>is not sleeping, the king rides.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6476'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6477'>Here was trouble again--a conflict of authority.  Nobody knew which</div><div class='line' id='LC6478'>of us to believe; I still had some reputation left.  The magician&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC6479'>scorn was stirred, and he said:</div><div class='line' id='LC6480'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6481'>&quot;Lo, I have seen many wonderful soothsayers and prophets and</div><div class='line' id='LC6482'>magicians in my life days, but none before that could sit idle and</div><div class='line' id='LC6483'>see to the heart of things with never an incantation to help.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6484'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6485'>&quot;You have lived in the woods, and lost much by it.  I use incantations</div><div class='line' id='LC6486'>myself, as this good brotherhood are aware--but only on occasions</div><div class='line' id='LC6487'>of moment.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6488'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6489'>When it comes to sarcasming, I reckon I know how to keep my end up.</div><div class='line' id='LC6490'>That jab made this fellow squirm.  The abbot inquired after the</div><div class='line' id='LC6491'>queen and the court, and got this information:</div><div class='line' id='LC6492'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6493'>&quot;They be all on sleep, being overcome by fatigue, like as to the king.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6494'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6495'>I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC6496'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6497'>&quot;That is merely another lie.  Half of them are about their amusements,</div><div class='line' id='LC6498'>the queen and the other half are not sleeping, they ride.  Now</div><div class='line' id='LC6499'>perhaps you can spread yourself a little, and tell us where the king</div><div class='line' id='LC6500'>and queen and all that are this moment riding with them are going?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6501'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6502'>&quot;They sleep now, as I said; but on the morrow they will ride,</div><div class='line' id='LC6503'>for they go a journey toward the sea.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6504'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6505'>&quot;And where will they be the day after to-morrow at vespers?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6506'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6507'>&quot;Far to the north of Camelot, and half their journey will be done.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6508'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6509'>&quot;That is another lie, by the space of a hundred and fifty miles.</div><div class='line' id='LC6510'>Their journey will not be merely half done, it will be all done,</div><div class='line' id='LC6511'>and they will be _here_, in this valley.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6512'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6513'>_That_ was a noble shot!  It set the abbot and the monks in a whirl</div><div class='line' id='LC6514'>of excitement, and it rocked the enchanter to his base.  I followed</div><div class='line' id='LC6515'>the thing right up:</div><div class='line' id='LC6516'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6517'>&quot;If the king does not arrive, I will have myself ridden on a rail:</div><div class='line' id='LC6518'>if he does I will ride you on a rail instead.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6519'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6520'>Next day I went up to the telephone office and found that the king</div><div class='line' id='LC6521'>had passed through two towns that were on the line.  I spotted</div><div class='line' id='LC6522'>his progress on the succeeding day in the same way.  I kept these</div><div class='line' id='LC6523'>matters to myself.  The third day&#39;s reports showed that if he</div><div class='line' id='LC6524'>kept up his gait he would arrive by four in the afternoon.  There</div><div class='line' id='LC6525'>was still no sign anywhere of interest in his coming; there seemed</div><div class='line' id='LC6526'>to be no preparations making to receive him in state; a strange</div><div class='line' id='LC6527'>thing, truly.  Only one thing could explain this: that other</div><div class='line' id='LC6528'>magician had been cutting under me, sure.  This was true.  I asked</div><div class='line' id='LC6529'>a friend of mine, a monk, about it, and he said, yes, the magician</div><div class='line' id='LC6530'>had tried some further enchantments and found out that the court</div><div class='line' id='LC6531'>had concluded to make no journey at all, but stay at home.  Think</div><div class='line' id='LC6532'>of that!  Observe how much a reputation was worth in such a country.</div><div class='line' id='LC6533'>These people had seen me do the very showiest bit of magic in</div><div class='line' id='LC6534'>history, and the only one within their memory that had a positive</div><div class='line' id='LC6535'>value, and yet here they were, ready to take up with an adventurer</div><div class='line' id='LC6536'>who could offer no evidence of his powers but his mere unproven word.</div><div class='line' id='LC6537'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6538'>However, it was not good politics to let the king come without</div><div class='line' id='LC6539'>any fuss and feathers at all, so I went down and drummed up a</div><div class='line' id='LC6540'>procession of pilgrims and smoked out a batch of hermits and</div><div class='line' id='LC6541'>started them out at two o&#39;clock to meet him.  And that was the</div><div class='line' id='LC6542'>sort of state he arrived in.  The abbot was helpless with rage</div><div class='line' id='LC6543'>and humiliation when I brought him out on a balcony and showed</div><div class='line' id='LC6544'>him the head of the state marching in and never a monk on hand to</div><div class='line' id='LC6545'>offer him welcome, and no stir of life or clang of joy-bell to glad</div><div class='line' id='LC6546'>his spirit.  He took one look and then flew to rouse out his forces.</div><div class='line' id='LC6547'>The next minute the bells were dinning furiously, and the various</div><div class='line' id='LC6548'>buildings were vomiting monks and nuns, who went swarming in a</div><div class='line' id='LC6549'>rush toward the coming procession; and with them went that magician</div><div class='line' id='LC6550'>--and he was on a rail, too, by the abbot&#39;s order; and his reputation</div><div class='line' id='LC6551'>was in the mud, and mine was in the sky again.  Yes, a man can</div><div class='line' id='LC6552'>keep his trademark current in such a country, but he can&#39;t sit</div><div class='line' id='LC6553'>around and do it; he has got to be on deck and attending to business</div><div class='line' id='LC6554'>right along.</div><div class='line' id='LC6555'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6556'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6557'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6558'>CHAPTER XXV</div><div class='line' id='LC6559'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6560'>A COMPETITIVE EXAMINATION</div><div class='line' id='LC6561'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6562'>When the king traveled for change of air, or made a progress, or</div><div class='line' id='LC6563'>visited a distant noble whom he wished to bankrupt with the cost</div><div class='line' id='LC6564'>of his keep, part of the administration moved with him.  It was</div><div class='line' id='LC6565'>a fashion of the time.  The Commission charged with the examination</div><div class='line' id='LC6566'>of candidates for posts in the army came with the king to the</div><div class='line' id='LC6567'>Valley, whereas they could have transacted their business just</div><div class='line' id='LC6568'>as well at home.  And although this expedition was strictly a</div><div class='line' id='LC6569'>holiday excursion for the king, he kept some of his business</div><div class='line' id='LC6570'>functions going just the same.  He touched for the evil, as usual;</div><div class='line' id='LC6571'>he held court in the gate at sunrise and tried cases, for he was</div><div class='line' id='LC6572'>himself Chief Justice of the King&#39;s Bench.</div><div class='line' id='LC6573'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6574'>He shone very well in this latter office.  He was a wise and humane</div><div class='line' id='LC6575'>judge, and he clearly did his honest best and fairest,--according</div><div class='line' id='LC6576'>to his lights.  That is a large reservation.  His lights--I mean</div><div class='line' id='LC6577'>his rearing--often colored his decisions.  Whenever there was a</div><div class='line' id='LC6578'>dispute between a noble or gentleman and a person of lower degree,</div><div class='line' id='LC6579'>the king&#39;s leanings and sympathies were for the former class always,</div><div class='line' id='LC6580'>whether he suspected it or not.  It was impossible that this should</div><div class='line' id='LC6581'>be otherwise.  The blunting effects of slavery upon the slaveholder&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC6582'>moral perceptions are known and conceded, the world over; and a</div><div class='line' id='LC6583'>privileged class, an aristocracy, is but a band of slaveholders</div><div class='line' id='LC6584'>under another name.  This has a harsh sound, and yet should not</div><div class='line' id='LC6585'>be offensive to any--even to the noble himself--unless the fact</div><div class='line' id='LC6586'>itself be an offense: for the statement simply formulates a fact.</div><div class='line' id='LC6587'>The repulsive feature of slavery is the _thing_, not its name.  One</div><div class='line' id='LC6588'>needs but to hear an aristocrat speak of the classes that are below</div><div class='line' id='LC6589'>him to recognize--and in but indifferently modified measure</div><div class='line' id='LC6590'>--the very air and tone of the actual slaveholder; and behind these</div><div class='line' id='LC6591'>are the slaveholder&#39;s spirit, the slaveholder&#39;s blunted feeling.</div><div class='line' id='LC6592'>They are the result of the same cause in both cases: the possessor&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC6593'>old and inbred custom of regarding himself as a superior being.</div><div class='line' id='LC6594'>The king&#39;s judgments wrought frequent injustices, but it was merely</div><div class='line' id='LC6595'>the fault of his training, his natural and unalterable sympathies.</div><div class='line' id='LC6596'>He was as unfitted for a judgeship as would be the average mother</div><div class='line' id='LC6597'>for the position of milk-distributor to starving children in</div><div class='line' id='LC6598'>famine-time; her own children would fare a shade better than the rest.</div><div class='line' id='LC6599'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6600'>One very curious case came before the king.  A young girl, an</div><div class='line' id='LC6601'>orphan, who had a considerable estate, married a fine young fellow</div><div class='line' id='LC6602'>who had nothing.  The girl&#39;s property was within a seigniory held</div><div class='line' id='LC6603'>by the Church.  The bishop of the diocese, an arrogant scion of</div><div class='line' id='LC6604'>the great nobility, claimed the girl&#39;s estate on the ground that</div><div class='line' id='LC6605'>she had married privately, and thus had cheated the Church out</div><div class='line' id='LC6606'>of one of its rights as lord of the seigniory--the one heretofore</div><div class='line' id='LC6607'>referred to as le droit du seigneur.  The penalty of refusal or</div><div class='line' id='LC6608'>avoidance was confiscation.  The girl&#39;s defense was, that the</div><div class='line' id='LC6609'>lordship of the seigniory was vested in the bishop, and the</div><div class='line' id='LC6610'>particular right here involved was not transferable, but must be</div><div class='line' id='LC6611'>exercised by the lord himself or stand vacated; and that an older</div><div class='line' id='LC6612'>law, of the Church itself, strictly barred the bishop from exercising</div><div class='line' id='LC6613'>it.  It was a very odd case, indeed.</div><div class='line' id='LC6614'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6615'>It reminded me of something I had read in my youth about the</div><div class='line' id='LC6616'>ingenious way in which the aldermen of London raised the money</div><div class='line' id='LC6617'>that built the Mansion House.  A person who had not taken the</div><div class='line' id='LC6618'>Sacrament according to the Anglican rite could not stand as a</div><div class='line' id='LC6619'>candidate for sheriff of London.  Thus Dissenters were ineligible;</div><div class='line' id='LC6620'>they could not run if asked, they could not serve if elected.</div><div class='line' id='LC6621'>The aldermen, who without any question were Yankees in disguise,</div><div class='line' id='LC6622'>hit upon this neat device: they passed a by-law imposing a fine</div><div class='line' id='LC6623'>of L400 upon any one who should refuse to be a candidate for</div><div class='line' id='LC6624'>sheriff, and a fine of L600 upon any person who, after being</div><div class='line' id='LC6625'>elected sheriff, refused to serve.  Then they went to work and</div><div class='line' id='LC6626'>elected a lot of Dissenters, one after another, and kept it up</div><div class='line' id='LC6627'>until they had collected L15,000 in fines; and there stands the</div><div class='line' id='LC6628'>stately Mansion House to this day, to keep the blushing citizen</div><div class='line' id='LC6629'>in mind of a long past and lamented day when a band of Yankees</div><div class='line' id='LC6630'>slipped into London and played games of the sort that has given</div><div class='line' id='LC6631'>their race a unique and shady reputation among all truly good</div><div class='line' id='LC6632'>and holy peoples that be in the earth.</div><div class='line' id='LC6633'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6634'>The girl&#39;s case seemed strong to me; the bishop&#39;s case was just</div><div class='line' id='LC6635'>as strong.  I did not see how the king was going to get out of</div><div class='line' id='LC6636'>this hole.  But he got out.  I append his decision:</div><div class='line' id='LC6637'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6638'>&quot;Truly I find small difficulty here, the matter being even a</div><div class='line' id='LC6639'>child&#39;s affair for simpleness.  An the young bride had conveyed</div><div class='line' id='LC6640'>notice, as in duty bound, to her feudal lord and proper master</div><div class='line' id='LC6641'>and protector the bishop, she had suffered no loss, for the said</div><div class='line' id='LC6642'>bishop could have got a dispensation making him, for temporary</div><div class='line' id='LC6643'>conveniency, eligible to the exercise of his said right, and thus</div><div class='line' id='LC6644'>would she have kept all she had.  Whereas, failing in her first</div><div class='line' id='LC6645'>duty, she hath by that failure failed in all; for whoso, clinging</div><div class='line' id='LC6646'>to a rope, severeth it above his hands, must fall; it being no</div><div class='line' id='LC6647'>defense to claim that the rest of the rope is sound, neither any</div><div class='line' id='LC6648'>deliverance from his peril, as he shall find.  Pardy, the woman&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC6649'>case is rotten at the source.  It is the decree of the court that</div><div class='line' id='LC6650'>she forfeit to the said lord bishop all her goods, even to the</div><div class='line' id='LC6651'>last farthing that she doth possess, and be thereto mulcted in</div><div class='line' id='LC6652'>the costs.  Next!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6653'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6654'>Here was a tragic end to a beautiful honeymoon not yet three months</div><div class='line' id='LC6655'>old.  Poor young creatures!  They had lived these three months</div><div class='line' id='LC6656'>lapped to the lips in worldly comforts.  These clothes and trinkets</div><div class='line' id='LC6657'>they were wearing were as fine and dainty as the shrewdest stretch</div><div class='line' id='LC6658'>of the sumptuary laws allowed to people of their degree; and in</div><div class='line' id='LC6659'>these pretty clothes, she crying on his shoulder, and he trying</div><div class='line' id='LC6660'>to comfort her with hopeful words set to the music of despair,</div><div class='line' id='LC6661'>they went from the judgment seat out into the world homeless,</div><div class='line' id='LC6662'>bedless, breadless; why, the very beggars by the roadsides were</div><div class='line' id='LC6663'>not so poor as they.</div><div class='line' id='LC6664'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6665'>Well, the king was out of the hole; and on terms satisfactory to</div><div class='line' id='LC6666'>the Church and the rest of the aristocracy, no doubt.  Men write</div><div class='line' id='LC6667'>many fine and plausible arguments in support of monarchy, but</div><div class='line' id='LC6668'>the fact remains that where every man in a State has a vote, brutal</div><div class='line' id='LC6669'>laws are impossible.  Arthur&#39;s people were of course poor material</div><div class='line' id='LC6670'>for a republic, because they had been debased so long by monarchy;</div><div class='line' id='LC6671'>and yet even they would have been intelligent enough to make short</div><div class='line' id='LC6672'>work of that law which the king had just been administering if it</div><div class='line' id='LC6673'>had been submitted to their full and free vote.  There is a phrase</div><div class='line' id='LC6674'>which has grown so common in the world&#39;s mouth that it has come</div><div class='line' id='LC6675'>to seem to have sense and meaning--the sense and meaning implied</div><div class='line' id='LC6676'>when it is used; that is the phrase which refers to this or that or</div><div class='line' id='LC6677'>the other nation as possibly being &quot;capable of self-government&quot;;</div><div class='line' id='LC6678'>and the implied sense of it is, that there has been a nation</div><div class='line' id='LC6679'>somewhere, some time or other which _wasn&#39;t_ capable of it--wasn&#39;t as</div><div class='line' id='LC6680'>able to govern itself as some self-appointed specialists were or</div><div class='line' id='LC6681'>would be to govern it.  The master minds of all nations, in all</div><div class='line' id='LC6682'>ages, have sprung in affluent multitude from the mass of the nation,</div><div class='line' id='LC6683'>and from the mass of the nation only--not from its privileged</div><div class='line' id='LC6684'>classes; and so, no matter what the nation&#39;s intellectual grade</div><div class='line' id='LC6685'>was; whether high or low, the bulk of its ability was in the long</div><div class='line' id='LC6686'>ranks of its nameless and its poor, and so it never saw the day</div><div class='line' id='LC6687'>that it had not the material in abundance whereby to govern itself.</div><div class='line' id='LC6688'>Which is to assert an always self-proven fact: that even the best</div><div class='line' id='LC6689'>governed and most free and most enlightened monarchy is still</div><div class='line' id='LC6690'>behind the best condition attainable by its people; and that the</div><div class='line' id='LC6691'>same is true of kindred governments of lower grades, all the way</div><div class='line' id='LC6692'>down to the lowest.</div><div class='line' id='LC6693'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6694'>King Arthur had hurried up the army business altogether beyond</div><div class='line' id='LC6695'>my calculations.  I had not supposed he would move in the matter</div><div class='line' id='LC6696'>while I was away; and so I had not mapped out a scheme for determining</div><div class='line' id='LC6697'>the merits of officers; I had only remarked that it would be wise</div><div class='line' id='LC6698'>to submit every candidate to a sharp and searching examination;</div><div class='line' id='LC6699'>and privately I meant to put together a list of military qualifications</div><div class='line' id='LC6700'>that nobody could answer to but my West Pointers.  That ought</div><div class='line' id='LC6701'>to have been attended to before I left; for the king was so taken</div><div class='line' id='LC6702'>with the idea of a standing army that he couldn&#39;t wait but must</div><div class='line' id='LC6703'>get about it at once, and get up as good a scheme of examination</div><div class='line' id='LC6704'>as he could invent out of his own head.</div><div class='line' id='LC6705'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6706'>I was impatient to see what this was; and to show, too, how much</div><div class='line' id='LC6707'>more admirable was the one which I should display to the Examining</div><div class='line' id='LC6708'>Board.  I intimated this, gently, to the king, and it fired his</div><div class='line' id='LC6709'>curiosity.  When the Board was assembled, I followed him in; and</div><div class='line' id='LC6710'>behind us came the candidates.  One of these candidates was a bright</div><div class='line' id='LC6711'>young West Pointer of mine, and with him were a couple of my</div><div class='line' id='LC6712'>West Point professors.</div><div class='line' id='LC6713'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6714'>When I saw the Board, I did not know whether to cry or to laugh.</div><div class='line' id='LC6715'>The head of it was the officer known to later centuries as Norroy</div><div class='line' id='LC6716'>King-at-Arms!  The two other members were chiefs of bureaus in</div><div class='line' id='LC6717'>his department; and all three were priests, of course; all officials</div><div class='line' id='LC6718'>who had to know how to read and write were priests.</div><div class='line' id='LC6719'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6720'>My candidate was called first, out of courtesy to me, and the head</div><div class='line' id='LC6721'>of the Board opened on him with official solemnity:</div><div class='line' id='LC6722'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6723'>&quot;Name?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6724'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6725'>&quot;Mal-ease.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6726'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6727'>&quot;Son of?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6728'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6729'>&quot;Webster.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6730'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6731'>&quot;Webster--Webster.  H&#39;m--I--my memory faileth to recall the</div><div class='line' id='LC6732'>name.  Condition?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6733'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6734'>&quot;Weaver.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6735'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6736'>&quot;Weaver!--God keep us!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6737'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6738'>The king was staggered, from his summit to his foundations; one</div><div class='line' id='LC6739'>clerk fainted, and the others came near it.  The chairman pulled</div><div class='line' id='LC6740'>himself together, and said indignantly:</div><div class='line' id='LC6741'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6742'>&quot;It is sufficient.  Get you hence.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6743'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6744'>But I appealed to the king.  I begged that my candidate might be</div><div class='line' id='LC6745'>examined.  The king was willing, but the Board, who were all</div><div class='line' id='LC6746'>well-born folk, implored the king to spare them the indignity of</div><div class='line' id='LC6747'>examining the weaver&#39;s son.  I knew they didn&#39;t know enough to</div><div class='line' id='LC6748'>examine him anyway, so I joined my prayers to theirs and the king</div><div class='line' id='LC6749'>turned the duty over to my professors.  I had had a blackboard</div><div class='line' id='LC6750'>prepared, and it was put up now, and the circus began.  It was</div><div class='line' id='LC6751'>beautiful to hear the lad lay out the science of war, and wallow</div><div class='line' id='LC6752'>in details of battle and siege, of supply, transportation, mining</div><div class='line' id='LC6753'>and countermining, grand tactics, big strategy and little strategy,</div><div class='line' id='LC6754'>signal service, infantry, cavalry, artillery, and all about siege</div><div class='line' id='LC6755'>guns, field guns, gatling guns, rifled guns, smooth bores, musket</div><div class='line' id='LC6756'>practice, revolver practice--and not a solitary word of it all</div><div class='line' id='LC6757'>could these catfish make head or tail of, you understand--and it</div><div class='line' id='LC6758'>was handsome to see him chalk off mathematical nightmares on the</div><div class='line' id='LC6759'>blackboard that would stump the angels themselves, and do it like</div><div class='line' id='LC6760'>nothing, too--all about eclipses, and comets, and solstices, and</div><div class='line' id='LC6761'>constellations, and mean time, and sidereal time, and dinner time,</div><div class='line' id='LC6762'>and bedtime, and every other imaginable thing above the clouds or</div><div class='line' id='LC6763'>under them that you could harry or bullyrag an enemy with and make</div><div class='line' id='LC6764'>him wish he hadn&#39;t come--and when the boy made his military salute</div><div class='line' id='LC6765'>and stood aside at last, I was proud enough to hug him, and all</div><div class='line' id='LC6766'>those other people were so dazed they looked partly petrified,</div><div class='line' id='LC6767'>partly drunk, and wholly caught out and snowed under.  I judged</div><div class='line' id='LC6768'>that the cake was ours, and by a large majority.</div><div class='line' id='LC6769'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6770'>Education is a great thing.  This was the same youth who had come</div><div class='line' id='LC6771'>to West Point so ignorant that when I asked him, &quot;If a general</div><div class='line' id='LC6772'>officer should have a horse shot under him on the field of battle,</div><div class='line' id='LC6773'>what ought he to do?&quot; answered up naively and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC6774'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6775'>&quot;Get up and brush himself.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6776'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6777'>One of the young nobles was called up now.  I thought I would</div><div class='line' id='LC6778'>question him a little myself.  I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC6779'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6780'>&quot;Can your lordship read?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6781'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6782'>His face flushed indignantly, and he fired this at me:</div><div class='line' id='LC6783'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6784'>&quot;Takest me for a clerk?  I trow I am not of a blood that--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6785'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6786'>&quot;Answer the question!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6787'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6788'>He crowded his wrath down and made out to answer &quot;No.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6789'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6790'>&quot;Can you write?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6791'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6792'>He wanted to resent this, too, but I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC6793'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6794'>&quot;You will confine yourself to the questions, and make no comments.</div><div class='line' id='LC6795'>You are not here to air your blood or your graces, and nothing</div><div class='line' id='LC6796'>of the sort will be permitted.  Can you write?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6797'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6798'>&quot;No.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6799'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6800'>&quot;Do you know the multiplication table?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6801'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6802'>&quot;I wit not what ye refer to.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6803'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6804'>&quot;How much is 9 times 6?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6805'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6806'>&quot;It is a mystery that is hidden from me by reason that the emergency</div><div class='line' id='LC6807'>requiring the fathoming of it hath not in my life-days occurred,</div><div class='line' id='LC6808'>and so, not having no need to know this thing, I abide barren</div><div class='line' id='LC6809'>of the knowledge.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6810'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6811'>&quot;If A trade a barrel of onions to B, worth 2 pence the bushel,</div><div class='line' id='LC6812'>in exchange for a sheep worth 4 pence and a dog worth a penny,</div><div class='line' id='LC6813'>and C kill the dog before delivery, because bitten by the same,</div><div class='line' id='LC6814'>who mistook him for D, what sum is still due to A from B, and</div><div class='line' id='LC6815'>which party pays for the dog, C or D, and who gets the money?</div><div class='line' id='LC6816'>If A, is the penny sufficient, or may he claim consequential damages</div><div class='line' id='LC6817'>in the form of additional money to represent the possible profit</div><div class='line' id='LC6818'>which might have inured from the dog, and classifiable as earned</div><div class='line' id='LC6819'>increment, that is to say, usufruct?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6820'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6821'>&quot;Verily, in the all-wise and unknowable providence of God, who</div><div class='line' id='LC6822'>moveth in mysterious ways his wonders to perform, have I never</div><div class='line' id='LC6823'>heard the fellow to this question for confusion of the mind and</div><div class='line' id='LC6824'>congestion of the ducts of thought.  Wherefore I beseech you let</div><div class='line' id='LC6825'>the dog and the onions and these people of the strange and godless</div><div class='line' id='LC6826'>names work out their several salvations from their piteous and</div><div class='line' id='LC6827'>wonderful difficulties without help of mine, for indeed their</div><div class='line' id='LC6828'>trouble is sufficient as it is, whereas an I tried to help I should</div><div class='line' id='LC6829'>but damage their cause the more and yet mayhap not live myself</div><div class='line' id='LC6830'>to see the desolation wrought.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6831'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6832'>&quot;What do you know of the laws of attraction and gravitation?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6833'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6834'>&quot;If there be such, mayhap his grace the king did promulgate them</div><div class='line' id='LC6835'>whilst that I lay sick about the beginning of the year and thereby</div><div class='line' id='LC6836'>failed to hear his proclamation.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6837'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6838'>&quot;What do you know of the science of optics?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6839'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6840'>&quot;I know of governors of places, and seneschals of castles, and</div><div class='line' id='LC6841'>sheriffs of counties, and many like small offices and titles of</div><div class='line' id='LC6842'>honor, but him you call the Science of Optics I have not heard</div><div class='line' id='LC6843'>of before; peradventure it is a new dignity.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6844'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6845'>&quot;Yes, in this country.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6846'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6847'>Try to conceive of this mollusk gravely applying for an official</div><div class='line' id='LC6848'>position, of any kind under the sun!  Why, he had all the earmarks</div><div class='line' id='LC6849'>of a typewriter copyist, if you leave out the disposition to</div><div class='line' id='LC6850'>contribute uninvited emendations of your grammar and punctuation.</div><div class='line' id='LC6851'>It was unaccountable that he didn&#39;t attempt a little help of that</div><div class='line' id='LC6852'>sort out of his majestic supply of incapacity for the job.  But that</div><div class='line' id='LC6853'>didn&#39;t prove that he hadn&#39;t material in him for the disposition,</div><div class='line' id='LC6854'>it only proved that he wasn&#39;t a typewriter copyist yet.  After</div><div class='line' id='LC6855'>nagging him a little more, I let the professors loose on him and</div><div class='line' id='LC6856'>they turned him inside out, on the line of scientific war, and</div><div class='line' id='LC6857'>found him empty, of course.  He knew somewhat about the warfare</div><div class='line' id='LC6858'>of the time--bushwhacking around for ogres, and bull-fights in</div><div class='line' id='LC6859'>the tournament ring, and such things--but otherwise he was empty</div><div class='line' id='LC6860'>and useless.  Then we took the other young noble in hand, and he</div><div class='line' id='LC6861'>was the first one&#39;s twin, for ignorance and incapacity.  I delivered</div><div class='line' id='LC6862'>them into the hands of the chairman of the Board with the comfortable</div><div class='line' id='LC6863'>consciousness that their cake was dough.  They were examined in</div><div class='line' id='LC6864'>the previous order of precedence.</div><div class='line' id='LC6865'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6866'>&quot;Name, so please you?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6867'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6868'>&quot;Pertipole, son of Sir Pertipole, Baron of Barley Mash.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6869'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6870'>&quot;Grandfather?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6871'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6872'>&quot;Also Sir Pertipole, Baron of Barley Mash.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6873'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6874'>&quot;Great-grandfather?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6875'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6876'>&quot;The same name and title.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6877'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6878'>&quot;Great-great-grandfather?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6879'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6880'>&quot;We had none, worshipful sir, the line failing before it had</div><div class='line' id='LC6881'>reached so far back.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6882'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6883'>&quot;It mattereth not.  It is a good four generations, and fulfilleth</div><div class='line' id='LC6884'>the requirements of the rule.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6885'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6886'>&quot;Fulfills what rule?&quot; I asked.</div><div class='line' id='LC6887'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6888'>&quot;The rule requiring four generations of nobility or else the</div><div class='line' id='LC6889'>candidate is not eligible.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6890'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6891'>&quot;A man not eligible for a lieutenancy in the army unless he can</div><div class='line' id='LC6892'>prove four generations of noble descent?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6893'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6894'>&quot;Even so; neither lieutenant nor any other officer may be commissioned</div><div class='line' id='LC6895'>without that qualification.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6896'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6897'>&quot;Oh, come, this is an astonishing thing.  What good is such a</div><div class='line' id='LC6898'>qualification as that?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6899'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6900'>&quot;What good?  It is a hardy question, fair sir and Boss, since it doth</div><div class='line' id='LC6901'>go far to impugn the wisdom of even our holy Mother Church herself.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6902'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6903'>&quot;As how?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6904'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6905'>&quot;For that she hath established the self-same rule regarding</div><div class='line' id='LC6906'>saints.  By her law none may be canonized until he hath lain dead</div><div class='line' id='LC6907'>four generations.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6908'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6909'>&quot;I see, I see--it is the same thing.  It is wonderful.  In the one</div><div class='line' id='LC6910'>case a man lies dead-alive four generations--mummified in ignorance</div><div class='line' id='LC6911'>and sloth--and that qualifies him to command live people, and take</div><div class='line' id='LC6912'>their weal and woe into his impotent hands; and in the other case,</div><div class='line' id='LC6913'>a man lies bedded with death and worms four generations, and that</div><div class='line' id='LC6914'>qualifies him for office in the celestial camp.  Does the king&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC6915'>grace approve of this strange law?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6916'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6917'>The king said:</div><div class='line' id='LC6918'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6919'>&quot;Why, truly I see naught about it that is strange.  All places of</div><div class='line' id='LC6920'>honor and of profit do belong, by natural right, to them that be</div><div class='line' id='LC6921'>of noble blood, and so these dignities in the army are their</div><div class='line' id='LC6922'>property and would be so without this or any rule.  The rule is</div><div class='line' id='LC6923'>but to mark a limit.  Its purpose is to keep out too recent blood,</div><div class='line' id='LC6924'>which would bring into contempt these offices, and men of lofty</div><div class='line' id='LC6925'>lineage would turn their backs and scorn to take them.  I were</div><div class='line' id='LC6926'>to blame an I permitted this calamity.  _You_ can permit it an you</div><div class='line' id='LC6927'>are minded so to do, for you have the delegated authority, but</div><div class='line' id='LC6928'>that the king should do it were a most strange madness and not</div><div class='line' id='LC6929'>comprehensible to any.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6930'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6931'>&quot;I yield.  Proceed, sir Chief of the Herald&#39;s College.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6932'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6933'>The chairman resumed as follows:</div><div class='line' id='LC6934'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6935'>&quot;By what illustrious achievement for the honor of the Throne and</div><div class='line' id='LC6936'>State did the founder of your great line lift himself to the</div><div class='line' id='LC6937'>sacred dignity of the British nobility?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6938'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6939'>&quot;He built a brewery.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6940'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6941'>&quot;Sire, the Board finds this candidate perfect in all the requirements</div><div class='line' id='LC6942'>and qualifications for military command, and doth hold his case</div><div class='line' id='LC6943'>open for decision after due examination of his competitor.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6944'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6945'>The competitor came forward and proved exactly four generations</div><div class='line' id='LC6946'>of nobility himself.  So there was a tie in military qualifications</div><div class='line' id='LC6947'>that far.</div><div class='line' id='LC6948'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6949'>He stood aside a moment, and Sir Pertipole was questioned further:</div><div class='line' id='LC6950'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6951'>&quot;Of what condition was the wife of the founder of your line?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6952'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6953'>&quot;She came of the highest landed gentry, yet she was not noble;</div><div class='line' id='LC6954'>she was gracious and pure and charitable, of a blameless life and</div><div class='line' id='LC6955'>character, insomuch that in these regards was she peer of the</div><div class='line' id='LC6956'>best lady in the land.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6957'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6958'>&quot;That will do.  Stand down.&quot;  He called up the competing lordling</div><div class='line' id='LC6959'>again, and asked: &quot;What was the rank and condition of the</div><div class='line' id='LC6960'>great-grandmother who conferred British nobility upon your</div><div class='line' id='LC6961'>great house?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6962'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6963'>&quot;She was a king&#39;s leman and did climb to that splendid eminence</div><div class='line' id='LC6964'>by her own unholpen merit from the sewer where she was born.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6965'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6966'>&quot;Ah, this, indeed, is true nobility, this is the right and perfect</div><div class='line' id='LC6967'>intermixture.  The lieutenancy is yours, fair lord.  Hold it not in</div><div class='line' id='LC6968'>contempt; it is the humble step which will lead to grandeurs more</div><div class='line' id='LC6969'>worthy of the splendor of an origin like to thine.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC6970'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6971'>I was down in the bottomless pit of humiliation.  I had promised</div><div class='line' id='LC6972'>myself an easy and zenith-scouring triumph, and this was the outcome!</div><div class='line' id='LC6973'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6974'>I was almost ashamed to look my poor disappointed cadet in the</div><div class='line' id='LC6975'>face.  I told him to go home and be patient, this wasn&#39;t the end.</div><div class='line' id='LC6976'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC6977'>I had a private audience with the king, and made a proposition.</div><div class='line' id='LC6978'>I said it was quite right to officer that regiment with nobilities,</div><div class='line' id='LC6979'>and he couldn&#39;t have done a wiser thing.  It would also be a good</div><div class='line' id='LC6980'>idea to add five hundred officers to it; in fact, add as many</div><div class='line' id='LC6981'>officers as there were nobles and relatives of nobles in the</div><div class='line' id='LC6982'>country, even if there should finally be five times as many officers</div><div class='line' id='LC6983'>as privates in it; and thus make it the crack regiment, the envied</div><div class='line' id='LC6984'>regiment, the King&#39;s Own regiment, and entitled to fight on its</div><div class='line' id='LC6985'>own hook and in its own way, and go whither it would and come</div><div class='line' id='LC6986'>when it pleased, in time of war, and be utterly swell and independent.</div><div class='line' id='LC6987'>This would make that regiment the heart&#39;s desire of all the</div><div class='line' id='LC6988'>nobility, and they would all be satisfied and happy.  Then we</div><div class='line' id='LC6989'>would make up the rest of the standing army out of commonplace</div><div class='line' id='LC6990'>materials, and officer it with nobodies, as was proper--nobodies</div><div class='line' id='LC6991'>selected on a basis of mere efficiency--and we would make this</div><div class='line' id='LC6992'>regiment toe the line, allow it no aristocratic freedom from</div><div class='line' id='LC6993'>restraint, and force it to do all the work and persistent hammering,</div><div class='line' id='LC6994'>to the end that whenever the King&#39;s Own was tired and wanted to go</div><div class='line' id='LC6995'>off for a change and rummage around amongst ogres and have a good</div><div class='line' id='LC6996'>time, it could go without uneasiness, knowing that matters were in</div><div class='line' id='LC6997'>safe hands behind it, and business going to be continued at the</div><div class='line' id='LC6998'>old stand, same as usual.  The king was charmed with the idea.</div><div class='line' id='LC6999'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7000'>When I noticed that, it gave me a valuable notion.  I thought</div><div class='line' id='LC7001'>I saw my way out of an old and stubborn difficulty at last.  You</div><div class='line' id='LC7002'>see, the royalties of the Pendragon stock were a long-lived race</div><div class='line' id='LC7003'>and very fruitful.  Whenever a child was born to any of these</div><div class='line' id='LC7004'>--and it was pretty often--there was wild joy in the nation&#39;s mouth,</div><div class='line' id='LC7005'>and piteous sorrow in the nation&#39;s heart.  The joy was questionable,</div><div class='line' id='LC7006'>but the grief was honest.  Because the event meant another call</div><div class='line' id='LC7007'>for a Royal Grant.  Long was the list of these royalties, and</div><div class='line' id='LC7008'>they were a heavy and steadily increasing burden upon the treasury</div><div class='line' id='LC7009'>and a menace to the crown.  Yet Arthur could not believe this</div><div class='line' id='LC7010'>latter fact, and he would not listen to any of my various projects</div><div class='line' id='LC7011'>for substituting something in the place of the royal grants.  If I</div><div class='line' id='LC7012'>could have persuaded him to now and then provide a support for</div><div class='line' id='LC7013'>one of these outlying scions from his own pocket, I could have</div><div class='line' id='LC7014'>made a grand to-do over it, and it would have had a good effect</div><div class='line' id='LC7015'>with the nation; but no, he wouldn&#39;t hear of such a thing.  He had</div><div class='line' id='LC7016'>something like a religious passion for royal grant; he seemed to</div><div class='line' id='LC7017'>look upon it as a sort of sacred swag, and one could not irritate</div><div class='line' id='LC7018'>him in any way so quickly and so surely as by an attack upon that</div><div class='line' id='LC7019'>venerable institution.  If I ventured to cautiously hint that there</div><div class='line' id='LC7020'>was not another respectable family in England that would humble</div><div class='line' id='LC7021'>itself to hold out the hat--however, that is as far as I ever got;</div><div class='line' id='LC7022'>he always cut me short there, and peremptorily, too.</div><div class='line' id='LC7023'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7024'>But I believed I saw my chance at last.  I would form this crack</div><div class='line' id='LC7025'>regiment out of officers alone--not a single private.  Half of it</div><div class='line' id='LC7026'>should consist of nobles, who should fill all the places up to</div><div class='line' id='LC7027'>Major-General, and serve gratis and pay their own expenses; and</div><div class='line' id='LC7028'>they would be glad to do this when they should learn that the rest</div><div class='line' id='LC7029'>of the regiment would consist exclusively of princes of the blood.</div><div class='line' id='LC7030'>These princes of the blood should range in rank from Lieutenant-General</div><div class='line' id='LC7031'>up to Field Marshal, and be gorgeously salaried and equipped and</div><div class='line' id='LC7032'>fed by the state.  Moreover--and this was the master stroke</div><div class='line' id='LC7033'>--it should be decreed that these princely grandees should be always</div><div class='line' id='LC7034'>addressed by a stunningly gaudy and awe-compelling title (which</div><div class='line' id='LC7035'>I would presently invent), and they and they only in all England</div><div class='line' id='LC7036'>should be so addressed.  Finally, all princes of the blood should</div><div class='line' id='LC7037'>have free choice; join that regiment, get that great title, and</div><div class='line' id='LC7038'>renounce the royal grant, or stay out and receive a grant.  Neatest</div><div class='line' id='LC7039'>touch of all: unborn but imminent princes of the blood could be</div><div class='line' id='LC7040'>_born_ into the regiment, and start fair, with good wages and a</div><div class='line' id='LC7041'>permanent situation, upon due notice from the parents.</div><div class='line' id='LC7042'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7043'>All the boys would join, I was sure of that; so, all existing</div><div class='line' id='LC7044'>grants would be relinquished; that the newly born would always</div><div class='line' id='LC7045'>join was equally certain.  Within sixty days that quaint and</div><div class='line' id='LC7046'>bizarre anomaly, the Royal Grant, would cease to be a living fact,</div><div class='line' id='LC7047'>and take its place among the curiosities of the past.</div><div class='line' id='LC7048'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7049'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7050'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7051'>CHAPTER XXVI</div><div class='line' id='LC7052'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7053'>THE FIRST NEWSPAPER</div><div class='line' id='LC7054'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7055'>When I told the king I was going out disguised as a petty freeman</div><div class='line' id='LC7056'>to scour the country and familiarize myself with the humbler life</div><div class='line' id='LC7057'>of the people, he was all afire with the novelty of the thing</div><div class='line' id='LC7058'>in a minute, and was bound to take a chance in the adventure</div><div class='line' id='LC7059'>himself--nothing should stop him--he would drop everything and</div><div class='line' id='LC7060'>go along--it was the prettiest idea he had run across for many</div><div class='line' id='LC7061'>a day.  He wanted to glide out the back way and start at once;</div><div class='line' id='LC7062'>but I showed him that that wouldn&#39;t answer.  You see, he was billed</div><div class='line' id='LC7063'>for the king&#39;s-evil--to touch for it, I mean--and it wouldn&#39;t be</div><div class='line' id='LC7064'>right to disappoint the house and it wouldn&#39;t make a delay worth</div><div class='line' id='LC7065'>considering, anyway, it was only a one-night stand.  And I thought</div><div class='line' id='LC7066'>he ought to tell the queen he was going away.  He clouded up at</div><div class='line' id='LC7067'>that and looked sad.  I was sorry I had spoken, especially when</div><div class='line' id='LC7068'>he said mournfully:</div><div class='line' id='LC7069'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7070'>&quot;Thou forgettest that Launcelot is here; and where Launcelot is,</div><div class='line' id='LC7071'>she noteth not the going forth of the king, nor what day he returneth.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC7072'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7073'>Of course, I changed the Subject.  Yes, Guenever was beautiful,</div><div class='line' id='LC7074'>it is true, but take her all around she was pretty slack.  I never</div><div class='line' id='LC7075'>meddled in these matters, they weren&#39;t my affair, but I did hate</div><div class='line' id='LC7076'>to see the way things were going on, and I don&#39;t mind saying that</div><div class='line' id='LC7077'>much.  Many&#39;s the time she had asked me, &quot;Sir Boss, hast seen</div><div class='line' id='LC7078'>Sir Launcelot about?&quot; but if ever she went fretting around for</div><div class='line' id='LC7079'>the king I didn&#39;t happen to be around at the time.</div><div class='line' id='LC7080'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7081'>There was a very good lay-out for the king&#39;s-evil business--very</div><div class='line' id='LC7082'>tidy and creditable.  The king sat under a canopy of state; about</div><div class='line' id='LC7083'>him were clustered a large body of the clergy in full canonicals.</div><div class='line' id='LC7084'>Conspicuous, both for location and personal outfit, stood Marinel,</div><div class='line' id='LC7085'>a hermit of the quack-doctor species, to introduce the sick.  All</div><div class='line' id='LC7086'>abroad over the spacious floor, and clear down to the doors,</div><div class='line' id='LC7087'>in a thick jumble, lay or sat the scrofulous, under a strong light.</div><div class='line' id='LC7088'>It was as good as a tableau; in fact, it had all the look of being</div><div class='line' id='LC7089'>gotten up for that, though it wasn&#39;t.  There were eight hundred</div><div class='line' id='LC7090'>sick people present.  The work was slow; it lacked the interest</div><div class='line' id='LC7091'>of novelty for me, because I had seen the ceremonies before;</div><div class='line' id='LC7092'>the thing soon became tedious, but the proprieties required me</div><div class='line' id='LC7093'>to stick it out.  The doctor was there for the reason that in all</div><div class='line' id='LC7094'>such crowds there were many people who only imagined something</div><div class='line' id='LC7095'>was the matter with them, and many who were consciously sound</div><div class='line' id='LC7096'>but wanted the immortal honor of fleshly contact with a king, and</div><div class='line' id='LC7097'>yet others who pretended to illness in order to get the piece of</div><div class='line' id='LC7098'>coin that went with the touch.  Up to this time this coin had been</div><div class='line' id='LC7099'>a wee little gold piece worth about a third of a dollar.  When you</div><div class='line' id='LC7100'>consider how much that amount of money would buy, in that age</div><div class='line' id='LC7101'>and country, and how usual it was to be scrofulous, when not dead,</div><div class='line' id='LC7102'>you would understand that the annual king&#39;s-evil appropriation was</div><div class='line' id='LC7103'>just the River and Harbor bill of that government for the grip it</div><div class='line' id='LC7104'>took on the treasury and the chance it afforded for skinning the</div><div class='line' id='LC7105'>surplus.  So I had privately concluded to touch the treasury itself</div><div class='line' id='LC7106'>for the king&#39;s-evil.  I covered six-sevenths of the appropriation</div><div class='line' id='LC7107'>into the treasury a week before starting from Camelot on my</div><div class='line' id='LC7108'>adventures, and ordered that the other seventh be inflated into</div><div class='line' id='LC7109'>five-cent nickels and delivered into the hands of the head clerk</div><div class='line' id='LC7110'>of the King&#39;s Evil Department; a nickel to take the place of each</div><div class='line' id='LC7111'>gold coin, you see, and do its work for it.  It might strain the</div><div class='line' id='LC7112'>nickel some, but I judged it could stand it.  As a rule, I do not</div><div class='line' id='LC7113'>approve of watering stock, but I considered it square enough</div><div class='line' id='LC7114'>in this case, for it was just a gift, anyway.  Of course, you can</div><div class='line' id='LC7115'>water a gift as much as you want to; and I generally do.  The old</div><div class='line' id='LC7116'>gold and silver coins of the country were of ancient and unknown</div><div class='line' id='LC7117'>origin, as a rule, but some of them were Roman; they were ill-shapen,</div><div class='line' id='LC7118'>and seldom rounder than a moon that is a week past the full; they</div><div class='line' id='LC7119'>were hammered, not minted, and they were so worn with use that</div><div class='line' id='LC7120'>the devices upon them were as illegible as blisters, and looked</div><div class='line' id='LC7121'>like them.  I judged that a sharp, bright new nickel, with a</div><div class='line' id='LC7122'>first-rate likeness of the king on one side of it and Guenever</div><div class='line' id='LC7123'>on the other, and a blooming pious motto, would take the tuck out</div><div class='line' id='LC7124'>of scrofula as handy as a nobler coin and please the scrofulous</div><div class='line' id='LC7125'>fancy more; and I was right.  This batch was the first it was</div><div class='line' id='LC7126'>tried on, and it worked to a charm.  The saving in expense was</div><div class='line' id='LC7127'>a notable economy.  You will see that by these figures: We touched</div><div class='line' id='LC7128'>a trifle over 700 of the 800 patients; at former rates, this would</div><div class='line' id='LC7129'>have cost the government about $240; at the new rate we pulled</div><div class='line' id='LC7130'>through for about $35, thus saving upward of $200 at one swoop.</div><div class='line' id='LC7131'>To appreciate the full magnitude of this stroke, consider these</div><div class='line' id='LC7132'>other figures: the annual expenses of a national government amount</div><div class='line' id='LC7133'>to the equivalent of a contribution of three days&#39; average wages of</div><div class='line' id='LC7134'>every individual of the population, counting every individual as</div><div class='line' id='LC7135'>if he were a man.  If you take a nation of 60,000,000, where average</div><div class='line' id='LC7136'>wages are $2 per day, three days&#39; wages taken from each individual</div><div class='line' id='LC7137'>will provide $360,000,000 and pay the government&#39;s expenses.  In my</div><div class='line' id='LC7138'>day, in my own country, this money was collected from imposts,</div><div class='line' id='LC7139'>and the citizen imagined that the foreign importer paid it, and it</div><div class='line' id='LC7140'>made him comfortable to think so; whereas, in fact, it was paid</div><div class='line' id='LC7141'>by the American people, and was so equally and exactly distributed</div><div class='line' id='LC7142'>among them that the annual cost to the 100-millionaire and the</div><div class='line' id='LC7143'>annual cost to the sucking child of the day-laborer was precisely</div><div class='line' id='LC7144'>the same--each paid $6.  Nothing could be equaler than that,</div><div class='line' id='LC7145'>I reckon.  Well, Scotland and Ireland were tributary to Arthur,</div><div class='line' id='LC7146'>and the united populations of the British Islands amounted to</div><div class='line' id='LC7147'>something less than 1,000,000.  A mechanic&#39;s average wage was</div><div class='line' id='LC7148'>3 cents a day, when he paid his own keep.  By this rule the national</div><div class='line' id='LC7149'>government&#39;s expenses were $90,000 a year, or about $250 a day.</div><div class='line' id='LC7150'>Thus, by the substitution of nickels for gold on a king&#39;s-evil</div><div class='line' id='LC7151'>day, I not only injured no one, dissatisfied no one, but pleased</div><div class='line' id='LC7152'>all concerned and saved four-fifths of that day&#39;s national expense</div><div class='line' id='LC7153'>into the bargain--a saving which would have been the equivalent</div><div class='line' id='LC7154'>of $800,000 in my day in America.  In making this substitution</div><div class='line' id='LC7155'>I had drawn upon the wisdom of a very remote source--the wisdom</div><div class='line' id='LC7156'>of my boyhood--for the true statesman does not despise any wisdom,</div><div class='line' id='LC7157'>howsoever lowly may be its origin: in my boyhood I had always</div><div class='line' id='LC7158'>saved my pennies and contributed buttons to the foreign missionary</div><div class='line' id='LC7159'>cause.  The buttons would answer the ignorant savage as well as</div><div class='line' id='LC7160'>the coin, the coin would answer me better than the buttons; all</div><div class='line' id='LC7161'>hands were happy and nobody hurt.</div><div class='line' id='LC7162'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7163'>Marinel took the patients as they came.  He examined the candidate;</div><div class='line' id='LC7164'>if he couldn&#39;t qualify he was warned off; if he could he was passed</div><div class='line' id='LC7165'>along to the king.  A priest pronounced the words, &quot;They shall</div><div class='line' id='LC7166'>lay their hands on the sick, and they shall recover.&quot;  Then the king</div><div class='line' id='LC7167'>stroked the ulcers, while the reading continued; finally, the</div><div class='line' id='LC7168'>patient graduated and got his nickel--the king hanging it around</div><div class='line' id='LC7169'>his neck himself--and was dismissed.  Would you think that that</div><div class='line' id='LC7170'>would cure?  It certainly did.  Any mummery will cure if the</div><div class='line' id='LC7171'>patient&#39;s faith is strong in it.  Up by Astolat there was a chapel</div><div class='line' id='LC7172'>where the Virgin had once appeared to a girl who used to herd</div><div class='line' id='LC7173'>geese around there--the girl said so herself--and they built the</div><div class='line' id='LC7174'>chapel upon that spot and hung a picture in it representing the</div><div class='line' id='LC7175'>occurrence--a picture which you would think it dangerous for a sick</div><div class='line' id='LC7176'>person to approach; whereas, on the contrary, thousands of the lame</div><div class='line' id='LC7177'>and the sick came and prayed before it every year and went away</div><div class='line' id='LC7178'>whole and sound; and even the well could look upon it and live.</div><div class='line' id='LC7179'>Of course, when I was told these things I did not believe them;</div><div class='line' id='LC7180'>but when I went there and saw them I had to succumb.  I saw the</div><div class='line' id='LC7181'>cures effected myself; and they were real cures and not questionable.</div><div class='line' id='LC7182'>I saw cripples whom I had seen around Camelot for years on crutches,</div><div class='line' id='LC7183'>arrive and pray before that picture, and put down their crutches</div><div class='line' id='LC7184'>and walk off without a limp.  There were piles of crutches there</div><div class='line' id='LC7185'>which had been left by such people as a testimony.</div><div class='line' id='LC7186'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7187'>In other places people operated on a patient&#39;s mind, without saying</div><div class='line' id='LC7188'>a word to him, and cured him.  In others, experts assembled patients</div><div class='line' id='LC7189'>in a room and prayed over them, and appealed to their faith, and</div><div class='line' id='LC7190'>those patients went away cured.  Wherever you find a king who can&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC7191'>cure the king&#39;s-evil you can be sure that the most valuable</div><div class='line' id='LC7192'>superstition that supports his throne--the subject&#39;s belief in</div><div class='line' id='LC7193'>the divine appointment of his sovereign--has passed away.  In my</div><div class='line' id='LC7194'>youth the monarchs of England had ceased to touch for the evil,</div><div class='line' id='LC7195'>but there was no occasion for this diffidence: they could have</div><div class='line' id='LC7196'>cured it forty-nine times in fifty.</div><div class='line' id='LC7197'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC7198'>Well, when the priest had been droning for three hours, and the</div><div class='line' id='LC7199'>good king polishing the evidences, and the sick were still pressing</div><div class='line' id='LC7200'>forward as plenty as ever, I got to feeling intolerably bored.</div><div class='line' id='LC7201'>I was sitting by an open window not far from the canopy of state.</div><div class='line' id='LC7202'>For the five hundredth time a patient stood forward to have his</div><div class='line' id='LC7203'>repulsivenesses stroked; again those words were being droned out:</div><div class='line' id='LC7204'>&quot;they shall lay their hands on the sick&quot;--when outside there rang</div><div class='line' id='LC7205'>clear as a clarion a note that enchanted my soul and tumbled</div><div class='line' id='LC7206'>thirteen worthless centuries about my ears: &quot;Camelot _Weekly</div><div class='line' id='LC7207'>Hosannah and Literary Volcano!_--latest irruption--only two cents</div><div class='line' id='LC7208'>--all about the big miracle in the Valley of Holiness!&quot;  One greater</div><div class='line' id='LC7209'>than kings had arrived--the newsboy.
