It was this:</div><div class='line' id='LC10903'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC10904'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;DE PAR LE ROI.</div><div class='line' id='LC10905'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC10906'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Know that the great lord and illus-</div><div class='line' id='LC10907'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;trious Kni8ht, SIR SAGRAMOR LE</div><div class='line' id='LC10908'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;DESIROUS having condescended to</div><div class='line' id='LC10909'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;meet the King&#39;s Minister, Hank Mor-</div><div class='line' id='LC10910'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;gan, the which is surnamed The Boss,</div><div class='line' id='LC10911'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;for satisfgction of offence anciently given,</div><div class='line' id='LC10912'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;these wilL engage in the lists by</div><div class='line' id='LC10913'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Camelot about the fourth hour of the</div><div class='line' id='LC10914'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;morning of the sixteenth day of this</div><div class='line' id='LC10915'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;next succeeding month. The battle</div><div class='line' id='LC10916'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;will be a l outrance, sith the said offence</div><div class='line' id='LC10917'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;was of a deadly sort, admitting of no</div><div class='line' id='LC10918'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;comPosition.</div><div class='line' id='LC10919'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC10920'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;DE PAR LE ROI</div><div class='line' id='LC10921'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC10922'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC10923'>Clarence&#39;s editorial reference to this affair was to this effect:</div><div class='line' id='LC10924'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC10925'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;It will be observed, by a gl7nce at our</div><div class='line' id='LC10926'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;advertising columns, that the commu-</div><div class='line' id='LC10927'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;nity is to be favored with a treat of un-</div><div class='line' id='LC10928'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;usual interest in the tournament line.</div><div class='line' id='LC10929'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The names of the artists are warrant of</div><div class='line' id='LC10930'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;good enterrainment. The box-office</div><div class='line' id='LC10931'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;will be open at noon of the 13th; ad-</div><div class='line' id='LC10932'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;mission 3 cents, reserved seatsh 5; pro-</div><div class='line' id='LC10933'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ceeds to go to the hospital fund  The</div><div class='line' id='LC10934'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;royal pair and all the Court will be pres-</div><div class='line' id='LC10935'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ent. With these exceptions, and the</div><div class='line' id='LC10936'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;press and the clergy, the free list is strict-</div><div class='line' id='LC10937'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ly susPended. Parties are hereby warn-</div><div class='line' id='LC10938'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ed against buying tickets of speculators;</div><div class='line' id='LC10939'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;they will not be good at the door.</div><div class='line' id='LC10940'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Everybody knows and likes The Boss,</div><div class='line' id='LC10941'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;everybody knows and likes Sir Sag.;</div><div class='line' id='LC10942'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;come, let us give the lads a good send-</div><div class='line' id='LC10943'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;off. ReMember, the proceeds go to a</div><div class='line' id='LC10944'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;great and free charity, and one whose</div><div class='line' id='LC10945'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;broad begevolence stretches out its help-</div><div class='line' id='LC10946'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ing hand, warm with the blood of a lov-</div><div class='line' id='LC10947'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ing heart, to all that suffer, regardless of</div><div class='line' id='LC10948'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;race, creed, condition or color--the</div><div class='line' id='LC10949'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;only charity yet established in the earth</div><div class='line' id='LC10950'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;which has no politico-religious stop-</div><div class='line' id='LC10951'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;cock on its compassion, but says Here</div><div class='line' id='LC10952'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;flows the stream, let ALL come and</div><div class='line' id='LC10953'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;drink! Turn out, all hands! fetch along</div><div class='line' id='LC10954'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;your dou3hnuts and your gum-drops</div><div class='line' id='LC10955'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and have a good time. Pie for sale on</div><div class='line' id='LC10956'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the grounds, and rocks to crack it with;</div><div class='line' id='LC10957'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and ciRcus-lemonade--three drops of</div><div class='line' id='LC10958'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;lime juice to a barrel of water.</div><div class='line' id='LC10959'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC10960'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;N.B. This is the first tournament</div><div class='line' id='LC10961'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;under the new law, whidh allow each</div><div class='line' id='LC10962'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;combatant to use any weapon he may pre-</div><div class='line' id='LC10963'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;fer. You may want to make a note of that.</div><div class='line' id='LC10964'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC10965'>Up to the day set, there was no talk in all Britain of anything</div><div class='line' id='LC10966'>but this combat.  All other topics sank into insignificance and</div><div class='line' id='LC10967'>passed out of men&#39;s thoughts and interest.  It was not because</div><div class='line' id='LC10968'>a tournament was a great matter, it was not because Sir Sagramor</div><div class='line' id='LC10969'>had found the Holy Grail, for he had not, but had failed; it was</div><div class='line' id='LC10970'>not because the second (official) personage in the kingdom was</div><div class='line' id='LC10971'>one of the duellists; no, all these features were commonplace.</div><div class='line' id='LC10972'>Yet there was abundant reason for the extraordinary interest which</div><div class='line' id='LC10973'>this coming fight was creating.  It was born of the fact that all</div><div class='line' id='LC10974'>the nation knew that this was not to be a duel between mere men,</div><div class='line' id='LC10975'>so to speak, but a duel between two mighty magicians; a duel not</div><div class='line' id='LC10976'>of muscle but of mind, not of human skill but of superhuman art</div><div class='line' id='LC10977'>and craft; a final struggle for supremacy between the two master</div><div class='line' id='LC10978'>enchanters of the age.  It was realized that the most prodigious</div><div class='line' id='LC10979'>achievements of the most renowned knights could not be worthy</div><div class='line' id='LC10980'>of comparison with a spectacle like this; they could be but child&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC10981'>play, contrasted with this mysterious and awful battle of the gods.</div><div class='line' id='LC10982'>Yes, all the world knew it was going to be in reality a duel</div><div class='line' id='LC10983'>between Merlin and me, a measuring of his magic powers against</div><div class='line' id='LC10984'>mine.  It was known that Merlin had been busy whole days and nights</div><div class='line' id='LC10985'>together, imbuing Sir Sagramor&#39;s arms and armor with supernal</div><div class='line' id='LC10986'>powers of offense and defense, and that he had procured for him</div><div class='line' id='LC10987'>from the spirits of the air a fleecy veil which would render the</div><div class='line' id='LC10988'>wearer invisible to his antagonist while still visible to other</div><div class='line' id='LC10989'>men.  Against Sir Sagramor, so weaponed and protected, a thousand</div><div class='line' id='LC10990'>knights could accomplish nothing; against him no known enchantments</div><div class='line' id='LC10991'>could prevail.  These facts were sure; regarding them there was</div><div class='line' id='LC10992'>no doubt, no reason for doubt.  There was but one question: might</div><div class='line' id='LC10993'>there be still other enchantments, _unknown_ to Merlin, which could</div><div class='line' id='LC10994'>render Sir Sagramor&#39;s veil transparent to me, and make his enchanted</div><div class='line' id='LC10995'>mail vulnerable to my weapons?  This was the one thing to be</div><div class='line' id='LC10996'>decided in the lists.  Until then the world must remain in suspense.</div><div class='line' id='LC10997'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC10998'>So the world thought there was a vast matter at stake here, and</div><div class='line' id='LC10999'>the world was right, but it was not the one they had in their</div><div class='line' id='LC11000'>minds.  No, a far vaster one was upon the cast of this die:</div><div class='line' id='LC11001'>_the life of knight-errantry_.  I was a champion, it was true, but</div><div class='line' id='LC11002'>not the champion of the frivolous black arts, I was the champion</div><div class='line' id='LC11003'>of hard unsentimental common-sense and reason.  I was entering</div><div class='line' id='LC11004'>the lists to either destroy knight-errantry or be its victim.</div><div class='line' id='LC11005'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11006'>Vast as the show-grounds were, there were no vacant spaces in them</div><div class='line' id='LC11007'>outside of the lists, at ten o&#39;clock on the morning of the 16th.</div><div class='line' id='LC11008'>The mammoth grand-stand was clothed in flags, streamers, and rich</div><div class='line' id='LC11009'>tapestries, and packed with several acres of small-fry tributary</div><div class='line' id='LC11010'>kings, their suites, and the British aristocracy; with our own</div><div class='line' id='LC11011'>royal gang in the chief place, and each and every individual</div><div class='line' id='LC11012'>a flashing prism of gaudy silks and velvets--well, I never saw</div><div class='line' id='LC11013'>anything to begin with it but a fight between an Upper Mississippi</div><div class='line' id='LC11014'>sunset and the aurora borealis.  The huge camp of beflagged and</div><div class='line' id='LC11015'>gay-colored tents at one end of the lists, with a stiff-standing</div><div class='line' id='LC11016'>sentinel at every door and a shining shield hanging by him for</div><div class='line' id='LC11017'>challenge, was another fine sight.  You see, every knight was</div><div class='line' id='LC11018'>there who had any ambition or any caste feeling; for my feeling</div><div class='line' id='LC11019'>toward their order was not much of a secret, and so here was their</div><div class='line' id='LC11020'>chance.  If I won my fight with Sir Sagramor, others would have</div><div class='line' id='LC11021'>the right to call me out as long as I might be willing to respond.</div><div class='line' id='LC11022'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11023'>Down at our end there were but two tents; one for me, and another</div><div class='line' id='LC11024'>for my servants.  At the appointed hour the king made a sign, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11025'>the heralds, in their tabards, appeared and made proclamation,</div><div class='line' id='LC11026'>naming the combatants and stating the cause of quarrel.  There</div><div class='line' id='LC11027'>was a pause, then a ringing bugle-blast, which was the signal for</div><div class='line' id='LC11028'>us to come forth.  All the multitude caught their breath, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11029'>an eager curiosity flashed into every face.</div><div class='line' id='LC11030'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11031'>Out from his tent rode great Sir Sagramor, an imposing tower</div><div class='line' id='LC11032'>of iron, stately and rigid, his huge spear standing upright in its</div><div class='line' id='LC11033'>socket and grasped in his strong hand, his grand horse&#39;s face and</div><div class='line' id='LC11034'>breast cased in steel, his body clothed in rich trappings that</div><div class='line' id='LC11035'>almost dragged the ground--oh, a most noble picture.  A great</div><div class='line' id='LC11036'>shout went up, of welcome and admiration.</div><div class='line' id='LC11037'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11038'>And then out I came.  But I didn&#39;t get any shout.  There was</div><div class='line' id='LC11039'>a wondering and eloquent silence for a moment, then a great wave</div><div class='line' id='LC11040'>of laughter began to sweep along that human sea, but a warning</div><div class='line' id='LC11041'>bugle-blast cut its career short.  I was in the simplest and</div><div class='line' id='LC11042'>comfortablest of gymnast costumes--flesh-colored tights from neck</div><div class='line' id='LC11043'>to heel, with blue silk puffings about my loins, and bareheaded.</div><div class='line' id='LC11044'>My horse was not above medium size, but he was alert, slender-limbed,</div><div class='line' id='LC11045'>muscled with watchsprings, and just a greyhound to go.  He was</div><div class='line' id='LC11046'>a beauty, glossy as silk, and naked as he was when he was born,</div><div class='line' id='LC11047'>except for bridle and ranger-saddle.</div><div class='line' id='LC11048'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11049'>The iron tower and the gorgeous bedquilt came cumbrously but</div><div class='line' id='LC11050'>gracefully pirouetting down the lists, and we tripped lightly up</div><div class='line' id='LC11051'>to meet them.  We halted; the tower saluted, I responded; then</div><div class='line' id='LC11052'>we wheeled and rode side by side to the grand-stand and faced</div><div class='line' id='LC11053'>our king and queen, to whom we made obeisance.  The queen exclaimed:</div><div class='line' id='LC11054'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11055'>&quot;Alack, Sir Boss, wilt fight naked, and without lance or sword or--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11056'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11057'>But the king checked her and made her understand, with a polite</div><div class='line' id='LC11058'>phrase or two, that this was none of her business.  The bugles</div><div class='line' id='LC11059'>rang again; and we separated and rode to the ends of the lists,</div><div class='line' id='LC11060'>and took position.  Now old Merlin stepped into view and cast</div><div class='line' id='LC11061'>a dainty web of gossamer threads over Sir Sagramor which turned</div><div class='line' id='LC11062'>him into Hamlet&#39;s ghost; the king made a sign, the bugles blew,</div><div class='line' id='LC11063'>Sir Sagramor laid his great lance in rest, and the next moment here</div><div class='line' id='LC11064'>he came thundering down the course with his veil flying out behind,</div><div class='line' id='LC11065'>and I went whistling through the air like an arrow to meet him</div><div class='line' id='LC11066'>--cocking my ear the while, as if noting the invisible knight&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC11067'>position and progress by hearing, not sight.  A chorus of encouraging</div><div class='line' id='LC11068'>shouts burst out for him, and one brave voice flung out a heartening</div><div class='line' id='LC11069'>word for me--said:</div><div class='line' id='LC11070'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11071'>&quot;Go it, slim Jim!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11072'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11073'>It was an even bet that Clarence had procured that favor for me</div><div class='line' id='LC11074'>--and furnished the language, too.  When that formidable lance-point</div><div class='line' id='LC11075'>was within a yard and a half of my breast I twitched my horse aside</div><div class='line' id='LC11076'>without an effort, and the big knight swept by, scoring a blank.</div><div class='line' id='LC11077'>I got plenty of applause that time.  We turned, braced up, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11078'>down we came again.  Another blank for the knight, a roar of</div><div class='line' id='LC11079'>applause for me.  This same thing was repeated once more; and</div><div class='line' id='LC11080'>it fetched such a whirlwind of applause that Sir Sagramor lost his</div><div class='line' id='LC11081'>temper, and at once changed his tactics and set himself the task</div><div class='line' id='LC11082'>of chasing me down.  Why, he hadn&#39;t any show in the world at that;</div><div class='line' id='LC11083'>it was a game of tag, with all the advantage on my side; I whirled</div><div class='line' id='LC11084'>out of his path with ease whenever I chose, and once I slapped him</div><div class='line' id='LC11085'>on the back as I went to the rear.  Finally I took the chase into</div><div class='line' id='LC11086'>my own hands; and after that, turn, or twist, or do what he would,</div><div class='line' id='LC11087'>he was never able to get behind me again; he found himself always</div><div class='line' id='LC11088'>in front at the end of his maneuver.  So he gave up that business</div><div class='line' id='LC11089'>and retired to his end of the lists.  His temper was clear gone now,</div><div class='line' id='LC11090'>and he forgot himself and flung an insult at me which disposed</div><div class='line' id='LC11091'>of mine.  I slipped my lasso from the horn of my saddle, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11092'>grasped the coil in my right hand.  This time you should have seen</div><div class='line' id='LC11093'>him come!--it was a business trip, sure; by his gait there was</div><div class='line' id='LC11094'>blood in his eye.  I was sitting my horse at ease, and swinging</div><div class='line' id='LC11095'>the great loop of my lasso in wide circles about my head; the</div><div class='line' id='LC11096'>moment he was under way, I started for him; when the space between</div><div class='line' id='LC11097'>us had narrowed to forty feet, I sent the snaky spirals of the rope</div><div class='line' id='LC11098'>a-cleaving through the air, then darted aside and faced about and</div><div class='line' id='LC11099'>brought my trained animal to a halt with all his feet braced under</div><div class='line' id='LC11100'>him for a surge.  The next moment the rope sprang taut and yanked</div><div class='line' id='LC11101'>Sir Sagramor out of the saddle!  Great Scott, but there was</div><div class='line' id='LC11102'>a sensation!</div><div class='line' id='LC11103'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11104'>Unquestionably, the popular thing in this world is novelty.  These</div><div class='line' id='LC11105'>people had never seen anything of that cowboy business before,</div><div class='line' id='LC11106'>and it carried them clear off their feet with delight.  From all</div><div class='line' id='LC11107'>around and everywhere, the shout went up:</div><div class='line' id='LC11108'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11109'>&quot;Encore! encore!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11110'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11111'>I wondered where they got the word, but there was no time to cipher</div><div class='line' id='LC11112'>on philological matters, because the whole knight-errantry hive</div><div class='line' id='LC11113'>was just humming now, and my prospect for trade couldn&#39;t have</div><div class='line' id='LC11114'>been better.  The moment my lasso was released and Sir Sagramor</div><div class='line' id='LC11115'>had been assisted to his tent, I hauled in the slack, took my</div><div class='line' id='LC11116'>station and began to swing my loop around my head again.  I was</div><div class='line' id='LC11117'>sure to have use for it as soon as they could elect a successor</div><div class='line' id='LC11118'>for Sir Sagramor, and that couldn&#39;t take long where there were</div><div class='line' id='LC11119'>so many hungry candidates.  Indeed, they elected one straight off</div><div class='line' id='LC11120'>--Sir Hervis de Revel.</div><div class='line' id='LC11121'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11122'>_Bzz_!  Here he came, like a house afire; I dodged: he passed like</div><div class='line' id='LC11123'>a flash, with my horse-hair coils settling around his neck;</div><div class='line' id='LC11124'>a second or so later, _fst_! his saddle was empty.</div><div class='line' id='LC11125'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11126'>I got another encore; and another, and another, and still another.</div><div class='line' id='LC11127'>When I had snaked five men out, things began to look serious to</div><div class='line' id='LC11128'>the ironclads, and they stopped and consulted together.  As a</div><div class='line' id='LC11129'>result, they decided that it was time to waive etiquette and send</div><div class='line' id='LC11130'>their greatest and best against me.  To the astonishment of that</div><div class='line' id='LC11131'>little world, I lassoed Sir Lamorak de Galis, and after him</div><div class='line' id='LC11132'>Sir Galahad.  So you see there was simply nothing to be done now,</div><div class='line' id='LC11133'>but play their right bower--bring out the superbest of the superb,</div><div class='line' id='LC11134'>the mightiest of the mighty, the great Sir Launcelot himself!</div><div class='line' id='LC11135'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11136'>A proud moment for me?  I should think so.  Yonder was Arthur,</div><div class='line' id='LC11137'>King of Britain; yonder was Guenever; yes, and whole tribes of</div><div class='line' id='LC11138'>little provincial kings and kinglets; and in the tented camp yonder,</div><div class='line' id='LC11139'>renowned knights from many lands; and likewise the selectest body</div><div class='line' id='LC11140'>known to chivalry, the Knights of the Table Round, the most</div><div class='line' id='LC11141'>illustrious in Christendom; and biggest fact of all, the very sun</div><div class='line' id='LC11142'>of their shining system was yonder couching his lance, the focal</div><div class='line' id='LC11143'>point of forty thousand adoring eyes; and all by myself, here was</div><div class='line' id='LC11144'>I laying for him.  Across my mind flitted the dear image of a</div><div class='line' id='LC11145'>certain hello-girl of West Hartford, and I wished she could see</div><div class='line' id='LC11146'>me now.  In that moment, down came the Invincible, with the rush</div><div class='line' id='LC11147'>of a whirlwind--the courtly world rose to its feet and bent forward</div><div class='line' id='LC11148'>--the fateful coils went circling through the air, and before you</div><div class='line' id='LC11149'>could wink I was towing Sir Launcelot across the field on his</div><div class='line' id='LC11150'>back, and kissing my hand to the storm of waving kerchiefs and</div><div class='line' id='LC11151'>the thunder-crash of applause that greeted me!</div><div class='line' id='LC11152'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11153'>Said I to myself, as I coiled my lariat and hung it on my saddle-horn,</div><div class='line' id='LC11154'>and sat there drunk with glory, &quot;The victory is perfect--no other</div><div class='line' id='LC11155'>will venture against me--knight-errantry is dead.&quot;  Now imagine my</div><div class='line' id='LC11156'>astonishment--and everybody else&#39;s, too--to hear the peculiar</div><div class='line' id='LC11157'>bugle-call which announces that another competitor is about to</div><div class='line' id='LC11158'>enter the lists!  There was a mystery here; I couldn&#39;t account for</div><div class='line' id='LC11159'>this thing.  Next, I noticed Merlin gliding away from me; and then</div><div class='line' id='LC11160'>I noticed that my lasso was gone!  The old sleight-of-hand expert</div><div class='line' id='LC11161'>had stolen it, sure, and slipped it under his robe.</div><div class='line' id='LC11162'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11163'>The bugle blew again.  I looked, and down came Sagramor riding</div><div class='line' id='LC11164'>again, with his dust brushed off and his veil nicely re-arranged.</div><div class='line' id='LC11165'>I trotted up to meet him, and pretended to find him by the sound</div><div class='line' id='LC11166'>of his horse&#39;s hoofs.  He said:</div><div class='line' id='LC11167'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11168'>&quot;Thou&#39;rt quick of ear, but it will not save thee from this!&quot; and</div><div class='line' id='LC11169'>he touched the hilt of his great sword.  &quot;An ye are not able to see</div><div class='line' id='LC11170'>it, because of the influence of the veil, know that it is no cumbrous</div><div class='line' id='LC11171'>lance, but a sword--and I ween ye will not be able to avoid it.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11172'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11173'>His visor was up; there was death in his smile.  I should never</div><div class='line' id='LC11174'>be able to dodge his sword, that was plain.  Somebody was going</div><div class='line' id='LC11175'>to die this time.  If he got the drop on me, I could name the</div><div class='line' id='LC11176'>corpse.  We rode forward together, and saluted the royalties.</div><div class='line' id='LC11177'>This time the king was disturbed.  He said:</div><div class='line' id='LC11178'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11179'>&quot;Where is thy strange weapon?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11180'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11181'>&quot;It is stolen, sire.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11182'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11183'>&quot;Hast another at hand?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11184'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11185'>&quot;No, sire, I brought only the one.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11186'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11187'>Then Merlin mixed in:</div><div class='line' id='LC11188'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11189'>&quot;He brought but the one because there was but the one to bring.</div><div class='line' id='LC11190'>There exists none other but that one.  It belongeth to the king</div><div class='line' id='LC11191'>of the Demons of the Sea.  This man is a pretender, and ignorant,</div><div class='line' id='LC11192'>else he had known that that weapon can be used in but eight bouts</div><div class='line' id='LC11193'>only, and then it vanisheth away to its home under the sea.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11194'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11195'>&quot;Then is he weaponless,&quot; said the king.  &quot;Sir Sagramore, ye will</div><div class='line' id='LC11196'>grant him leave to borrow.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11197'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11198'>&quot;And I will lend!&quot; said Sir Launcelot, limping up.  &quot;He is as</div><div class='line' id='LC11199'>brave a knight of his hands as any that be on live, and he shall</div><div class='line' id='LC11200'>have mine.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11201'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11202'>He put his hand on his sword to draw it, but Sir Sagramor said:</div><div class='line' id='LC11203'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11204'>&quot;Stay, it may not be.  He shall fight with his own weapons; it</div><div class='line' id='LC11205'>was his privilege to choose them and bring them.  If he has erred,</div><div class='line' id='LC11206'>on his head be it.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11207'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11208'>&quot;Knight!&quot; said the king.  &quot;Thou&#39;rt overwrought with passion; it</div><div class='line' id='LC11209'>disorders thy mind.  Wouldst kill a naked man?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11210'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11211'>&quot;An he do it, he shall answer it to me,&quot; said Sir Launcelot.</div><div class='line' id='LC11212'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11213'>&quot;I will answer it to any he that desireth!&quot; retorted Sir Sagramor hotly.</div><div class='line' id='LC11214'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11215'>Merlin broke in, rubbing his hands and smiling his lowdownest</div><div class='line' id='LC11216'>smile of malicious gratification:</div><div class='line' id='LC11217'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11218'>&quot;&#39;Tis well said, right well said!  And &#39;tis enough of parleying,</div><div class='line' id='LC11219'>let my lord the king deliver the battle signal.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11220'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11221'>The king had to yield.  The bugle made proclamation, and we turned</div><div class='line' id='LC11222'>apart and rode to our stations.  There we stood, a hundred yards</div><div class='line' id='LC11223'>apart, facing each other, rigid and motionless, like horsed statues.</div><div class='line' id='LC11224'>And so we remained, in a soundless hush, as much as a full minute,</div><div class='line' id='LC11225'>everybody gazing, nobody stirring.  It seemed as if the king could</div><div class='line' id='LC11226'>not take heart to give the signal.  But at last he lifted his hand,</div><div class='line' id='LC11227'>the clear note of the bugle followed, Sir Sagramor&#39;s long blade</div><div class='line' id='LC11228'>described a flashing curve in the air, and it was superb to see him</div><div class='line' id='LC11229'>come.  I sat still.  On he came.  I did not move.  People got so</div><div class='line' id='LC11230'>excited that they shouted to me:</div><div class='line' id='LC11231'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11232'>&quot;Fly, fly!  Save thyself!  This is murther!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11233'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11234'>I never budged so much as an inch till that thundering apparition</div><div class='line' id='LC11235'>had got within fifteen paces of me; then I snatched a dragoon</div><div class='line' id='LC11236'>revolver out of my holster, there was a flash and a roar, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11237'>the revolver was back in the holster before anybody could tell</div><div class='line' id='LC11238'>what had happened.</div><div class='line' id='LC11239'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11240'>Here was a riderless horse plunging by, and yonder lay Sir Sagramor,</div><div class='line' id='LC11241'>stone dead.</div><div class='line' id='LC11242'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11243'>The people that ran to him were stricken dumb to find that the life</div><div class='line' id='LC11244'>was actually gone out of the man and no reason for it visible,</div><div class='line' id='LC11245'>no hurt upon his body, nothing like a wound.  There was a hole</div><div class='line' id='LC11246'>through the breast of his chain-mail, but they attached no importance</div><div class='line' id='LC11247'>to a little thing like that; and as a bullet wound there produces</div><div class='line' id='LC11248'>but little blood, none came in sight because of the clothing and</div><div class='line' id='LC11249'>swaddlings under the armor.  The body was dragged over to let</div><div class='line' id='LC11250'>the king and the swells look down upon it.  They were stupefied</div><div class='line' id='LC11251'>with astonishment naturally.  I was requested to come and explain</div><div class='line' id='LC11252'>the miracle.  But I remained in my tracks, like a statue, and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC11253'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11254'>&quot;If it is a command, I will come, but my lord the king knows that</div><div class='line' id='LC11255'>I am where the laws of combat require me to remain while any desire</div><div class='line' id='LC11256'>to come against me.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11257'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11258'>I waited.  Nobody challenged.  Then I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC11259'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11260'>&quot;If there are any who doubt that this field is well and fairly won,</div><div class='line' id='LC11261'>I do not wait for them to challenge me, I challenge them.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11262'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11263'>&quot;It is a gallant offer,&quot; said the king, &quot;and well beseems you.</div><div class='line' id='LC11264'>Whom will you name first?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11265'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11266'>&quot;I name none, I challenge all!  Here I stand, and dare the chivalry</div><div class='line' id='LC11267'>of England to come against me--not by individuals, but in mass!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11268'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11269'>&quot;What!&quot; shouted a score of knights.</div><div class='line' id='LC11270'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11271'>&quot;You have heard the challenge.  Take it, or I proclaim you recreant</div><div class='line' id='LC11272'>knights and vanquished, every one!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11273'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11274'>It was a &quot;bluff&quot; you know.  At such a time it is sound judgment</div><div class='line' id='LC11275'>to put on a bold face and play your hand for a hundred times what</div><div class='line' id='LC11276'>it is worth; forty-nine times out of fifty nobody dares to &quot;call,&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11277'>and you rake in the chips.  But just this once--well, things looked</div><div class='line' id='LC11278'>squally!  In just no time, five hundred knights were scrambling</div><div class='line' id='LC11279'>into their saddles, and before you could wink a widely scattering</div><div class='line' id='LC11280'>drove were under way and clattering down upon me.  I snatched</div><div class='line' id='LC11281'>both revolvers from the holsters and began to measure distances</div><div class='line' id='LC11282'>and calculate chances.</div><div class='line' id='LC11283'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11284'>Bang!  One saddle empty.  Bang! another one.  Bang--bang, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11285'>I bagged two.  Well, it was nip and tuck with us, and I knew it.</div><div class='line' id='LC11286'>If I spent the eleventh shot without convincing these people,</div><div class='line' id='LC11287'>the twelfth man would kill me, sure.  And so I never did feel</div><div class='line' id='LC11288'>so happy as I did when my ninth downed its man and I detected</div><div class='line' id='LC11289'>the wavering in the crowd which is premonitory of panic.  An instant</div><div class='line' id='LC11290'>lost now could knock out my last chance.  But I didn&#39;t lose it.</div><div class='line' id='LC11291'>I raised both revolvers and pointed them--the halted host stood</div><div class='line' id='LC11292'>their ground just about one good square moment, then broke and fled.</div><div class='line' id='LC11293'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11294'>The day was mine.  Knight-errantry was a doomed institution.  The</div><div class='line' id='LC11295'>march of civilization was begun.  How did I feel?  Ah, you never</div><div class='line' id='LC11296'>could imagine it.</div><div class='line' id='LC11297'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11298'>And Brer Merlin?  His stock was flat again.  Somehow, every time</div><div class='line' id='LC11299'>the magic of fol-de-rol tried conclusions with the magic of science,</div><div class='line' id='LC11300'>the magic of fol-de-rol got left.</div><div class='line' id='LC11301'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11302'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11303'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11304'>CHAPTER XL</div><div class='line' id='LC11305'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11306'>THREE YEARS LATER</div><div class='line' id='LC11307'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11308'>When I broke the back of knight-errantry that time, I no longer</div><div class='line' id='LC11309'>felt obliged to work in secret.  So, the very next day I exposed</div><div class='line' id='LC11310'>my hidden schools, my mines, and my vast system of clandestine</div><div class='line' id='LC11311'>factories and workshops to an astonished world.  That is to say,</div><div class='line' id='LC11312'>I exposed the nineteenth century to the inspection of the sixth.</div><div class='line' id='LC11313'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11314'>Well, it is always a good plan to follow up an advantage promptly.</div><div class='line' id='LC11315'>The knights were temporarily down, but if I would keep them so</div><div class='line' id='LC11316'>I must just simply paralyze them--nothing short of that would</div><div class='line' id='LC11317'>answer.  You see, I was &quot;bluffing&quot; that last time in the field;</div><div class='line' id='LC11318'>it would be natural for them to work around to that conclusion,</div><div class='line' id='LC11319'>if I gave them a chance.  So I must not give them time; and I didn&#39;t.</div><div class='line' id='LC11320'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11321'>I renewed my challenge, engraved it on brass, posted it up where</div><div class='line' id='LC11322'>any priest could read it to them, and also kept it standing in</div><div class='line' id='LC11323'>the advertising columns of the paper.</div><div class='line' id='LC11324'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11325'>I not only renewed it, but added to its proportions.  I said,</div><div class='line' id='LC11326'>name the day, and I would take fifty assistants and stand up</div><div class='line' id='LC11327'>_against the massed chivalry of the whole earth and destroy it_.</div><div class='line' id='LC11328'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11329'>I was not bluffing this time.  I meant what I said; I could do</div><div class='line' id='LC11330'>what I promised.  There wasn&#39;t any way to misunderstand the language</div><div class='line' id='LC11331'>of that challenge.  Even the dullest of the chivalry perceived</div><div class='line' id='LC11332'>that this was a plain case of &quot;put up, or shut up.&quot;  They were</div><div class='line' id='LC11333'>wise and did the latter.  In all the next three years they gave</div><div class='line' id='LC11334'>me no trouble worth mentioning.</div><div class='line' id='LC11335'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11336'>Consider the three years sped.  Now look around on England.  A happy</div><div class='line' id='LC11337'>and prosperous country, and strangely altered.  Schools everywhere,</div><div class='line' id='LC11338'>and several colleges; a number of pretty good newspapers.  Even</div><div class='line' id='LC11339'>authorship was taking a start; Sir Dinadan the Humorist was first</div><div class='line' id='LC11340'>in the field, with a volume of gray-headed jokes which I had been</div><div class='line' id='LC11341'>familiar with during thirteen centuries.  If he had left out that</div><div class='line' id='LC11342'>old rancid one about the lecturer I wouldn&#39;t have said anything;</div><div class='line' id='LC11343'>but I couldn&#39;t stand that one.  I suppressed the book and hanged</div><div class='line' id='LC11344'>the author.</div><div class='line' id='LC11345'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11346'>Slavery was dead and gone; all men were equal before the law;</div><div class='line' id='LC11347'>taxation had been equalized.  The telegraph, the telephone, the</div><div class='line' id='LC11348'>phonograph, the typewriter, the sewing-machine, and all the thousand</div><div class='line' id='LC11349'>willing and handy servants of steam and electricity were working</div><div class='line' id='LC11350'>their way into favor.  We had a steamboat or two on the Thames,</div><div class='line' id='LC11351'>we had steam warships, and the beginnings of a steam commercial</div><div class='line' id='LC11352'>marine; I was getting ready to send out an expedition to discover</div><div class='line' id='LC11353'>America.</div><div class='line' id='LC11354'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11355'>We were building several lines of railway, and our line from</div><div class='line' id='LC11356'>Camelot to London was already finished and in operation.  I was</div><div class='line' id='LC11357'>shrewd enough to make all offices connected with the passenger</div><div class='line' id='LC11358'>service places of high and distinguished honor.  My idea was</div><div class='line' id='LC11359'>to attract the chivalry and nobility, and make them useful and keep</div><div class='line' id='LC11360'>them out of mischief.  The plan worked very well, the competition</div><div class='line' id='LC11361'>for the places was hot.  The conductor of the 4.33 express was</div><div class='line' id='LC11362'>a duke; there wasn&#39;t a passenger conductor on the line below</div><div class='line' id='LC11363'>the degree of earl.  They were good men, every one, but they had</div><div class='line' id='LC11364'>two defects which I couldn&#39;t cure, and so had to wink at: they</div><div class='line' id='LC11365'>wouldn&#39;t lay aside their armor, and they would &quot;knock down&quot; fare</div><div class='line' id='LC11366'>--I mean rob the company.</div><div class='line' id='LC11367'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11368'>There was hardly a knight in all the land who wasn&#39;t in some useful</div><div class='line' id='LC11369'>employment.  They were going from end to end of the country in all</div><div class='line' id='LC11370'>manner of useful missionary capacities; their penchant for wandering,</div><div class='line' id='LC11371'>and their experience in it, made them altogether the most effective</div><div class='line' id='LC11372'>spreaders of civilization we had.  They went clothed in steel and</div><div class='line' id='LC11373'>equipped with sword and lance and battle-axe, and if they couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC11374'>persuade a person to try a sewing-machine on the installment plan,</div><div class='line' id='LC11375'>or a melodeon, or a barbed-wire fence, or a prohibition journal,</div><div class='line' id='LC11376'>or any of the other thousand and one things they canvassed for,</div><div class='line' id='LC11377'>they removed him and passed on.</div><div class='line' id='LC11378'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11379'>I was very happy.  Things were working steadily toward a secretly</div><div class='line' id='LC11380'>longed-for point.  You see, I had two schemes in my head which</div><div class='line' id='LC11381'>were the vastest of all my projects.  The one was to overthrow the</div><div class='line' id='LC11382'>Catholic Church and set up the Protestant faith on its ruins</div><div class='line' id='LC11383'>--not as an Established Church, but a go-as-you-please one; and</div><div class='line' id='LC11384'>the other project was to get a decree issued by and by, commanding</div><div class='line' id='LC11385'>that upon Arthur&#39;s death unlimited suffrage should be introduced,</div><div class='line' id='LC11386'>and given to men and women alike--at any rate to all men, wise</div><div class='line' id='LC11387'>or unwise, and to all mothers who at middle age should be found</div><div class='line' id='LC11388'>to know nearly as much as their sons at twenty-one.  Arthur was</div><div class='line' id='LC11389'>good for thirty years yet, he being about my own age--that is</div><div class='line' id='LC11390'>to say, forty--and I believed that in that time I could easily</div><div class='line' id='LC11391'>have the active part of the population of that day ready and eager</div><div class='line' id='LC11392'>for an event which should be the first of its kind in the history</div><div class='line' id='LC11393'>of the world--a rounded and complete governmental revolution</div><div class='line' id='LC11394'>without bloodshed.  The result to be a republic.  Well, I may</div><div class='line' id='LC11395'>as well confess, though I do feel ashamed when I think of it:</div><div class='line' id='LC11396'>I was beginning to have a base hankering to be its first president</div><div class='line' id='LC11397'>myself.  Yes, there was more or less human nature in me; I found</div><div class='line' id='LC11398'>that out.</div><div class='line' id='LC11399'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11400'>Clarence was with me as concerned the revolution, but in a modified</div><div class='line' id='LC11401'>way.  His idea was a republic, without privileged orders, but with</div><div class='line' id='LC11402'>a hereditary royal family at the head of it instead of an elective</div><div class='line' id='LC11403'>chief magistrate.  He believed that no nation that had ever known</div><div class='line' id='LC11404'>the joy of worshiping a royal family could ever be robbed of it</div><div class='line' id='LC11405'>and not fade away and die of melancholy.  I urged that kings were</div><div class='line' id='LC11406'>dangerous.  He said, then have cats.  He was sure that a royal</div><div class='line' id='LC11407'>family of cats would answer every purpose.  They would be as useful</div><div class='line' id='LC11408'>as any other royal family, they would know as much, they would</div><div class='line' id='LC11409'>have the same virtues and the same treacheries, the same disposition</div><div class='line' id='LC11410'>to get up shindies with other royal cats, they would be laughably</div><div class='line' id='LC11411'>vain and absurd and never know it, they would be wholly inexpensive;</div><div class='line' id='LC11412'>finally, they would have as sound a divine right as any other</div><div class='line' id='LC11413'>royal house, and &quot;Tom VII, or Tom XI, or Tom XIV by the grace</div><div class='line' id='LC11414'>of God King,&quot; would sound as well as it would when applied to</div><div class='line' id='LC11415'>the ordinary royal tomcat with tights on.  &quot;And as a rule,&quot; said</div><div class='line' id='LC11416'>he, in his neat modern English, &quot;the character of these cats would</div><div class='line' id='LC11417'>be considerably above the character of the average king, and this</div><div class='line' id='LC11418'>would be an immense moral advantage to the nation, for the reason</div><div class='line' id='LC11419'>that a nation always models its morals after its monarch&#39;s.  The</div><div class='line' id='LC11420'>worship of royalty being founded in unreason, these graceful and</div><div class='line' id='LC11421'>harmless cats would easily become as sacred as any other royalties,</div><div class='line' id='LC11422'>and indeed more so, because it would presently be noticed that</div><div class='line' id='LC11423'>they hanged nobody, beheaded nobody, imprisoned nobody, inflicted</div><div class='line' id='LC11424'>no cruelties or injustices of any sort, and so must be worthy of</div><div class='line' id='LC11425'>a deeper love and reverence than the customary human king, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11426'>would certainly get it.  The eyes of the whole harried world would</div><div class='line' id='LC11427'>soon be fixed upon this humane and gentle system, and royal butchers</div><div class='line' id='LC11428'>would presently begin to disappear; their subjects would fill</div><div class='line' id='LC11429'>the vacancies with catlings from our own royal house; we should</div><div class='line' id='LC11430'>become a factory; we should supply the thrones of the world; within</div><div class='line' id='LC11431'>forty years all Europe would be governed by cats, and we should</div><div class='line' id='LC11432'>furnish the cats.  The reign of universal peace would begin then,</div><div class='line' id='LC11433'>to end no more forever....  Me-e-e-yow-ow-ow-ow--fzt!--wow!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11434'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11435'>Hang him, I supposed he was in earnest, and was beginning to be</div><div class='line' id='LC11436'>persuaded by him, until he exploded that cat-howl and startled me</div><div class='line' id='LC11437'>almost out of my clothes.  But he never could be in earnest.  He</div><div class='line' id='LC11438'>didn&#39;t know what it was.  He had pictured a distinct and perfectly</div><div class='line' id='LC11439'>rational and feasible improvement upon constitutional monarchy,</div><div class='line' id='LC11440'>but he was too feather-headed to know it, or care anything about</div><div class='line' id='LC11441'>it, either.  I was going to give him a scolding, but Sandy came</div><div class='line' id='LC11442'>flying in at that moment, wild with terror, and so choked with sobs</div><div class='line' id='LC11443'>that for a minute she could not get her voice.  I ran and took her</div><div class='line' id='LC11444'>in my arms, and lavished caresses upon her and said, beseechingly:</div><div class='line' id='LC11445'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11446'>&quot;Speak, darling, speak!  What is it?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11447'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11448'>Her head fell limp upon my bosom, and she gasped, almost inaudibly:</div><div class='line' id='LC11449'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11450'>&quot;HELLO-CENTRAL!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11451'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11452'>&quot;Quick!&quot; I shouted to Clarence; &quot;telephone the king&#39;s homeopath</div><div class='line' id='LC11453'>to come!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11454'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11455'>In two minutes I was kneeling by the child&#39;s crib, and Sandy was</div><div class='line' id='LC11456'>dispatching servants here, there, and everywhere, all over the</div><div class='line' id='LC11457'>palace.  I took in the situation almost at a glance--membranous</div><div class='line' id='LC11458'>croup!  I bent down and whispered:</div><div class='line' id='LC11459'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11460'>&quot;Wake up, sweetheart!  Hello-Central.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11461'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11462'>She opened her soft eyes languidly, and made out to say:</div><div class='line' id='LC11463'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11464'>&quot;Papa.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11465'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11466'>That was a comfort.  She was far from dead yet.  I sent for</div><div class='line' id='LC11467'>preparations of sulphur, I rousted out the croup-kettle myself;</div><div class='line' id='LC11468'>for I don&#39;t sit down and wait for doctors when Sandy or the child</div><div class='line' id='LC11469'>is sick.  I knew how to nurse both of them, and had had experience.</div><div class='line' id='LC11470'>This little chap had lived in my arms a good part of its small life,</div><div class='line' id='LC11471'>and often I could soothe away its troubles and get it to laugh</div><div class='line' id='LC11472'>through the tear-dews on its eye-lashes when even its mother couldn&#39;t.</div><div class='line' id='LC11473'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11474'>Sir Launcelot, in his richest armor, came striding along the great</div><div class='line' id='LC11475'>hall now on his way to the stock-board; he was president of the</div><div class='line' id='LC11476'>stock-board, and occupied the Siege Perilous, which he had bought</div><div class='line' id='LC11477'>of Sir Galahad; for the stock-board consisted of the Knights of</div><div class='line' id='LC11478'>the Round Table, and they used the Round Table for business purposes</div><div class='line' id='LC11479'>now.  Seats at it were worth--well, you would never believe the</div><div class='line' id='LC11480'>figure, so it is no use to state it.  Sir Launcelot was a bear, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11481'>he had put up a corner in one of the new lines, and was just getting</div><div class='line' id='LC11482'>ready to squeeze the shorts to-day; but what of that?  He was</div><div class='line' id='LC11483'>the same old Launcelot, and when he glanced in as he was passing</div><div class='line' id='LC11484'>the door and found out that his pet was sick, that was enough</div><div class='line' id='LC11485'>for him; bulls and bears might fight it out their own way for all</div><div class='line' id='LC11486'>him, he would come right in here and stand by little Hello-Central</div><div class='line' id='LC11487'>for all he was worth.  And that was what he did.  He shied his</div><div class='line' id='LC11488'>helmet into the corner, and in half a minute he had a new wick</div><div class='line' id='LC11489'>in the alcohol lamp and was firing up on the croup-kettle.  By this</div><div class='line' id='LC11490'>time Sandy had built a blanket canopy over the crib, and everything</div><div class='line' id='LC11491'>was ready.</div><div class='line' id='LC11492'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11493'>Sir Launcelot got up steam, he and I loaded up the kettle with</div><div class='line' id='LC11494'>unslaked lime and carbolic acid, with a touch of lactic acid added</div><div class='line' id='LC11495'>thereto, then filled the thing up with water and inserted the</div><div class='line' id='LC11496'>steam-spout under the canopy.  Everything was ship-shape now,</div><div class='line' id='LC11497'>and we sat down on either side of the crib to stand our watch.</div><div class='line' id='LC11498'>Sandy was so grateful and so comforted that she charged a couple</div><div class='line' id='LC11499'>of church-wardens with willow-bark and sumach-tobacco for us,</div><div class='line' id='LC11500'>and told us to smoke as much as we pleased, it couldn&#39;t get under</div><div class='line' id='LC11501'>the canopy, and she was used to smoke, being the first lady in the</div><div class='line' id='LC11502'>land who had ever seen a cloud blown.  Well, there couldn&#39;t be</div><div class='line' id='LC11503'>a more contented or comfortable sight than Sir Launcelot in his</div><div class='line' id='LC11504'>noble armor sitting in gracious serenity at the end of a yard</div><div class='line' id='LC11505'>of snowy church-warden.  He was a beautiful man, a lovely man,</div><div class='line' id='LC11506'>and was just intended to make a wife and children happy.  But, of</div><div class='line' id='LC11507'>course Guenever--however, it&#39;s no use to cry over what&#39;s done and</div><div class='line' id='LC11508'>can&#39;t be helped.</div><div class='line' id='LC11509'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11510'>Well, he stood watch-and-watch with me, right straight through,</div><div class='line' id='LC11511'>for three days and nights, till the child was out of danger; then</div><div class='line' id='LC11512'>he took her up in his great arms and kissed her, with his plumes</div><div class='line' id='LC11513'>falling about her golden head, then laid her softly in Sandy&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC11514'>lap again and took his stately way down the vast hall, between</div><div class='line' id='LC11515'>the ranks of admiring men-at-arms and menials, and so disappeared.</div><div class='line' id='LC11516'>And no instinct warned me that I should never look upon him again</div><div class='line' id='LC11517'>in this world!  Lord, what a world of heart-break it is.</div><div class='line' id='LC11518'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11519'>The doctors said we must take the child away, if we would coax</div><div class='line' id='LC11520'>her back to health and strength again.  And she must have sea-air.</div><div class='line' id='LC11521'>So we took a man-of-war, and a suite of two hundred and sixty</div><div class='line' id='LC11522'>persons, and went cruising about, and after a fortnight of this we</div><div class='line' id='LC11523'>stepped ashore on the French coast, and the doctors thought it</div><div class='line' id='LC11524'>would be a good idea to make something of a stay there.  The little</div><div class='line' id='LC11525'>king of that region offered us his hospitalities, and we were glad</div><div class='line' id='LC11526'>to accept.  If he had had as many conveniences as he lacked, we</div><div class='line' id='LC11527'>should have been plenty comfortable enough; even as it was, we</div><div class='line' id='LC11528'>made out very well, in his queer old castle, by the help of comforts</div><div class='line' id='LC11529'>and luxuries from the ship.</div><div class='line' id='LC11530'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11531'>At the end of a month I sent the vessel home for fresh supplies,</div><div class='line' id='LC11532'>and for news.  We expected her back in three or four days.  She</div><div class='line' id='LC11533'>would bring me, along with other news, the result of a certain</div><div class='line' id='LC11534'>experiment which I had been starting.  It was a project of mine</div><div class='line' id='LC11535'>to replace the tournament with something which might furnish an</div><div class='line' id='LC11536'>escape for the extra steam of the chivalry, keep those bucks</div><div class='line' id='LC11537'>entertained and out of mischief, and at the same time preserve</div><div class='line' id='LC11538'>the best thing in them, which was their hardy spirit of emulation.</div><div class='line' id='LC11539'>I had had a choice band of them in private training for some time,</div><div class='line' id='LC11540'>and the date was now arriving for their first public effort.</div><div class='line' id='LC11541'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11542'>This experiment was baseball.  In order to give the thing vogue</div><div class='line' id='LC11543'>from the start, and place it out of the reach of criticism, I chose</div><div class='line' id='LC11544'>my nines by rank, not capacity.  There wasn&#39;t a knight in either</div><div class='line' id='LC11545'>team who wasn&#39;t a sceptered sovereign.  As for material of this</div><div class='line' id='LC11546'>sort, there was a glut of it always around Arthur.  You couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC11547'>throw a brick in any direction and not cripple a king.  Of course,</div><div class='line' id='LC11548'>I couldn&#39;t get these people to leave off their armor; they wouldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC11549'>do that when they bathed.  They consented to differentiate the</div><div class='line' id='LC11550'>armor so that a body could tell one team from the other, but that</div><div class='line' id='LC11551'>was the most they would do.  So, one of the teams wore chain-mail</div><div class='line' id='LC11552'>ulsters, and the other wore plate-armor made of my new Bessemer</div><div class='line' id='LC11553'>steel.  Their practice in the field was the most fantastic thing I</div><div class='line' id='LC11554'>ever saw.  Being ball-proof, they never skipped out of the way,</div><div class='line' id='LC11555'>but stood still and took the result; when a Bessemer was at the bat</div><div class='line' id='LC11556'>and a ball hit him, it would bound a hundred and fifty yards</div><div class='line' id='LC11557'>sometimes.  And when a man was running, and threw himself on his</div><div class='line' id='LC11558'>stomach to slide to his base, it was like an iron-clad coming into</div><div class='line' id='LC11559'>port.  At first I appointed men of no rank to act as umpires, but</div><div class='line' id='LC11560'>I had to discontinue that.  These people were no easier to please</div><div class='line' id='LC11561'>than other nines.  The umpire&#39;s first decision was usually his</div><div class='line' id='LC11562'>last; they broke him in two with a bat, and his friends toted him</div><div class='line' id='LC11563'>home on a shutter.  When it was noticed that no umpire ever survived</div><div class='line' id='LC11564'>a game, umpiring got to be unpopular.  So I was obliged to appoint</div><div class='line' id='LC11565'>somebody whose rank and lofty position under the government would</div><div class='line' id='LC11566'>protect him.</div><div class='line' id='LC11567'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11568'>Here are the names of the nines:</div><div class='line' id='LC11569'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11570'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BESSEMERS                   ULSTERS</div><div class='line' id='LC11571'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11572'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;KING ARTHUR.                EMPEROR LUCIUS.</div><div class='line' id='LC11573'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;KING LOT OF LOTHIAN.        KING LOGRIS.</div><div class='line' id='LC11574'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;KING OF NORTHGALIS.         KING MARHALT OF IRELAND.</div><div class='line' id='LC11575'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;KING MARSIL.                KING MORGANORE.</div><div class='line' id='LC11576'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;KING OF LITTLE BRITAIN.     KING MARK OF CORNWALL.</div><div class='line' id='LC11577'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;KING LABOR.                 KING NENTRES OF GARLOT.</div><div class='line' id='LC11578'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;KING PELLAM OF LISTENGESE.  KING MELIODAS OF LIONES.</div><div class='line' id='LC11579'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;KING BAGDEMAGUS.            KING OF THE LAKE.</div><div class='line' id='LC11580'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;KING TOLLEME LA FEINTES.    THE SOWDAN OF SYRIA.</div><div class='line' id='LC11581'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11582'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Umpire--CLARENCE.</div><div class='line' id='LC11583'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11584'>The first public game would certainly draw fifty thousand people;</div><div class='line' id='LC11585'>and for solid fun would be worth going around the world to see.</div><div class='line' id='LC11586'>Everything would be favorable; it was balmy and beautiful spring</div><div class='line' id='LC11587'>weather now, and Nature was all tailored out in her new clothes.</div><div class='line' id='LC11588'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11589'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11590'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11591'>CHAPTER XLI</div><div class='line' id='LC11592'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11593'>THE INTERDICT</div><div class='line' id='LC11594'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11595'>However, my attention was suddenly snatched from such matters;</div><div class='line' id='LC11596'>our child began to lose ground again, and we had to go to sitting</div><div class='line' id='LC11597'>up with her, her case became so serious.  We couldn&#39;t bear to allow</div><div class='line' id='LC11598'>anybody to help in this service, so we two stood watch-and-watch,</div><div class='line' id='LC11599'>day in and day out.  Ah, Sandy, what a right heart she had, how</div><div class='line' id='LC11600'>simple, and genuine, and good she was!  She was a flawless wife</div><div class='line' id='LC11601'>and mother; and yet I had married her for no other particular</div><div class='line' id='LC11602'>reasons, except that by the customs of chivalry she was my property</div><div class='line' id='LC11603'>until some knight should win her from me in the field.  She had</div><div class='line' id='LC11604'>hunted Britain over for me; had found me at the hanging-bout</div><div class='line' id='LC11605'>outside of London, and had straightway resumed her old place at</div><div class='line' id='LC11606'>my side in the placidest way and as of right.  I was a New Englander,</div><div class='line' id='LC11607'>and in my opinion this sort of partnership would compromise her,</div><div class='line' id='LC11608'>sooner or later.  She couldn&#39;t see how, but I cut argument short</div><div class='line' id='LC11609'>and we had a wedding.</div><div class='line' id='LC11610'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11611'>Now I didn&#39;t know I was drawing a prize, yet that was what I did</div><div class='line' id='LC11612'>draw.  Within the twelvemonth I became her worshiper; and ours</div><div class='line' id='LC11613'>was the dearest and perfectest comradeship that ever was.  People</div><div class='line' id='LC11614'>talk about beautiful friendships between two persons of the same</div><div class='line' id='LC11615'>sex.  What is the best of that sort, as compared with the friendship</div><div class='line' id='LC11616'>of man and wife, where the best impulses and highest ideals of</div><div class='line' id='LC11617'>both are the same?  There is no place for comparison between</div><div class='line' id='LC11618'>the two friendships; the one is earthly, the other divine.</div><div class='line' id='LC11619'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11620'>In my dreams, along at first, I still wandered thirteen centuries</div><div class='line' id='LC11621'>away, and my unsatisfied spirit went calling and harking all up</div><div class='line' id='LC11622'>and down the unreplying vacancies of a vanished world.  Many a</div><div class='line' id='LC11623'>time Sandy heard that imploring cry come from my lips in my sleep.</div><div class='line' id='LC11624'>With a grand magnanimity she saddled that cry of mine upon our</div><div class='line' id='LC11625'>child, conceiving it to be the name of some lost darling of mine.</div><div class='line' id='LC11626'>It touched me to tears, and it also nearly knocked me off my feet,</div><div class='line' id='LC11627'>too, when she smiled up in my face for an earned reward, and played</div><div class='line' id='LC11628'>her quaint and pretty surprise upon me:</div><div class='line' id='LC11629'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11630'>&quot;The name of one who was dear to thee is here preserved, here made</div><div class='line' id='LC11631'>holy, and the music of it will abide alway in our ears.  Now</div><div class='line' id='LC11632'>thou&#39;lt kiss me, as knowing the name I have given the child.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11633'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11634'>But I didn&#39;t know it, all the same.  I hadn&#39;t an idea in the</div><div class='line' id='LC11635'>world; but it would have been cruel to confess it and spoil her</div><div class='line' id='LC11636'>pretty game; so I never let on, but said:</div><div class='line' id='LC11637'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11638'>&quot;Yes, I know, sweetheart--how dear and good it is of you, too!</div><div class='line' id='LC11639'>But I want to hear these lips of yours, which are also mine, utter</div><div class='line' id='LC11640'>it first--then its music will be perfect.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11641'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11642'>Pleased to the marrow, she murmured:</div><div class='line' id='LC11643'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11644'>&quot;HELLO-CENTRAL!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11645'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11646'>I didn&#39;t laugh--I am always thankful for that--but the strain</div><div class='line' id='LC11647'>ruptured every cartilage in me, and for weeks afterward I could</div><div class='line' id='LC11648'>hear my bones clack when I walked.  She never found out her mistake.</div><div class='line' id='LC11649'>The first time she heard that form of salute used at the telephone</div><div class='line' id='LC11650'>she was surprised, and not pleased; but I told her I had given</div><div class='line' id='LC11651'>order for it: that henceforth and forever the telephone must</div><div class='line' id='LC11652'>always be invoked with that reverent formality, in perpetual honor</div><div class='line' id='LC11653'>and remembrance of my lost friend and her small namesake.  This</div><div class='line' id='LC11654'>was not true.  But it answered.</div><div class='line' id='LC11655'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11656'>Well, during two weeks and a half we watched by the crib, and in</div><div class='line' id='LC11657'>our deep solicitude we were unconscious of any world outside of</div><div class='line' id='LC11658'>that sick-room.  Then our reward came: the center of the universe</div><div class='line' id='LC11659'>turned the corner and began to mend.  Grateful?  It isn&#39;t the term.</div><div class='line' id='LC11660'>There _isn&#39;t_ any term for it.  You know that yourself, if you&#39;ve</div><div class='line' id='LC11661'>watched your child through the Valley of the Shadow and seen it</div><div class='line' id='LC11662'>come back to life and sweep night out of the earth with one</div><div class='line' id='LC11663'>all-illuminating smile that you could cover with your hand.</div><div class='line' id='LC11664'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11665'>Why, we were back in this world in one instant!  Then we looked</div><div class='line' id='LC11666'>the same startled thought into each other&#39;s eyes at the same</div><div class='line' id='LC11667'>moment; more than two weeks gone, and that ship not back yet!</div><div class='line' id='LC11668'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11669'>In another minute I appeared in the presence of my train.  They</div><div class='line' id='LC11670'>had been steeped in troubled bodings all this time--their faces</div><div class='line' id='LC11671'>showed it.  I called an escort and we galloped five miles to a</div><div class='line' id='LC11672'>hilltop overlooking the sea.  Where was my great commerce that</div><div class='line' id='LC11673'>so lately had made these glistening expanses populous and beautiful</div><div class='line' id='LC11674'>with its white-winged flocks?  Vanished, every one!  Not a sail,</div><div class='line' id='LC11675'>from verge to verge, not a smoke-bank--just a dead and empty</div><div class='line' id='LC11676'>solitude, in place of all that brisk and breezy life.</div><div class='line' id='LC11677'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11678'>I went swiftly back, saying not a word to anybody.  I told Sandy</div><div class='line' id='LC11679'>this ghastly news.  We could imagine no explanation that would</div><div class='line' id='LC11680'>begin to explain.  Had there been an invasion? an earthquake?</div><div class='line' id='LC11681'>a pestilence?  Had the nation been swept out of existence?  But</div><div class='line' id='LC11682'>guessing was profitless.  I must go--at once.  I borrowed the king&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC11683'>navy--a &quot;ship&quot; no bigger than a steam launch--and was soon ready.</div><div class='line' id='LC11684'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11685'>The parting--ah, yes, that was hard.  As I was devouring the child</div><div class='line' id='LC11686'>with last kisses, it brisked up and jabbered out its vocabulary!</div><div class='line' id='LC11687'>--the first time in more than two weeks, and it made fools of us</div><div class='line' id='LC11688'>for joy.  The darling mispronunciations of childhood!--dear me,</div><div class='line' id='LC11689'>there&#39;s no music that can touch it; and how one grieves when it</div><div class='line' id='LC11690'>wastes away and dissolves into correctness, knowing it will never</div><div class='line' id='LC11691'>visit his bereaved ear again.  Well, how good it was to be able</div><div class='line' id='LC11692'>to carry that gracious memory away with me!</div><div class='line' id='LC11693'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11694'>I approached England the next morning, with the wide highway of</div><div class='line' id='LC11695'>salt water all to myself.  There were ships in the harbor, at</div><div class='line' id='LC11696'>Dover, but they were naked as to sails, and there was no sign</div><div class='line' id='LC11697'>of life about them.  It was Sunday; yet at Canterbury the streets</div><div class='line' id='LC11698'>were empty; strangest of all, there was not even a priest in sight,</div><div class='line' id='LC11699'>and no stroke of a bell fell upon my ear.  The mournfulness of</div><div class='line' id='LC11700'>death was everywhere.  I couldn&#39;t understand it.  At last, in</div><div class='line' id='LC11701'>the further edge of that town I saw a small funeral procession</div><div class='line' id='LC11702'>--just a family and a few friends following a coffin--no priest;</div><div class='line' id='LC11703'>a funeral without bell, book, or candle; there was a church there</div><div class='line' id='LC11704'>close at hand, but they passed it by weeping, and did not enter it;</div><div class='line' id='LC11705'>I glanced up at the belfry, and there hung the bell, shrouded in</div><div class='line' id='LC11706'>black, and its tongue tied back.  Now I knew!  Now I understood</div><div class='line' id='LC11707'>the stupendous calamity that had overtaken England.  Invasion?</div><div class='line' id='LC11708'>Invasion is a triviality to it.  It was the INTERDICT!</div><div class='line' id='LC11709'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11710'>I asked no questions; I didn&#39;t need to ask any.  The Church had</div><div class='line' id='LC11711'>struck; the thing for me to do was to get into a disguise, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11712'>go warily.  One of my servants gave me a suit of clothes, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11713'>when we were safe beyond the town I put them on, and from that time</div><div class='line' id='LC11714'>I traveled alone; I could not risk the embarrassment of company.</div><div class='line' id='LC11715'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11716'>A miserable journey.  A desolate silence everywhere.  Even in</div><div class='line' id='LC11717'>London itself.  Traffic had ceased; men did not talk or laugh, or</div><div class='line' id='LC11718'>go in groups, or even in couples; they moved aimlessly about, each</div><div class='line' id='LC11719'>man by himself, with his head down, and woe and terror at his heart.</div><div class='line' id='LC11720'>The Tower showed recent war-scars.  Verily, much had been happening.</div><div class='line' id='LC11721'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11722'>Of course, I meant to take the train for Camelot.  Train!  Why,</div><div class='line' id='LC11723'>the station was as vacant as a cavern.  I moved on.  The journey</div><div class='line' id='LC11724'>to Camelot was a repetition of what I had already seen.  The Monday</div><div class='line' id='LC11725'>and the Tuesday differed in no way from the Sunday.  I arrived</div><div class='line' id='LC11726'>far in the night.  From being the best electric-lighted town in</div><div class='line' id='LC11727'>the kingdom and the most like a recumbent sun of anything you ever</div><div class='line' id='LC11728'>saw, it was become simply a blot--a blot upon darkness--that is</div><div class='line' id='LC11729'>to say, it was darker and solider than the rest of the darkness,</div><div class='line' id='LC11730'>and so you could see it a little better; it made me feel as if</div><div class='line' id='LC11731'>maybe it was symbolical--a sort of sign that the Church was going to</div><div class='line' id='LC11732'>_keep_ the upper hand now, and snuff out all my beautiful civilization</div><div class='line' id='LC11733'>just like that.  I found no life stirring in the somber streets.</div><div class='line' id='LC11734'>I groped my way with a heavy heart.  The vast castle loomed black</div><div class='line' id='LC11735'>upon the hilltop, not a spark visible about it.  The drawbridge</div><div class='line' id='LC11736'>was down, the great gate stood wide, I entered without challenge,</div><div class='line' id='LC11737'>my own heels making the only sound I heard--and it was sepulchral</div><div class='line' id='LC11738'>enough, in those huge vacant courts.</div><div class='line' id='LC11739'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11740'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11741'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11742'>CHAPTER XLII</div><div class='line' id='LC11743'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11744'>WAR!</div><div class='line' id='LC11745'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11746'>I found Clarence alone in his quarters, drowned in melancholy;</div><div class='line' id='LC11747'>and in place of the electric light, he had reinstituted the ancient</div><div class='line' id='LC11748'>rag-lamp, and sat there in a grisly twilight with all curtains</div><div class='line' id='LC11749'>drawn tight.  He sprang up and rushed for me eagerly, saying:</div><div class='line' id='LC11750'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11751'>&quot;Oh, it&#39;s worth a billion milrays to look upon a live person again!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11752'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11753'>He knew me as easily as if I hadn&#39;t been disguised at all.  Which</div><div class='line' id='LC11754'>frightened me; one may easily believe that.</div><div class='line' id='LC11755'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11756'>&quot;Quick, now, tell me the meaning of this fearful disaster,&quot; I said.</div><div class='line' id='LC11757'>&quot;How did it come about?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11758'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11759'>&quot;Well, if there hadn&#39;t been any Queen Guenever, it wouldn&#39;t have</div><div class='line' id='LC11760'>come so early; but it would have come, anyway.  It would have</div><div class='line' id='LC11761'>come on your own account by and by; by luck, it happened to come</div><div class='line' id='LC11762'>on the queen&#39;s.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11763'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11764'>&quot;_And_ Sir Launcelot&#39;s?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11765'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11766'>&quot;Just so.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11767'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11768'>&quot;Give me the details.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11769'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11770'>&quot;I reckon you will grant that during some years there has been</div><div class='line' id='LC11771'>only one pair of eyes in these kingdoms that has not been looking</div><div class='line' id='LC11772'>steadily askance at the queen and Sir Launcelot--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11773'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11774'>&quot;Yes, King Arthur&#39;s.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11775'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11776'>&quot;--and only one heart that was without suspicion--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11777'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11778'>&quot;Yes--the king&#39;s; a heart that isn&#39;t capable of thinking evil</div><div class='line' id='LC11779'>of a friend.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11780'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11781'>&quot;Well, the king might have gone on, still happy and unsuspecting,</div><div class='line' id='LC11782'>to the end of his days, but for one of your modern improvements</div><div class='line' id='LC11783'>--the stock-board.  When you left, three miles of the London,</div><div class='line' id='LC11784'>Canterbury and Dover were ready for the rails, and also ready and</div><div class='line' id='LC11785'>ripe for manipulation in the stock-market.  It was wildcat, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11786'>everybody knew it.  The stock was for sale at a give-away.  What</div><div class='line' id='LC11787'>does Sir Launcelot do, but--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11788'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11789'>&quot;Yes, I know; he quietly picked up nearly all of it for a song;</div><div class='line' id='LC11790'>then he bought about twice as much more, deliverable upon call;</div><div class='line' id='LC11791'>and he was about to call when I left.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11792'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11793'>&quot;Very well, he did call.  The boys couldn&#39;t deliver.  Oh, he had</div><div class='line' id='LC11794'>them--and he just settled his grip and squeezed them.  They were</div><div class='line' id='LC11795'>laughing in their sleeves over their smartness in selling stock</div><div class='line' id='LC11796'>to him at 15 and 16 and along there that wasn&#39;t worth 10.
