Well,</div><div class='line' id='LC11797'>when they had laughed long enough on that side of their mouths,</div><div class='line' id='LC11798'>they rested-up that side by shifting the laugh to the other side.</div><div class='line' id='LC11799'>That was when they compromised with the Invincible at 283!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11800'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11801'>&quot;Good land!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11802'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11803'>&quot;He skinned them alive, and they deserved it--anyway, the whole</div><div class='line' id='LC11804'>kingdom rejoiced.  Well, among the flayed were Sir Agravaine and</div><div class='line' id='LC11805'>Sir Mordred, nephews to the king.  End of the first act.  Act</div><div class='line' id='LC11806'>second, scene first, an apartment in Carlisle castle, where the</div><div class='line' id='LC11807'>court had gone for a few days&#39; hunting.  Persons present, the</div><div class='line' id='LC11808'>whole tribe of the king&#39;s nephews.  Mordred and Agravaine propose</div><div class='line' id='LC11809'>to call the guileless Arthur&#39;s attention to Guenever and Sir</div><div class='line' id='LC11810'>Launcelot.  Sir Gawaine, Sir Gareth, and Sir Gaheris will have</div><div class='line' id='LC11811'>nothing to do with it.  A dispute ensues, with loud talk; in the</div><div class='line' id='LC11812'>midst of it enter the king.  Mordred and Agravaine spring their</div><div class='line' id='LC11813'>devastating tale upon him.  _Tableau_.  A trap is laid for Launcelot,</div><div class='line' id='LC11814'>by the king&#39;s command, and Sir Launcelot walks into it.  He made</div><div class='line' id='LC11815'>it sufficiently uncomfortable for the ambushed witnesses--to wit,</div><div class='line' id='LC11816'>Mordred, Agravaine, and twelve knights of lesser rank, for he</div><div class='line' id='LC11817'>killed every one of them but Mordred; but of course that couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC11818'>straighten matters between Launcelot and the king, and didn&#39;t.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11819'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11820'>&quot;Oh, dear, only one thing could result--I see that.  War, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11821'>the knights of the realm divided into a king&#39;s party and a</div><div class='line' id='LC11822'>Sir Launcelot&#39;s party.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11823'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11824'>&quot;Yes--that was the way of it.  The king sent the queen to the</div><div class='line' id='LC11825'>stake, proposing to purify her with fire.  Launcelot and his</div><div class='line' id='LC11826'>knights rescued her, and in doing it slew certain good old friends</div><div class='line' id='LC11827'>of yours and mine--in fact, some of the best we ever had; to wit,</div><div class='line' id='LC11828'>Sir Belias le Orgulous, Sir Segwarides, Sir Griflet le Fils de Dieu,</div><div class='line' id='LC11829'>Sir Brandiles, Sir Aglovale--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11830'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11831'>&quot;Oh, you tear out my heartstrings.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11832'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11833'>&quot;--wait, I&#39;m not done yet--Sir Tor, Sir Gauter, Sir Gillimer--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11834'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11835'>&quot;The very best man in my subordinate nine.  What a handy right-fielder</div><div class='line' id='LC11836'>he was!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11837'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11838'>&quot;--Sir Reynold&#39;s three brothers, Sir Damus, Sir Priamus, Sir Kay</div><div class='line' id='LC11839'>the Stranger--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11840'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11841'>&quot;My peerless short-stop!  I&#39;ve seen him catch a daisy-cutter in</div><div class='line' id='LC11842'>his teeth.  Come, I can&#39;t stand this!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11843'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11844'>&quot;--Sir Driant, Sir Lambegus, Sir Herminde, Sir Pertilope,</div><div class='line' id='LC11845'>Sir Perimones, and--whom do you think?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11846'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11847'>&quot;Rush!  Go on.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11848'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11849'>&quot;Sir Gaheris, and Sir Gareth--both!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11850'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11851'>&quot;Oh, incredible!  Their love for Launcelot was indestructible.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11852'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11853'>&quot;Well, it was an accident.  They were simply onlookers; they were</div><div class='line' id='LC11854'>unarmed, and were merely there to witness the queen&#39;s punishment.</div><div class='line' id='LC11855'>Sir Launcelot smote down whoever came in the way of his blind fury,</div><div class='line' id='LC11856'>and he killed these without noticing who they were.  Here is an</div><div class='line' id='LC11857'>instantaneous photograph one of our boys got of the battle; it&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC11858'>for sale on every news-stand.  There--the figures nearest the queen</div><div class='line' id='LC11859'>are Sir Launcelot with his sword up, and Sir Gareth gasping his</div><div class='line' id='LC11860'>latest breath.  You can catch the agony in the queen&#39;s face through</div><div class='line' id='LC11861'>the curling smoke.  It&#39;s a rattling battle-picture.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11862'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11863'>&quot;Indeed, it is.  We must take good care of it; its historical value</div><div class='line' id='LC11864'>is incalculable.  Go on.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11865'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11866'>&quot;Well, the rest of the tale is just war, pure and simple.  Launcelot</div><div class='line' id='LC11867'>retreated to his town and castle of Joyous Gard, and gathered</div><div class='line' id='LC11868'>there a great following of knights.  The king, with a great host,</div><div class='line' id='LC11869'>went there, and there was desperate fighting during several days,</div><div class='line' id='LC11870'>and, as a result, all the plain around was paved with corpses</div><div class='line' id='LC11871'>and cast-iron.  Then the Church patched up a peace between Arthur</div><div class='line' id='LC11872'>and Launcelot and the queen and everybody--everybody but Sir Gawaine.</div><div class='line' id='LC11873'>He was bitter about the slaying of his brothers, Gareth and Gaheris,</div><div class='line' id='LC11874'>and would not be appeased.  He notified Launcelot to get him</div><div class='line' id='LC11875'>thence, and make swift preparation, and look to be soon attacked.</div><div class='line' id='LC11876'>So Launcelot sailed to his Duchy of Guienne with his following, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11877'>Gawaine soon followed with an army, and he beguiled Arthur to go</div><div class='line' id='LC11878'>with him.  Arthur left the kingdom in Sir Mordred&#39;s hands until</div><div class='line' id='LC11879'>you should return--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11880'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11881'>&quot;Ah--a king&#39;s customary wisdom!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11882'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11883'>&quot;Yes.  Sir Mordred set himself at once to work to make his kingship</div><div class='line' id='LC11884'>permanent.  He was going to marry Guenever, as a first move; but</div><div class='line' id='LC11885'>she fled and shut herself up in the Tower of London.  Mordred</div><div class='line' id='LC11886'>attacked; the Bishop of Canterbury dropped down on him with the</div><div class='line' id='LC11887'>Interdict.  The king returned; Mordred fought him at Dover, at</div><div class='line' id='LC11888'>Canterbury, and again at Barham Down.  Then there was talk of peace</div><div class='line' id='LC11889'>and a composition.  Terms, Mordred to have Cornwall and Kent during</div><div class='line' id='LC11890'>Arthur&#39;s life, and the whole kingdom afterward.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11891'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11892'>&quot;Well, upon my word!  My dream of a republic to _be_ a dream, and</div><div class='line' id='LC11893'>so remain.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11894'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11895'>&quot;Yes.  The two armies lay near Salisbury.  Gawaine--Gawaine&#39;s head</div><div class='line' id='LC11896'>is at Dover Castle, he fell in the fight there--Gawaine appeared to</div><div class='line' id='LC11897'>Arthur in a dream, at least his ghost did, and warned him to</div><div class='line' id='LC11898'>refrain from conflict for a month, let the delay cost what it might.</div><div class='line' id='LC11899'>But battle was precipitated by an accident.  Arthur had given</div><div class='line' id='LC11900'>order that if a sword was raised during the consultation over</div><div class='line' id='LC11901'>the proposed treaty with Mordred, sound the trumpet and fall on!</div><div class='line' id='LC11902'>for he had no confidence in Mordred.  Mordred had given a similar</div><div class='line' id='LC11903'>order to _his_ people.  Well, by and by an adder bit a knight&#39;s heel;</div><div class='line' id='LC11904'>the knight forgot all about the order, and made a slash at the</div><div class='line' id='LC11905'>adder with his sword.  Inside of half a minute those two prodigious</div><div class='line' id='LC11906'>hosts came together with a crash!  They butchered away all day.</div><div class='line' id='LC11907'>Then the king--however, we have started something fresh since</div><div class='line' id='LC11908'>you left--our paper has.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11909'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11910'>&quot;No?  What is that?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11911'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11912'>&quot;War correspondence!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11913'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11914'>&quot;Why, that&#39;s good.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11915'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11916'>&quot;Yes, the paper was booming right along, for the Interdict made</div><div class='line' id='LC11917'>no impression, got no grip, while the war lasted.  I had war</div><div class='line' id='LC11918'>correspondents with both armies.  I will finish that battle by</div><div class='line' id='LC11919'>reading you what one of the boys says:</div><div class='line' id='LC11920'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11921'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&#39;Then the king looked about him, and then was he</div><div class='line' id='LC11922'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ware of all his host and of all his good knights</div><div class='line' id='LC11923'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;were left no more on live but two knights, that</div><div class='line' id='LC11924'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;was Sir Lucan de Butlere, and his brother Sir</div><div class='line' id='LC11925'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Bedivere: and they were full sore wounded.  Jesu</div><div class='line' id='LC11926'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;mercy, said the king, where are all my noble</div><div class='line' id='LC11927'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;knights becomen?  Alas that ever I should see this</div><div class='line' id='LC11928'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;doleful day.  For now, said Arthur, I am come to</div><div class='line' id='LC11929'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;mine end.  But would to God that I wist where were</div><div class='line' id='LC11930'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;that traitor Sir Mordred, that hath caused all</div><div class='line' id='LC11931'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;this mischief.  Then was King Arthur ware where Sir</div><div class='line' id='LC11932'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mordred leaned upon his sword among a great heap</div><div class='line' id='LC11933'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;of dead men.  Now give me my spear, said Arthur</div><div class='line' id='LC11934'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;unto Sir Lucan, for yonder I have espied the</div><div class='line' id='LC11935'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;traitor that all this woe hath wrought.  Sir, let</div><div class='line' id='LC11936'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;him be, said Sir Lucan, for he is unhappy; and if</div><div class='line' id='LC11937'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ye pass this unhappy day, ye shall be right well</div><div class='line' id='LC11938'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;revenged upon him.  Good lord, remember ye of your</div><div class='line' id='LC11939'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;night&#39;s dream, and what the spirit of Sir Gawaine</div><div class='line' id='LC11940'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;told you this night, yet God of his great goodness</div><div class='line' id='LC11941'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;hath preserved you hitherto.  Therefore, for God&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC11942'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;sake, my lord, leave off by this. For blessed be</div><div class='line' id='LC11943'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;God ye have won the field: for here we be three</div><div class='line' id='LC11944'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;on live, and with Sir Mordred is none on live.</div><div class='line' id='LC11945'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;And if ye leave off now, this wicked day of</div><div class='line' id='LC11946'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;destiny is past.  Tide me death, betide me life,</div><div class='line' id='LC11947'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;saith the king, now I see him yonder alone, he</div><div class='line' id='LC11948'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;shall never escape mine hands, for at a better</div><div class='line' id='LC11949'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;avail shall I never have him.  God speed you well,</div><div class='line' id='LC11950'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;said Sir Bedivere.  Then the king gat his spear</div><div class='line' id='LC11951'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;in both his hands, and ran toward Sir Mordred</div><div class='line' id='LC11952'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;crying, Traitor, now is thy death day come.  And</div><div class='line' id='LC11953'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;when Sir Mordred heard Sir Arthur, he ran until</div><div class='line' id='LC11954'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;him with his sword drawn in his hand.  And then</div><div class='line' id='LC11955'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;King Arthur smote Sir Mordred under the shield,</div><div class='line' id='LC11956'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;with a foin of his spear throughout the body more</div><div class='line' id='LC11957'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;than a fathom.  And when Sir Mordred felt that he</div><div class='line' id='LC11958'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;had his death&#39;s wound, he thrust himself, with</div><div class='line' id='LC11959'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the might that he had, up to the butt of King</div><div class='line' id='LC11960'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Arthur&#39;s spear.  And right so he smote his father</div><div class='line' id='LC11961'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Arthur with his sword holden in both his hands,</div><div class='line' id='LC11962'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;on the side of the head, that the sword pierced</div><div class='line' id='LC11963'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the helmet and the brain-pan, and therewithal</div><div class='line' id='LC11964'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sir Mordred fell stark dead to the earth.  And</div><div class='line' id='LC11965'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the noble Arthur fell in a swoon to the earth,</div><div class='line' id='LC11966'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and there he swooned oft-times--&#39;&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11967'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11968'>&quot;That is a good piece of war correspondence, Clarence; you are</div><div class='line' id='LC11969'>a first-rate newspaper man.  Well--is the king all right?  Did</div><div class='line' id='LC11970'>he get well?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11971'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11972'>&quot;Poor soul, no.  He is dead.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11973'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11974'>I was utterly stunned; it had not seemed to me that any wound</div><div class='line' id='LC11975'>could be mortal to him.</div><div class='line' id='LC11976'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11977'>&quot;And the queen, Clarence?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11978'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11979'>&quot;She is a nun, in Almesbury.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11980'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11981'>&quot;What changes! and in such a short while.  It is inconceivable.</div><div class='line' id='LC11982'>What next, I wonder?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11983'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11984'>&quot;I can tell you what next.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11985'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11986'>&quot;Well?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11987'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11988'>&quot;Stake our lives and stand by them!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11989'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11990'>&quot;What do you mean by that?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11991'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11992'>&quot;The Church is master now.  The Interdict included you with Mordred;</div><div class='line' id='LC11993'>it is not to be removed while you remain alive.  The clans are</div><div class='line' id='LC11994'>gathering.  The Church has gathered all the knights that are left</div><div class='line' id='LC11995'>alive, and as soon as you are discovered we shall have business</div><div class='line' id='LC11996'>on our hands.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC11997'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC11998'>&quot;Stuff!  With our deadly scientific war-material; with our hosts</div><div class='line' id='LC11999'>of trained--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12000'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12001'>&quot;Save your breath--we haven&#39;t sixty faithful left!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12002'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12003'>&quot;What are you saying?  Our schools, our colleges, our vast</div><div class='line' id='LC12004'>workshops, our--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12005'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12006'>&quot;When those knights come, those establishments will empty themselves</div><div class='line' id='LC12007'>and go over to the enemy.  Did you think you had educated the</div><div class='line' id='LC12008'>superstition out of those people?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12009'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12010'>&quot;I certainly did think it.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12011'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12012'>&quot;Well, then, you may unthink it.  They stood every strain easily</div><div class='line' id='LC12013'>--until the Interdict.  Since then, they merely put on a bold</div><div class='line' id='LC12014'>outside--at heart they are quaking.  Make up your mind to it</div><div class='line' id='LC12015'>--when the armies come, the mask will fall.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12016'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12017'>&quot;It&#39;s hard news.  We are lost.  They will turn our own science</div><div class='line' id='LC12018'>against us.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12019'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12020'>&quot;No they won&#39;t.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12021'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12022'>&quot;Why?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12023'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12024'>&quot;Because I and a handful of the faithful have blocked that game.</div><div class='line' id='LC12025'>I&#39;ll tell you what I&#39;ve done, and what moved me to it.  Smart as</div><div class='line' id='LC12026'>you are, the Church was smarter.  It was the Church that sent</div><div class='line' id='LC12027'>you cruising--through her servants, the doctors.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12028'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12029'>&quot;Clarence!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12030'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12031'>&quot;It is the truth.  I know it.  Every officer of your ship was</div><div class='line' id='LC12032'>the Church&#39;s picked servant, and so was every man of the crew.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12033'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12034'>&quot;Oh, come!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12035'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12036'>&quot;It is just as I tell you.  I did not find out these things at once,</div><div class='line' id='LC12037'>but I found them out finally.  Did you send me verbal information,</div><div class='line' id='LC12038'>by the commander of the ship, to the effect that upon his return</div><div class='line' id='LC12039'>to you, with supplies, you were going to leave Cadiz--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12040'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12041'>&quot;Cadiz!  I haven&#39;t been at Cadiz at all!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12042'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12043'>&quot;--going to leave Cadiz and cruise in distant seas indefinitely,</div><div class='line' id='LC12044'>for the health of your family?  Did you send me that word?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12045'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12046'>&quot;Of course not.  I would have written, wouldn&#39;t I?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12047'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12048'>&quot;Naturally.  I was troubled and suspicious.  When the commander</div><div class='line' id='LC12049'>sailed again I managed to ship a spy with him.  I have never</div><div class='line' id='LC12050'>heard of vessel or spy since.  I gave myself two weeks to hear</div><div class='line' id='LC12051'>from you in.  Then I resolved to send a ship to Cadiz.  There was</div><div class='line' id='LC12052'>a reason why I didn&#39;t.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12053'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12054'>&quot;What was that?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12055'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12056'>&quot;Our navy had suddenly and mysteriously disappeared!  Also, as</div><div class='line' id='LC12057'>suddenly and as mysteriously, the railway and telegraph and</div><div class='line' id='LC12058'>telephone service ceased, the men all deserted, poles were cut</div><div class='line' id='LC12059'>down, the Church laid a ban upon the electric light!  I had to be</div><div class='line' id='LC12060'>up and doing--and straight off.  Your life was safe--nobody in</div><div class='line' id='LC12061'>these kingdoms but Merlin would venture to touch such a magician</div><div class='line' id='LC12062'>as you without ten thousand men at his back--I had nothing to</div><div class='line' id='LC12063'>think of but how to put preparations in the best trim against your</div><div class='line' id='LC12064'>coming.  I felt safe myself--nobody would be anxious to touch</div><div class='line' id='LC12065'>a pet of yours.  So this is what I did.  From our various works</div><div class='line' id='LC12066'>I selected all the men--boys I mean--whose faithfulness under</div><div class='line' id='LC12067'>whatsoever pressure I could swear to, and I called them together</div><div class='line' id='LC12068'>secretly and gave them their instructions.  There are fifty-two of</div><div class='line' id='LC12069'>them; none younger than fourteen, and none above seventeen years old.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12070'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12071'>&quot;Why did you select boys?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12072'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12073'>&quot;Because all the others were born in an atmosphere of superstition</div><div class='line' id='LC12074'>and reared in it.  It is in their blood and bones.  We imagined</div><div class='line' id='LC12075'>we had educated it out of them; they thought so, too; the Interdict</div><div class='line' id='LC12076'>woke them up like a thunderclap!  It revealed them to themselves,</div><div class='line' id='LC12077'>and it revealed them to me, too.  With boys it was different.  Such</div><div class='line' id='LC12078'>as have been under our training from seven to ten years have had</div><div class='line' id='LC12079'>no acquaintance with the Church&#39;s terrors, and it was among these</div><div class='line' id='LC12080'>that I found my fifty-two.  As a next move, I paid a private visit</div><div class='line' id='LC12081'>to that old cave of Merlin&#39;s--not the small one--the big one--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12082'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12083'>&quot;Yes, the one where we secretly established our first great electric</div><div class='line' id='LC12084'>plant when I was projecting a miracle.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12085'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12086'>&quot;Just so.  And as that miracle hadn&#39;t become necessary then,</div><div class='line' id='LC12087'>I thought it might be a good idea to utilize the plant now.  I&#39;ve</div><div class='line' id='LC12088'>provisioned the cave for a siege--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12089'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12090'>&quot;A good idea, a first-rate idea.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12091'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12092'>&quot;I think so.  I placed four of my boys there as a guard--inside,</div><div class='line' id='LC12093'>and out of sight.  Nobody was to be hurt--while outside; but any</div><div class='line' id='LC12094'>attempt to enter--well, we said just let anybody try it!  Then</div><div class='line' id='LC12095'>I went out into the hills and uncovered and cut the secret wires</div><div class='line' id='LC12096'>which connected your bedroom with the wires that go to the dynamite</div><div class='line' id='LC12097'>deposits under all our vast factories, mills, workshops, magazines,</div><div class='line' id='LC12098'>etc., and about midnight I and my boys turned out and connected</div><div class='line' id='LC12099'>that wire with the cave, and nobody but you and I suspects where</div><div class='line' id='LC12100'>the other end of it goes to.  We laid it under ground, of course, and</div><div class='line' id='LC12101'>it was all finished in a couple of hours or so.  We sha&#39;n&#39;t have</div><div class='line' id='LC12102'>to leave our fortress now when we want to blow up our civilization.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12103'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12104'>&quot;It was the right move--and the natural one; military necessity,</div><div class='line' id='LC12105'>in the changed condition of things.  Well, what changes _have_ come!</div><div class='line' id='LC12106'>We expected to be besieged in the palace some time or other, but</div><div class='line' id='LC12107'>--however, go on.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12108'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12109'>&quot;Next, we built a wire fence.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12110'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12111'>&quot;Wire fence?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12112'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12113'>&quot;Yes.  You dropped the hint of it yourself, two or three years ago.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12114'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12115'>&quot;Oh, I remember--the time the Church tried her strength against</div><div class='line' id='LC12116'>us the first time, and presently thought it wise to wait for a</div><div class='line' id='LC12117'>hopefuler season.  Well, how have you arranged the fence?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12118'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12119'>&quot;I start twelve immensely strong wires--naked, not insulated</div><div class='line' id='LC12120'>--from a big dynamo in the cave--dynamo with no brushes except</div><div class='line' id='LC12121'>a positive and a negative one--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12122'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12123'>&quot;Yes, that&#39;s right.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12124'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12125'>&quot;The wires go out from the cave and fence in a circle of level</div><div class='line' id='LC12126'>ground a hundred yards in diameter; they make twelve independent</div><div class='line' id='LC12127'>fences, ten feet apart--that is to say, twelve circles within</div><div class='line' id='LC12128'>circles--and their ends come into the cave again.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12129'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12130'>&quot;Right; go on.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12131'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12132'>&quot;The fences are fastened to heavy oaken posts only three feet apart,</div><div class='line' id='LC12133'>and these posts are sunk five feet in the ground.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12134'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12135'>&quot;That is good and strong.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12136'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12137'>&quot;Yes.  The wires have no ground-connection outside of the cave.</div><div class='line' id='LC12138'>They go out from the positive brush of the dynamo; there is a</div><div class='line' id='LC12139'>ground-connection through the negative brush; the other ends of</div><div class='line' id='LC12140'>the wire return to the cave, and each is grounded independently.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12141'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12142'>&quot;No, no, that won&#39;t do!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12143'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12144'>&quot;Why?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12145'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12146'>&quot;It&#39;s too expensive--uses up force for nothing.  You don&#39;t want</div><div class='line' id='LC12147'>any ground-connection except the one through the negative brush.</div><div class='line' id='LC12148'>The other end of every wire must be brought back into the cave</div><div class='line' id='LC12149'>and fastened independently, and _without_ any ground-connection.</div><div class='line' id='LC12150'>Now, then, observe the economy of it.  A cavalry charge hurls</div><div class='line' id='LC12151'>itself against the fence; you are using no power, you are spending</div><div class='line' id='LC12152'>no money, for there is only one ground-connection till those horses</div><div class='line' id='LC12153'>come against the wire; the moment they touch it they form a</div><div class='line' id='LC12154'>connection with the negative brush _through the ground_, and drop</div><div class='line' id='LC12155'>dead.  Don&#39;t you see?--you are using no energy until it is needed;</div><div class='line' id='LC12156'>your lightning is there, and ready, like the load in a gun; but</div><div class='line' id='LC12157'>it isn&#39;t costing you a cent till you touch it off.  Oh, yes, the</div><div class='line' id='LC12158'>single ground-connection--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12159'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12160'>&quot;Of course!  I don&#39;t know how I overlooked that.  It&#39;s not only</div><div class='line' id='LC12161'>cheaper, but it&#39;s more effectual than the other way, for if wires</div><div class='line' id='LC12162'>break or get tangled, no harm is done.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12163'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12164'>&quot;No, especially if we have a tell-tale in the cave and disconnect</div><div class='line' id='LC12165'>the broken wire.  Well, go on.  The gatlings?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12166'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12167'>&quot;Yes--that&#39;s arranged.  In the center of the inner circle, on a</div><div class='line' id='LC12168'>spacious platform six feet high, I&#39;ve grouped a battery of thirteen</div><div class='line' id='LC12169'>gatling guns, and provided plenty of ammunition.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12170'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12171'>&quot;That&#39;s it.  They command every approach, and when the Church&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC12172'>knights arrive, there&#39;s going to be music.  The brow of the</div><div class='line' id='LC12173'>precipice over the cave--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12174'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12175'>&quot;I&#39;ve got a wire fence there, and a gatling.  They won&#39;t drop any</div><div class='line' id='LC12176'>rocks down on us.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12177'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12178'>&quot;Well, and the glass-cylinder dynamite torpedoes?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12179'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12180'>&quot;That&#39;s attended to.  It&#39;s the prettiest garden that was ever</div><div class='line' id='LC12181'>planted.  It&#39;s a belt forty feet wide, and goes around the outer</div><div class='line' id='LC12182'>fence--distance between it and the fence one hundred yards--kind of</div><div class='line' id='LC12183'>neutral ground that space is.  There isn&#39;t a single square yard</div><div class='line' id='LC12184'>of that whole belt but is equipped with a torpedo.  We laid them</div><div class='line' id='LC12185'>on the surface of the ground, and sprinkled a layer of sand over</div><div class='line' id='LC12186'>them.  It&#39;s an innocent looking garden, but you let a man start</div><div class='line' id='LC12187'>in to hoe it once, and you&#39;ll see.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12188'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12189'>&quot;You tested the torpedoes?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12190'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12191'>&quot;Well, I was going to, but--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12192'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12193'>&quot;But what?  Why, it&#39;s an immense oversight not to apply a--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12194'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12195'>&quot;Test?  Yes, I know; but they&#39;re all right; I laid a few in the</div><div class='line' id='LC12196'>public road beyond our lines and they&#39;ve been tested.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12197'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12198'>&quot;Oh, that alters the case.  Who did it?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12199'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12200'>&quot;A Church committee.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12201'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12202'>&quot;How kind!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12203'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12204'>&quot;Yes.  They came to command us to make submission.  You see they</div><div class='line' id='LC12205'>didn&#39;t really come to test the torpedoes; that was merely an incident.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12206'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12207'>&quot;Did the committee make a report?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12208'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12209'>&quot;Yes, they made one.  You could have heard it a mile.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12210'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12211'>&quot;Unanimous?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12212'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12213'>&quot;That was the nature of it.  After that I put up some signs, for the</div><div class='line' id='LC12214'>protection of future committees, and we have had no intruders since.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12215'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12216'>&quot;Clarence, you&#39;ve done a world of work, and done it perfectly.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12217'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12218'>&quot;We had plenty of time for it; there wasn&#39;t any occasion for hurry.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12219'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12220'>We sat silent awhile, thinking.  Then my mind was made up, and</div><div class='line' id='LC12221'>I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC12222'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12223'>&quot;Yes, everything is ready; everything is shipshape, no detail is</div><div class='line' id='LC12224'>wanting.  I know what to do now.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12225'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12226'>&quot;So do I; sit down and wait.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12227'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12228'>&quot;No, _sir_! rise up and _strike_!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12229'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12230'>&quot;Do you mean it?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12231'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12232'>&quot;Yes, indeed!  The _de_fensive isn&#39;t in my line, and the _of_fensive</div><div class='line' id='LC12233'>is.  That is, when I hold a fair hand--two-thirds as good a hand</div><div class='line' id='LC12234'>as the enemy.  Oh, yes, we&#39;ll rise up and strike; that&#39;s our game.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12235'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12236'>&quot;A hundred to one you are right.  When does the performance begin?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12237'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12238'>&quot;_Now!_  We&#39;ll proclaim the Republic.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12239'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12240'>&quot;Well, that _will_ precipitate things, sure enough!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12241'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12242'>&quot;It will make them buzz, I tell you!  England will be a hornets&#39;</div><div class='line' id='LC12243'>nest before noon to-morrow, if the Church&#39;s hand hasn&#39;t lost its</div><div class='line' id='LC12244'>cunning--and we know it hasn&#39;t.  Now you write and I&#39;ll dictate thus:</div><div class='line' id='LC12245'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12246'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&quot;PROCLAMATION</div><div class='line' id='LC12247'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12248'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;---</div><div class='line' id='LC12249'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12250'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&quot;BE IT KNOWN UNTO ALL.  Whereas the king having died</div><div class='line' id='LC12251'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and left no heir, it becomes my duty to continue the</div><div class='line' id='LC12252'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;executive authority vested in me, until a government</div><div class='line' id='LC12253'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;shall have been created and set in motion.  The</div><div class='line' id='LC12254'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;monarchy has lapsed, it no longer exists.  By</div><div class='line' id='LC12255'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;consequence, all political power has reverted to its</div><div class='line' id='LC12256'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;original source, the people of the nation.  With the</div><div class='line' id='LC12257'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;monarchy, its several adjuncts died also; wherefore</div><div class='line' id='LC12258'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;there is no longer a nobility, no longer a privileged</div><div class='line' id='LC12259'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;class, no longer an Established Church; all men are</div><div class='line' id='LC12260'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;become exactly equal; they are upon one common</div><div class='line' id='LC12261'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;level, and religion is free.  _A Republic is hereby</div><div class='line' id='LC12262'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;proclaimed_, as being the natural estate of a nation</div><div class='line' id='LC12263'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;when other authority has ceased.  It is the duty of</div><div class='line' id='LC12264'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the British people to meet together immediately,</div><div class='line' id='LC12265'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and by their votes elect representatives and deliver</div><div class='line' id='LC12266'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;into their hands the government.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12267'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12268'>I signed it &quot;The Boss,&quot; and dated it from Merlin&#39;s Cave.</div><div class='line' id='LC12269'>Clarence said--</div><div class='line' id='LC12270'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12271'>&quot;Why, that tells where we are, and invites them to call right away.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12272'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12273'>&quot;That is the idea.  We _strike_--by the Proclamation--then it&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC12274'>their innings.  Now have the thing set up and printed and posted,</div><div class='line' id='LC12275'>right off; that is, give the order; then, if you&#39;ve got a couple</div><div class='line' id='LC12276'>of bicycles handy at the foot of the hill, ho for Merlin&#39;s Cave!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12277'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12278'>&quot;I shall be ready in ten minutes.  What a cyclone there is going</div><div class='line' id='LC12279'>to be to-morrow when this piece of paper gets to work!...  It&#39;s a</div><div class='line' id='LC12280'>pleasant old palace, this is; I wonder if we shall ever again</div><div class='line' id='LC12281'>--but never mind about that.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12282'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12283'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12284'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12285'>CHAPTER XLIII</div><div class='line' id='LC12286'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12287'>THE BATTLE OF THE SAND BELT</div><div class='line' id='LC12288'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12289'>In Merlin&#39;s Cave--Clarence and I and fifty-two fresh, bright,</div><div class='line' id='LC12290'>well-educated, clean-minded young British boys.  At dawn I sent</div><div class='line' id='LC12291'>an order to the factories and to all our great works to stop</div><div class='line' id='LC12292'>operations and remove all life to a safe distance, as everything</div><div class='line' id='LC12293'>was going to be blown up by secret mines, &quot;_and no telling at what</div><div class='line' id='LC12294'>moment--therefore, vacate at once_.&quot;  These people knew me, and</div><div class='line' id='LC12295'>had confidence in my word.  They would clear out without waiting</div><div class='line' id='LC12296'>to part their hair, and I could take my own time about dating the</div><div class='line' id='LC12297'>explosion.  You couldn&#39;t hire one of them to go back during the</div><div class='line' id='LC12298'>century, if the explosion was still impending.</div><div class='line' id='LC12299'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12300'>We had a week of waiting.  It was not dull for me, because I was</div><div class='line' id='LC12301'>writing all the time.  During the first three days, I finished</div><div class='line' id='LC12302'>turning my old diary into this narrative form; it only required</div><div class='line' id='LC12303'>a chapter or so to bring it down to date.  The rest of the week</div><div class='line' id='LC12304'>I took up in writing letters to my wife.  It was always my habit</div><div class='line' id='LC12305'>to write to Sandy every day, whenever we were separate, and now</div><div class='line' id='LC12306'>I kept up the habit for love of it, and of her, though I couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC12307'>do anything with the letters, of course, after I had written them.</div><div class='line' id='LC12308'>But it put in the time, you see, and was almost like talking;</div><div class='line' id='LC12309'>it was almost as if I was saying, &quot;Sandy, if you and Hello-Central</div><div class='line' id='LC12310'>were here in the cave, instead of only your photographs, what</div><div class='line' id='LC12311'>good times we could have!&quot;  And then, you know, I could imagine</div><div class='line' id='LC12312'>the baby goo-gooing something out in reply, with its fists in its</div><div class='line' id='LC12313'>mouth and itself stretched across its mother&#39;s lap on its back,</div><div class='line' id='LC12314'>and she a-laughing and admiring and worshipping, and now and then</div><div class='line' id='LC12315'>tickling under the baby&#39;s chin to set it cackling, and then maybe</div><div class='line' id='LC12316'>throwing in a word of answer to me herself--and so on and so on</div><div class='line' id='LC12317'>--well, don&#39;t you know, I could sit there in the cave with my pen,</div><div class='line' id='LC12318'>and keep it up, that way, by the hour with them.  Why, it was</div><div class='line' id='LC12319'>almost like having us all together again.</div><div class='line' id='LC12320'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12321'>I had spies out every night, of course, to get news.  Every report</div><div class='line' id='LC12322'>made things look more and more impressive.  The hosts were gathering,</div><div class='line' id='LC12323'>gathering; down all the roads and paths of England the knights were</div><div class='line' id='LC12324'>riding, and priests rode with them, to hearten these original</div><div class='line' id='LC12325'>Crusaders, this being the Church&#39;s war.  All the nobilities, big</div><div class='line' id='LC12326'>and little, were on their way, and all the gentry.  This was all</div><div class='line' id='LC12327'>as was expected.  We should thin out this sort of folk to such</div><div class='line' id='LC12328'>a degree that the people would have nothing to do but just step</div><div class='line' id='LC12329'>to the front with their republic and--</div><div class='line' id='LC12330'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12331'>Ah, what a donkey I was!  Toward the end of the week I began to get</div><div class='line' id='LC12332'>this large and disenchanting fact through my head: that the mass</div><div class='line' id='LC12333'>of the nation had swung their caps and shouted for the republic for</div><div class='line' id='LC12334'>about one day, and there an end!  The Church, the nobles, and</div><div class='line' id='LC12335'>the gentry then turned one grand, all-disapproving frown upon them</div><div class='line' id='LC12336'>and shriveled them into sheep!  From that moment the sheep had</div><div class='line' id='LC12337'>begun to gather to the fold--that is to say, the camps--and offer</div><div class='line' id='LC12338'>their valueless lives and their valuable wool to the &quot;righteous</div><div class='line' id='LC12339'>cause.&quot;  Why, even the very men who had lately been slaves were</div><div class='line' id='LC12340'>in the &quot;righteous cause,&quot; and glorifying it, praying for it,</div><div class='line' id='LC12341'>sentimentally slabbering over it, just like all the other commoners.</div><div class='line' id='LC12342'>Imagine such human muck as this; conceive of this folly!</div><div class='line' id='LC12343'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12344'>Yes, it was now &quot;Death to the Republic!&quot; everywhere--not a dissenting</div><div class='line' id='LC12345'>voice.  All England was marching against us!  Truly, this was more</div><div class='line' id='LC12346'>than I had bargained for.</div><div class='line' id='LC12347'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12348'>I watched my fifty-two boys narrowly; watched their faces, their</div><div class='line' id='LC12349'>walk, their unconscious attitudes: for all these are a language</div><div class='line' id='LC12350'>--a language given us purposely that it may betray us in times of</div><div class='line' id='LC12351'>emergency, when we have secrets which we want to keep.  I knew</div><div class='line' id='LC12352'>that that thought would keep saying itself over and over again</div><div class='line' id='LC12353'>in their minds and hearts, _All England is marching against us!_</div><div class='line' id='LC12354'>and ever more strenuously imploring attention with each repetition,</div><div class='line' id='LC12355'>ever more sharply realizing itself to their imaginations, until</div><div class='line' id='LC12356'>even in their sleep they would find no rest from it, but hear</div><div class='line' id='LC12357'>the vague and flitting creatures of the dreams say, _All England_</div><div class='line' id='LC12358'>--ALL ENGLAND!--_is marching against you_!  I knew all this would</div><div class='line' id='LC12359'>happen; I knew that ultimately the pressure would become so great</div><div class='line' id='LC12360'>that it would compel utterance; therefore, I must be ready with an</div><div class='line' id='LC12361'>answer at that time--an answer well chosen and tranquilizing.</div><div class='line' id='LC12362'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12363'>I was right.  The time came.  They HAD to speak.  Poor lads, it</div><div class='line' id='LC12364'>was pitiful to see, they were so pale, so worn, so troubled.  At</div><div class='line' id='LC12365'>first their spokesman could hardly find voice or words; but he</div><div class='line' id='LC12366'>presently got both.  This is what he said--and he put it in the</div><div class='line' id='LC12367'>neat modern English taught him in my schools:</div><div class='line' id='LC12368'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12369'>&quot;We have tried to forget what we are--English boys!  We have tried</div><div class='line' id='LC12370'>to put reason before sentiment, duty before love; our minds</div><div class='line' id='LC12371'>approve, but our hearts reproach us.  While apparently it was</div><div class='line' id='LC12372'>only the nobility, only the gentry, only the twenty-five or thirty</div><div class='line' id='LC12373'>thousand knights left alive out of the late wars, we were of one</div><div class='line' id='LC12374'>mind, and undisturbed by any troubling doubt; each and every one</div><div class='line' id='LC12375'>of these fifty-two lads who stand here before you, said, &#39;They</div><div class='line' id='LC12376'>have chosen--it is their affair.&#39;  But think!--the matter is</div><div class='line' id='LC12377'>altered--_All England is marching against us_!  Oh, sir, consider!</div><div class='line' id='LC12378'>--reflect!--these people are our people, they are bone of our bone,</div><div class='line' id='LC12379'>flesh of our flesh, we love them--do not ask us to destroy our nation!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12380'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12381'>Well, it shows the value of looking ahead, and being ready for</div><div class='line' id='LC12382'>a thing when it happens.  If I hadn&#39;t foreseen this thing and been</div><div class='line' id='LC12383'>fixed, that boy would have had me!--I couldn&#39;t have said a word.</div><div class='line' id='LC12384'>But I was fixed.  I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC12385'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12386'>&quot;My boys, your hearts are in the right place, you have thought the</div><div class='line' id='LC12387'>worthy thought, you have done the worthy thing.  You are English</div><div class='line' id='LC12388'>boys, you will remain English boys, and you will keep that name</div><div class='line' id='LC12389'>unsmirched.  Give yourselves no further concern, let your minds be</div><div class='line' id='LC12390'>at peace.  Consider this: while all England is marching against</div><div class='line' id='LC12391'>us, who is in the van?  Who, by the commonest rules of war, will</div><div class='line' id='LC12392'>march in the front?  Answer me.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12393'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12394'>&quot;The mounted host of mailed knights.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12395'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12396'>&quot;True.  They are thirty thousand strong.  Acres deep they will march.</div><div class='line' id='LC12397'>Now, observe: none but _they_ will ever strike the sand-belt!  Then</div><div class='line' id='LC12398'>there will be an episode!  Immediately after, the civilian multitude</div><div class='line' id='LC12399'>in the rear will retire, to meet business engagements elsewhere.</div><div class='line' id='LC12400'>None but nobles and gentry are knights, and _none but these_ will</div><div class='line' id='LC12401'>remain to dance to our music after that episode.  It is absolutely</div><div class='line' id='LC12402'>true that we shall have to fight nobody but these thirty thousand</div><div class='line' id='LC12403'>knights.  Now speak, and it shall be as you decide.  Shall we</div><div class='line' id='LC12404'>avoid the battle, retire from the field?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12405'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12406'>&quot;NO!!!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12407'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12408'>The shout was unanimous and hearty.</div><div class='line' id='LC12409'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12410'>&quot;Are you--are you--well, afraid of these thirty thousand knights?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12411'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12412'>That joke brought out a good laugh, the boys&#39; troubles vanished</div><div class='line' id='LC12413'>away, and they went gaily to their posts.  Ah, they were a darling</div><div class='line' id='LC12414'>fifty-two!  As pretty as girls, too.</div><div class='line' id='LC12415'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12416'>I was ready for the enemy now.  Let the approaching big day come</div><div class='line' id='LC12417'>along--it would find us on deck.</div><div class='line' id='LC12418'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12419'>The big day arrived on time.  At dawn the sentry on watch in the</div><div class='line' id='LC12420'>corral came into the cave and reported a moving black mass under</div><div class='line' id='LC12421'>the horizon, and a faint sound which he thought to be military</div><div class='line' id='LC12422'>music.  Breakfast was just ready; we sat down and ate it.</div><div class='line' id='LC12423'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12424'>This over, I made the boys a little speech, and then sent out</div><div class='line' id='LC12425'>a detail to man the battery, with Clarence in command of it.</div><div class='line' id='LC12426'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12427'>The sun rose presently and sent its unobstructed splendors over</div><div class='line' id='LC12428'>the land, and we saw a prodigious host moving slowly toward us,</div><div class='line' id='LC12429'>with the steady drift and aligned front of a wave of the sea.</div><div class='line' id='LC12430'>Nearer and nearer it came, and more and more sublimely imposing</div><div class='line' id='LC12431'>became its aspect; yes, all England was there, apparently.  Soon</div><div class='line' id='LC12432'>we could see the innumerable banners fluttering, and then the sun</div><div class='line' id='LC12433'>struck the sea of armor and set it all aflash.  Yes, it was a fine</div><div class='line' id='LC12434'>sight; I hadn&#39;t ever seen anything to beat it.</div><div class='line' id='LC12435'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12436'>At last we could make out details.  All the front ranks, no telling</div><div class='line' id='LC12437'>how many acres deep, were horsemen--plumed knights in armor.</div><div class='line' id='LC12438'>Suddenly we heard the blare of trumpets; the slow walk burst into</div><div class='line' id='LC12439'>a gallop, and then--well, it was wonderful to see!  Down swept</div><div class='line' id='LC12440'>that vast horse-shoe wave--it approached the sand-belt--my breath</div><div class='line' id='LC12441'>stood still; nearer, nearer--the strip of green turf beyond the</div><div class='line' id='LC12442'>yellow belt grew narrow--narrower still--became a mere ribbon in</div><div class='line' id='LC12443'>front of the horses--then disappeared under their hoofs.  Great</div><div class='line' id='LC12444'>Scott!  Why, the whole front of that host shot into the sky with</div><div class='line' id='LC12445'>a thunder-crash, and became a whirling tempest of rags and fragments;</div><div class='line' id='LC12446'>and along the ground lay a thick wall of smoke that hid what was</div><div class='line' id='LC12447'>left of the multitude from our sight.</div><div class='line' id='LC12448'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12449'>Time for the second step in the plan of campaign!  I touched</div><div class='line' id='LC12450'>a button, and shook the bones of England loose from her spine!</div><div class='line' id='LC12451'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12452'>In that explosion all our noble civilization-factories went up in</div><div class='line' id='LC12453'>the air and disappeared from the earth.  It was a pity, but it</div><div class='line' id='LC12454'>was necessary.  We could not afford to let the enemy turn our own</div><div class='line' id='LC12455'>weapons against us.</div><div class='line' id='LC12456'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12457'>Now ensued one of the dullest quarter-hours I had ever endured.</div><div class='line' id='LC12458'>We waited in a silent solitude enclosed by our circles of wire,</div><div class='line' id='LC12459'>and by a circle of heavy smoke outside of these.  We couldn&#39;t</div><div class='line' id='LC12460'>see over the wall of smoke, and we couldn&#39;t see through it.  But</div><div class='line' id='LC12461'>at last it began to shred away lazily, and by the end of another</div><div class='line' id='LC12462'>quarter-hour the land was clear and our curiosity was enabled</div><div class='line' id='LC12463'>to satisfy itself.  No living creature was in sight!  We now</div><div class='line' id='LC12464'>perceived that additions had been made to our defenses.  The</div><div class='line' id='LC12465'>dynamite had dug a ditch more than a hundred feet wide, all around</div><div class='line' id='LC12466'>us, and cast up an embankment some twenty-five feet high on both</div><div class='line' id='LC12467'>borders of it.  As to destruction of life, it was amazing.  Moreover,</div><div class='line' id='LC12468'>it was beyond estimate.  Of course, we could not _count_ the dead,</div><div class='line' id='LC12469'>because they did not exist as individuals, but merely as homogeneous</div><div class='line' id='LC12470'>protoplasm, with alloys of iron and buttons.</div><div class='line' id='LC12471'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12472'>No life was in sight, but necessarily there must have been some</div><div class='line' id='LC12473'>wounded in the rear ranks, who were carried off the field under</div><div class='line' id='LC12474'>cover of the wall of smoke; there would be sickness among the</div><div class='line' id='LC12475'>others--there always is, after an episode like that.  But there</div><div class='line' id='LC12476'>would be no reinforcements; this was the last stand of the chivalry</div><div class='line' id='LC12477'>of England; it was all that was left of the order, after the recent</div><div class='line' id='LC12478'>annihilating wars.  So I felt quite safe in believing that the</div><div class='line' id='LC12479'>utmost force that could for the future be brought against us</div><div class='line' id='LC12480'>would be but small; that is, of knights.  I therefore issued a</div><div class='line' id='LC12481'>congratulatory proclamation to my army in these words:</div><div class='line' id='LC12482'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12483'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SOLDIERS, CHAMPIONS OF HUMAN LIBERTY AND EQUALITY:</div><div class='line' id='LC12484'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Your General congratulates you!  In the pride of his</div><div class='line' id='LC12485'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;strength and the vanity of his renown, an arrogant</div><div class='line' id='LC12486'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;enemy came against you.  You were ready.  The conflict</div><div class='line' id='LC12487'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;was brief; on your side, glorious.  This mighty</div><div class='line' id='LC12488'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;victory, having been achieved utterly without loss,</div><div class='line' id='LC12489'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;stands without example in history.  So long as the</div><div class='line' id='LC12490'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;planets shall continue to move in their orbits, the</div><div class='line' id='LC12491'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BATTLE OF THE SAND-BELT will not perish out of the</div><div class='line' id='LC12492'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;memories of men.</div><div class='line' id='LC12493'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12494'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;THE BOSS.</div><div class='line' id='LC12495'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12496'>I read it well, and the applause I got was very gratifying to me.</div><div class='line' id='LC12497'>I then wound up with these remarks:</div><div class='line' id='LC12498'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12499'>&quot;The war with the English nation, as a nation, is at an end.</div><div class='line' id='LC12500'>The nation has retired from the field and the war.  Before it can</div><div class='line' id='LC12501'>be persuaded to return, war will have ceased.  This campaign is</div><div class='line' id='LC12502'>the only one that is going to be fought.  It will be brief</div><div class='line' id='LC12503'>--the briefest in history.  Also the most destructive to life,</div><div class='line' id='LC12504'>considered from the standpoint of proportion of casualties to</div><div class='line' id='LC12505'>numbers engaged.  We are done with the nation; henceforth we deal</div><div class='line' id='LC12506'>only with the knights.  English knights can be killed, but they</div><div class='line' id='LC12507'>cannot be conquered.  We know what is before us.  While one of</div><div class='line' id='LC12508'>these men remains alive, our task is not finished, the war is not</div><div class='line' id='LC12509'>ended.  We will kill them all.&quot;  [Loud and long continued applause.]</div><div class='line' id='LC12510'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12511'>I picketed the great embankments thrown up around our lines by</div><div class='line' id='LC12512'>the dynamite explosion--merely a lookout of a couple of boys</div><div class='line' id='LC12513'>to announce the enemy when he should appear again.</div><div class='line' id='LC12514'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12515'>Next, I sent an engineer and forty men to a point just beyond</div><div class='line' id='LC12516'>our lines on the south, to turn a mountain brook that was there,</div><div class='line' id='LC12517'>and bring it within our lines and under our command, arranging</div><div class='line' id='LC12518'>it in such a way that I could make instant use of it in an emergency.</div><div class='line' id='LC12519'>The forty men were divided into two shifts of twenty each, and</div><div class='line' id='LC12520'>were to relieve each other every two hours.  In ten hours the</div><div class='line' id='LC12521'>work was accomplished.</div><div class='line' id='LC12522'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12523'>It was nightfall now, and I withdrew my pickets.  The one who</div><div class='line' id='LC12524'>had had the northern outlook reported a camp in sight, but visible</div><div class='line' id='LC12525'>with the glass only.  He also reported that a few knights had been</div><div class='line' id='LC12526'>feeling their way toward us, and had driven some cattle across our</div><div class='line' id='LC12527'>lines, but that the knights themselves had not come very near.</div><div class='line' id='LC12528'>That was what I had been expecting.  They were feeling us, you</div><div class='line' id='LC12529'>see; they wanted to know if we were going to play that red terror</div><div class='line' id='LC12530'>on them again.  They would grow bolder in the night, perhaps.</div><div class='line' id='LC12531'>I believed I knew what project they would attempt, because it was</div><div class='line' id='LC12532'>plainly the thing I would attempt myself if I were in their places</div><div class='line' id='LC12533'>and as ignorant as they were.  I mentioned it to Clarence.</div><div class='line' id='LC12534'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12535'>&quot;I think you are right,&quot; said he; &quot;it is the obvious thing for</div><div class='line' id='LC12536'>them to try.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12537'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12538'>&quot;Well, then,&quot; I said, &quot;if they do it they are doomed.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12539'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12540'>&quot;Certainly.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12541'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12542'>&quot;They won&#39;t have the slightest show in the world.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12543'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12544'>&quot;Of course they won&#39;t.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12545'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12546'>&quot;It&#39;s dreadful, Clarence.  It seems an awful pity.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12547'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12548'>The thing disturbed me so that I couldn&#39;t get any peace of mind</div><div class='line' id='LC12549'>for thinking of it and worrying over it.  So, at last, to quiet</div><div class='line' id='LC12550'>my conscience, I framed this message to the knights:</div><div class='line' id='LC12551'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12552'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;TO THE HONORABLE THE COMMANDER OF THE INSURGENT</div><div class='line' id='LC12553'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;CHIVALRY OF ENGLAND: YOU fight in vain.  We know</div><div class='line' id='LC12554'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;your strength--if one may call it by that name.</div><div class='line' id='LC12555'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We know that at the utmost you cannot bring</div><div class='line' id='LC12556'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;against us above five and twenty thousand knights.</div><div class='line' id='LC12557'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Therefore, you have no chance--none whatever.</div><div class='line' id='LC12558'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Reflect: we are well equipped, well fortified, we</div><div class='line' id='LC12559'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;number 54.  Fifty-four what?  Men?  No, MINDS--the</div><div class='line' id='LC12560'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;capablest in the world; a force against which</div><div class='line' id='LC12561'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;mere animal might may no more hope to prevail than</div><div class='line' id='LC12562'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;may the idle waves of the sea hope to prevail</div><div class='line' id='LC12563'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;against the granite barriers of England.  Be advised.</div><div class='line' id='LC12564'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We offer you your lives; for the sake of your</div><div class='line' id='LC12565'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;families, do not reject the gift.  We offer you</div><div class='line' id='LC12566'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;this chance, and it is the last: throw down your</div><div class='line' id='LC12567'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;arms; surrender unconditionally to the Republic,</div><div class='line' id='LC12568'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and all will be forgiven.</div><div class='line' id='LC12569'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12570'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(Signed) THE BOSS.</div><div class='line' id='LC12571'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12572'>I read it to Clarence, and said I proposed to send it by a flag</div><div class='line' id='LC12573'>of truce.  He laughed the sarcastic laugh he was born with, and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC12574'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12575'>&quot;Somehow it seems impossible for you to ever fully realize what</div><div class='line' id='LC12576'>these nobilities are.  Now let us save a little time and trouble.</div><div class='line' id='LC12577'>Consider me the commander of the knights yonder.  Now, then,</div><div class='line' id='LC12578'>you are the flag of truce; approach and deliver me your message,</div><div class='line' id='LC12579'>and I will give you your answer.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12580'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12581'>I humored the idea.  I came forward under an imaginary guard of</div><div class='line' id='LC12582'>the enemy&#39;s soldiers, produced my paper, and read it through.</div><div class='line' id='LC12583'>For answer, Clarence struck the paper out of my hand, pursed up</div><div class='line' id='LC12584'>a scornful lip and said with lofty disdain:</div><div class='line' id='LC12585'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12586'>&quot;Dismember me this animal, and return him in a basket to the</div><div class='line' id='LC12587'>base-born knave who sent him; other answer have I none!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12588'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12589'>How empty is theory in presence of fact!  And this was just fact,</div><div class='line' id='LC12590'>and nothing else.  It was the thing that would have happened,</div><div class='line' id='LC12591'>there was no getting around that.  I tore up the paper and granted</div><div class='line' id='LC12592'>my mistimed sentimentalities a permanent rest.</div><div class='line' id='LC12593'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12594'>Then, to business.  I tested the electric signals from the gatling</div><div class='line' id='LC12595'>platform to the cave, and made sure that they were all right;</div><div class='line' id='LC12596'>I tested and retested those which commanded the fences--these</div><div class='line' id='LC12597'>were signals whereby I could break and renew the electric current</div><div class='line' id='LC12598'>in each fence independently of the others at will.  I placed the</div><div class='line' id='LC12599'>brook-connection under the guard and authority of three of my</div><div class='line' id='LC12600'>best boys, who would alternate in two-hour watches all night and</div><div class='line' id='LC12601'>promptly obey my signal, if I should have occasion to give it</div><div class='line' id='LC12602'>--three revolver-shots in quick succession.  Sentry-duty was discarded</div><div class='line' id='LC12603'>for the night, and the corral left empty of life; I ordered that</div><div class='line' id='LC12604'>quiet be maintained in the cave, and the electric lights turned</div><div class='line' id='LC12605'>down to a glimmer.</div><div class='line' id='LC12606'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12607'>As soon as it was good and dark, I shut off the current from all</div><div class='line' id='LC12608'>the fences, and then groped my way out to the embankment bordering</div><div class='line' id='LC12609'>our side of the great dynamite ditch.  I crept to the top of it</div><div class='line' id='LC12610'>and lay there on the slant of the muck to watch.  But it was</div><div class='line' id='LC12611'>too dark to see anything.  As for sounds, there were none.  The</div><div class='line' id='LC12612'>stillness was deathlike.  True, there were the usual night-sounds</div><div class='line' id='LC12613'>of the country--the whir of night-birds, the buzzing of insects,</div><div class='line' id='LC12614'>the barking of distant dogs, the mellow lowing of far-off kine</div><div class='line' id='LC12615'>--but these didn&#39;t seem to break the stillness, they only intensified</div><div class='line' id='LC12616'>it, and added a grewsome melancholy to it into the bargain.</div><div class='line' id='LC12617'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12618'>I presently gave up looking, the night shut down so black, but</div><div class='line' id='LC12619'>I kept my ears strained to catch the least suspicious sound, for</div><div class='line' id='LC12620'>I judged I had only to wait, and I shouldn&#39;t be disappointed.</div><div class='line' id='LC12621'>However, I had to wait a long time.  At last I caught what you</div><div class='line' id='LC12622'>may call in distinct glimpses of sound dulled metallic sound.</div><div class='line' id='LC12623'>I pricked up my ears, then, and held my breath, for this was the</div><div class='line' id='LC12624'>sort of thing I had been waiting for.  This sound thickened, and</div><div class='line' id='LC12625'>approached--from toward the north.  Presently, I heard it at my</div><div class='line' id='LC12626'>own level--the ridge-top of the opposite embankment, a hundred</div><div class='line' id='LC12627'>feet or more away.  Then I seemed to see a row of black dots appear</div><div class='line' id='LC12628'>along that ridge--human heads?  I couldn&#39;t tell; it mightn&#39;t be</div><div class='line' id='LC12629'>anything at all; you can&#39;t depend on your eyes when your imagination</div><div class='line' id='LC12630'>is out of focus.  However, the question was soon settled.  I heard</div><div class='line' id='LC12631'>that metallic noise descending into the great ditch.  It augmented</div><div class='line' id='LC12632'>fast, it spread all along, and it unmistakably furnished me this</div><div class='line' id='LC12633'>fact: an armed host was taking up its quarters in the ditch.  Yes,</div><div class='line' id='LC12634'>these people were arranging a little surprise party for us.  We</div><div class='line' id='LC12635'>could expect entertainment about dawn, possibly earlier.</div><div class='line' id='LC12636'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12637'>I groped my way back to the corral now; I had seen enough.  I went</div><div class='line' id='LC12638'>to the platform and signaled to turn the current on to the two</div><div class='line' id='LC12639'>inner fences.  Then I went into the cave, and found everything</div><div class='line' id='LC12640'>satisfactory there--nobody awake but the working-watch.  I woke</div><div class='line' id='LC12641'>Clarence and told him the great ditch was filling up with men,</div><div class='line' id='LC12642'>and that I believed all the knights were coming for us in a body.</div><div class='line' id='LC12643'>It was my notion that as soon as dawn approached we could expect</div><div class='line' id='LC12644'>the ditch&#39;s ambuscaded thousands to swarm up over the embankment</div><div class='line' id='LC12645'>and make an assault, and be followed immediately by the rest</div><div class='line' id='LC12646'>of their army.</div><div class='line' id='LC12647'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12648'>Clarence said:</div><div class='line' id='LC12649'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12650'>&quot;They will be wanting to send a scout or two in the dark to make</div><div class='line' id='LC12651'>preliminary observations.  Why not take the lightning off the</div><div class='line' id='LC12652'>outer fences, and give them a chance?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12653'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12654'>&quot;I&#39;ve already done it, Clarence.  Did you ever know me to be</div><div class='line' id='LC12655'>inhospitable?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12656'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12657'>&quot;No, you are a good heart.  I want to go and--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12658'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12659'>&quot;Be a reception committee?  I will go, too.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12660'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12661'>We crossed the corral and lay down together between the two inside</div><div class='line' id='LC12662'>fences.  Even the dim light of the cave had disordered our eyesight</div><div class='line' id='LC12663'>somewhat, but the focus straightway began to regulate itself and</div><div class='line' id='LC12664'>soon it was adjusted for present circumstances.  We had had to feel</div><div class='line' id='LC12665'>our way before, but we could make out to see the fence posts now.</div><div class='line' id='LC12666'>We started a whispered conversation, but suddenly Clarence broke</div><div class='line' id='LC12667'>off and said:</div><div class='line' id='LC12668'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12669'>&quot;What is that?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12670'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12671'>&quot;What is what?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12672'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12673'>&quot;That thing yonder.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12674'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12675'>&quot;What thing--where?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12676'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12677'>&quot;There beyond you a little piece--dark something--a dull shape</div><div class='line' id='LC12678'>of some kind--against the second fence.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12679'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12680'>I gazed and he gazed.  I said:</div><div class='line' id='LC12681'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12682'>&quot;Could it be a man, Clarence?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12683'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12684'>&quot;No, I think not.  If you notice, it looks a lit--why, it _is_</div><div class='line' id='LC12685'>a man!--leaning on the fence.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12686'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12687'>&quot;I certainly believe it is; let us go and see.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12688'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12689'>We crept along on our hands and knees until we were pretty close,</div><div class='line' id='LC12690'>and then looked up.  Yes, it was a man--a dim great figure in armor,</div><div class='line' id='LC12691'>standing erect, with both hands on the upper wire--and, of course,</div><div class='line' id='LC12692'>there was a smell of burning flesh.  Poor fellow, dead as a</div><div class='line' id='LC12693'>door-nail, and never knew what hurt him.  He stood there like a</div><div class='line' id='LC12694'>statue--no motion about him, except that his plumes swished about</div><div class='line' id='LC12695'>a little in the night wind.  We rose up and looked in through</div><div class='line' id='LC12696'>the bars of his visor, but couldn&#39;t make out whether we knew him</div><div class='line' id='LC12697'>or not--features too dim and shadowed.</div><div class='line' id='LC12698'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12699'>We heard muffled sounds approaching, and we sank down to the ground</div><div class='line' id='LC12700'>where we were.  We made out another knight vaguely; he was coming</div><div class='line' id='LC12701'>very stealthily, and feeling his way.  He was near enough now for</div><div class='line' id='LC12702'>us to see him put out a hand, find an upper wire, then bend and</div><div class='line' id='LC12703'>step under it and over the lower one.  Now he arrived at the</div><div class='line' id='LC12704'>first knight--and started slightly when he discovered him.  He</div><div class='line' id='LC12705'>stood a moment--no doubt wondering why the other one didn&#39;t move</div><div class='line' id='LC12706'>on; then he said, in a low voice, &quot;Why dreamest thou here, good</div><div class='line' id='LC12707'>Sir Mar--&quot; then he laid his hand on the corpse&#39;s shoulder--and just</div><div class='line' id='LC12708'>uttered a little soft moan and sunk down dead.  Killed by a dead</div><div class='line' id='LC12709'>man, you see--killed by a dead friend, in fact.  There was something</div><div class='line' id='LC12710'>awful about it.</div><div class='line' id='LC12711'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12712'>These early birds came scattering along after each other, about</div><div class='line' id='LC12713'>one every five minutes in our vicinity, during half an hour.</div><div class='line' id='LC12714'>They brought no armor of offense but their swords; as a rule,</div><div class='line' id='LC12715'>they carried the sword ready in the hand, and put it forward and</div><div class='line' id='LC12716'>found the wires with it.
