We would now and then see a blue spark</div><div class='line' id='LC12717'>when the knight that caused it was so far away as to be invisible</div><div class='line' id='LC12718'>to us; but we knew what had happened, all the same; poor fellow,</div><div class='line' id='LC12719'>he had touched a charged wire with his sword and been electrocuted.</div><div class='line' id='LC12720'>We had brief intervals of grim stillness, interrupted with piteous</div><div class='line' id='LC12721'>regularity by the clash made by the falling of an iron-clad; and</div><div class='line' id='LC12722'>this sort of thing was going on, right along, and was very creepy</div><div class='line' id='LC12723'>there in the dark and lonesomeness.</div><div class='line' id='LC12724'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12725'>We concluded to make a tour between the inner fences.  We elected</div><div class='line' id='LC12726'>to walk upright, for convenience&#39;s sake; we argued that if discerned,</div><div class='line' id='LC12727'>we should be taken for friends rather than enemies, and in any case</div><div class='line' id='LC12728'>we should be out of reach of swords, and these gentry did not seem</div><div class='line' id='LC12729'>to have any spears along.  Well, it was a curious trip.  Everywhere</div><div class='line' id='LC12730'>dead men were lying outside the second fence--not plainly visible,</div><div class='line' id='LC12731'>but still visible; and we counted fifteen of those pathetic</div><div class='line' id='LC12732'>statues--dead knights standing with their hands on the upper wire.</div><div class='line' id='LC12733'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12734'>One thing seemed to be sufficiently demonstrated: our current</div><div class='line' id='LC12735'>was so tremendous that it killed before the victim could cry out.</div><div class='line' id='LC12736'>Pretty soon we detected a muffled and heavy sound, and next moment</div><div class='line' id='LC12737'>we guessed what it was.  It was a surprise in force coming! I whispered</div><div class='line' id='LC12738'>Clarence to go and wake the army, and notify it to wait in silence</div><div class='line' id='LC12739'>in the cave for further orders.  He was soon back, and we stood</div><div class='line' id='LC12740'>by the inner fence and watched the silent lightning do its awful</div><div class='line' id='LC12741'>work upon that swarming host.  One could make out but little of</div><div class='line' id='LC12742'>detail; but he could note that a black mass was piling itself up</div><div class='line' id='LC12743'>beyond the second fence.  That swelling bulk was dead men!  Our</div><div class='line' id='LC12744'>camp was enclosed with a solid wall of the dead--a bulwark,</div><div class='line' id='LC12745'>a breastwork, of corpses, you may say.  One terrible thing about</div><div class='line' id='LC12746'>this thing was the absence of human voices; there were no cheers,</div><div class='line' id='LC12747'>no war cries; being intent upon a surprise, these men moved as</div><div class='line' id='LC12748'>noiselessly as they could; and always when the front rank was near</div><div class='line' id='LC12749'>enough to their goal to make it proper for them to begin to get</div><div class='line' id='LC12750'>a shout ready, of course they struck the fatal line and went down</div><div class='line' id='LC12751'>without testifying.</div><div class='line' id='LC12752'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12753'>I sent a current through the third fence now; and almost immediately</div><div class='line' id='LC12754'>through the fourth and fifth, so quickly were the gaps filled up.</div><div class='line' id='LC12755'>I believed the time was come now for my climax; I believed that</div><div class='line' id='LC12756'>that whole army was in our trap.  Anyway, it was high time to find</div><div class='line' id='LC12757'>out.  So I touched a button and set fifty electric suns aflame</div><div class='line' id='LC12758'>on the top of our precipice.</div><div class='line' id='LC12759'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12760'>Land, what a sight!  We were enclosed in three walls of dead men!</div><div class='line' id='LC12761'>All the other fences were pretty nearly filled with the living,</div><div class='line' id='LC12762'>who were stealthily working their way forward through the wires.</div><div class='line' id='LC12763'>The sudden glare paralyzed this host, petrified them, you may say,</div><div class='line' id='LC12764'>with astonishment; there was just one instant for me to utilize</div><div class='line' id='LC12765'>their immobility in, and I didn&#39;t lose the chance.  You see, in</div><div class='line' id='LC12766'>another instant they would have recovered their faculties, then</div><div class='line' id='LC12767'>they&#39;d have burst into a cheer and made a rush, and my wires</div><div class='line' id='LC12768'>would have gone down before it; but that lost instant lost them</div><div class='line' id='LC12769'>their opportunity forever; while even that slight fragment of time</div><div class='line' id='LC12770'>was still unspent, I shot the current through all the fences and</div><div class='line' id='LC12771'>struck the whole host dead in their tracks!  _There_ was a groan</div><div class='line' id='LC12772'>you could _hear_!  It voiced the death-pang of eleven thousand men.</div><div class='line' id='LC12773'>It swelled out on the night with awful pathos.</div><div class='line' id='LC12774'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12775'>A glance showed that the rest of the enemy--perhaps ten thousand</div><div class='line' id='LC12776'>strong--were between us and the encircling ditch, and pressing</div><div class='line' id='LC12777'>forward to the assault.  Consequently we had them _all!_ and had</div><div class='line' id='LC12778'>them past help.  Time for the last act of the tragedy.  I fired</div><div class='line' id='LC12779'>the three appointed revolver shots--which meant:</div><div class='line' id='LC12780'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12781'>&quot;Turn on the water!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12782'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12783'>There was a sudden rush and roar, and in a minute the mountain</div><div class='line' id='LC12784'>brook was raging through the big ditch and creating a river a</div><div class='line' id='LC12785'>hundred feet wide and twenty-five deep.</div><div class='line' id='LC12786'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12787'>&quot;Stand to your guns, men!  Open fire!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12788'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12789'>The thirteen gatlings began to vomit death into the fated ten</div><div class='line' id='LC12790'>thousand.  They halted, they stood their ground a moment against</div><div class='line' id='LC12791'>that withering deluge of fire, then they broke, faced about and</div><div class='line' id='LC12792'>swept toward the ditch like chaff before a gale.  A full fourth</div><div class='line' id='LC12793'>part of their force never reached the top of the lofty embankment;</div><div class='line' id='LC12794'>the three-fourths reached it and plunged over--to death by drowning.</div><div class='line' id='LC12795'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12796'>Within ten short minutes after we had opened fire, armed resistance</div><div class='line' id='LC12797'>was totally annihilated, the campaign was ended, we fifty-four were</div><div class='line' id='LC12798'>masters of England.  Twenty-five thousand men lay dead around us.</div><div class='line' id='LC12799'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12800'>But how treacherous is fortune!  In a little while--say an hour</div><div class='line' id='LC12801'>--happened a thing, by my own fault, which--but I have no heart</div><div class='line' id='LC12802'>to write that.  Let the record end here.</div><div class='line' id='LC12803'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12804'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12805'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12806'>CHAPTER XLIV</div><div class='line' id='LC12807'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12808'>A POSTSCRIPT BY CLARENCE</div><div class='line' id='LC12809'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12810'>I, Clarence, must write it for him.  He proposed that we two</div><div class='line' id='LC12811'>go out and see if any help could be accorded the wounded.  I was</div><div class='line' id='LC12812'>strenuous against the project.  I said that if there were many,</div><div class='line' id='LC12813'>we could do but little for them; and it would not be wise for us to</div><div class='line' id='LC12814'>trust ourselves among them, anyway.  But he could seldom be turned</div><div class='line' id='LC12815'>from a purpose once formed; so we shut off the electric current</div><div class='line' id='LC12816'>from the fences, took an escort along, climbed over the enclosing</div><div class='line' id='LC12817'>ramparts of dead knights, and moved out upon the field.  The first</div><div class='line' id='LC12818'>wounded mall who appealed for help was sitting with his back</div><div class='line' id='LC12819'>against a dead comrade.  When The Boss bent over him and spoke</div><div class='line' id='LC12820'>to him, the man recognized him and stabbed him.  That knight was</div><div class='line' id='LC12821'>Sir Meliagraunce, as I found out by tearing off his helmet.  He</div><div class='line' id='LC12822'>will not ask for help any more.</div><div class='line' id='LC12823'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12824'>We carried The Boss to the cave and gave his wound, which was</div><div class='line' id='LC12825'>not very serious, the best care we could.  In this service we had</div><div class='line' id='LC12826'>the help of Merlin, though we did not know it.  He was disguised</div><div class='line' id='LC12827'>as a woman, and appeared to be a simple old peasant goodwife.</div><div class='line' id='LC12828'>In this disguise, with brown-stained face and smooth shaven, he</div><div class='line' id='LC12829'>had appeared a few days after The Boss was hurt and offered to cook</div><div class='line' id='LC12830'>for us, saying her people had gone off to join certain new camps</div><div class='line' id='LC12831'>which the enemy were forming, and that she was starving.  The Boss</div><div class='line' id='LC12832'>had been getting along very well, and had amused himself with</div><div class='line' id='LC12833'>finishing up his record.</div><div class='line' id='LC12834'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12835'>We were glad to have this woman, for we were short handed.  We</div><div class='line' id='LC12836'>were in a trap, you see--a trap of our own making.  If we stayed</div><div class='line' id='LC12837'>where we were, our dead would kill us; if we moved out of our</div><div class='line' id='LC12838'>defenses, we should no longer be invincible.  We had conquered;</div><div class='line' id='LC12839'>in turn we were conquered.  The Boss recognized this; we all</div><div class='line' id='LC12840'>recognized it.  If we could go to one of those new camps and</div><div class='line' id='LC12841'>patch up some kind of terms with the enemy--yes, but The Boss</div><div class='line' id='LC12842'>could not go, and neither could I, for I was among the first that</div><div class='line' id='LC12843'>were made sick by the poisonous air bred by those dead thousands.</div><div class='line' id='LC12844'>Others were taken down, and still others.  To-morrow--</div><div class='line' id='LC12845'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12846'>_To-morrow._  It is here.  And with it the end.  About midnight</div><div class='line' id='LC12847'>I awoke, and saw that hag making curious passes in the air about</div><div class='line' id='LC12848'>The Boss&#39;s head and face, and wondered what it meant.  Everybody</div><div class='line' id='LC12849'>but the dynamo-watch lay steeped in sleep; there was no sound.</div><div class='line' id='LC12850'>The woman ceased from her mysterious foolery, and started tip-toeing</div><div class='line' id='LC12851'>toward the door.  I called out:</div><div class='line' id='LC12852'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12853'>&quot;Stop!  What have you been doing?&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12854'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12855'>She halted, and said with an accent of malicious satisfaction:</div><div class='line' id='LC12856'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12857'>&quot;Ye were conquerors; ye are conquered!  These others are perishing</div><div class='line' id='LC12858'>--you also.  Ye shall all die in this place--every one--except _him_.</div><div class='line' id='LC12859'>He sleepeth now--and shall sleep thirteen centuries.  I am Merlin!&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12860'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12861'>Then such a delirium of silly laughter overtook him that he reeled</div><div class='line' id='LC12862'>about like a drunken man, and presently fetched up against one</div><div class='line' id='LC12863'>of our wires.  His mouth is spread open yet; apparently he is still</div><div class='line' id='LC12864'>laughing.  I suppose the face will retain that petrified laugh until</div><div class='line' id='LC12865'>the corpse turns to dust.</div><div class='line' id='LC12866'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12867'>The Boss has never stirred--sleeps like a stone.  If he does not</div><div class='line' id='LC12868'>wake to-day we shall understand what kind of a sleep it is, and</div><div class='line' id='LC12869'>his body will then be borne to a place in one of the remote recesses</div><div class='line' id='LC12870'>of the cave where none will ever find it to desecrate it.  As for</div><div class='line' id='LC12871'>the rest of us--well, it is agreed that if any one of us ever</div><div class='line' id='LC12872'>escapes alive from this place, he will write the fact here, and</div><div class='line' id='LC12873'>loyally hide this Manuscript with The Boss, our dear good chief,</div><div class='line' id='LC12874'>whose property it is, be he alive or dead.</div><div class='line' id='LC12875'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12876'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12877'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12878'>THE END OF THE MANUSCRIPT</div><div class='line' id='LC12879'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12880'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12881'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12882'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12883'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12884'>FINAL P.S. BY M.T.</div><div class='line' id='LC12885'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12886'>The dawn was come when I laid the Manuscript aside.  The rain</div><div class='line' id='LC12887'>had almost ceased, the world was gray and sad, the exhausted storm</div><div class='line' id='LC12888'>was sighing and sobbing itself to rest.  I went to the stranger&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC12889'>room, and listened at his door, which was slightly ajar.  I could</div><div class='line' id='LC12890'>hear his voice, and so I knocked.  There was no answer, but I still</div><div class='line' id='LC12891'>heard the voice.  I peeped in.  The man lay on his back in bed,</div><div class='line' id='LC12892'>talking brokenly but with spirit, and punctuating with his arms,</div><div class='line' id='LC12893'>which he thrashed about, restlessly, as sick people do in delirium.</div><div class='line' id='LC12894'>I slipped in softly and bent over him.  His mutterings and</div><div class='line' id='LC12895'>ejaculations went on.  I spoke--merely a word, to call his attention.</div><div class='line' id='LC12896'>His glassy eyes and his ashy face were alight in an instant with</div><div class='line' id='LC12897'>pleasure, gratitude, gladness, welcome:</div><div class='line' id='LC12898'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12899'>&quot;Oh, Sandy, you are come at last--how I have longed for you!  Sit</div><div class='line' id='LC12900'>by me--do not leave me--never leave me again, Sandy, never again.</div><div class='line' id='LC12901'>Where is your hand?--give it me, dear, let me hold it--there</div><div class='line' id='LC12902'>--now all is well, all is peace, and I am happy again--_we_ are happy</div><div class='line' id='LC12903'>again, isn&#39;t it so, Sandy?  You are so dim, so vague, you are but</div><div class='line' id='LC12904'>a mist, a cloud, but you are _here_, and that is blessedness sufficient;</div><div class='line' id='LC12905'>and I have your hand; don&#39;t take it away--it is for only a little</div><div class='line' id='LC12906'>while, I shall not require it long....  Was that the child?...</div><div class='line' id='LC12907'>Hello-Central!... she doesn&#39;t answer.  Asleep, perhaps?  Bring her</div><div class='line' id='LC12908'>when she wakes, and let me touch her hands, her face, her hair,</div><div class='line' id='LC12909'>and tell her good-bye....  Sandy!  Yes, you are there.  I lost</div><div class='line' id='LC12910'>myself a moment, and I thought you were gone....  Have I been</div><div class='line' id='LC12911'>sick long?  It must be so; it seems months to me.  And such dreams!</div><div class='line' id='LC12912'>such strange and awful dreams, Sandy!  Dreams that were as real</div><div class='line' id='LC12913'>as reality--delirium, of course, but _so_ real!  Why, I thought</div><div class='line' id='LC12914'>the king was dead, I thought you were in Gaul and couldn&#39;t get</div><div class='line' id='LC12915'>home, I thought there was a revolution; in the fantastic frenzy</div><div class='line' id='LC12916'>of these dreams, I thought that Clarence and I and a handful of</div><div class='line' id='LC12917'>my cadets fought and exterminated the whole chivalry of England!</div><div class='line' id='LC12918'>But even that was not the strangest.  I seemed to be a creature</div><div class='line' id='LC12919'>out of a remote unborn age, centuries hence, and even _that_ was</div><div class='line' id='LC12920'>as real as the rest!  Yes, I seemed to have flown back out of that</div><div class='line' id='LC12921'>age into this of ours, and then forward to it again, and was set</div><div class='line' id='LC12922'>down, a stranger and forlorn in that strange England, with an</div><div class='line' id='LC12923'>abyss of thirteen centuries yawning between me and you! between</div><div class='line' id='LC12924'>me and my home and my friends! between me and all that is dear</div><div class='line' id='LC12925'>to me, all that could make life worth the living!  It was awful</div><div class='line' id='LC12926'>--awfuler than you can ever imagine, Sandy.  Ah, watch by me, Sandy</div><div class='line' id='LC12927'>--stay by me every moment--_don&#39;t_ let me go out of my mind again;</div><div class='line' id='LC12928'>death is nothing, let it come, but not with those dreams, not with</div><div class='line' id='LC12929'>the torture of those hideous dreams--I cannot endure _that_ again....</div><div class='line' id='LC12930'>Sandy?...&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12931'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12932'>He lay muttering incoherently some little time; then for a time he</div><div class='line' id='LC12933'>lay silent, and apparently sinking away toward death.  Presently</div><div class='line' id='LC12934'>his fingers began to pick busily at the coverlet, and by that sign</div><div class='line' id='LC12935'>I knew that his end was at hand with the first suggestion of the</div><div class='line' id='LC12936'>death-rattle in his throat he started up slightly, and seemed</div><div class='line' id='LC12937'>to listen: then he said:</div><div class='line' id='LC12938'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12939'>&quot;A bugle?...  It is the king!  The drawbridge, there!  Man the</div><div class='line' id='LC12940'>battlements!--turn out the--&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC12941'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12942'>He was getting up his last &quot;effect&quot;; but he never finished it.</div><div class='line' id='LC12943'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12944'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12945'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12946'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12947'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12948'>End of the Project Gutenberg EBook of A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC12949'>Court, Complete, by Mark Twain (Samuel Clemens)</div><div class='line' id='LC12950'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12951'>*** END OF THIS PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK CONNECTICUT YANKEE ***</div><div class='line' id='LC12952'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12953'>***** This file should be named 86.txt or 86.zip *****</div><div class='line' id='LC12954'>This and all associated files of various formats will be found in:</div><div class='line' id='LC12955'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;http://www.gutenberg.net/8/86/</div><div class='line' id='LC12956'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12957'>Produced by David Widger and Janet Blenkinship</div><div class='line' id='LC12958'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12959'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12960'>Updated editions will replace the previous one--the old editions</div><div class='line' id='LC12961'>will be renamed.</div><div class='line' id='LC12962'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC12963'>Creating the works from public domain print editions means that no</div><div class='line' id='LC12964'>one owns a United States copyright in these works, so the Foundation</div><div class='line' id='LC12965'>(and you!) can copy and distribute it in the United States without</div><div class='line' id='LC12966'>permission and without paying copyright royalties. Any alternate format must include the full Project Gutenberg-tm</div><div class='line' id='LC13097'>License as specified in paragraph 1.E.1.</div><div class='line' id='LC13098'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13099'>1.E.7.  Do not charge a fee for access to, viewing, displaying,</div><div class='line' id='LC13100'>performing, copying or distributing any Project Gutenberg-tm works</div><div class='line' id='LC13101'>unless you comply with paragraph 1.E.8 or 1.E.9.</div><div class='line' id='LC13102'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13103'>1.E.8.  You may charge a reasonable fee for copies of or providing</div><div class='line' id='LC13104'>access to or distributing Project Gutenberg-tm electronic works provided</div><div class='line' id='LC13105'>that</div><div class='line' id='LC13106'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13107'>- You pay a royalty fee of 20% of the gross profits you derive from</div><div class='line' id='LC13108'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the use of Project Gutenberg-tm works calculated using the method</div><div class='line' id='LC13109'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;you already use to calculate your applicable taxes.  The fee is</div><div class='line' id='LC13110'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;owed to the owner of the Project Gutenberg-tm trademark, but he</div><div class='line' id='LC13111'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;has agreed to donate royalties under this paragraph to the</div><div class='line' id='LC13112'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation.  Royalty payments</div><div class='line' id='LC13113'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;must be paid within 60 days following each date on which you</div><div class='line' id='LC13114'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;prepare (or are legally required to prepare) your periodic tax</div><div class='line' id='LC13115'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;returns.  Royalty payments should be clearly marked as such and</div><div class='line' id='LC13116'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;sent to the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation at the</div><div class='line' id='LC13117'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;address specified in Section 4, &quot;Information about donations to</div><div class='line' id='LC13118'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation.&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC13119'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13120'>- You provide a full refund of any money paid by a user who notifies</div><div class='line' id='LC13121'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;you in writing (or by e-mail) within 30 days of receipt that s/he</div><div class='line' id='LC13122'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;does not agree to the terms of the full Project Gutenberg-tm</div><div class='line' id='LC13123'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;License.  You must require such a user to return or</div><div class='line' id='LC13124'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;destroy all copies of the works possessed in a physical medium</div><div class='line' id='LC13125'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and discontinue all use of and all access to other copies of</div><div class='line' id='LC13126'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Project Gutenberg-tm works.</div><div class='line' id='LC13127'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13128'>- You provide, in accordance with paragraph 1.F.3, a full refund of any</div><div class='line' id='LC13129'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;money paid for a work or a replacement copy, if a defect in the</div><div class='line' id='LC13130'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;electronic work is discovered and reported to you within 90 days</div><div class='line' id='LC13131'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;of receipt of the work.</div><div class='line' id='LC13132'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13133'>- You comply with all other terms of this agreement for free</div><div class='line' id='LC13134'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;distribution of Project Gutenberg-tm works.</div><div class='line' id='LC13135'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13136'>1.E.9.  If you wish to charge a fee or distribute a Project Gutenberg-tm</div><div class='line' id='LC13137'>electronic work or group of works on different terms than are set</div><div class='line' id='LC13138'>forth in this agreement, you must obtain permission in writing from</div><div class='line' id='LC13139'>both the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation and Michael</div><div class='line' id='LC13140'>Hart, the owner of the Project Gutenberg-tm trademark.  Contact the</div><div class='line' id='LC13141'>Foundation as set forth in Section 3 below.</div><div class='line' id='LC13142'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13143'>1.F.</div><div class='line' id='LC13144'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13145'>1.F.1.  Project Gutenberg volunteers and employees expend considerable</div><div class='line' id='LC13146'>effort to identify, do copyright research on, transcribe and proofread</div><div class='line' id='LC13147'>public domain works in creating the Project Gutenberg-tm</div><div class='line' id='LC13148'>collection.  Despite these efforts, Project Gutenberg-tm electronic</div><div class='line' id='LC13149'>works, and the medium on which they may be stored, may contain</div><div class='line' id='LC13150'>&quot;Defects,&quot; such as, but not limited to, incomplete, inaccurate or</div><div class='line' id='LC13151'>corrupt data, transcription errors, a copyright or other intellectual</div><div class='line' id='LC13152'>property infringement, a defective or damaged disk or other medium, a</div><div class='line' id='LC13153'>computer virus, or computer codes that damage or cannot be read by</div><div class='line' id='LC13154'>your equipment.</div><div class='line' id='LC13155'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13156'>1.F.2.  LIMITED WARRANTY, DISCLAIMER OF DAMAGES - Except for the &quot;Right</div><div class='line' id='LC13157'>of Replacement or Refund&quot; described in paragraph 1.F.3, the Project</div><div class='line' id='LC13158'>Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation, the owner of the Project</div><div class='line' id='LC13159'>Gutenberg-tm trademark, and any other party distributing a Project</div><div class='line' id='LC13160'>Gutenberg-tm electronic work under this agreement, disclaim all</div><div class='line' id='LC13161'>liability to you for damages, costs and expenses, including legal</div><div class='line' id='LC13162'>fees.  YOU AGREE THAT YOU HAVE NO REMEDIES FOR NEGLIGENCE, STRICT</div><div class='line' id='LC13163'>LIABILITY, BREACH OF WARRANTY OR BREACH OF CONTRACT EXCEPT THOSE</div><div class='line' id='LC13164'>PROVIDED IN PARAGRAPH F3.  YOU AGREE THAT THE FOUNDATION, THE</div><div class='line' id='LC13165'>TRADEMARK OWNER, AND ANY DISTRIBUTOR UNDER THIS AGREEMENT WILL NOT BE</div><div class='line' id='LC13166'>LIABLE TO YOU FOR ACTUAL, DIRECT, INDIRECT, CONSEQUENTIAL, PUNITIVE OR</div><div class='line' id='LC13167'>INCIDENTAL DAMAGES EVEN IF YOU GIVE NOTICE OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH</div><div class='line' id='LC13168'>DAMAGE.</div><div class='line' id='LC13169'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13170'>1.F.3.  LIMITED RIGHT OF REPLACEMENT OR REFUND - If you discover a</div><div class='line' id='LC13171'>defect in this electronic work within 90 days of receiving it, you can</div><div class='line' id='LC13172'>receive a refund of the money (if any) you paid for it by sending a</div><div class='line' id='LC13173'>written explanation to the person you received the work from.  If you</div><div class='line' id='LC13174'>received the work on a physical medium, you must return the medium with</div><div class='line' id='LC13175'>your written explanation.  The person or entity that provided you with</div><div class='line' id='LC13176'>the defective work may elect to provide a replacement copy in lieu of a</div><div class='line' id='LC13177'>refund.  If you received the work electronically, the person or entity</div><div class='line' id='LC13178'>providing it to you may choose to give you a second opportunity to</div><div class='line' id='LC13179'>receive the work electronically in lieu of a refund.  If the second copy</div><div class='line' id='LC13180'>is also defective, you may demand a refund in writing without further</div><div class='line' id='LC13181'>opportunities to fix the problem.</div><div class='line' id='LC13182'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13183'>1.F.4.  Except for the limited right of replacement or refund set forth</div><div class='line' id='LC13184'>in paragraph 1.F.3, this work is provided to you &#39;AS-IS&#39; WITH NO OTHER</div><div class='line' id='LC13185'>WARRANTIES OF ANY KIND, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO</div><div class='line' id='LC13186'>WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTIBILITY OR FITNESS FOR ANY PURPOSE.</div><div class='line' id='LC13187'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13188'>1.F.5.  Some states do not allow disclaimers of certain implied</div><div class='line' id='LC13189'>warranties or the exclusion or limitation of certain types of damages.</div><div class='line' id='LC13190'>If any disclaimer or limitation set forth in this agreement violates the</div><div class='line' id='LC13191'>law of the state applicable to this agreement, the agreement shall be</div><div class='line' id='LC13192'>interpreted to make the maximum disclaimer or limitation permitted by</div><div class='line' id='LC13193'>the applicable state law.  The invalidity or unenforceability of any</div><div class='line' id='LC13194'>provision of this agreement shall not void the remaining provisions.</div><div class='line' id='LC13195'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13196'>1.F.6.  INDEMNITY - You agree to indemnify and hold the Foundation, the</div><div class='line' id='LC13197'>trademark owner, any agent or employee of the Foundation, anyone</div><div class='line' id='LC13198'>providing copies of Project Gutenberg-tm electronic works in accordance</div><div class='line' id='LC13199'>with this agreement, and any volunteers associated with the production,</div><div class='line' id='LC13200'>promotion and distribution of Project Gutenberg-tm electronic works,</div><div class='line' id='LC13201'>harmless from all liability, costs and expenses, including legal fees,</div><div class='line' id='LC13202'>that arise directly or indirectly from any of the following which you do</div><div class='line' id='LC13203'>or cause to occur: (a) distribution of this or any Project Gutenberg-tm</div><div class='line' id='LC13204'>work, (b) alteration, modification, or additions or deletions to any</div><div class='line' id='LC13205'>Project Gutenberg-tm work, and (c) any Defect you cause.</div><div class='line' id='LC13206'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13207'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13208'>Section  2.  Information about the Mission of Project Gutenberg-tm</div><div class='line' id='LC13209'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13210'>Project Gutenberg-tm is synonymous with the free distribution of</div><div class='line' id='LC13211'>electronic works in formats readable by the widest variety of computers</div><div class='line' id='LC13212'>including obsolete, old, middle-aged and new computers.  It exists</div><div class='line' id='LC13213'>because of the efforts of hundreds of volunteers and donations from</div><div class='line' id='LC13214'>people in all walks of life.</div><div class='line' id='LC13215'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13216'>Volunteers and financial support to provide volunteers with the</div><div class='line' id='LC13217'>assistance they need, is critical to reaching Project Gutenberg-tm&#39;s</div><div class='line' id='LC13218'>goals and ensuring that the Project Gutenberg-tm collection will</div><div class='line' id='LC13219'>remain freely available for generations to come.  In 2001, the Project</div><div class='line' id='LC13220'>Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation was created to provide a secure</div><div class='line' id='LC13221'>and permanent future for Project Gutenberg-tm and future generations.</div><div class='line' id='LC13222'>To learn more about the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation</div><div class='line' id='LC13223'>and how your efforts and donations can help, see Sections 3 and 4</div><div class='line' id='LC13224'>and the Foundation web page at http://www.pglaf.org.</div><div class='line' id='LC13225'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13226'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13227'>Section 3.  Information about the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive</div><div class='line' id='LC13228'>Foundation</div><div class='line' id='LC13229'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13230'>The Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation is a non profit</div><div class='line' id='LC13231'>501(c)(3) educational corporation organized under the laws of the</div><div class='line' id='LC13232'>state of Mississippi and granted tax exempt status by the Internal</div><div class='line' id='LC13233'>Revenue Service.  The Foundation&#39;s EIN or federal tax identification</div><div class='line' id='LC13234'>number is 64-6221541.  Its 501(c)(3) letter is posted at</div><div class='line' id='LC13235'>http://pglaf.org/fundraising.  Contributions to the Project Gutenberg</div><div class='line' id='LC13236'>Literary Archive Foundation are tax deductible to the full extent</div><div class='line' id='LC13237'>permitted by U.S. federal laws and your state&#39;s laws.</div><div class='line' id='LC13238'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13239'>The Foundation&#39;s principal office is located at 4557 Melan Dr. S.</div><div class='line' id='LC13240'>Fairbanks, AK, 99712., but its volunteers and employees are scattered</div><div class='line' id='LC13241'>throughout numerous locations.  Its business office is located at</div><div class='line' id='LC13242'>809 North 1500 West, Salt Lake City, UT 84116, (801) 596-1887, email</div><div class='line' id='LC13243'>business@pglaf.org.  Email contact links and up to date contact</div><div class='line' id='LC13244'>information can be found at the Foundation&#39;s web site and official</div><div class='line' id='LC13245'>page at http://pglaf.org</div><div class='line' id='LC13246'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13247'>For additional contact information:</div><div class='line' id='LC13248'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Dr. Gregory B. Newby</div><div class='line' id='LC13249'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Chief Executive and Director</div><div class='line' id='LC13250'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;gbnewby@pglaf.org</div><div class='line' id='LC13251'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13252'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13253'>Section 4.  Information about Donations to the Project Gutenberg</div><div class='line' id='LC13254'>Literary Archive Foundation</div><div class='line' id='LC13255'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13256'>Project Gutenberg-tm depends upon and cannot survive without wide</div><div class='line' id='LC13257'>spread public support and donations to carry out its mission of</div><div class='line' id='LC13258'>increasing the number of public domain and licensed works that can be</div><div class='line' id='LC13259'>freely distributed in machine readable form accessible by the widest</div><div class='line' id='LC13260'>array of equipment including outdated equipment.  Many small donations</div><div class='line' id='LC13261'>($1 to $5,000) are particularly important to maintaining tax exempt</div><div class='line' id='LC13262'>status with the IRS.</div><div class='line' id='LC13263'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13264'>The Foundation is committed to complying with the laws regulating</div><div class='line' id='LC13265'>charities and charitable donations in all 50 states of the United</div><div class='line' id='LC13266'>States.  Compliance requirements are not uniform and it takes a</div><div class='line' id='LC13267'>considerable effort, much paperwork and many fees to meet and keep up</div><div class='line' id='LC13268'>with these requirements.  We do not solicit donations in locations</div><div class='line' id='LC13269'>where we have not received written confirmation of compliance.  To</div><div class='line' id='LC13270'>SEND DONATIONS or determine the status of compliance for any</div><div class='line' id='LC13271'>particular state visit http://pglaf.org</div><div class='line' id='LC13272'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13273'>While we cannot and do not solicit contributions from states where we</div><div class='line' id='LC13274'>have not met the solicitation requirements, we know of no prohibition</div><div class='line' id='LC13275'>against accepting unsolicited donations from donors in such states who</div><div class='line' id='LC13276'>approach us with offers to donate.</div><div class='line' id='LC13277'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13278'>International donations are gratefully accepted, but we cannot make</div><div class='line' id='LC13279'>any statements concerning tax treatment of donations received from</div><div class='line' id='LC13280'>outside the United States.  U.S. laws alone swamp our small staff.</div><div class='line' id='LC13281'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13282'>Please check the Project Gutenberg Web pages for current donation</div><div class='line' id='LC13283'>methods and addresses.  Donations are accepted in a number of other</div><div class='line' id='LC13284'>ways including including checks, online payments and credit card</div><div class='line' id='LC13285'>donations.  To donate, please visit: http://pglaf.org/donate</div><div class='line' id='LC13286'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13287'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13288'>Section 5.  General Information About Project Gutenberg-tm electronic</div><div class='line' id='LC13289'>works.</div><div class='line' id='LC13290'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13291'>Professor Michael S. Hart is the originator of the Project Gutenberg-tm</div><div class='line' id='LC13292'>concept of a library of electronic works that could be freely shared</div><div class='line' id='LC13293'>with anyone.  For thirty years, he produced and distributed Project</div><div class='line' id='LC13294'>Gutenberg-tm eBooks with only a loose network of volunteer support.</div><div class='line' id='LC13295'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13296'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13297'>Project Gutenberg-tm eBooks are often created from several printed</div><div class='line' id='LC13298'>editions, all of which are confirmed as Public Domain in the U.S.</div><div class='line' id='LC13299'>unless a copyright notice is included.  Thus, we do not necessarily</div><div class='line' id='LC13300'>keep eBooks in compliance with any particular paper edition.</div><div class='line' id='LC13301'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13302'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13303'>Most people start at our Web site which has the main PG search facility:</div><div class='line' id='LC13304'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13305'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;http://www.gutenberg.net</div><div class='line' id='LC13306'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC13307'>This Web site includes information about Project Gutenberg-tm,</div><div class='line' id='LC13308'>including how to make donations to the Project Gutenberg Literary</div><div class='line' id='LC13309'>Archive Foundation, how to help produce our new eBooks, and how to</div><div class='line' id='LC13310'>subscribe to our email newsletter to hear about new eBooks.</div></pre></div></td>
         </tr>
       </table>
  </div>
